title: Shop Local - Merchants Aim To Bring Great Experiences To Customers This Saturday And Every Day
author: Maggie Trovato; Mtrovato@Chespub. Com
content:
Shop Local - Merchants Aim To Bring Great Experiences To Customers This Saturday And Every Day

 November 24, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; Mtrovato@Chespub. Com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1078
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - For some, shopping is all about the experience of walking into a store to sniff a candle, touch the sleeve of a soft, cashmere sweater or even sample an infused cocktail.On Small Business Saturday - and everyday - local businesses in Easton are making sure that each of their customers has the particular experience that makes getting out of the house to go shopping, rather than doing it from the convenience of your couch, worth it.Mark Greene, owner of the clothing store Sailor in Downtown Easton, describes why it's so great to shop local with a simple phrase: "It always fits better in a small box.""In other words, we're not a big box store," he said. "So there's always better product and better stuff and more one-on-one in a small box (store)."Not only do you get that one-on-one time with a store owner or employee, but you get the opportunity to do business with those that keep money in the community, Greene said.Joan Hoge-North owns The Mercantile, a boutique next door to Sailor that has been open for about 18 months.Hoge-North said she gives what she can when she is approached by different organizations for things like silent auctions.One thing she's been doing since she opened is putting a quarter aside every time someone declines a shopping bag for the items they have purchased."For every bag not used, I donate a quarter to conservation on the Shore," she said. "Last year it was the equivalent of about 560 bags, and I made a gift to Eastern Shore Land Conservancy."This year, Hoge-North said they are up to more than 600 bags not used.Those 600 plus quarters will be donated to ShoreRivers, she said.Saturday, Nov. 25, the Saturday after Black Friday, is Small Business Saturday - a day to celebrate and support small businesses during the busiest shopping season of the year.Small Business Saturday was founded by American Express in 2010 and has been officially cosponsored by the U.S. Small Business Administration since 2011. Reported projected spending among U.S. consumers who shopped at independent retailers and restaurants on Small Business Saturday reached an estimated $17.9 billion, according to the 2022 Small Business Saturday Consumer Insights Survey commissioned by American Express.Deena Kilmon, director of strategic initiatives at Easton Economic Development, said small shop owners are "the heartbeat of Easton.""They create its personality, they open their doors to our visitors and locals with a smile, they support our non-profits with their many donations and they are crucial players in all of the amazing events we have downtown that are free to the community," she said.Darcy Bernot, the owner of Lizzy Dee, which is also located in downtown Easton, said that buying local is worthwhile because the gifts are often more thoughtful and unique."We mostly buy from what are called made-to-order companies," Bernot said."That means that they only make what I and other store owners order. So you're not going to see these things coast to coast, all over the place."Kilmon said that three-quarters of every dollar spent locally stays in the local economy."Those dollars are crucial to maintaining a healthy downtown," she said.Until opening The Mercantile, Hoge-North spent her career in the nonprofit sector."This is something completely different," she said."But the nonprofit - giving back - is just a part of who I am, who the store is."Supporting other small makers, women-owned businesses and socially-and environmentally-conscious brands is something Hoge-North makes an effort to do in her store."A lot of things in here have a story that comes with them," she said. "People like giving that too, and knowing that through their purchase, they're giving back and helping someone else."Some of the best holiday gifts in The Mercantile, Hoge-North said, are dish towels that show off local pride and cocktail infusers - tall, glass jars of dried items like orange slices and rosemary that you can add the liquor of your choice to."Like, this one says tequila is best," Hoge-North says, pointing to a jar. "You let it sit for three days, you strain it out, you make an awesome margarita."This weekend, The Mercantile will be offering samples of the three different infusers in the shop.Along with the opportunity to take a sip of a cocktail (or three), Hoge-North said The Mercantile will be offering a few sales beginning Friday and ending Sunday. There will be discounts on all jackets and tops, a buy-oneget-one-half-off deal on jeans and select boots will be on sale.Starting next Tuesday, The Mercantile will be open seven days a week for the holiday season."To make it easier for everybody," Hoge-North said.Sailor has also extended its hours for the holiday season.Greene said it will be open from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. on Monday through Saturday and from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. on Sundays.For those looking to gift their loved ones with name brand items like like Patagonia, Vineyard Vines and Lilly Pulitzer, Sailor is the place to go.Open from 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. on Saturday, Lizzy Dee will have gift guides posted around the boutique.The guides will have different groupings of merchandise on them based on personality and style to make gift giving a piece of cake this year.Hoge-North said shopping downtown keeps Easton thriving."It's one of the reasons people love living on the Shore is that we have a really vibrant downtown," she said. "People shop for an experience. They come downtown to hear the stories, to see the different things, to be a part of all that's going on, and there's a lot going on this weekend."Those interested in learning more about Small Business Saturday and the different merchants in Easton can visit DiscoverEaston.com.

title: Keeping things frugal pays off
author: Mary Hunt
content:
Keeping things frugal pays off

 November 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 285
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As the cost of basic consumer goods continues to be much higher than a year ago, frugality is fast becoming its own art form. I hope the following encouraging tips from your fellow readers on how to be a frugal rockstar will inspire all of us to pay attention and embrace ways we can immediately begin to see more money left in our wallets.Over the past six months, I've been on a tear to declutter and get organized. It has made a huge impact on my spending.Basically, I've stopped spending money on stuff I have already but just didn't know where to find it. The key is knowing what you have and finding it when needed. If you can't find your stuff easily, you might buy something you already have or, even worse, believe you got rid of it, buy a replacement, and then find the original shortly after. - Millie, New Jersey We have a new weekly menu item at our house - Everything But the Kitchen Sink Soup. Basically, this is just throwing a bunch of whateveris-in-the-fridge to make a soup in order to get rid of stuff that's about to go bad or otherwise needs to be used up. You can put so much stuff into soups, and you can freeze leftover soup, too. Really helps to prevent food waste. If you need instructions on how to do this, look up Cotter-Crunch.com. When you get there, use the search function to find that "recipe." - Erica, California I started using grocery delivery during the pandemic. Even taking into consideration the monthly/annual delivery fee, I've stuck with it because it significantly reduces my impulse buys, which continues to save us money. And we have all but eliminated spending on junk food. - Molly, Pennsylvania 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Find ways to cut all prices by up to half
author: Mary Hunt
content:
Find ways to cut all prices by up to half

 November 28, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 337
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It's a benchmark, a goal, a mindset - a kind of game I play with myself. Whatever the price tag - real or perceived - I challenge myself to find a way to get it down to "half the price." Here's an example.Harold and I make a business trip to California about every month, to take care of a business we have there and to stay connected with friends and family. We've done this so often, by now, I know about how much those plane tickets will be. And every month I take the challenge to cut the cost in half.Sometimes I make it; other times, I must concede to something far less than half the price. But now and then I hit it just right, and it feels like I won the jackpot.Not long ago, by agreeing to take a later flight, applying a special discount code, not checking any bags and not being picky about our seats, we flew for less than $100 each, round trip. These days, that's nearly unheard of.Then there are the times that I get the price of something down to nothing by deciding not to buy at all - doing without or deciding to wait. It amazes me just how often, if I'm just willing to wait a day or two, that "urgent need" kind of fades away.Living your life for half the price is not easy. It takes skill and determination to go against the tide and buck a system that says it's OK to spend all we have now, plus what we hope we'll get in the future. It takes the strength of character to protest against the message that it's OK to have what you want now and pay for it later.Here's the principle, the thing I hope you will take away from this: It's the money you don't spend that gives you the freedom to live the life you love.Think about it, embrace it, live it. I promise it can change your life.Mary Hunt is the founder of EverydayCheapskate.com, a frugal living blog, and the author of the book "Debt-Proof Living." COPYRIGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM

title: First Country Christmas Market nets $1K for local 4-H, FFA
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
First Country Christmas Market nets $1K for local 4-H, FFA

 November 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 15 | Section: News 
 
 783
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - "Phenomenal" is how one vendor described the firstever Country Christmas Market sponsored by Caroline and Dorchester 4-H Clubs and Caroline County FFA.The day was chilly but sunny, and the main pavilion of the Caroline County 4-H Park south of Denton saw a steady stream of shoppers from 10 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. Saturday, Nov. 25.Outside, Jimmy Watkins' petting zoo welcomed kids and provided rides on Wedgie the Shetland pony, while inside about 30 vendors had set up their wares. Santa, dressed in cowboy duds, listened to requests from believers young and old.Event chairpersons Missy Saathoff of Denton and Taylor McCann of Federalsburg were "pleasantly surprised and impressed" by the turnout."We joke and say this is our first rodeo," Taylor said. "Everything's gone well, vendors seem happy, and so are we." "We've had a really good crowd so far, and hopefully that keeps up throughout the day," Saathoff said at about 2 p.m. "We should have a few hundred dollars to donate between Caroline-Dorchester 4-H, as well as Caroline FFA, so we're happy about that." Each of the three organizations received over $300, Saathoff reported Monday, Nov. 27.A tree decorating showdown garnered donations. "Dorchester County 4-H's tree won the decorating contest (donations) by $6, so it was a close race for the contest," Saathoff said via text message.She estimated about 980 visitors attended the event."These ladies did a wonderful job; I can't say enough about how great they were," said Cambridge photographer Candi Taylor, who sold her wildlife photos converted to canvas on Saturday."I've sold a bunch of them already," she said. "This (market) has been phenomenal. People like to shop local." The market was promoted as a Shop Small Saturday event, where holiday shoppers could buy gifts and decorations from "country and western vendors and other local favorites," according to the event poster.Vendors offered a wide range of merchandise - from boutique clothing and freeze-dried candy to handwrought iron tools and hand-painted wine glasses."I love seeing the smiles," said Mandy Nash of American Corner.She sold homemade gnomes and NFL-themed weighted snowmen made from socks, and she took orders to make more.Nicole Jackson of The Merry Magpie, based in Cambridge, said she and her husband Michael had "been slammed." They moved from Texas in the spring and create personalized, laser-cut ornaments and plaques.Vendors paid a fee to display their wares, while tables were provided for them. Organizers even gave them coffee and donuts.Lunch and dinner were available to purchase from The Farmer's Daughter BBQ. A raffle was offered, and door prizes rewarded shoppers throughout the day. A tree-wrapping service was also available."I would say it's been exceptional," said Navonne Owen, Caroline County 4-H educator with University of Maryland Extension. "I mean, people were coming in before the doors opened at 10 a.m.They've had a steady crowd all day." Longtime Talbot County 4-H leader Linda Brown, who is also the Culinary Arts lead teacher at Easton High School, shopped with her daughter and grandchildren."I think this is a wonderful community activity and a great way for 4-H and FFA to not only explain the program, but all these folks are learning about 4-H and FFA by coming out, so that's important," Brown said."The community needs to know that we exist and we're educating and doing great things for kids," she said. "Too often, the news is about kids that make bad choices, and this is all about (kids) making good choices." "All in all, (it was) a great day, and we can't wait to hold the event next year and continue raising money and awareness for these great organizations," Saathoff said.

title: Shore Gives More raises record breaking $310,178
content:
Shore Gives More raises record breaking $310,178

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 273
 Words 

 Read News Document

 SALISBURY - A day celebrating philanthropy culminated in a recording breaking $310,178 raised for participating Lower Shore nonprofits.More than 2,279 donations were made during the ninth annual Shore Gives More Giving Tuesday campaign.Since its inception, the campaign has raised more than $1.8 million to benefit local organizations.Giving Tuesday, held each year on the Tuesday following Thanksgiving, is an international 24-hour online giving movement.The local campaign, known as The Shore Gives More, is hosted by the Community Foundation of the Eastern Shore and assists local nonprofits with the fundraising effort. By providing an online donation platform, marketing and technical support, the campaign makes a significant impact through collective philanthropy."Nonprofits provide critical services to the local community, and fundraisers like Giving Tuesday help charities connect with donors," said Erica Joseph, CFES president. "Giving Tuesday has become its own holiday around the Shore, and the local generosity really shines a spotlight on how wonderful our region is."The Shore Gives More was first launched as a Giving Tuesday campaign for the Lower Eastern Shore in 2015 and raised just under $4,285 in its first year."As the area's leading philanthropic resource, the Community Foundation, understands the complexities around charitable giving, and we work hard to simplify the giving process for both donors and nonprofits," Joseph said."By giving through the Shore Gives More campaign, donors know their gifts will have an impact close to home."The campaign received sponsorships from 47 ABC and Shore United Bank, which significantly increased the campaign presence.To learn more about the "Shore Gives More" Giving Tuesday campaign for local nonprofits, visit CFES.org or ShoreGivesMore.org to view individual nonprofit participants.

title: Investors consider climate change before buying homes
content:
Investors consider climate change before buying homes

 December 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 908
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A recent Forbes survey reveals nearly a third of Americans cited climate change as a reason to move last year.For aspiring homeowners, climate has transitioned from a selling point to a critical risk factor.Prospective home buyers must educate themselves on the tangible impacts of climate change to safeguard their property investments from potential catastrophic events.When sizing up a property, environmental considerations used to be a matter of taste. Does the buyer prefer warm, sunny summers on the coast or the snug, cool, white winters of the northern interior? Now, aspiring homeowners must consider how climate change will affect their property over the long run and what costs they may incur as a result."As awareness of risk grows, the financial value of risky places drops," says climate futurist Alex Steffen. The rising costs of climate change will make some properties indefensible."[They] will be unofficially abandoned. That will then create more problems. Bonds for big projects, loans, mortgages, business investment, insurance, talented workers - all will grow more scarce then, the value will crash," Steffen predicts.Coining the term " brittleness bubble," Steffen wants to raise awareness. These brittle properties, prone to sudden, irreparable climate-fueled failure could create unrecoverable losses for their owners. The climate crisis poses dire choices, especially for those buying a home for the first time.Yet being forewarned is being forearmed. The sooner investors and home buyers alike bone up on the ground facts of climate risk, the better they can mitigate their property portfolio against the perils of extreme weather.FEW GOOD OPTIONSAs a global phenomenon, climate change impacts human populations everywhere. No region in America is truly immune from the fallout. When disaster strikes one part of the country, everyone suffers since they depend on the supply of goods and services nationwide.However, some regions are being hit sooner and harder than others. This information can help those buying land as an investment navigate the ever-changing climate map.Data from First Street and Moody's Analytics shows that Texas, Florida, New Jersey, and California, four of the country's largest and most populous states, are all likely to face more climate change risk sooner.With its vast coastline and wetland ecosystem, Florida is most vulnerable to rising sea temperatures and exacerbated tropical storms. The state has been a favorite destination for "snowbirds" from the North, especially among Canadian homebuyers. Florida accounts for almost half of all Canadian property purchases in the United States.According to the 30-year forecast by Moody's, climate change events will continue to affect communities up and down the East Coast and, at some point, will impact the livability of states such as Florida and the Carolinas. In the Southwest, e.g., Arizona, record heat and fires increase weather dangers and threaten reliable water supplies.The nation's interior is also feeling the climate stress, with intense heat and unprecedented rainfalls recorded in recent years. As the weather becomes more extreme, smaller, less exposed cities such as Boise, Idaho, are poised for an influx of newcomers seeking shelter from climate catastrophe.FLOODS AND FIRESOf all the natural disasters impacting home valuations in the U.S., wildfires and flooding are among the most damaging.As more study on climate change risk is undertaken, the potential effect on the American real estate market becomes apparent. For instance, the journal Nature Climate Change recently published a study that claims property prices in flood zones are overvalued by $121 to $237 billion."Increasing flood risk under climate change is creating a bubble that threatens the stability of the U.S. housing market," said lead author Dr. Jesse Gourevitch, a postdoctoral fellow at the Environmental Defense Fund."These risks are largely unaccounted for in property transactions, encouraging development in flood-prone areas.Accurately pricing the costs of flooding in home values can support adaptation to flood risk, but may leave many worse off."Unfactored environmental risks bode poorly for low-income households. The study found this demographic may lose up to 10% of their property's market value to the risk of significant flooding."For many people, their most valuable asset is their home. We need policy approaches that improve the transparency of climate risk in markets while providing increased support and protection for frontline communities," said co-author Dr. Carolyn Kousky, Associate Vice President for Economics and Policy at the Environmental Defense Fund.INSURE YOURSELFThe rising risks will make home ownership, already out of reach for most Americans, even more unaffordable. The increasing costs of covering the damage from natural disasters are unsustainable for homeowners and insurance companies.Huge claims from natural disasters in states such as California and Florida leave companies rethinking their risk and opting out of insuring susceptible regions.State-backed insurers cover some gaps in this landscape, but the premiums only sometimes cover the bills that homeowners are forced to pay. This situation worsens as climate change continues to upend the weather patterns and wreak havoc through extreme weather events.Slowing the impact of climate change is a global effort requiring deeper coordination between governments, corporations, citizens, and the world. Unfortunately, the average American can do little to change the broader trends However, by being informed of the dangers posed by climate catastrophe, homeowners can prepare for the worst and safeguard their families' future. Real estate remains many Americans' primary investment vehicle, so contingency planning is urgent. Without it, a local extreme weather disaster could bring untold financial ruin. 
 
 Caption: Threats associated with climate change, such as severe weather, are being considered by real estate investors when buying homes. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on how climate‑related risks affect real‑estate investment decisions, property values, mortgages and insurance, which are core economic and business concerns, with climate change as the underlying factor.

title: Emmanuel Episcopal sets up shop for worthwhile cause
author: Laura Tayman; ltayman@chespub.com
content:
Emmanuel Episcopal sets up shop for worthwhile cause

 December 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman; ltayman@chespub.com | Page: 12 | Section: News 
 
 451
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN - The Rev. Claire Nevin-Field, Rector of Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Chestertown remembered a day in late summer where she smelled something delicious coming from the church's kitchen. "It was volunteers of the church making jam for this (November) event," she said, "That's how much work it takes for this to happen."The event is Emmanuel Episcopal Church's annual Christmas Bazaar, now 30 years old, with no sign of slowing down. Their Friday night preview party had 200 attendees, who got a peak at what was offered and a first chance to purchase items before the event was officially open to the public."All of the items you see here were donated," said Coordinator Linda Robbs, who has chaired the event for 12 years. "We have a very invested parish, and a lot of volunteers."One volunteer, Jenny Freebery who was supervising the "Elegant Elephant" table of higher end items like silver and crystal, said, "I love shopping for a cause."The cause is fundraising for three nonprofits, different every year. For the 2023 event, proceeds will go to Echo Hills Outdoor School in Worton that provides experiential outdoor education programs on their 240-acre campus; the Bayside Hoyas who sponsor activities for youth to help the next generation of the community achieve their full potential; and Minary's Dream Alliance that works to improve the lives of families and youth in the Mid-Shore region, particularly those families that are disadvantaged and underserved by existing institutions and organizations.Each year three other nonprofits are chosen, with a requirement that the recipients have to wait at least two years before being nominated again.Nancy Henderson supervised the knitting table, with items from scarves to mittens to ornaments, lovingly made by the ecumenical knitting club that meets weekly at the church. The kitchen volunteers were busily making homemade sandwiches and desserts for patrons and volunteers.A silent auction was also a big part of the event, with bids on everything from signed books, to boat rides, to art work, and even Saki, just flown to Maryland from Japan, again all donations from individuals and businesses.The day brought out a special visitor, the former Rector of Emmanuel, the Rev.Dr. Darcy Williams. "It's just wonderful, I always have to come," said Williams. "It's a real labor of love."Barbara Fisher, a friend of a church volunteer, said she drives to Chestertown every year to shop. "I love it," she said. "It makes me want to live here."Cashiers proclaimed it was a great day for selling toward the end of the event. Robbins said, "It's really unique that we can raise this much money for local nonprofits.It's worth it." 
 
 Caption: Nancy Henderson and Anne Bricker supervise the knitting table at the recent Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Chestertown. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a community fundraising bazaar organized by a church, highlighting local economic activity, donations, and charitable fundraising, which aligns best with Business/Economy. It also involves cultural elements like knitting and art, making Arts & Culture a secondary fit.

title: The Narrows celebrates 40th anniversary
content:
The Narrows celebrates 40th anniversary

 December 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 402
 Words 

 Read News Document

 KENT NARROWS - Owners of The Narrows Restaurant, known for their elegant waterfront dining, the Hardesty family held a party at the end of October for longtime friends and patrons of the restaurant, celebrating their 40th year in business.Bo and Brenda Hardesty opened the restaurant the day after Thanksgiving in November 1983.Since then, they have experienced great success, according to Brenda, "due to the great support of our local community.""We've had some great chefs over the years," she added, "and I can't say enough about our wait staff. We like to take care of our staff because they are so good."Almost since the restaurant opened, Veteran's Day has been recognized by providing a free meal once a year to veterans, in thanks for their service to the nation. Honoring veterans began at The Narrows Restaurant as Bo wanted to honor the memory of his youngest brother, Michael Hardesty, who gave his life serving in the U.S. Army during the Vietnam War.The Hardestys are also loyal supporters of the local fire departments and have always been leaders in protecting public health."When our restaurant first opened, we didn't have cigarette vending machines, and we were the first restaurant to have a 'smoke free' dining area," Brenda said. "That was before it became law, as smoking has not been permitted in any restaurants for many years now."Bo and Brenda's daughters, Kelly and Kate, now manage the restaurant. Bo comes in frequently, but the daughters are in charge, they quipped.The Narrows Restaurant has become well known for overnight mailing of different dishes of their foods all over the nation."During the pandemic, those overnight orders for our crab cakes and crab soups helped us stay open," shared Brenda."[And] you should see all the boxes that go out of here in December! People wanting to overnight mail their family and friends foods they love."The restaurant is open daily at 11 a.m. and closes most evenings at 9 p.m., except Friday and Saturdays when it stays open a little longer. You can view their menu online at thenarrowsrestaurant.com. 
 
 Caption: Outside The Narrows Restaurant in Grasonville, members of the Hardesty family celebrate the 40th anniversary of the restaurant.
 
From left, restaurant founders Bo and Brenda Hardesty, with daughters Kelly Hardesty Phipps and Kate Hardesty Pizzo who manage the restaurant now. The restaurant continues to be family owned, well known for its elegant waterfront dining.
 
WWW.STARDEM.COM 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Tasty Toucan shines as national Paleta Champion
content:
Tasty Toucan shines as national Paleta Champion

 December 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 8 | Section: News 
 
 427
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE - Kent Island's Tasty Toucan emerged victorious at the North American Ice Cream Association 2023 Paleta Competition at their annual convention in Las Vegas.The North American Ice Cream Association, a dedicated trade organization committed to advancing the frozen dessert industry, annually recognizes outstanding contributions and innovation. Tasty Toucan seized the title of Paleta Champion, solidifying their place as an example of excellence in the frozen dessert industry.For those unfamiliar with the term, a Paleta is a Mexican-origin frozen treat, similar to a popsicle, that has gained popularity in the United States. Unlike traditional popsicles, paletas are crafted from fresh fruits, chocolate, or cream. The distinguishing factor lies in their use of natural ingredients and creative flavor combinations, offering a more authentic and artisanal experience.The six artisan Paleta competitors had two hours to make their best strawberry and chocolate popsicle/Paleta. Nikki Neboshynsky, owner and chief tasty officer of Tasty Toucan, Stevensville whirred and stirred her best recipes before the judges. Her final submissions were Summer Tango and 'Tis the Season.The judges analyzed every pop/paleta for taste, uniqueness, presentation and appeal to the market.The Summer Tango is a delightful blend of whole strawberries, fresh-squeezed lemon juice, twisted with layers of mango, dipped in Tajin. On the other hand, the 'Tis the Season features chocolate fudge infused with natural peppermint extract and adorned with shimmering candy cane pieces.Neboshynky's entries are a true standout, earning unanimous praise from the judges for its unique flavor profile, exceptional texture, and eye-catching presentation."We are thrilled to recognize Tasty Toucan and Nikki Neboshynsky as the Paleta Champion of 2023," stated Evan Waldt, Board member of NAICA. "Their Paleta not only demonstrated exceptional craftsmanship but also highlighted the innovative spirit that drives our industry. It's an honor to celebrate their talents and dedication to the craft."Neboshynsky shared her excitement about the win, saying, "Tasty Toucan's goal has always been to deliver sweet frozen treats with incredible flavor from natural ingredients, this competition was the perfect platform to showcase that.We are incredibly proud to have received this recognition and are excited to continue our journey of creating unique and delicious popsicles."To savor these award-winning paletas, head to Tasty Toucan at 400 Love Point Road in Stevensville.Additionally, you can find them at various concerts, festivals, and catering events. Don't miss the chance to indulge in the authentic and bold flavors that set Tasty Toucan's paletas apart. 
 
 Caption: Nikki Neboshynsky, owner of Stevensville's Tasty Toucan, prepares her winning treats for the judges of the North American Ice Cream Association's competition in Las Vegas. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a local company's win in a national frozen dessert competition, focusing on product innovation and industry recognition, which aligns best with Business/Economy.

title: Easton Utilities proposes electric, gas rate increases
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Easton Utilities proposes electric, gas rate increases

 December 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 777
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Easton Utilities is proposing increases to its electric and gas rates, citing inflation's impact on the cost of operations as a main driver for the price hike.The utility company's Monday evening presentation to the Easton Town Council marked the first time in six years Easton Utilities had come before town leaders with increases for electric and gas rates.Easton Utilities is a townowned, not-for-profit utility company operating electric, gas, water, wastewater, cable television and internet services for the Town of Easton and portions of the surrounding area.Over the last few years, the company has kept "cost-consciousness" in mind through keeping compensation levels below the inflation rate, assuming greater risk to dial back on some insurance coverage and changing the company's medical insurance, said Hugh Grunden, Easton Utilities' president and CEO.Easton Utilities invested over $17 million into its electric and gas infrastructure to maintain and increase reliability of services, most of which has gone toward the electric department.The roughly $15 million spent on electric improvements in the last four years includes installation of a concrete duct bank across the runway at Easton Airport, improving reliability in the northern parts of the service areas and reconductoring, or replacing wires or cables, in historic Easton.However, rising supply chain costs for transformers, overhead wires and gas meters, along with investments yielding losses for gas and electric, led to the need to increase rates in the new year to ensure reliability.Those issues have led to a "drastic" fall off in Easton Utilities' earnings, said Steve Ochse, the company's senior vice president and chief financial officer.To recover what's been invested, Easton Utilities proposed increasing its electric base revenue to $4.45 million.For typical residential electric customers, that means the newly proposed rates would increase monthly bills by about $24, though the actual number is likely to be lower after litigating the rates with the state's Public Service Commission, Ochse said.The company also proposed increasing its natural gas base revenue by $520,000. Typical residential gas customers would see a $7 increase in monthly bills.Revenue collected from base rates pays for operations, maintenance and infrastructure replacements for electric and gas systems in Easton, but not the energy itself.If the proposed rate increases are approved by the Town Council in mid-December, Easton Utilities will file formal rate increase requests with the state Public Service Commission late this month.From there, the PSC will likely hold a public hearing on the proposed rates next spring and make a final determination, though approval may not come until late spring or early summer 2024.At Monday's meeting, Grunden said the rate increases being recommended are "well below" the overall rate of inflation customers experience elsewhere in their lives, and even with the changes being proposed, customers' average bills will remain lower than those of neighboring utilities.The decline in energy costs this year, which are projected to continue into next year, would further reduce the increase to average customers' electric bills when comparing this December and December 2022, according to the company's presentation.And in a similar comparison for Easton Utilities' typical gas customers, an average total bill with the newly proposed rates would be 31 cents less per day than a December 2022 bill.Ochse said the lower energy costs make now "perfect timing" to do a rate increase."This time last year would not have been an ideal situation - we knew energy costs were high, we knew we were losing money on both departments, but we held off because we were hoping that we would see the energy costs come down and our impact on our customers would be less," he said.There were no public comments at the meeting on the proposed changes, though council members asked about profits from Easton Utilities' other services being used to offset costs and if the company could maintain reliability and quality of service without increases in base rates.John Horner, Easton Utilities' executive vice president and chief operating officer, emphasized the importance of implementing the base rate increases sooner rather than later."It's important for us to go through this process now, because waiting really much longer means that we'll have an additional third, or maybe fourth, fiscal year - in the case of the gas business - with negative net income, and it will begin to impact those three important metrics, and most importantly, could impact safety."Public hearings on the two pieces of legislation authorizing the revisions to electric and gas rates will remain open until the council's Dec. 18 meeting. 
 
 Caption: Steve Ochse, Easton Utilities' senior vice president and chief financial officer, speaks to town leaders during an Easton Town Council meeting Monday, Dec. 4. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a municipal utility's proposed rate increases, financial impacts, and inflation, which are primarily economic/business issues, though it involves town council decisions linking it to local government.

Nominations opened for Talbot County's Community Impact Awards

 The Talbot County Department of Economic Development and Tourism and the Economic Development Commission are now accepting online nominations for the 2023 Community Impact Awards.These awards are presented each year to recognize outstanding businesses, nonprofits, community projects and individuals who have made a significant impact in Talbot County. Winners will be announced at the annual Talbot County Business Appreciation Summit to be held on Thursday, May 2, at a.m. at the Tidewater Inn in Easton.The Summit is hosted each year by the Talbot County Department of Economic Development and Tourism in partnership with the Talbot County Economic Development Commission."Your nominations help us recognize those who are doing extraordinary things to make Talbot County a prosperous, forward-thinking place to live and work," said Cassandra Vanhooser, director of economic development and tourism for Talbot County. "Our businesses and the people who make them work are award-worthy, and we're grateful to recognize so many of them through this event and in the nomination process."Last year's winners included Channel Marker Inc. Residential Crisis Services, Chesapeake Landing Seafood Restaurant, Choptank Community Health System, Ferry Cove Oyster Hatchery, and McDaniel resident and volunteer Bill Shrieves."This is an exciting event for the business community," says Vanhooser. "We want to recognize the businesses and individuals in Talbot County who have made a significant impact on the community in 2023.I'm looking forward to seeing the impressive list of winners from this year's event."Nominations for the 2023 awards are being accepted until Monday, Jan. 15. The form can be found online at TalbotWorks.org.The Talbot County Department of Economic Development and Tourism's mission is to enhance and promote a business-friendly environment for current and prospective enterprises and to advocate for policies that support and strengthen the economic vitality of Talbot County. The department's vision for Talbot County is built on the principles of strong communities, empowered businesses and innovative solutions.

title: Net worth of homeowners 40% higher than renters
author: Mid Shore Board Of Realtors
content:
Net worth of homeowners 40% higher than renters

 December 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mid Shore Board Of Realtors | Page: 11 | Section: News 
 
 514
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For some, it can be hard to decide whether to rent or to buy a home, said Shelby Roney, president of the Mid-Shore Board of Realtors.There are so many factors to consider, but a new study may help make this decision a bit easier.The Survey of Consumer Finances, conducted by the Federal Reserve Board every three years, shows valuable insights into the net worth disparity between homeowners and renters.In an informative revelation, the average net worth of a homeowner surpassed that of a renter by nearly 40 times.Homeowners in the U.S. had a median net worth of $255,000, compared to renters who had a net worth of $6,300.The surge in homeowner net worth can be largely attributed to the unprecedented rise in home prices during the so-called "unicorn" years for housing. The term "unicorn," for real estate purposes refers to something greatly desired (unheard of record low interest rates) yet difficult or impossible to find (that perfect home in a record low inventory market).In the real estate realm, it signifies the extraordinary conditions experienced during the last few years when interest rates were 3 to 4% or lower.The scarcity of available homes for sale, coupled with a substantial influx of buyers taking advantage of historically low mortgage rates, led to an imbalance in supply and demand, propelling home prices to new heights. Consequently, homeowners who possessed a home during this period experienced substantial growth in their equity.For those still contemplating the decision to rent or buy, it may be tempting to wonder if the opportunity for significant net worth growth has passed.Despite mortgage rates around 7 to 8%, many areas of the Eastern Shore continue to see higher home prices due to persistent low supply compared to steady demand.Expert predictions suggest ongoing growth in the housing market, although at a slower pace than the record surge observed in the past two years.Roney said, "I tell my clients who are considering buying to think of homeownership as a longterm investment, just like the stock market, with the potential for net worth growth, portfolio building and generational wealth opportunities." While attending the National Association of Realtors conference in Anaheim, CA in November, Roney had the opportunity to hear Jessica Lautz, deputy chief economist for NAR, speak about the real estate market.Roney said Lautz underscored the importance of weighing the total cost of homeownership against the financial benefits when deciding between renting and buying. The latest federal data showing the median net worth of homeowners at 40% higher really demonstrates the wealth gain associated with homeownership.For those grappling with the decision to rent or buy, connecting with a Mid-Shore Board of Realtors agent to discuss the options and possibility of homeownership is the first step toward the potential of a higher net. The likelihood of a substantial boost in net worth over time serves as a compelling reason to consider homeownership.The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors' mission is to advocate for its members and the public to preserve the right to own, transfer and utilize real property.For more news and information check out the website midshoreboardofrealtors.com. 
 
 Caption: SHELBY RONEY 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses homeowner vs renter net worth, housing market trends, and real‑estate economics, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Economic Humbug - One-Third Of Americans Are Skipping Christmas Gifts Thanks To Inflation
author: Jon Dulin; Wealth Of Geeks Undefined
content:
Economic Humbug - One-Third Of Americans Are Skipping Christmas Gifts Thanks To Inflation

 December 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jon Dulin; Wealth Of Geeks Undefined | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 888
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Inflation seems to have found its way into Santa's workshop - and the elves aren't happy. A recent survey found that more than one in three Americans are skipping gift-giving this year thanks to inflation, while 50% say Santa will be less generous than in previous years.Even though it appears that consumers are handling a slowing economy, some cracks are forming. Credit card debt is rising.
Almost half of Americans say they won't pay off their holiday purchases by the due date.
Additionally, over half of people surveyed report feelings of anxiety.
Luckily, there are steps one can take to limit the damage to their finances and the stress they experience during this time of year.
A SNAPSHOT OF CHRISTMAS 2023 According to a Wallethub study, Christmas 2023 will see a thriftier Santa. Over one in three Americans say they will not give gifts due to inflation, and 28% say they plan to spend less on holiday shopping. Almost half say that inflation has affected their charitable giving.
Forty-eight percent of Americans said they planned to start their holiday shopping earlier in hopes of smaller monthly bills as opposed to one large one. It could also help them take advantage of earlier sales many retailers offer to get consumers in the door.
Dana M. Peterson, chief economist at The Conference Board, says, "October's Consumer Confidence Index suggests Americans are entering the holiday season in a somewhat cautious mood, with the overall, present situation, and expectations indexes all seeing dips." She continues, "The softening in confidence may have affected overall holiday spending plans.
Planned spending on non-gift items fell materially this year." CHRISTMAS PRESENT VS CHRISTMAS PAST Christmas spending has fluctuated in recent years. The overall amount people planned to spend on holiday gifts plummeted during the pandemic, from $942 in 2019 to $805 in 2020. Last year, people spent an average of $932.
The $923 estimated spending this year is a slight decrease from last year. But with conflicting consumer data, retailers are stuck. Still reeling from excess inventory after the pandemic and its negative impact on their bottom lines, they're nervous about stocking up because of softer consumer demand. As the season progresses, this could lead to many out-of-stock items or even fewer discounts if demand is higher than forecasts.
DEBT IN THE NAME OF CHRISTMAS CHEER Instead of cash stuffing throughout the year in preparation for the upcoming holiday season, many people rely on credit for Christmas shopping.
While budgeting is not a magic bullet, it can help an individual maintain perspective and plan more efficiently for increased spending at the end of the year.
Sadly, credit card debt is almost synonymous with the holidays.
People start racking up debt around October and continue through mid-to-late December.
Then, they spend at least a portion of the following year paying off that debt.
This year, though, consumer credit behavior is a little more telling, hinting at a financial struggle amid growing inflation in a sinking economy. Almost one out of five Americans plan to apply for a new credit card to help with their holiday expenses.
Nearly one in four Americans say they are still paying off last holiday season's credit card debt, and roughly half say they won't pay off their purchases in full by the due date.
STRESS AND THE HOLIDAYS: IT'S NOTHING NEW Stress is also synonymous with the holiday season, and spas offer special packages ingeniously targeted at those who may feel the pressure of the holidays.
Physician referral site Sesame polled 500 respondents about their mental health and stress levels as they approach the holidays. Two-thirds said they were experiencing moderate to extreme holiday stress levels, including increases in: · Anxiety (52%) · Depression (41%) · Financial stress (66%).
Some of the most stressful parts of the holiday shopping season include: · Coming up with gift ideas (35%) · Holiday weight gain (33%) · Crowds (28%) · Finding the best deals (20%) · Cost of gifts (17%).
Only about 34% of Americans polled said that they would consider seeking counseling to help them deal with the stress. About 14% said that they are interested in seeking professional help from a mental health counselor but feel that they are not able to afford it now.
CHRISTMAS SURVIVAL TIPS FOR LESS FINANCIAL STRESS The good news is there are solutions to lessen or avoid much of the stress surrounding the holidays.
The simplest for most is to plan ahead by knowing how much money can go towards gifts. Then, keep a list of receipts to avoid overspending.
Some people should pick up a side hustle if money is tight, like becoming a rideshare driver or helping others wrap gifts. There are many ways to double your money so that the cost of gifts is not as stressful.
Many people (35%) feel stressed about coming up with gift ideas. To limit this stress, contact the person and ask what they need. Alternatively, ask their friends or family for ideas.
Finally, it's critical to take some personal time to limit stress and enjoy the true meaning of the holiday season. By being proactive and intentional this year, it's possible to make this season the most enjoyable one yet.
This article was produced by Media Decision and syndicated by Wealth of Geeks. 
 
 Caption: ASSOCIATED PRESS

 A man dressed as Santa Claus waves as a train arrives carrying passengers for a Christmas tree lighting ceremony and parade Saturday, Nov. 25, 2023, in Plains, Ga. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily discusses inflation‑driven changes in consumer spending, credit‑card debt, and economic anxiety around the holiday season, which aligns with the Business/Economy topic. Health is a secondary theme due to mentions of stress, anxiety, and mental‑health impacts.

title: Realty Navigator Celebrates Grand Re-Opening Of Kent Island Offices
author: Eric Sylvia; Special To The Star Democrat
content:
Realty Navigator Celebrates Grand Re-Opening Of Kent Island Offices

 December 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Eric Sylvia; Special To The Star Democrat | Page: 15 | Section: News 
 
 414
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTER - On a cool, but festive December afternoon, the team at Realty Navigator in Chester, invited family, friends and business colleagues to come and celebrate the grand re-opening of their offices at 110 South Piney Road, Suite 110. Members of the Queen Anne's County Chamber of Commerce, Mid-Shore Board of Realtors and Queen Anne's County Commissioners were on hand to join the celebration.Realty Navigator is comprised of a group of hand-selected realtors who have been very successful in both listing and selling homes, land, and light commercial properties, and conducting rental transactions and property management.
They have worked with buyers and sellers to achieve their personal and investment needs for both short-and long-term goals. Individually they have all worked with developers and builders, business owners, and charitable groups and have created a broad database of clients and business associates that help to sell or acquire what their clients request, by direct word-of-mouth referral.
With the corporate drive of demanding high agent counts within larger franchises, which isn't necessarily reflective of a quality sales team, Realty Navigator focuses more on relationship building and disseminating information through their database, digital and print marketing and internet/social media to meet or exceed their client's individual needs.
Realty Navigator has 60+ years of combined sales experience within their select group of realtors.
This affords Realty Navigator the opportunity to provide topshelf Real Estate Services while catering to their client's unique needs. Their preferred service area expands from Annapolis and Anne Arundel County to Prince George's, Charles, Calvert, and St. Mary's County in the south, in the West and North we cover Montgomery, Frederick, and Howard counties, and East.
Realty Navigator has experts in Chester in Queen Anne's, Caroline, Talbot, Kent, and Dorchester Counties, and a broad network of strong referral partners across the entire state of Maryland, the country and even Europe.
If you decide not to renew your current listing agreement, if you are ready to put your house up for sale for the first time, move up, or size it down a notch, let Realty Navigator conduct a market analysis and marketing plan organized to meet your goals, or, if you are ready to buy your first, second, vacation home or investment property Realty Navigator has an agent for you. 
 
 Caption: ERIC SYLVIA

 Petra Quinn and Vince Payne cut the ribbon officially opening their new location in Chester.

title: Benedictine Recognizes Staff Milestones
author: Contributed

Benedictine Recognizes Staff Milestones

 December 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 RIDGELY - Benedictine celebrated milestones in service for 50 of its dedicated staff members in early December. The awards were presented to employees with 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, and 30, 45, and 55 years of service.Phyllis Young celebrated 55 years with Benedictine. During her tenure, Young filled many roles in the School residential program, as a Nursing Assistant, Vocational Teacher, Home Economics Teacher and Summer Camp Teacher's Aide.
She was previously honored by the Maryland Association of Nonpublic Special Education Facilities as a recipient of the Inspiring Dreams, Changing Lives Award.
Executive Assistant Carolyn Ebling celebrated 45 years with Benedictine.
"Carolyn, is the person behind the scenes who has positively affected so many people during her time at Benedictine," said Executive Director Scott Evans. "She works tirelessly, never seeking recognition, and her dedication, support and guidance is invaluable."
"Benedictine commends all its staff milestone awardees for their compassion, dedication, dependability and caring devotion for the children and adults they serve and for their commitment to Benedictine," the organization said in a press release. "These traits are demonstrated in their interactions with the people they support and their families, as well as their co-workers and community partners."
Benedictine employs over 350 staff that are dedicated to serving children and adults with moderate to severe developmental disabilities and autism.
For more information on Benedictine's events, services and ways to support, please contact Claudia.cunningham@benschool.org or 410 634 2292.

title: Swimming Santas gifted delightful day for raising funds, spirits
author: Debra Messick; Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Swimming Santas gifted delightful day for raising funds, spirits

 December 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Debra Messick; Special to the Star Democrat | Page: 8 | Section: News 
 
 370
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Despite December's usually frightful forecast, every year a group of hardy souls wearing Santa hats head to the Hyatt Regency Chesapeake Bay Resort to willingly take a dip in the nippy Chop tank River.They do it gladly, for love and money - love of community, money to help others in need - as part of the Care and Share Fund, Inc. annual Santa Swim.
Individuals and teams signing up enlist sponsors who contribute money for their effort. The donated dollars are used to help improve life for the many at risk adults and children throughout Dorchester County.
Holiday programs funded by the Santa Swim provide individuals and families with food, clothes, toys, and other items. But throughout the year, the Fund also aids those with critical needs that are not able to be filled by public sources or Dorchester County Department of Social Services during the clients' period of crisis. The nonprofit Care & Share Fund, which began in 1998, also provides help with prescriptions, utility payments to prevent cut-off, medical equipment, hearing aids, diabetic supplies, and a variety of other services, including free notary service.
Fortunately, the weather for this year's festive dunk on Saturday, Dec. 9 at 11 a.m. was anything but frightful for the 20 swimmers, who helped raise a bit over $5,000.
"This is a wonderful holiday tradition that raises funds for an organization doing good for the community. The weather for the event was the best I can remember in years but even when the weather is horrible there is a solid group of community centered residents going out into the river to help those in our county that need assistance," noted Dorchester County Chamber of Commerce President/CEO Bill Christopher.
Michael S. Wheatley, now in his fifth year as Care and Share President, was grateful for all those involved who supported the event, raising money and awareness.
"Everyone who contributed helps our organization make a difference for needy families right here in Dorchester County, in our home communities" Wheatley noted.
For more information, visit careandsharefund.com or call 443-521-4070. 
 
 Caption: CONTRIBUTED

 Partners in Giving prepare to take the plunge for the Care & Share Fund, an organization tasked with meeting critical needs for county residents, not only at Christmas, but year round.

title: Cambridge Rotary Club learns what's next for local newspapers
author: CONTRIBUTED
content:
Cambridge Rotary Club learns what's next for local newspapers

 December 21, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CONTRIBUTED | Page: A6 | Section: News 
 
 265
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Jim Johnson, executive editor for APG Chesapeake, spoke to the Rotary Club of Cambridge about the company and, specifically, the Dorchester Star.Johnson said of the 12 newspapers owned by APG, 11 are based in Maryland, with the other in Delaware.
With each, there are ongoing goals to make the newspapers better and to fit the community they represent.
Johnson shared the papers are placing more focus on local news and arts coverage to accomplish this goal.
Since the Dorchester Star is a free newspaper, all revenue comes from advertisements.
Effective the week of Dec. 4, the paper will be printed on Wednesday.
"Since many of the sales brochures begin on Wednesday, it only made sense to have the paper available on the first day of the sale," Johnson said.
He added that they have created a partnership with local radio station WHCP.
More about the partnership will be coming as it develops.
Jim encouraged the Rotarians to send any local stories to the paper and other APG papers for publication.
The articles are needed to continue making the paper effective for the community.
Johnson and his wife, Bridget, moved to Cambridge from Red Wing, Minn. Earlier this year. He has been a newspaper editor in Minnesota, Wisconsin, Nebraska and California, including a time with The Omaha-World Harold overseeing technology and information security. From 2012-2020, Jim and Bridget owned a newspaper in Iowa. He said, "with Covid, it became difficult to continue the paper." He felt the move to APG, based in Easton, became a great step for his career.

title: Double payments to slash mortgage principal - how does that work?
content:
Double payments to slash mortgage principal - how does that work?

 December 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 149
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Dear Cheapskate: Would you please explain how making double mortgage payments works to reduce the principal? - Stephanie Dear Stephanie: Sure!Let's say you have these loan terms: $150,000 principal at 6% interest for 15 years.
Your monthly payments are $1,265.78.
You are about to make your first monthly payment.
If you asked for an amortization schedule, you know that payment will be allocated $750 to interest, and $515.78 to the principal.
After you make your first double payment, your new principal balance is $149,484.21, because the entire $1,265.78 of your second payment went toward reducing the principal balance or for "principal prepayment." Typically, the terms of a home mortgage allow you to make any amount of additional principal payment during the month once you have paid the payment and interest due. It doesn't have to be a full payment. (Don't assume anything, though.
Check the terms of your mortgage.)
COPYRIGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM 
 
 Caption: MARY HUNT

title: Tinned Fish Market on the Rise as 'Affordable Luxury'
author: Cara Campbell; Wealth Of Geeks
content:
Tinned Fish Market on the Rise as 'Affordable Luxury'

 January 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Cara Campbell; Wealth Of Geeks | Page: 7A | Section: News 
 
 802
 Words 

 Read News Document

 According to a report by Persistence Market Research, the tinned fish market in the United States is predicted to reach $17.2 billion by the end of 2033.That's a jump from $9.5 billion in 2022.
Part of the demand is driven by consumers becoming more health-conscious.
Tinned fish contains omega-3 fatty acids, which are known to help with heart and brain health, and they help protect against the negative impacts of mercury, which some other fresh fish are known for.
Health coach Karen Kelly from Seasonal Cravings says tinned fish is excellent for several reasons. "I often recommend canned fish to my clients who need more nutrient-dense foods in their diet and are looking for convenience.
It is readily available, easy to prepare, and affordable," she says. "It tastes great in grain bowls, with leftover roasted vegetables and a drizzle of your favorite salad dressing." WHAT IS TINNED FISH?
Tinned fish, or canned fish, are fish that have been processed, sealed, and sterilized.
Some popular examples include tuna, sardines, salmon mackerel, anchovies, and herring. And while many are probably familiar with a classic tuna sandwich, tinned fish has gone way beyond that, finding its way onto everything from charcuterie boards to upscale restaurant menus.
TIKTOK REVIVAL
Part of the recent increase in sales is attributed to the "rediscovery" of tinned fish on social media. Anna Hezel is an Epicurious senior editor and the author of Tin to Table: Fancy, Snacky Recipes for Tin-thusiasts and A-fish-ionados. She says, "Getting into tinned fish is a little intimidating if you've never bought a particular product, and you have no idea what it's going to look like when the lid is peeled back.
TikTok has really helped demystify this category of seafood for so many people and celebrated the social and visual aspects of collecting and eating tinned fish." The hashtag #tinnedfish has 116.4 million views on TikTok as of this writing, and it's also cultivated a community called #tinnedfishtok, which has nearly 68 million views.
ORIGINS
Although a younger North American audience may be discovering tinned fish for the first time, it's a food with a long history. It originated in the 1700s in France, when preserved foods were in great demand. Their long shelf life and accessibility were precious for the French military.
Hezel says COVID-19 played a part in opening up American markets to the industry more recently. "I think there was a big cultural shift during the onset of COVID-19 when people started seeking out shelf-stable foods way more and also started to do their grocery shopping online a lot more," she says. "This coincided with the launch of a bunch of new tinned fish brands with availability in the U.S., and from there, the trend hasn't really slowed down." AFFORDABLE LUXURY
The booming trend on TikTok is revamping the image of tinned fish for many young people. Either they didn't know what to do with it or were scared by it.
Now, says Hezel, canned fish has become an approachable form of luxury, mainly at a significant cost reduction from fresh seafood, like ahi tuna.
"I think of certain hobbies, like collecting wines, which require hundreds of dollars just to get started," says Hezel. "By comparison, you can buy a really beautifully crafted, hand-packed tin of sardines in amazing olive oil from Portugal for $6." Much like appreciating the craftsmanship that goes into a chef-made lobster ravioli dish or a perfectly selected bottle of wine, "you get to taste all of this skill and tradition that's gone into preparing the fish without buying a plane ticket or paying for a restaurant meal," says Hezel.
HOW TO USE TINNED FISH AT HOME
Tinned fish is a versatile ingredient. A quick search online will reveal a wide array of pasta, salads, charcuterie boards, toasts, and more creative ways for tinned fish lovers to consume this product.
Lavender & Macarons food blogger Iryna Bychkiv says she eats tinned sardines at least once a week. "They make an excellent 'emergency' food when you're too tired or busy to cook a complicated meal," she says.
On the flip side, if she has time, she'll make a sardine salad with boiled potatoes, eggs, chopped cucumber, and green onion. "It's very filling and satisfying, plus sardines are packed with proteinso it's a win-win." Hezel loves to make tinned fish the star of the show when she's having a fancy dinner or a date night.
"I love to make a big, elaborate salad, buy a nice loaf of sourdough, and open two or three tins to try," she says.
HERE TO STAY
With the market set to grow over the next 10 years, the popularity, availability and choice for tinned fish isn't going anywhere.
It's affordable, nutritious, convenient, and versatile.
It may appear on pantry shelves, restaurant menus, and date nights for years.
This article was produced by the Gourmet Bon Vivant and syndicated by Wealth of Geeks. 
 
 Caption: WEALTH OF GEEKS

 BURKHARD MÜCKE/WIKIMEDIA COMMONS

 Anchovy Pizza 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily discusses market size, growth forecasts, and consumer trends for tinned fish, which aligns with business and economic reporting, while also mentioning health benefits as a secondary aspect.

title: WBOC dropped from Breezeline cable lineup
author: Natalie Jones
content:
WBOC dropped from Breezeline cable lineup

 January 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Local News 
 
 551
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Breezeline, a local cable provider serving viewers in the Mid-Shore region, dropped Salisbury-based news station WBOC-TV from its lineup on Dec. 31, upsetting many customers.The cable provider made the decision to drop the CBS-affiliated news station from its lineup due to WBOC being an out-of-market station to the communities Breezeline serves, according to a statement on the news station's website.
Those communities — some in Talbot, Queen Anne's and Kent counties — are in the Baltimore viewing area, per Nielsen Media Research.
According to Andrew Walton, a spokesperson for Breezeline, the Federal Communications Commission designated WJZ, the CBS affiliate in Baltimore, as the in-market station. WBOC, an out-of-market station, is not significantly viewed, he said in an email.
Nielsen determines the designated market area based on viewing patterns. The designated market areas and stations within those areas are published quarterly, and the FCC has established processes for subsequent modifications.
Breezeline notified its customers in November about the drop of WBOC from its local lineups, Walton said.
Craig Jahelka, president of Draper Media, the company that owns WBOC, stressed that the decision was not a carriage dispute, or made because the station and the cable provider couldn't agree. It was a unilateral decision by Breezeline, he said.
Jahelka, a former journalist, said it was "very frustrating" for the decision to be made for the station by Breezeline executives not in WBOC's coverage area.
"Without us ... people don't know what's going on," he said.
News stations in Baltimore won't cover stories local to the Mid-Shore region, or the area's weather and sports, Jahelka added.
Walton said the discontinuation of carriage was instituted to manage costs for customers.
While there is constant pressure on rates because of large, ongoing increases in content costs, Breezeline works to manage costs where possible to make sure its video service provides a strong value for customers, he added.
"We understand the disappointment that some Grasonville customers feel about WBOC," Walton said via email. "Yet, all Breezeline TV viewers would have been burdened with the cost of both channels when the content on WBOC substantially duplicates that found on WJZ. In addition, local content on WBOC can be accessed on their website for free."
This is not the first time WBOC was dropped from Breezeline's lineup.
In late December 2014, Atlantic Broadband, which was rebranded as Breezeline in early 2022, dropped the news station after a local programming review.
The volume of public outcry then about the decision prompted the cable provider to restore WBOC to its channel lineup within a month, Jahelka said.
While Jahelka can't force the cable provider to add the station back to its lineup, a resurgence of public outcry about the decision could potentially prompt Breezeline to return the channel, he added.
WBOC itself has already been inundated with calls from upset viewers. Some viewers have taken to social media to voice frustration with the decision.
Jahelka encouraged customers to contact Breezeline, saying it's the only way for the cable provider to understand how important WBOC's coverage is to Delmarva residents.
Viewers with concerns or complaints can reach out to Breezeline via email at breezeline@breezeline.com.
But for now, those interested in viewing WBOC's news programs can watch via its website or the WBOC app. News is also available via WBOC's social media.
This story has been updated from an earlier version to include the most current contact information for Breezeline. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a cable provider's business decision to drop a news station from its lineup, focusing on market designations, cost management, and consumer impact, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.

title: A year in review at Londonderry on the Tred Avon
author: LONDONDERRY ON THE TRED AVON
content:
A year in review at Londonderry on the Tred Avon

 January 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LONDONDERRY ON THE TRED AVON | Section: Life 
 
 441
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As Londonderry on the Tred Avon reflects on 2023 and looks ahead to 2024, it is thankful for the dedication and enthusiasm of their team, residents and community partners who all played vital roles in this year's success.This same team has set the stage for an even stronger 2024.
A few highlighted achievements include:
Londonderry proudly welcomed new CEO Christine Harrington in September. With Harrington's extensive experience as both an organizational leader and day-to-day manager in the senior living work field, with over 15 years in an executive role, she has been an ideal fit for the community.
"We were thrilled to welcome Christine this past September," said Rachel Smith, Londonderry's sales and marketing director. "Getting to know her and witnessing the unique value she adds to our community and team has been a delight. We're eagerly looking forward to the future and counting on her as an integral part of our exceptional team."
Londonderry also continued its record of community recognition in 2023 winning Best Retirement/55+ Community in the APG Best of the Best Chesapeake Community Choice Awards and being named a finalist in the Senior Living Category.
Other awards included, "Best Residential Community" in Talbot and Dorchester Counties for the fourth year by the readers of Coastal Style magazine as well as "Best Retirement Community" in What's Up Eastern Shore magazine.
Also in 2023, Londonderry was pleased to introduce our New Board President, John Flohr, along with two new additions to our Board, Steve Cades and Jean Rhian.
Jennifer Hughes, Londonderry Controller, graduated from Shore Leadership, a nine-month program where participants learn through face-to-face discussions with local community leaders and experts from organizations and institutions that shape the region's economic structure and culture.
On Oct. 19, Londonderry hosted their annual themed event, with Casino Night being 2023's theme.
The event was attended by more than 100 guests, which included residents, residents' families, members of the Board of Directors, local elected officials and other community members. Guests walked a red carpet, played table games led by a professional croupier with fun money and were entertained by a live band while enjoying casino-themed drinks and appetizers.
"The accomplishments of this past year are a testament to the dedication of our incredible team members, Board of Directors, residents and supportive community business partners," said Harrington. "We are truly fortunate to have so many wonderful people contributing to our commitment of excellence on campus. As we step into 2024, we're excited to enhance retirement living at Londonderry through innovation and advancement."
As the new year gets underway, there are ownership opportunities available. To learn more about what residences are available, please contact Rachel Smith, Sales and Marketing Director at rsmith@londonderrytredavon.com .
