title: No consensus on dealing with projected deficit
author: DAVID REEL
content:
No consensus on dealing with projected deficit

 March 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 869
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last November, progressives in Maryland were thrilled when Democratic candidate Wes Moore was elected governor in a landslide after defeating nine much more well-known opponents in a Democratic primary. They were even more thrilled when progressive Democratic candidates were elected to replace moderate Democratic members and Republican members in the Maryland House of Delegates and the Maryland Senate.Those elections further solidified the Democratic veto- proof supermajorities in both houses of the General Assembly.
Going into the 2014 General Assembly session, progressives seemed to be large and in charge. They looked forward to further advancing their progressive public policy agenda.
As the 90-day session begins to wind down, that has not been the case, especially on tax and budget matters. It is increasingly clear the Democratic supermajorities are not monolithic, nor is the governor fully embracing an aggressive progressive tax and budget agenda.
This outcome was not expected when Gov. Moore presented his proposed state budget in mid-January. Then there was consensus that a balanced state budget would be easily approved before or by the end of the session as required by the Maryland Constitution.
Recently that consensus has been shaken to the core based on five consecutive revised State Board of Revenue Estimates projecting state budget deficits will be the largest since the "Great Recession" which began in December 2007 and ended in June 2009.
Next fiscal year, the deficit is projected to reach $1 billion. In fiscal year 2027, the last year of Gov. Moore's first term, it is projected to grow to $1.3 billion. A year later, it is projected to more than double to $3 billion and could be $4 billion the following fiscal year. These projections do not include the impact of funding to address a $3.1 billion deficit in the state Transportation Trust Fund and $8 billion to fully implement the Blueprint for Maryland's Future (The Kirwan Report).
As a result, there has been intense and even contentious debate in the Democratic supermajorities on what to do and when to do it. The answer depends on who you ask and where they sit.
The Democratic House majority leader, Democratic chair of the House Ways and Means Committee, and the Democratic chair of the House Appropriations Committee, are united in saying the General Assembly needs to raise taxes and needs to raise them now. The Democratic Senate president and Democratic chair of the Senate Budget and Taxation Committee are saying not so fast, we do not need to raise taxes in this session.
Gov. Moore agrees with the Senate leader's position, there is no need for tax increases for now. Asked if that position would hold beyond the current year, Moore has said, "I just know that the bar for raising taxes not just this year, but for every single year for me, it's going to be a very high bar."
His budget secretary has elaborated on Moore's overall strategy on budgets and taxes going forward by saying, "These revenue trends continue to underscore the necessity of taking bold steps to improve our economy, create jobs and bring new businesses and population to Maryland."
No doubt the Moore administration is aware of the results when Maryland Democratic General Assembly supermajorities approved a wide range of tax and fee increases proposed by progressive Democratic Gov. Martin O'Malley. With a "Change Maryland" message that resonated with Republican, Democratic and unaffiliated voters, Republican Larry Hogan won two terms as governor and now has an opportunity to be elected to the U.S. Senate.
As is almost always the case In Maryland, final decisions over increasing state spending and increasing state taxes and fees will come down to how much and when?
The larger question is how Democratic Party control of the state government will be impacted if the current divide between the shrinking moderate wing of the party and the growing progressive wing of the party on budget and tax matters is not resolved.
One unforeseen obstacle to resolving this divide are comments made recently by one high profile progressive Democratic county executive and agreed to by another.
Anne Arundel County Executive Steuart Pittman said the failure of long-standing progressive "tax reform" goals to gain support in the General Assembly is because "loopholes are everywhere for interests that lobby for loopholes. It's baked into the system. Legislators survive on a diet of campaign contributions to get into office and to stay there. The largest donors tend to be the very interests lobbying for loopholes and opposing a fair distribution of the tax burden."
Montgomery County Executive Marc Elrich agreed with that observation.
Such remarks are not going to help advance progressive positions in the General Assembly even when their party has supermajorities.
Given all of the above, one can ask if the dynamics in the state legislature may be open to real change. What if Republican members who are accustomed to being largely irrelevant on budget and tax matters in Annapolis, forge a working relationship with moderate Democratic members on issues of common interest such as spending and taxes?
Likely? No. Probable? No. Possible? Maybe.
In politics anything is possible. Ask Larry Hogan and Wes Moore. I suspect both were told early on when they launched their gubernatorial campaigns that winning was not possible.
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant who lives in Easton. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses state budget deficits, tax policy, and fiscal decisions, which are core economic and business issues, making Business/Economy the most fitting category.

title: Senators hear arguments for 32-hour work week
author: TORRENCE BANKS Capital News Service
content:
Senators hear arguments for 32-hour work week

 March 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TORRENCE BANKS Capital News Service | Section: Business 
 
 606
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — In 1955, Walter Reuther, head of what was then known as the United Automobile Workers (UAW), told a Senate hearing that coming technological advancements would make a four-day workweek possible.That was the last Senate hearing on the subject for nearly 70 years. The Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee finally ended the draught Thursday as lawmakers debated legislation, sponsored by Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vermont) that would reduce the standard workweek to 32 hours without cutting employees' pay.
"...Despite an explosion in technology and a massive increase in worker productivity, nothing has changed," Sanders said. "Think about that, huge transitions we have seen in the economy. But in terms of the workweek, nothing has changed."
Sanders said that the goal of his bill was to ensure that working-class citizens benefit from the revolutionary changes in the workplace over the past seven decades.
Introducing his measure Wednesday, Sanders said that U.S. workers had become over 400% more productive since the 1940s. Even so, people now are working longer hours at lower wages, he said.
UAW President Shawn Fain said that automation now allows a single worker to do what used to require 12 workers. Companies' obsession with ensuring productivity every second of the day has come at the cost of workers, he said.
"When people reach the end of their lives they never say I wish I'd make more money," Fain told senators. "What they wish for is they wish they had more time. There was a time when this phenomenon was supposed to lead to workers getting our time back, getting some of their lives back."
Forty percent of Americans work at least 50 hours a week, and 18% of today's workforce works more than 60 hours a week, according to research cited in Sanders' statement.
A 2019 study published by the International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health found that working more than 60 hours a week led to a decline in workers' mental health compared to those who worked standard hours.
"It causes an increase in cortisol levels, which lead to heart disease, cancers, strokes," Fain said about working extended hours during the week. "But given all those facts as someone is lucky enough to get to retire, typically when they weren't willing to work themselves to death their entire life, they face knee replacements, hip replacements, shoulder surgeries, and the rest of their lives, figuring out how they're going to survive."
But Liberty Vittert, a data science professor at the Olin Business School at Washington University in St. Louis, said that studies suggesting that working fewer hours leads to happiness are flawed. Vittert said that many of the studies showing an increase in happiness find the effects are short-term and that long-term studies show that happiness does not increase over time.
In addition, only companies that can cut out extra meetings and coffee breaks during the day participate in these studies, excluding more than 70% of the U.S. job economy, Vittert said.
"If you want to see those same employees really stressed out, just see what happens when their employers lay them off to hire part-time workers instead, or have to close their doors because they cannot make enough revenue," Vittert said.
She pointed out that older workers who cannot complete the same amount of work in fewer hours are at a disadvantage.
Sen. Bill Cassidy of Louisiana, the ranking Republican on the panel, emphasized that there is no law preventing companies from already enacting a 32-hour workweek and that federal intervention is not necessary.
"Let's give flexibility to workers and employers — don't have government come in and intervene," said Roger King, senior labor and employment counsel at the HR Policy Association. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on Senate legislation and debate about reducing the workweek, a labor and economic policy issue, placed in the Business section, with secondary references to health impacts of long hours.

title: Inflation: Higher prices for car insurance, beer, housing, fabric, baby formula
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Newspapers
content:
Inflation: Higher prices for car insurance, beer, housing, fabric, baby formula

 March 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Newspapers | Section: Business 
 
 442
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Inflation was up 3.2% in February compared to a year ago with higher prices for housing, car insurance, dining and items such as beer, baby formula, sew machines and fabric.Prices for consumer goods, items such as insurance and staples including food and housing are up 20% from before the COVID pandemic and its shutdowns and massive spending and monetary measures.
U.S. prices are up 18.6% since January 2021 when President Joe Biden took office.
The Consumer Price Index for February shows higher prices across the U.S. as voters continue to have consternation over their personal finances and the economy.
Housing helped drive the overall 3.2% CPI inflation rate with a 5.7% increase in costs from Feb. 2023.
Rents are up 5.8% as affordable housing continues to be a problem for many households across the country.
Higher prices are also showing up in spending areas across the economy creating reelection challenges for Biden in his rematch with former president Donald Trump.
Car insurance rates are up a whopping 20.6% compared a year ago, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Prices for food at restaurants are up 4.5% with the industry facing continued labor shortages, higher prices for food, alcoholic beverages and equipment and increased financing costs and debt loads stemming from Federal Reserve interest rate hikes to tackle inflation.
Baby formula and baby food have jumped 8.8%.
Tuition for day care and preschools are 5.5% more expansive than 12 months ago.
Sewing machines are fabric prices have increased 11% since last February. Those increase have been seen with patterns, equipment and fabric and comes as JoAnn's Fabric, a major retailer in the space, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.
Tax service providers have hiked their prices by 9.8% over the past year.
Cameras and photo equipment are 9% more expensive
Beer prices are up 4.1%.The beer market has seen some upheavals with the higher prices impacting consumer decisions and the growth in popularity of brands such as Yuengling and Modelo.
Bud Light is still the top U.S. beer brand but was its popularity negatively impacted after a social media ad featuring transgender influencer Dylan Mulvaney and an Anheuser-Busch marketing executive deriding the brand's customer base as 'too fratty.'
Higher grocery prices have eased some from their inflation wave highs but are still up 2.2% from a year ago. Smartphone prices are down 10.5% from a year ago, according to BLS.
Public opinion polls show voters rank inflation and the economy among their top concerns. That comes despite Biden, Democrats and media acolytes touting some strong macro-economic figures.
U.S. prices rose 7.7% during Trump's term in office (2017-2021), according to BLS. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on inflation, price increases across consumer goods, housing, insurance, and the broader economic impact, which aligns directly with the Business/Economy topic. While it has national relevance, the primary angle is economic rather than general news.

title: New owner hopes to be a 'steward' of Robert Morris Inn's history
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
New owner hopes to be a 'steward' of Robert Morris Inn's history

 March 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Business 
 
 577
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — The owner of the historic Robert Morris Inn, which overlooks the Tred Avon River, has big dreams for this Oxford landmark.Part of creating owner David Snyder's dream is picking a great team. He chose veterans Gretchen Gordon and chef Sean Raspberry to help him implement a new menu and oversee renovations in the 16-room inn.
"Instead of watching all the cars go across to St. Michaels, we want to watch them coming across to come here, and this will be great for the town," Gordon said. "We will be open seven days a week."
By early April, the plan is to offer three meals a day.
The restaurant is called Financier. The offerings — like crispy ginger fried oysters, lamb sliders and tandoori chicken skewers — let you know this isn't some backwater joint. They want this to be a destination.
Snyder, who was a history major, read a lot about Robert Morris.
"The history of this property is unbelievable," Snyder said. "I still can't believe that I am associated with it."
The name of the restaurant comes from Morris' role as a financier during the American Revolution. He lived at the inn for three years and was a confidante of George Washington.
To capitalize on that notoriaty, Snyder wants to create Robert Morris beer along with bourbon and wine. He is balancing between celebrating what is historic and expanding and reenvisioning what is possible for future growth.
Some of the entrees speak to the wide-ranging palate of Chef Raspberry, who has cooked at The Inn at Perry Cabin, Out of the Fire and General Tanuki's. Asian-style crispy duck, cornmeal dusted crispy fried whole snapper and chimichurri marinated braised short rib enchalladas all make the choice difficult.
"I have been cooking for 40 years," Raspberry said. "(My food says) 'I am here. Come see me.' Me and general manager Gretchen, we were bound to meet, bottom line. It is a match made in heaven. I want to do 150 plates a day."
"I am excited about the whole menu," he said.
They have a plan to get into catering. Snyder said he would love to do weddings on site too.
The menu at the Inn is "Southwest meets the Chesapeake Bay," Gordon, who used to run Latitude 38 in Oxford and sold it, said. "This chef's flavors are right up there at the top."
Once they get that established, they will open for lunch and eventually create a breakfast and coffee bar.
Their goal is to convert an outdoor space behind the inn into a beer garden with views of the Strand and the Oxford Ferry. Snyder wants to get permission from the Historic District Commission to make these changes.
He employs around 20 people already. He has worked back of the house and front of the house, but his focus will be on building the brand and finding new opportunities for this property.
Snyder wants to convert the parking lot in the back of the Inn into permeable space like grass for people to play lawn games. Eventually, permits allowing, he wants to put a pool and putting green in the back and have yoga classes up on the roof.
"We can turn this back into the 'River View House,' and it will have views again," he said.
With all these plans, he remains aware that he has invested in something built in the 1700s.
"I want to bring it up and improve it in ways that future generations can use it," he said. "Just being a steward of that is incredible." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the new owner’s business plans, restaurant development, renovations, and economic impact of the historic Robert Morris Inn, making Business/Economy the most appropriate category.

title: Price of gas in state jumps 16 cents in week
author: Staff Writer
content:
Price of gas in state jumps 16 cents in week

 March 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 504
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have risen 16.6 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.50 per gallon on Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 12.5 cents per gallon higher than a month ago and stand 21.9 cents per gallon higher than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has declined 2.2 cents in the last week and stands at $4 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.49 per gallon on Sunday while the most expensive was $4.58 per gallon, a difference of $2.09 per gallon.The national average price of gasoline has risen 4.4 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.44 per gallon on Monday. The national average is up 18.7 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 1.6 cents per gallon higher than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
March 18, 2023: $3.28 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.43 per gallon)
March 18, 2022: $4.13 per gallon (U.S. Average: $4.27 per gallon)
March 18, 2021: $2.84 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.87per gallon)
March 18, 2020: $2.21 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.16 per gallon)
March 18, 2019: $2.57 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.56 per gallon)
March 18, 2018: $2.55 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.54/g)
March 18, 2017: $2.30 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.29 per gallon)
March 18, 2016: $1.98 per gallon (U.S. Average: $1.98 per gallon)
March 18, 2015: $2.42 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.42 per gallon)
March 18, 2014: $3.52 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.52 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore- $3.50 per gallon, up 19.3 cents per gallon from last week's $3.30 per gallon.
Washington DC- $3.57 per gallon, up 8.9 cents per gallon from last week's $3.48 per gallon.
Hagerstown- $3.47 per gallon, up 11.3 cents per gallon from last week's $3.36 per gallon.
"Most Americans continued to see average gasoline prices march higher last week. The reason is the season: gasoline demand is rising as more Americans are getting out, combined with the summer gasoline switchover, which is well underway, and continued refinery maintenance," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy.
He added: "The madness should slow down in the next few weeks as we've seen positive data that refinery output is starting to increase, a sign that the peak of maintenance season could be behind us."
In some positive news for Midwest motorists, the BP refinery in Whiting, Indiana, that can process 440,000 barrels of oil per day, is finally back to normal operations for the first time since an electrical failure happened in early February. For now, gas prices will likely continue to trend higher, but the fever may break soon. When it comes to diesel, the news has been good — above average temperatures have lowered heating oil demand, and average diesel prices are on the cusp of falling back below $4 per gallon." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on recent changes in gasoline prices, a consumer‑price and market trend story, which fits best under Business/Economy. It is not about safety, politics, or culture, making Business/Economy the most appropriate category.

title: Eclipse 2024: America gets ready for next month’s big celestial event (VIDEO)
author: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
Eclipse 2024: America gets ready for next month’s big celestial event (VIDEO)

 March 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor | Section: Travel 
 
 1382
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Mansfield, Texas, and Mansfield, Ohio, are more than 1,100 miles and a 17-hour drive from each other.But the two cities share more than a name.
Like communities from Texas to Maine, the two Mansfields are expecting a surge of visitors for next month's total solar eclipse.
On Monday, April 8, the total solar eclipse will cross North America with at least a partial view of the moon blocking out the sun throughout the continental U.S.
As many as 4 million people could travel to viewing sites across 13 states in the path of totality to view the moon completely blocking out the sun for between 3 and 4 minutes.
That path starts in Mexico and then traverses Texas and 12 other U.S. states including Oklahoma, Missouri, Kentucky, Illinois, Ohio, New York and into New England.
"It's simply the most spectacular sight you will see in your life," said Michael Zeiler, a self-professed eclipse chaser who operates GreatAmericanEclipse. com. He's been viewing celestial events since 1991.
There will not be another similar celestial event in the continental U.S. until 2044, according to Angela Des Jardins, a physics professor at Montana State University, who is a lead researcher in a NASA initiative deploying 1,000 faculty and students from dozens of colleges and schools throughout the country to analyze the eclipse.
Special glasses and viewers are needed to watch the eclipse in order to avoid potential eye and vision damage from staring at the sun.
TOURISM BOOST
In Mansfield, Ohio, Jodie Snavely expects as many 250,000 people to visit Richland County (which sits between Cleveland and Columbus).
"We have not had anything like this before. The last total eclipse in our region was 1806. But it's exciting to see the creativity of what the local businesses have planned before and during the eclipse for the residents and visitors," said Snavely, special projects director for Destination Mansfield — Richland County.
Eclipse viewing events will be held at Kingwood Center Gardens and the historic Ohio State Reformatory (a former prison where "Shawshank Redemption" was filmed and is celebrating its 30th anniversary.)
Snavely said some of Mansfield's eclipse marketing is tied to the movie.
Other creative events range from watching the eclipse during a yoga class at the Ohio Bird Sanctuary or with alpacas at a local farm to a weekend music festival and "You'll Burn Your Eye Out" eclipse watch party hosted by a local brewery.
Snavely said the area could see a $7 million tourism and economic boost from the event.
Tim Roberts, marketing and promotions manager for Mansfield, Texas' Convention & Visitors Bureau, said his town moved its spring musical festival to April 6 and renamed the Music Alley Eclipse Fest to coincide with the event.
"We are fully expecting 8,000 to 10,000 people based upon our hotel bookings. Our hotels are mostly booked that weekend," Roberts said, adding that some room rates are as high as $500 per night.
Mansfield — 34 miles southwest of Dallas — is also hosting eclipse watch parties. Roberts said he's seen interest from visitors as far as Europe including Poland.
Texas is the prime U.S. spot to view the event with the longest totality times (how long the moon will darken the sun), according to eclipse chasers and astronomers.
Zeiler said he is viewing the April event from Fredericksburg, Texas (70 miles northwest of San Antonio). He said Texas is the ideal U.S. spot because it is more prone to have clear weather on eclipse day and Fredericksburg is near multiple highways in case cloudy or inclement weather necessitated relocating to clearer skies.
'COMING FROM ALL OVER'
Many eclipse travelers are looking at camping options to enjoy the event.
Many campgrounds along the U.S. route have already or will sell out for the weekend leading up to the Monday eclipse.
"We've got them coming from all over," said Monica Garcia, general manager of Mystic Quarry, a camping site in Canyon Lake, Texas (in between Austin and San Antonio) that offers cabins, tents, teepees and spots for RVs.
Garcia expects to be sold out by eclipse day with remaining cabins and teepees running $230 per night.
The early April combination of spring break travel and the eclipse path near major population centers could make for one of the busiest travel periods in U.S. history.
OTHER TOP DESTINATIONSAixa Diaz, a spokesperson for AAA, said the likes of Cleveland and Dayton, Ohio; Buffalo and Syracuse, New York; Indianapolis, Little Rock, Arkansas and Burlington, Vermont; join Texas cities as the top eclipse destinations.
And, she said travelers are paying hefty prices.
"Flights to cities along the path of totality are averaging 28% higher compared to last year and hotels are 48% more expensive during the eclipse weekend compared to that same weekend in 2023," Diaz said.
In Ohio and other states, tourism bureaus, campground operators and universities are centering events around the eclipse.
Zeiler said northern Ohio on the shores of Lake Erie and spots along Lake Ontario in upstate New York could also offer clear viewing weather for viewers.
In the southeastern part of the state, Defiance County, Ohio and Ohio University are among those hosting events leading up and on April 8 including at the latter's Chillicothe campus.
Many astronomers and solar researchers are traveling to experience and analyze the event in person.
"Most of the solar specialists in our department (and actually around the country) are going to be in meetings or events that are in the path of totality for the eclipse itself," said Rachael Filwett, a physics professor at Montana State University specializing in space physics.
Des Jardins said 53 research teams (which include college and some high school students) will release high-altitude research balloons to study the impacts of the eclipse, including on the atmosphere and climate.
'ECLIPSE FLIGHTS'
Other cities and towns in the totality path — from Rochester, New York to Paducah, Kentucky — also have events planned the weekend before as well as eclipse day.
"Paducah was in the path of totality for the 2017 Great American Eclipse, so this is a 'twice in a lifetime event for the city," said Liz Hammonds, director of marketing and communications for the local convention and visitors bureau.
The Kentucky town, which sits at the confluence of the Ohio and Tennessee rivers between Nashville and St. Louis, will host an "X Marks the Spot" festival April 7-8 to celebrate the crossroads of the two eclipses.
Hammonds said an estimated 150,000 visitors are expected in western Kentucky including an influx of aircraft flying for celestial happening.
Southwest Airlines, Delta Air Lines and United Airlines also have flights coinciding when the solar eclipse travels across sections of the U.S.
United has five flights from Chicago and four from Houston on April 8 that will traverse the eclipse path, according to Remy Milburn, an airline spokesperson.
She said outbound bookings from San Antonio after the eclipse are up 288% compared to last year and destinations such as Cleveland and Little Rock are also seeing increased travel demand.
Southwest Airlines had eight flights on April 8 that could offer aerial views of the event including routes from Dallas to Pittsburgh, St. Louis to Houston and Austin to Indianapolis.
Grant Myatt, a spokesman for Delta Air Lines, said an eclipse flight from Austin to Detroit is sold out and there were limited seats left for another one from Dallas to Detroit.
The few seats left for those flights have fares running at $660 or more one way (and that's before fees and taxes).
AAA's Diaz said Niagara Falls is also a popular destination and the auto club's travel agents have also seen bookings for eclipse cruises on the Panama Canal and vacation packages to Mexico.
'BLOWN AWAY'
There will also be livestreams of the moon meeting the sun hosted by NASA as well as the Exploratorium in San Francisco.
Des Jardins said teams from Montana State and 74 other schools are working with those two groups. She's also interested to see how animals and insects react.
Robyn Higdon, senior project director and executive producer at the Exploratorium, said the museum will broadcast eclipse livestreams from Torreon, Mexico and Junction, Texas.
The museum partners with NASA and has numerous events and webinars with local schools, planetariums and museums across the country.
Higdon first got interested in eclipses in 1998. "I was just blown away," she said.
Higdon and Des Jardins will be part of a contingent viewing the eclipse from Junction. Texas.
"If anyone can travel to the eclipse in person the experience is worth it," Higdon said. "It's an all body, just incredible experience." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the economic and tourism impact of the upcoming solar eclipse, detailing visitor numbers, hotel bookings, and revenue boosts, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Kent County raises economic concerns over one-fish limit on charter boats
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Kent County raises economic concerns over one-fish limit on charter boats

 March 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 642
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Owners of charter boats in Kent County all seem to agree — a single-limit fish-per-person rule is going to hurt their business, especially when striped bass, rockfish, season begins May 16.During summer season, the rockfish size and limit will be 19 inches to 24 inches, and each person can keep one rockfish, new regulations state.
That might discourage clients from booking trips on charter boats, especially for a trip that costs almost $600 for a half day, say opponents of the limit.
The Kent County Commissioners recently sent a letter siding with the charter boat captains to Josh Kurtz, secretary of Natural Resources.
The letter expressed the county is opposed to the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission Addendum II to Amendment 7 of the Interstate Fishery Management Plan for striped bass.
"We are frustrated with the one-fish bag limit, the increased slot limit and all the restricted season dates which will negatively affect the Charter Boat industry," the letter states.
Commission President Ron Fithian composed the letter after attending a Feb. 17 meeting in Easton, alongside Kent County Director of Economic and Tourism Development Jamie Williams.
There, charter boat operators were joined by commercial fishermen to air grievances about proposed restrictions on catching striped bass in the Chesapeake Bay.
Rob Newberry, Delmarva Fisheries Association chairman, said at that meeting, "We've got to put a stop to this," referencing the overregulation commercial watermen are experiencing.
Fithian too expressed his concern over the matter on Tuesday, March 5, at the commission's weekly meeting, informing the public about the letter.
He restated how much the fishing industry means to the area.
"In 2022, we had $72 million dollars in visitor spending, so this is very detrimental to Kent County. This is going to affect the lodging, restaurants...any and all of them."
He added with a population of 13,000 full-time residents, they have about 1,500 boat slips, which turn into second homes for lodging.
Quite frankly, he said, it's going to be a "gut punch" to the county.
Already he knows of one group who schedules ten trips a year who have cancelled after learning of the policy in effect.
Williams, also at the meeting, has become more educated in the manner, since it will affect what she sees as well. She talked about how a one-limit catch rule will result in more catch-and-release, which will create more dead fish on the shores.
"It doesn't make common sense when you follow it down the line," Williams said.
At the public portion of the meeting, Newberry provided his statements. And like Fithian, gave an example of paying clients disenchanted with the idea of the one-catch policy.
He said a party from Talbot County normally rents a room 12 times a year to fish. They stay from Thursday until Saturday night and head home the next day. They cancelled all trips this year. That, he pointed out, is about $3,000 a night lost.
Newberry is not optimistic about the Department of Natural Resources' help either.
"The Department has showed no willing move to put forward to the charter boat industry to right this wrong."
He added when they reached out to Kurtz, they only received an effort on his part to ensure the captain and his mate each get a fish for themselves.
Unfortunately, with the regulations becoming more strict, Newberry told to the commissioners some people won't cooperate with the DNR any longer.
They might decide to not electronically report any fish caught.
The commissioners had no comment about that.
Fithian just wanted it to be made public their stance on this policy.
"We're speaking out against it and hoping something will get done down the road."
The position of DNR and ASMFC is that these emergency actions are needed, and the tighter striped bass fishing regulations are in response to ongoing population decline and rock-bottom reproduction.
In October 2023, according to the DNR, the results of the annual juvenile striped bass survey found the worst recruitment in Maryland since 1957. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the economic impact of new fishing regulations on charter boat operators and local tourism revenue, highlighting concerns from county officials and business stakeholders.
