title: 6 potential Chesapeake Bay ferry routes recommended in study
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
6 potential Chesapeake Bay ferry routes recommended in study

 August 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 465
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OCEAN CITY — A five-county Chesapeake Bay Passenger Ferry Consortium released a Passenger Ferry Feasibility study identifying promising opportunities to enhance transportation and economic growth across coastal communities in Maryland.The year-long study was released at this year's Maryland Association of Counties Conference, held in Ocean City last week. According to the study, the baseline system for the passenger ferry plan is estimated to handle approximately 50,000 riders per season. There are six potential passenger ferry routes, all branching out to different communities in the Chesapeake Bay including Baltimore, Annapolis, Easton and St. Michaels.
Despite an estimated $2.5 million in revenue, the study states that without adjustments or additional funding the ferry system will operate with an anticipated loss of $2.5 million during its first year. But the study shows that the ferry system could stimulate economic growth in the region.
Heather Tinelli, director of economic and tourism development for Queen Anne's County, said the study was brought together through a grant awarded to the Chesapeake Bay Passenger Ferry Consortium from the Economic Development Administration.
According to Tinelli, if the study is implemented, it has the potential to have a more than $14 million annual economic impact and create over 140 jobs.
"It's certainly not something that's going to happen overnight, but it is feasible, and if it's phased in I think there'll be a lot of visitors and residents that would look forward to the opportunity of getting out in the water," Tinelli said.
The study found significant support from community partners and stakeholders for a regional ferry system, with 67% of survey respondents expressing interest in the ferry service and 62% of community partners interested in engaging activities for visitors as well as residents.
Kristen Pironis, executive director of Visit Annapolis & Anne Arundel County, said in a press release that the study and the consortium showcases the transformative potential of the Chesapeake Bay.
"Five counties across the state joined forces to work on this effort," Pironis said. "As we explore next steps, this opportunity can expand to include partners across the Bay. We are optimistic about the study results and the path forward, which could better connect our Chesapeake Bay destinations and create economic impact across the entire state."
The five-counties consortium consisted of representatives from Anne Arundel, Calvert, Queen Anne's, Somerset and St. Mary's counties.
Tinelli noted the consortium worked hard to provide this information to the public and hopefully, if properly implemented, the results will benefit communities throughout the Shore.
"Tourism is a major economic development driver in the state of Maryland, and we feel that working in a regional approach as a consortium, and a Chesapeake Bay region is helpful, even if the ferry doesn't move forward," she said. "To work together to boost the whole region as a whole is a way to move the state's economy forward." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a feasibility study for new ferry routes, emphasizing economic impact, job creation, and tourism revenue, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic.

title: State gas prices drop to lowest level in 3 years
author: Staff Writer
content:
State gas prices drop to lowest level in 3 years

 August 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 465
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 10.7 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.35 per gallon today, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 15.4 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 43.9 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has declined 2.6 cents in the last week and stands at $3.69 per gallon — the lowest level in 940 days.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.99 per gallon yesterday while the most expensive was $3.99 per gallon, a difference of $1 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 4.2 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.37 per gallon today. The national average is down 11.4 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 47.8 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
August 19, 2023: $3.79 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.84 per gallon)August 19, 2022: $3.89 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.89 per gallon)August 19, 2021: $3.04 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.16 per gallon)August 19, 2020: $2.25 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.17 per gallon)August 19, 2019: $2.55 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.60 per gallon)August 19, 2018: $2.79 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.82 per gallon)August 19, 2017: $2.30 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.32 per gallon)August 19, 2016: $2.11 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.15 per gallon)August 19, 2015: $2.52 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.66 per gallon)August 19, 2014: $3.42 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.44 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.31 per gallon, down 13.3 cents per gallon from last week's $3.44 per gallon.
Washington, D.C.: DC- $3.59 per gallon, down 8.2 cents per gallon from last week's $3.67 per gallon.
Hagerstown: $3.32 per gallon, down 6.8 cents per gallon from last week's $3.39 per gallon.
"Gasoline and diesel prices continue to trail off across much of the country as summer demand fades away. Lower demand in other oil-consuming nations is also helping to lead the downward pressure on pump prices as we approach Labor Day," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "With little new action in the Middle East to rile up prices and Hurricane Ernesto remaining far out at sea, it looks like the downward trend could continue into the week ahead. As more schools begin to resume, gasoline demand will likely continue to ease. With the transition to winter gasoline less than a month away for the majority of the nation, gas prices will soon begin their seasonal cooling off— just as temperatures soon will as well." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: State releases Chesapeake Bay ferry crossing study
author: MICHAEL REID and MARTY MADDEN mreid@somdnews.commmadden@somdnews.com
content:
State releases Chesapeake Bay ferry crossing study

 August 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MICHAEL REID and MARTY MADDEN mreid@somdnews.commmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 804
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Marylanders who want to head to the Eastern Shore or those who want to travel to the Chesapeake Bay's western shores, including to Southern Maryland, now have to contend with lengthy driving distances punctuated by traffic, bridges and tolls. They may soon have another option.Instead of driving around the Chesapeake Bay, or over it via a 2-mile bridge, why not let those visiting other regions of the state do so by plying its waters via new ferry service, according to a feasibility study released last week at the annual Maryland Association of Counties conference in Ocean City.
"It leverages the Chesapeake as a connector and I think it can really provide a special service to not only tourists, but also the resident community as well," Liz Mildenstein, the executive director of the Visit St. Mary's tourism group, said. "It also connects communities that otherwise not have a connection."
Routes would begin as far north as Northeast and Chesapeake City all the way down to Crisfield. Eleven of the proposed stops are on the eastern side of the bay while 10 are on its western shores.
"The results of the Chesapeake Bay Passenger Ferry feasibility study mark a promising step forward in this project," Calvert County Commissioner President Earl "Buddy" Hance (R) said in a news release. "The ferry service could provide a new transportation link for our community and has the potential to significantly enhance tourism and boost the local economy for not just Calvert County, but all of the Chesapeake Bay region."
The study examined a plan that would consist of seven baseline passenger ferry routes, including Route 5, which would carry visitors to Solomons Island-St. Mary's City-Leonardtown-Crisfield.
Both of St. Mary's stops are on the Potomac River.
"I just don't know there's enough people coming from Crisfield coming over to St. Mary's County to spend money to make it an economic advantage for us," St. Mary's commissioner Eric Colvin (R) told Southern Maryland News. "I think in what I know about it, it doesn't necessarily look like there's a lot of benefit for St. Mary's County right now."
But Colvin also said one potential route that would be viable to St. Mary's would be one that went between the county and Washington, D.C.
"I think that would make more sense for us," Colvin said. "If people were able to jump on a very comfortable, very fast ferry from Washington and come down to St. Mary's City or Leonardtown for the day and eat and shop and take the ferry back to D.C., that might be a good day for them."
Route 3 consists of Annapolis-Galesville-Chesapeake Beach-Solomons Island-Salisbury-Crisfield, while Route 4 would encompass Annapolis-Tilghman Island-Chesapeake Beach-Easton-Oxford-Cambridge.
Calvert County Economic Development Director Julie Oberg said Chesapeake Beach would be considered an ideal location since "they've got the restaurants and the parking."
The other Southern Maryland-based plan is Route 6, which would connect Solomons Island with Cambridge.
Ridership forecast is estimated at more than 291,000 passengers annually, with Route 1 (Baltimore-Annapolis-Matapeake-St. Michael's-Kent Narrows-Rock Hall) the highest route at more than 87,000 riders.
Route 4 is estimated to carry more than 51,000 passengers while Routes 3 and 6 are expected to carry more than 25,000 riders. Route 5, which encompasses Solomons Island, the St. Mary's sites and Crisfield, are expected to carry just over 16,000 passengers annually.
The vessels are expected to carry 149 passengers at a time and cost about $10/hour, which Mildenstein is based on "surveys of what people would pay and the national averages."
The study added that the baseline season would be 26 weeks from about mid-April through mid-October.
The economic impact of the ferry stem is estimated to create more than 140 jobs and bring in $6.7 million in income.
The study added that a "significant influx of capital will be required" of at least $8 million in vessel acquisition costs, up to $5 million in station improvements, and about $5 million in annual operating costs.
The study also added that "the financial analysis estimates a net operating loss in the first year of operations without a subsidy of any kind."
"It could potentially work," Colvin said, "but there's still a lot that could be figured out in order to make it work, including where the money would come from, because we don't have room for it in our budget."
Colvin also added he didn't think "all of the infrastructure is fully built out for it."
"That's the part that gives me the most pause, but not in a bad way. It just means we have to do a little more research to understand how are we going to fund this going forward," Mildenstein said. "I think it would concern anybody, however there are various factors that can help that and change that."
At the Calvert County commissioners' staff session Tuesday morning, Oberg told the board the work on the feasibility study and the entire project "is a great example of collaboration."

It also involves county officials and planning, making Local Government a secondary match.

title: Easton EDC quarterly update provided to Town Council
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Easton EDC quarterly update provided to Town Council

 August 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 325
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Foot traffic at the Easton Visitor Center on South Harrison Street is increasing, according to Holly DeKarske, executive director of the Easton Economic Development Corporation.DeKarske presented a quarterly update on Easton EDC during Monday's Easton Town Council meeting.
"We just finished a year of managing the visitor's center, and foot traffic's basically doubled each month," DeKarske said.
DeKarske noted that there's been a rise in downtown foot traffic in recent months as well. "It was kind of a rough start to the spring, but it has gotten a lot better," she said.
The corporation strives to preserve historic Easton, as well as develop underutilized parts of the downtown. DeKarske discussed the organization's efforts in improving the visitor center, which includes procuring quotes for new outside signage and providing an interior that follows Americans with Disabilities Act accessibility requirements.
Ward 1 Councilmember Maureen Curry asked if there was a holdup in the town's work on redesigning the interior of the visitor center.
"There was a design, we are now tweaking, changing the design slightly," Mayor Megan Cook said. "Yes, there had been a holdup."
DeKarske noted other updates, such as welcoming Tom Maglio as marketing and events manager in July, updating the website and continuing to market towards the Spanish-speaking community.
She presented a breakdown of the corporation's funding sources for the 2024 calendar year. 65.4% of funding comes from the Town of Easton, 22.1% comes from grants and 12.5% comes from sponsorships.
Fiscal year 2025 grant funding for the Easton Economic Development Corporation includes, but is not limited to, $300,000 in Project Restore funds and $25,000 in Main Street Improvement Program funds, both from the Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development.
The latter goes toward marketing, DeKarske said, while the former was awarded to two downtown projects earlier this summer: a Dover Station project to revitalize a former roofing supply center on Dover Street and Dock Street Foundation's project to install a museum and visitor center centered around Frederick Douglass. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the Easton Economic Development Corporation's activities, funding, and downtown revitalization projects presented at a town council meeting, focusing on economic development rather than purely governmental procedures.

title: Average Maryland gas prices continue to drop
author: Staff Writer
content:
Average Maryland gas prices continue to drop

 August 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 428
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 8.9 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.26 per gallon, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland.Prices in Maryland are 23.5 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 46.3 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has declined 3.2 cents in the last week and stands at $3.67 per gallon, a multi-year low.
According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.89 per gallon Sunday, while the most expensive was $4.09 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 6.2 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.30 per gallon Monday. The national average is down 20.7 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 49.2 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average on Aug. 26 going back 10 years:
Aug. 26, 2023: $3.72 per gallon (U.S. average: $3.80 per gallon).2022: $3.79 per gallon (U.S. average: $3.84 per galon).2021: $3.01 per gallon (U.S. average: $3.14 per gallon).2020: $2.27 per gallon (U.S. average: $2.23 per gallon).2019: $2.50 per gallon (U.S. average: $2.58 per gallon).2018: $2.79 per gallon (U.S. average: $2.83 per gallon).2017: $2.30 per gallon (U.S. average: $2.36 per gallon).2016: $2.20 per gallon (U.S. average: $2.21 per gallon).2015: $2.46 per gallon (U.S. average: $2.56 per gallon).2014: $3.39 per gallon (U.S. average: $3.43 per gallon).
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.21 per gallon, down 10.1 cents per gallon from last week.
Washington: $3.58 per gallon, down 0.5 cents per gallon from last week.
Hagerstown: $3.21 per gallon, down 11.0 cents per gallon from last week.
"It seems fitting that, in the run-up to Labor Day, the national average has fallen for four straight weeks to its lowest point since February, giving Americans one last chance to hit the road with gas prices being less of a factor," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "GasBuddy is now tracking eight states where average gas prices are already below the $3 per gallon mark, along with nearly 20% of gas stations in the country selling gasoline at $2.99 or lower. These numbers will continue to look better every week as we move into fall. GasBuddy's Labor Day travel forecast, to be released tomorrow, will provide more good news about the millions of dollars Americans who are road-tripping will save compared to last year." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on recent changes in gasoline prices in Maryland and compares them to national trends, focusing on economic data and consumer impact, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Retailing is twice as nice for this Kent County business owner
author: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Retailing is twice as nice for this Kent County business owner

 August 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Business 
 
 586
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEENSTOWN — Building on her more than eight years of experience as owner of the unique gift and upcycled vintage furniture store Bee Crafty Collectibles on High Street in Chestertown, Helen Cowley has expanded her enterprise to include a second location on the high-profile Outlet Center Drive of Queenstown Premium Outlets.The well-crafted Bee Crafty Collectibles sign created by her husband's enterprise, Bee Crafty Metals, was affixed atop Cowley's suite number 17 in early August in anticipation of the soft opening, which occurred on Aug. 8.
Cowley said she had been thinking of opening a second location for a relatively short time before choosing to move forward.
"Well, I thought about it last year and (then) dismissed it. And then, I thought about it again, just this past May and poof, here I am," she said.
For the last two months, Cowley has been a merchandising, machine ordering and working to fit out the 3,000-square-foot retail space, which she feels will give her core customers more opportunities to find more of the goods and products they already love from her Chestertown location.
"When I looked at the space, I thought, well, this is really big, but then it just kind of clicked. I wanted it to be 'bridge to beach,'" she said, in reference to the distance visitors often travel between the Chesapeake Bay Bridge and the Maryland and Delaware beaches.
"So, in the middle of the bridge and the beach is Bee Crafty Collectibles, and I'm going to provide whatever the clientele needs, like kitchen wares, clothes, gifts, purses and socks, and many of the same things I have in Chestertown," Cowley said. "I just try to provide my customers with what I think they'll need so they don't have to go to a big box store."
Her signature product line from Maryland-centric Route One Apparel has been wildly popular in Chestertown, so she is expanding that at the Outlet to be able to fulfill the demand of the growing, tourist-based customer profile in Queenstown.
Some new merchandise she is stocking is the Happy Crates line of apparel and festive crates. Filling crates with fun activities for kids with cancer has been the mission of another local business — Happy Crates — since its inception in 2009. Ten percent of the sale of every Happy Crates item returns to the organization to help support the mission.
And in the fall, Cowley said, customers will discover that Bee Crafty Collectibles is the place to be for Baltimore Ravens sweatshirts and gear. Right now, the store is stocked with back-to-school essential backpacks, Foozy socks and Cowley's other new line of "Swifty" merchandise for Taylor Swift fans.
Thoughts of the grand opening a few weeks ago brought a tear of gratitude to Cowley's eye for all of her Chestertown customers who took the time to support her over those first few days.
"I am really trying to make it into an extraordinary gift store just like Chestertown is," she said. "I mean, it is extraordinary, and this is going to make me cry. In fact, the first weekend I had more Chestertown people in here than anyone else."
Cowley sees both her enterprises as an extension of her own family, and that's how she wants customers to feel.
And for anyone who may be wondering about the future of her store in Kent County, Cowley simply replied, "I am not leaving Chestertown in any way."
Store hours for the Queenstown location follow regular outlet mall hours; Monday through Saturday, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m., and Sunday, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a local retailer expanding to a second location, discussing store operations, product lines, and market demand, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Let us celebrate the mighty American worker
author: GLENN MOLLETTE
content:
Let us celebrate the mighty American worker

 August 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GLENN MOLLETTE | Section: News 
 
 590
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Labor Day weekend is upon us. Let's celebrate the laborers.The willing workers of America have been the backbone to making our country the greatest nation in the world. People from all over the world have come here in search of a better life by having the opportunity and the freedom to work hard in order to make their dreams come true. The will and the joy of working has made life better for millions who have realized their dreams in America.
An acquaintance of mine who has done very well throughout his life has always been a hard worker. He has said, "The harder I work, the luckier I get." Good fortune has never just fallen on him accidentally but he has always worked hard and good things have come his way.
There is no way that Americans can stop working. Our government and all that we have and know flourishes or dries up based upon our work. Our work produces products, delivers goods, raises crops, provides fuel and feeds our families.
A country cannot sit down and expect that all the people will be clothed, fed and medically cared for without a large group of working people. The nation who does not work will soon fold. Our government cares for a lot of people now. Millions of Americans receive Social Security checks and other types of government monetary support. This money does not grow on trees but is reproduced daily by America's laborers who have their nose to the grindstone.
If you have a job and are earning a paycheck, then rejoice for your good fortune. There are many less fortunate who would love to be working who no longer have the physical or mental ability to do so.
Work is a good way to spend your time. Good honest work will keep you out of trouble and is helpful in keeping you out of a state of depression. In most situations, work is physically, mentally and emotionally healthy for people. There are always those dead-end jobs that may be very tough physically and mentally.
Sometimes you may have to change jobs. In America, you can change jobs or start your own business, but you have the option of making a new plan.
My dad was a hard-working coal miner. We would have starved if he hadn't been willing to work in underground coal mines for almost 37 years. My mother was a hard worker. Thus, we always had food to eat. Work has a payoff; you can go to the grocery store. Of course, in this economy, we haven't been able to buy as much.
A dear friend manages a restaurant with 85 employees. Most of them are immigrants who have come into the country in the last three or four years. He said, "Without them I couldn't operate the restaurant. They are faithful, work hard and do a good job. They also have a network of friends who want to work so I don't have trouble filling jobs. If I had to depend on the local American people in our community, then our restaurant would never survive. The locals don't want to work."
Sadly, I've heard farmers in Ohio and Indiana talk the same way. Their farming labor is dependent on the immigrants.
America will continue to be a strong and great nation if all Americans will keep working. When we hand all our labor over to others and quit working, we will lose our country.
Glenn Mollette's appear in all 50 states. Learn more about his books, columns and music at GlennMollette.com. Email him at gmollette@aol.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is an opinion piece celebrating American workers and discussing labor, employment, and economic contributions, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy category.

title: Business owners weigh in on proposal to remove bag fee
author: Tom McCall
content:
Business owners weigh in on proposal to remove bag fee

 September 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 598
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As the Easton Town Council is divided over a proposal to eliminate the town's 10 cent fee for paper bags, some local business owners are voicing that requiring the fee limits their ability to make decisions for their businesses.The law establishing the fee, which was put in place after Easton banned the use of plastic bags, requires that businesses charge customers 10 cents for every paper bag used. The idea was to encourage the use of reusable bags.
Some members of the Town Council presented an ordinance to remove the fee at the council's Sept. 3 meeting.
Business owners are divided in their stances on the fee. Some like it, as in reality a paper bag costs them more than 10 cents, and the law helps them to recuperate some of those costs. Others think charging a customer at the end of their purchase is bad for business. Several have said they feel they should be able to choose whether or not to impose the fee.
Joe Petro owns Hair of the Dog Liquors on Marlboro Avenue.
"I don't think the 10 cents is a necessary cost to the consumer, especially in this day and age," Petro said. "From a retail perspective, we already factor the cost of the bag into doing business. To pass that on to the customer — everyone is getting hit over their head with price increases everywhere they go. I think it is ridiculous."
As a businessman, he finds the rule invasive.
"If I want to give someone a paper bag as a retailer, why can't I just give them a bag? Why do I have to charge them 10 cents?" he asked. "If I give them a bag, it is my understanding of the law that I could be charged or fined for not charging 10 cents."
But Petro said he can see both sides of the issue.
"One thing good about it is it has made a lot of customers say 'I will just take it and walk out with it.' But say someone comes in and spends $500 on a bunch of really expensive wine or booze, and then I am going to charge them 10 cents on top of that. It is kind of ridiculous," he said.
There is another business owner who has given up on paper altogether.
"I don't think the environmental impact providing paper or plastic isn't going to do justice. It is either all or none. What we are doing with reusable bags is essentially passing on the cost to our consumer," said Eat Sprout owner Ryan Groll.
He also noted the economics of scale, with large business often getting a better deal on purchasing these bags because of the number they purchase at a time. Profitability is further from reach for small business, he said.
"We want to continue to do the right thing, so we buy the reusable bags. We buy 3,000 to 4,000 at time, sometimes 6,000 to 10,000 at a time. In order for us to get these bags at the price we are selling, for $1.50, do the math. As a small business, we have to fork out $12,000 to $15,000 of upfront expense," Groll said.
As far as the 10 cent ban on paper bags, he is thoughtful about the goals of that policy.
"What are we trying to incentivize? Are we trying to eliminate it? Or are we trying to punish people for taking a single use bag. You should, I think, give the business the chance to choose whether or not they want to charge for a bag. I don't charge people to use my WiFi," Groll said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on how a municipal bag fee policy affects local businesses, highlighting economic concerns and business owners' viewpoints, making Business/Economy the strongest fit, with Local Government as a close secondary.

title: A better option for promoting Chesapeake Bay tourism
author: DAVID REEL
content:
A better option for promoting Chesapeake Bay tourism

 September 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 827
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A consortium of five Maryland counties — Anne Arundel, Calvert, Queen Anne's, St. Mary's and Somerset, recently released results of a $250,000 feasibility study on a new Chesapeake Bay passenger ferry system.The study concludes that passenger-only ferries — not vehicle-carrying ferries — serving Annapolis, Baltimore and the Eastern Shore destinations of Easton, Cambridge, Rock Hall, Kent Narrows, St. Michaels, Oxford, Chestertown and Crisfield are feasible.
Members of the consortium and other supporters of this new ferry system are well intentioned. The ferry feasibility study looks good on paper.
Upon closer scrutiny of the Aug. 24 executive summary of the consortium's feasibility study, there are a number of unanswered questions. There is also one alternative that should be thoroughly evaluated before proceeding further. The questions and alternative include:
Why does the consortium only have two Eastern Shore counties — Queen Anne's and Somerset?
Who will pay for projected start-up costs for a base line system requiring at least $8 million in ferry boat acquisitions and up to $5 million in necessary infrastructure improvements such as docks, passenger shelters, restrooms and attraction shuttle services at system destinations before ferry operations can begin?
Who will pay for projected $5 million in annual operating costs for a baseline system that will be only partially offset by the feasibility studies "suggestion" that 50,000 ferry passenger riders will generate $2.5 million in revenue in the first season of operation?
What is this suggestion of 50,000 riders based on?
Who will cover this deficit if passenger revenue is below projections?
What assurances are there this new venture will not replicate the historical record of cost overruns during start up and post start overruns on new transportation projects?
Where do the 67% of individuals live, who responded to a consortium-sponsored survey who expressed interest in the ferry service?
Where do the 62% of community partners live and/or operate, who have expressed interest in engaging activities for visitors to and residents of proposed ferry destinations?
Were survey respondents made fully aware that a new ferry system would not carry vehicles and would thus likely have a minimal impact at best on enormous amounts of vehicular traffic going to and from Ocean City every year?
Are consortium partners and supporters planning on state or local or government funding, for start-up and post start-up operating expenses? If so, how much?
Are they acknowledging the following current and projected fiscal realities in Maryland? The state and local governments in Maryland are facing significant challenges in funding current programs including the Blueprint for Maryland's Future (Kirwan Plan). Current projections are the state deficit will be $1 billion in 2026 and 2027, $3.5 billion in 2028, and $4 billion in 2029. Maryland also has a deficit in the state six-year transportation plan deficit that does not yet reflect the loss in toll revenue after the Key Bridge collapse and the yet to be finalized amount of state funding needed to rebuild that bridge. Earlier this week, the state proposed new cuts of cutting $1.3 billion from the six-year transportation plan after previous cuts of $ 3.3 billion to the plan a year ago, cuts that were partially restored by tapping the state's "rainy day" fund and increasing vehicle registration fees. Gov. Moore recently told Maryland Association of Counties Summer Conference attendees, all new state spending will be facing "extreme scrutiny."
Is it realistic to assume state and local funding for the launch and operation of a new Bay ferry service will be a priority or even considered in Annapolis or with local governments in the near future, if ever?
Has the consortium and supporters of more ferry service on the Chesapeake Bay given serious evaluation of an alternative to meet the goal of a new ferry service to promote tourism that could also help an endangered Chesapeake Bay way of life to survive and hopefully thrive?
There are over 400 charter boats registered in Maryland.
Operators of these charter boats have been and are dealing with extraordinary hardships due to new state regulations limiting the size and number of rockfish that can be caught by recreational fishing enthusiasts who historically come from within Maryland and beyond.
Charter boats could be more heavily promoted by destination marketing organization in the Chesapeake Bay region for Bay pleasure cruises. Charter boats can take clients anywhere they want to go, whenever they want to go, and for as long or as short a time as they want to go.
Charter boat operators also can provide data on the actual demand for Bay cruises that may or may not match data from the consortium's surveys on the demand for passenger ferry boats.
The next best step for the consortium is to meet with a representative group of charter boat captains to discuss their interest in, capacity for, and feasibility of providing more pleasure cruises on the bay. Charter boats could be a cost-effective alternative to a new, costly and unproven Chesapeake Bay passenger ferry system as the way to generate more tourism and economic benefits for the Eastern Shore and the entire Chesapeake Bay region. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a feasibility study, funding, and economic impact of a new ferry system to boost Chesapeake Bay tourism, making Business/Economy the most fitting category.

title: CWDI plans to sell land to Yacht Maintenance on Monday
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
CWDI plans to sell land to Yacht Maintenance on Monday

 September 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 427
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — After the settlement of a months-long lawsuit between the City of Cambridge, Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. and Yacht Maintenance Company over a land transfer agreement, CWDI is scheduled to sell property to Yacht Maintenance on Monday.The lawsuit, filed in May, alleged CWDI, the group spearheading the Cambridge Harbor project, was in violation of a transfer agreement it entered into with the city in June 2021. The transfer agreement gave CWDI roughly 22 acres of land — including about 2.6 acres of land subject to a lease agreement between the city and Yacht Maintenance — for $5.
CWDI has hoped to sell part of those 22 acres to Yacht Maintenance, but with the lawsuit that requested temporary, preliminary and permanent injunctions stopping defendants from transferring any portion of that property, CWDI had been unable to sell the land.
With the lawsuit settlement, the city and CWDI have entered into an agreement that allows CWDI to transfer property from the 2021 transfer agreement to Yacht Maintenance.
At the CWDI Board of Directors meeting on Sept. 11, Board President Angie Hengst said the sale of that property to Yacht Maintenance is scheduled for Monday, Sept. 16.
During the meeting, the board unanimously voted to allow Hengst or board Secretary-Treasurer Frank Narr to execute any documents necessary for the property transfer.
Narr said as part of the lawsuit settlement, CWDI has opened a separate bank account for the net proceeds from the upcoming property sale. He said CWDI will report how those dollars are being spent to the city and county once they receive that money.
"That was the spirit of the agreement so that the city and county are just aware of where those dollars are being spent," he said.
Narr said it was agreed with the city that none of the money from the property sale will be used for expenses incurred from litigation.
At the CWDI Board meeting on July 31, Narr brought up the need for CWDI to sell property so that it can use that money to pay for other expenses. During the Sept. 11 meeting, Narr said that CWDI's finances will look "a lot more favorable" once the sale is made.
At the end of the meeting, Hengst and Board Vice President Shay Lewis-Sisco expressed excitement and gratitude for the dismissal of the lawsuit with the city. Hengst said the board is looking forward to having a better working relationship with Cambridge and Dorchester County.
Cambridge Mayor Stephen Rideout, who attended the meeting, agreed with Hengst.
"So hopefully that'll continue and we can see really good things happening in the future," Hengst said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a property sale and lawsuit settlement involving a development corporation and the city, which is primarily a business transaction and is placed in the Business section.

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 10.2 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.07 per gallon today, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Diesel prices are also falling and are at their lowest level in nearly 1,000 days," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. But while nearly all states are seeing prices drop, refinery maintenance and some outages at California refineries have led to tight supply and rising prices — a situation I hope can be remedied by the end of the month and help California join in on the decline."

title: Four Eleven Kitchen opens at Packing House
author: Tom McCall
content:
Four Eleven Kitchen opens at Packing House

 September 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 363
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — On Sept. 12, about 100 people came to the Packing House to celebrate the opening of a community kitchen that hopes to incubate culinary talent with space and equipment.Four Eleven Kitchen, a shared-use commercial kitchen which will serve as a space for community collaboration, has Amanda Kidd as the driving force.
"About seven years have gone into this," Kidd said."With the support of our community, we have established relationships throughout the years. We were able to take on some partnerships and get some grants. We started out with a partnership with the state and partnership with University of Maryland Shore Regional Health, many partners including DHCD (Department of Housing a Community Development)."
Kidd is not so much a chef as a community connector. Many of the speeches given at the ribbon-cutting event spoke of her tenacity, vision and grit.
In front of the crowd, Kidd said, "I want you to know Four Eleven Kitchen is not just about me. It is about every food entrepreneur, every food business, restaurant owner. We want to be a support system for them. We want to connect not only the dots for the entrepreneur but also connect the community to the food."
She also said she wants to create a safe place for "foodpreneurs" to grow and scale their businesses so that the community can thrive.
"Food is one of the things that drops all barriers," she said.
The facility was equipped with gleaming stainless kitchen machinery. There is a professional-level bakery with mixers and convection ovens. The equipment will be available for community members to book in advance.
"There will be a booking portal that will allow them to go in and select their time, their day, what pieces they want to use so there isn't much overlap. We look for a lot of collaborations and synergy to start to happen," Kidd said.
Alyssa Boyd, owner of Humble Hearts Catering and Events, is catering about 80 events a year. She said she will be using this industrial kitchen in the future.
"We are going to be catering out of here and do some classes and being able to do some social events," Boyd said.
For more information about Four Eleven Kitchen, visit https://411.kitchen/. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'This is hard. It is history': Barber shop closing after more than a century
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
'This is hard. It is history': Barber shop closing after more than a century

 September 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 988
 Words 

 Read News Document

 After more than a century of serving Delaware, the Main Street Barber Shop in Newark will close its doors for the final time on Friday.Kim Teti, the sixth owner of the shop, is retiring after 31 years and moving to Florida. The shop, which is part of the Klondike Kate's building, will be turned into a merchandise shop for the restaurant or possibly be used as a dedicated place to pick up to-go meals.
It's a bittersweet moment for Teti, who has spent the past few weeks saying goodbye to longtime customers, many of whom have become like family.
"I am very sad, a little choked up right now," Teti said. "This is hard. Because it's closing after 100-some years, it is history."
The barber shop is located in the iconic Exchange Building, which was built in 1880 and is on the National Register of Historic Places. It was originally built as a grange hall and has housed a meat market, post office, pool hall, general store, movie theater, courthouse, jail, skating rink, gas station and — since 1979 — Klondike Kate's restaurant. One constant through the years has been the barber shop, which according to Newark Post archives, has been there in one form or another for at least 130 years.
Teti's long association with the barber shop began on a whim.
After growing up near Wilmington, she learned to be a barber while attending Delcastle Technical High School. She honed her skills working at a barber shop in the Hotel DuPont, where she learned from old-school Italian barbers working there, and then worked at a barber shop in Greenville.
Teti was driving through Newark one day when she saw the Main Street Barber Shop and decided to stop in and ask about part-time work. The owner at the time, Ralph Burchard, spent summers in Maine and was planning to close the shop for the summer unless he found someone to fill in for him.
"A week later, he gave me the key to the shop," Teti recalled. "He went from Memorial Day all the way to Labor Day, and I worked the entire summer all by myself."
She filled in for Burchard a couple more times and then, in the summer of 1993, a fire damaged Klondike Kate's and the barber shop. Burchard, then 81, decided to retire instead of dealing with the expense and stress of repairing the damage.
Teti decided to take over the business full time and her husband, a tile contractor, worked to restore the historic shop, which reopened a few months later.
Over the years, she has strived to keep the business in the style of what she calls an "antique barber shop," with a barber pole outside, high ceilings, large windows, original cabinets, old-style barber chairs, pictures of Frank Sinatra and Marlon Brando on the walls and a tile mural depicting Main Street of yesteryear.
"I never wanted to modernize it," Teti said. "I always wanted it to stay like turn of the century."
Though the barber shop hasn't changed much, Main Street has, Teti lamented.
"When I first came here, it was Jimmy's Diner, the Post House, and Eagle Furniture was up there. It was a mom-and-pop town," she said. "And then it changed. I liked the way it was. It was awesome."
When Teti took over the shop, she charged $7 for a haircut. Now, she has to charge between $20 and $25 to keep up with rising costs.
The addition of a covered deck for Klondike Kate's a few years ago made the barber shop a lot less visible, making it harder to draw in foot traffic.
"You can barely tell it's a barbershop," Teti said. "Back in the day, it stuck out like a sore thumb, and then they built the deck."
She has also seen the type of customer change. She used to get a lot of university students, but "now they go to the shops where they play the loud rap music and stuff like that," she said.
Still, the shop serves an eclectic mix of customers, some of whom started coming decades ago when Burchard was still in charge. At least one older customer recalls getting his hair cut at the shop when he was a kid, Teti said.
"We get all walks of life in here, everybody from politicians to construction people, lawyers, doctors, everybody comes here," she said, noting that she even cut the hair of future Super Bowl MVP Joe Flacco when he played for the Blue Hens.
Teti has kept the shop going as Klondike Kate's changed hands twice, each time promoting worry that the new owner might want a different use for the barber shop space. She expressed gratitude to current owner Gianmarco Martuscelli, who told her when he bought the restaurant in 2016 that she was welcome to stay for as long she liked.
"Gianmarco was nothing but happy for the barbershop to go on," she said. "But he did tell me a long time ago when he bought the building that when I was done, he had plans for it."
Teti had planned to keep the shop going even longer, but her husband recently suffered an injury that forced him to retire, so the couple decided it was time to move to Florida and take advantage of the second home they bought a few years ago.
She's looking forward to the warmer weather but doubts that she's hung up her barber shears for good.
"Most barbers work until they're in their 80s and can't work no more. I'm too young to really retire at 64 years old," she said, adding that she may find part-time work in Florida.
Teti said she'll miss her customers the most.
"It's not a hard job, and you make friends along the way. You don't get rich off of it, but it's a good career," she said. "I can honestly say that I never got up and said, 'Oh God, I gotta go to the job today.' It was always a happy place to come to." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the closure of a long‑standing local barber shop, discussing its history, ownership changes, and economic factors like rising costs, making it most relevant to the Business/Economy category.

title: AnywhereVet Mobile Clinic: a business of friendship
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
AnywhereVet Mobile Clinic: a business of friendship

 September 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Business 
 
 554
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — From building a lifelong friendship to establishing a veterinary clinic together, Paige Roberts and Holly Conroy, owners of the AnywhereVet mobile clinic, are an animal loving duo who have committed their lives to providing care to furry friends across the Eastern Shore.Together, Roberts and Conroy are changing the traditional approach to animal care through client education, individualized care and maintaining a human touch with every one of their patients.
According to Conroy, animal owners on the Shore can face many delays and difficulties when trying to get care. Conroy said she had the realization after her sister's dog got sick, and they had to travel over 2½ hours to get care.
"We need better vet care on the Shore," Conroy said. "The vet care is just so few and far between on the Shore. So we finally, kind of decided to lock down servicing this whole Shore area."
Roberts said they were both working at an emergency room in Laurel, Maryland, prior to owning the clinic together. They became friends while working overnight shifts. Conroy worked as a technician, and Roberts worked as a veterinarian.
Conroy said they worked really well together and became best friends due to their similar levels of commitment to their work and expectations of themselves.
Conroy said that though they were passionate about their work, it is a "thankless job," and working in emergency room services can make workers lose their love for their work due to being "beaten down all the time."
The idea of a mobile clinic restarted a passion for Roberts and Conroy.
Now, their clinic provides a variety of services to people throughout the Eastern Shore, including urgent care services, hospital transport, wellness services and emergency care.
For Roberts, it's important that they treat the whole patient. With their personalized care, they can provide services to cater to the individual needs of the animal and to the needs, wants and limitations of the owner.
"This is a way that we could really control all the components (from) the standard of care, the prices, and when you need to mark things up, and when you don't," Roberts said. "There's a time and a place to mark things up more significantly than other things. And we really think it's important that we're not profiting significantly off of the essential vital services like euthanasia."
Jamie Romph, client of AnywhereVet, said when her yellow lab Dixie got sick she turned to the AnywhereVet to provide Dixie with the most comfortable care she could. Even going as far as providing Dixie with pain medicine at 10 p.m.
"Those girls will be there for you, whether it's on video, answering a text message or (saying) 'hey, you're right. This is a real we'll be right out and we'll come help you through it,'" Romph said. "All the vets are great, but they work business hours. These girls have upped it a notch."
Roberts said they look forward to continuing to work across the Eastern Shore and hope to one day establish a brick and mortar clinic to better serve all their patients' needs.
"Every pet deserves care," Roberts said. "Every pet deserves that no matter what, even if they are fear aggressive and they want to bite my hand off, they still deserve care, and I will find a way. Holly and I are really good, and we still love them." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a mobile veterinary clinic as a business venture, discussing ownership, services, pricing, and expansion plans, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.

title: QA celebrates minority-owned business program initiative
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QA celebrates minority-owned business program initiative

 September 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 549
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — A collaborative initiative to strengthen minority owned business presented its first inaugural class to the Queen Anne's County Commissioners Sept. 10.Funded through the Rural Maryland Economic Development Fund, which is supported by the Maryland Department of Commerce and Upper Shore Regional Council and administered through Queen Anne's County Economic and Tourism Development, the Minority Entrepreneurship Training Accelerator (META) pilot program provided tailored mentoring, networking opportunities, and strategic resources to help small minority-business owners overcome challenges and achieve sustainable growth.
Presenting certificates of achievements to participants, Rebecca Murphy, founding consultant of Upper Shore Community Development Founder and Chief Strategist noted META was created with the belief that diversity and entrepreneurship strengthens communities and economy.
"It is with great pride and joy that we congratulate the graduates of the inaugural class of the Minority Entrepreneurship Training Accelerator program today at this commissioners meeting. We celebrate not only their accomplishments but also the bright futures that each of them is carving out in our community," she said.
"META is a six month intensive business development and coaching program aimed at providing a cohort of small minority businesses with the resources they need to scale," said Sam Shoge, cofounder and partner of Rivers and Roads Consulting, who served as program facilitator and coach.
The program intends to close the knowledge resource and funding gap between minority-owned and non-minority owned businesses, he said.
Data is applied across all minority businesses including women-owned and veteran-owned, he said, and the importance of the program is noted in the disparities between minority and non-minority owned businesses, he said.
The average revenue of black sole proprietorships versus non-minority sole proprietorships is $22,000 versus $50,000 respectively, according to Shoge.
On average non-minority owned businesses are six times larger than black-owned businesses, he said.
A total of 15 applications from women and minority owned businesses were received in 2023 and five Queen Anne's County businesses were selected to participate in the inaugural program, he said.
Participants included Moniesha Baynard, owner of Three Guys and a Girl Personal Chef and Catering; Diane Moorman-White, owner of DMW Soul Fitness; Timeka Wheeler, owner of Long Live Assisted Living; Deayna Ewell, owner of Onyx Beauty Supply Salon Barbershop; and Ebony Johnson, owner of Tips and Toes Nail Studio.
The six-month program at the Kent Island Library began its first seminar in February 2024 and concluded in August.
META entailed monthly business development seminars including a variety of topics such as market strategy, business planning, sales and customer service, bookkeeping best practices, licensing and regulation as well as personal coaching, Shoge said.
A key aspect of the program was how entrepreneurs can partner and collaborate and support fellow community small businesses, he said.
"Our secretary of commerce Secretary (Micheal) Gill always said that economic development is a team sport and that is very much reflected in this program here," Shoge said.
Officials were very happy with the outcome and success of the program, with many participants reporting increased revenues, Shoge said.
Transitioning from a 36-year veterinary career, participant Moorman-White, credited the program with giving her the push and the confidence to prove to herself she could turn her "side-gig" into a full time career.
"Probably the biggest thing the META program has done for me was it changed my mindset. I am now recognizing the power I possess to achieve my goals both big and small," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a minority entrepreneurship training program funded by economic development agencies, highlighting business development, mentoring, and economic impact, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Maryland small businesses get $10 million grant
author: STEVEN JACOBS JR. Capital News Service
content:
Maryland small businesses get $10 million grant

 September 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEVEN JACOBS JR. Capital News Service | Section: Business 
 
 226
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland small business owners will get help with legal, accounting and financial services under a new $10 million grant from the federal government, officials announced last week.The Treasury Department is awarding the money this fall as part of the American Small Business Opportunity Program.
The award came as good news to Maryland Gov. Wes Moore, who used to run his own small business helping underserved students navigate college.
"When people would tell me it's really hard to build a business in Maryland, my response to them was always the same: I know, I had to do it myself," Moore said in a Monday press call announcing the grant.
"This is going to help more Marylanders turn ideas into jobs and businesses," Moore said, "and turn individuals into job creators."
The money is meant to fuel local growth and provide innovative resources to disadvantaged start up businesses in the state, according to a Treasury press release.
This federal funding will go to the Maryland Technology Development Corporation, an independent instrument of the state that provides funding, insight, resources and connections to early stage companies.
"There are three 'T's' that every entrepreneur faces: they face a challenge of time, a challenge of talent, and a challenge of treasure," said Troy A. LeMaile-Stovall, CEO of TEDCO.
The program, he said, will "give them access to talent that they need to grow and scale their enterprises." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a federal grant administered by the state to support small businesses, focusing on economic development and business resources, which aligns directly with the Business/Economy category.

title: State gas prices drop; nationwide, they climb
author: Staff Writer
content:
State gas prices drop; nationwide, they climb

 September 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 452
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 1.7 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.05 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 23.8 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 55.5 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has declined 2.1 cents in the last week and stands at $3.55 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.77 per gallon yesterday while the most expensive was $4.19 per gallon, a difference of $1.42 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has risen 1.2 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.16 per gallon today. The national average is down 18.8 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 67.4 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
September 23, 2023: $3.60 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.83 per gallon)September 23, 2022: $3.43 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.67 per gallon)September 23, 2021: $3.09 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.18 per gallon)September 23, 2020: $2.22 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.19 per gallon)September 23, 2019: $2.59 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.66 per gallon)September 23, 2018: $2.80 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.83 per gallon)September 23, 2017: $2.56 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.56 per gallon)September 23, 2016: $2.26 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.21 per gallon)September 23, 2015: $2.25 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.28 per gallon)September 23, 2014: $3.31 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.33 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.01 per gallon, down 0.7 cents per gallon from last week's $3.01 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.21 per gallon, down 13.0 cents per gallon from last week's $3.34 per gallon.Hagerstown: $3.02 per gallon, down 0.4 cents per gallon from last week's $3.03 per gallon.
"With oil prices jumping after the U.S. Federal Reserve cut interest rates by a larger-than-expected half percent, we've seen some states where gas prices have inched back up, while others have continued to decline. Most of these increases should be temporary with declines returning in the days and weeks ahead," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "In addition, for California and areas of Nevada and western Arizona, areas that had been left out of the recent drops, refinery issues are improving and gas prices should start moving lower. While the future looks good for gas prices to continue trending lower for most in the weeks ahead, oil's jump may mute the downside potential just a bit — for now." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
