title: Venerable Chestertown bookseller celebrates 20 years
author: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Venerable Chestertown bookseller celebrates 20 years

 September 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 639
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — "Let's open a brick-and-mortar bookstore," wasn't exactly the phrase on many entrepreneurs' lips in 2004 when a newcomer to Chestertown saw the potential in a storefront in the 100 block of Cross Street.As owner Tom Martin tells it, he and wife Lizzie had only been in town a couple of times when they started exploring real estate with the intention of having a weekend home option.
And then Lizzie's hairdresser turned Martin's attention to a commercial property, an empty storefront on Cross Street.
Since leaving a political post in his mid-50s, Martin said, he set out on a personal journey that would hopefully have him figuring out what he wanted to do with the rest of his life. In the current vernacular, this "pivot" included working in both small- and large-scale bookstores in Washington, D.C.
The plan was to spend six months in this particular sector of retail, which he said he took to, "like a fish to water."
"When I got that job, it took me two days to say, 'Man, this is fun," Martin said.
And yet, when the storefront opportunity presented itself, he was not quick to put two and two together.
"How this all happened was very strange," he said. "It didn't happen by design; I was not looking for a bookshop."
But eventually he signed lease at 112 Cross Street, despite Lizzie's best efforts to dissuade him. Martin vividly recalled their exact conversation, which took place at Bethesda's Tastee Diner over breakfast one morning.
"You're going to what?" he said was his wife's reply when he revealed that he had decided that he wanted to move forward with opening a used bookstore in Chestertown.
"What would you even call it?" she replied skeptically. Martin relayed that he looked down at the beautiful breakfast on the table before him and replied, "I'm going to call it The Bookplate."
And so it began, with the books from his own vast collection, finds from local outlets like Dixon's Auction at Crumpton, and the good will of many who wished to donate either personally or from estate collections.
Fast-forward 20 years, and The Bookplate is thriving. The place is now home to some 50,000 old and new volumes, give or take, and has seen its fair share of customers, cultural events and milestones.
Since opening in 2004, Martin has not stressed over the effect technology has had on reading habits. Rather, he balances his approach to tome-centric retail by leaning into the sense of community he can build around books and reading.
This connection to the community goes way back, he said. Prior to the pandemic, the store had a small stage and was the place to be for local music, plays and impromptu poetry festivals.
That is the state of play at The Bookplate; there is always something going on in and around the store.
Martin said as a bookseller he chooses not to be influenced and prefers to cast a wide net when it comes to genres and titles.
When the occasion of the store's 20th anniversary on Sept. 11 came around, Martin said, the staff thought to recognize the day with some sort of celebration. At first, Martin said he downplayed the idea because of the way he approaches every day in his life. As a member of an alcohol recovery program for several decades standing, Martin said he is more than grateful for what he has been able to accomplish, in part, because he has been successful in maintaining his sobriety. He also feels it's important to convey the message to others who may be struggling that they should take heart that there is longevity in the program.
"Because of who I am and where I'm coming from, I'm just grateful to have the store. Life was turned around and it worked out well. And so, every time somebody comes through that door, I mean, that's a celebration." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a local bookstore's 20‑year milestone, its ownership, and its role as a community business, making Business/Economy the most fitting category, with Arts & Culture as a secondary relevance due to cultural events hosted at the store.

title: Volunteers donate $10K to Chesapeake Housing Mission
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Volunteers donate $10K to Chesapeake Housing Mission

 September 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 645
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Chesapeake Housing Mission board member and project engineer Dave Mayonado knew he would be building a ramp for a Cambridge resident Thursday morning with the help of a group of volunteers from Regal Rexnord. But he didn't know the volunteers would be donating more than their time.As the group gathered outside Ben Parks' home early Thursday morning to build a ramp, Mayonado was handed a check for $10,000 to be put toward the nonprofit's mission of offering home repair services to low-income families in Dorchester, Somerset, Wicomico and Worcester counties.
"This is super timely because it really is needed at this point," he said to the volunteers. "Particularly in this county here."
This is the third year that Regal Rexnord, an international manufacturing company with a facility in Cambridge, has organized a volunteer day with Chesapeake Housing Mission. Regal Rexnord's human resource business partner Beth Hancock said the company offers 16 hours of paid volunteer work and sets up multiple volunteer opportunities for employees each year.
Mayonado told the group that when COVID-related funding was available, it was easier to build ramps and offer other home repair services to families in need.
"But that's gone now," he said. "So we're having some funding agencies telling us they don't have the money."
Although Chesapeake Housing Mission is made up of volunteers, the organization needs money to buy materials for the projects they complete. Mayonado said every project costs about $2,000 to $3,000. He said the money comes through funding agencies and donations.
"So a situation like this (where) we have an opportunity for them not only to do the job, but then they're going to pay for these materials and maybe two more jobs, or maybe even three — it's pretty cool," he said.
Hancock said one of the reasons Regal Rexnord chose to donate money to Chesapeake Housing Mission was because there are many people in Dorchester County in need of health care services. She said there are people who can't get to doctors appointments because their family members can't get them out of their homes.
"So this is something that just goes so much further," she said. "And it just could be life-changing for someone who needs to get to the doctor."
Regal Rexnord materials manager Aurora Arriaga, who was volunteering with Chesapeake Housing Mission for a second year, said for people who have difficulties walking, a ramp affects not only where they can go, but how they feel. She said not being able to leave your house can feel isolating.
"So I think being able to help the people not feel so isolated, especially nowadays, is just an amazing thing to do," she said.
The group built a ramp outside of Ben Parks' front door. Parks, a retired waterman, hasn't been able to leave his home in about three months due to medical issues. The ramp built on Thursday will allow him to get in and out of his home safely.
As 14 of the Regal Rexnord employees moved and sawed lumber, the 15th employee, Cole Collins, removed vegetation from Parks' driveway. Although that task was not a part of the Chesapeake Housing Mission project, Collins — who owns Peninsula Dirt Works LLC along with being the manufacturing engineering manager at Regal Rexnord — noticed during a pre-construction meeting that the Parks' driveway is not level and is hard to walk on. He decided to bring his tractor to redo the driveway on Thursday.
Collins, who is a Dorchester County native, talked about the importance of giving back to the community.
"It's huge when businesses are able to give back to our local community," he said. "... And I'm glad to be able to give back as well. It's not much, but it's something."
Mayonado talked about the rewarding feeling of getting a hug from someone "who has been locked in their house and now is free."
"That's the reason we do it, honestly," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a corporate volunteer event and a $10K donation from Regal Rexnord to a local nonprofit, highlighting business involvement in community philanthropy and economic support for low‑income families.

title: ‘Ahead of the curve’: Maryland realtors not as affected by NAR settlement
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
‘Ahead of the curve’: Maryland realtors not as affected by NAR settlement

 September 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 632
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A $418 million settlement by the National Association of Realtors has brought forth changes to traditional practices of how broker commissions are paid. Maryland realtors, however, aren't having to adjust as much as their counterparts.The settlement was reached in May after class-action lawsuits by home sellers alleged antitrust violations stemming from requirements placed on listing brokers. The NAR denied any wrongdoing in connection to those claims.
In the wake of the settlement, two key changes from the NAR went into effect in August. First, homebuyers must sign a written agreement with an agent before that agent provides any services to the buyer. Second, offers of compensation from a seller to a buyer's agent may no longer be shared on multiple listing services, which are marketplaces for realtors.
The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors' stance on the changes is that there is now an increased sense of transparency for homebuyers and sellers.
"The lawsuit was really about transparency and how (buyer's agents are) getting paid," Shelby Roney, board president, said. "And it kind of makes you reiterate why you should be paid."
Roney, a realtor for Benson & Mangold Real Estate, said Maryland won't be feeling that first change as much as other states. She pointed out that Maryland has had buyer's agency since 1999, noting a law enacted in 2016 that required written buyer agency agreements.
Maryland realtors representing potential buyers are used to signing those written agreements, detailing to the buyer what services the agent will provide and at what cost. The national rule will reinforce that routine and force buyers and agents to sign agreements that are even clearer in outlining how much commission will cost for the agent.
"We've always been very proactive and ahead of the game, ahead of the curve," Roney said of Maryland.
Meanwhile, other states that did not have clear buyer's agency law had to quickly adjust to the new requirements.
"They were already freaking out before March," Roney said of other states. "When I was in California, there were agents from all over the country, and most of them did not have anything resembling buyer's agency. And it was very concerning for them, that they were nowhere prepared. How to explain it, how to even enforce it, how to word it, their state laws were going to have to change."
The increased focus on explicit buyer's agency agreements only furthers the advantages of a buyer paying their own agent rather than relying on a sub-agent during the buying process, Roney said.
Sub-agents are agents unaffiliated from the listing real estate broker but paid by the seller or seller's agent to assist prospective buyers. They do not work for the same company as the seller's agent.
Sub-agency is still alive in the state, according to Roney. However, sub-agents are only able to provide so much help to buyers since their loyalties are only to the seller. For prospective buyers, having a dedicated buyer's agent is beneficial.
"It's the biggest investment that you're going to make in your lifetime," she said of buying a home. Roney did note that many first-time homebuyers have benefitted from the seller paying the commission for an agent.
The option for a seller to offer compensation to a buyer's agent is still available, Roney said, though not through multiple listing service databases. Now, it'll be clear to buyers before any agreement is signed.
The benefits of having a buyer's agent are significant for buyers, especially when housing prices rise, the Mid-Shore Board of Realtors says. It'll also help realtors understand their value and be upfront about what "tier" of services they will offer depending on the compensation rate.
"You have to know your value and you have to explain your value, and you also have to decide what your tiers (of service) are," Roney said. " … Where do you want me to work for you?" 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the impact of a major real estate settlement on realtor practices and commissions, focusing on market and industry changes, which aligns best with the Business/Economy category.

title: More questions on the Chesapeake Bay ferry service
author: DAVID REEL
content:
More questions on the Chesapeake Bay ferry service

 September 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 839
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Recently, numerous media outlets provided updates on a proposal for a new Chesapeake Bay ferry service.The proposal suggests a fleet of passenger-only ferries connecting Annapolis, Baltimore, Kent Island, Easton, Cambridge, Rock Hall, St. Michaels, Oxford, Chestertown, Tilghman Island, Betterton, Havre de Grace, Solomons Island, Chesapeake Beach, North East, Leonardtown, Salisbury, Galesville and Crisfield.
The proposal suggests this new ferry service would help boost tourism and economic development in the Chesapeake Bay region of Maryland.
Previous media updates reported consultants for five Maryland counties that comprise the Chesapeake Bay Passenger Ferry Consortium — Anne Arundel, Calvert, St. Mary's, Somerset and Queen Anne's concluded a new passenger ferry system was feasible and cost effective.
The most recent media updates on this project report that Anne Arundel County alone has received a $3.9 million federal grant, a grant amount far less than a requested $7.2 million.
According to their grant application, Anne Arundel County plans to use the available federal grant money for new ferry service between Baltimore, Annapolis and Kent Island.
Later this month, a 17-person delegation will be traveling to Sweden. Their itinerary includes a tour of an electric passenger ferry factory and learning more about ferry planning.
The delegation includes representatives from the Maryland Departments of Commerce and Natural Resources, the Anne Arundel County Executive, Anne Arundel County senior staff members, Anne Arundel County Council members, Annapolis Mayor, Annapolis City Council members, Annapolis City senior staff, executive director of Visit Annapolis and Anne Arundel County, CEO of the Anne Arundel County Economic Development Corporation and executive director of the Resilience Authority of Annapolis and Anne Arundel County.
Funding for attendee costs on this trip includes donations of $25,000 from the Denker Foundation and an unspecified donation from the MHE Foundation.
While this most recent update is somewhat informative, it does not provide answers to a wide range of critical questions about this project, some of which were included in my recent commentary on this proposal.
In this commentary there are new unanswered questions.
Why are all the individuals going to Sweden from state government or Anne Arundel County?Why are there no attendees on the trip from Calvert, St Mary's, Queen Anne's and Somerset counties, all of which are members of the Chesapeake Bay Passenger Ferry Consortium?Do the donations from the two foundations cover all the attendee costs for the trip to Sweden? If not, where will the balance of funding come from?Why was one of their first priorities in the Anne Arundel County grant application ordering two electric ferry boats for service between Baltimore, Annapolis and Kent Island?Why is another first priority the placement of an order for boats before the end of 2024 when no ferry service is expected to start until 2027?How do these priorities impact the feasibility of and timeline for previously announced consortium plans to launch new passenger-only ferries serving all the locations listed above in the Chesapeake Bay Passenger Ferry Consortium proposal?What is the status on efforts securing a public/private partnership to operate the proposed new ferry system?
To date, money spent or approved on this new ferry proposal include a $250,000 federal grant for a feasibility study, another federal grant commitment of $3.9 million, another possible federal grant commitment for the balance of the original $7.2 million grant request that was recently denied.
While all of the above questions merit answers, I suggest there are two questions that merit immediate answers before any more money is spent or requested for this new ferry proposal.
Have members of the Chesapeake Bay Passenger Ferry Consortium spoken to, or will they speak to owners and operators of Chesapeake Bay tour boats to discuss the impact on their business of a new ferry system operated by a public and private partnership?
A number of these charter tour boat operators already offer regularly scheduled Bay tours. They regularly go to and from Baltimore, Annapolis, St. Michaels, Crisfield, and Cambridge among other Bay locations. Some tour operators also offer customized tours to anywhere clients want to go on the Bay, whenever they want to go, and for as long a time or as short a time they want to go. Recently, a local small business in Easton recently chartered a tour boat for a customized roundtrip between Kent Island and Baltimore for an Orioles game. By all accounts, this trip was a great success.
Have members of the Chesapeake Bay Passenger Ferry Consortium spoken to, or will they speak to owners and operators of recreational fishing charter boats to discuss on if and how they can expand their services to meet the increased public demand for Bay tours as projected in the consortium's feasibility study on a new ferry? These charter fishing boat operators especially need help as their livelihood and way of life is currently seriously threatened by new state regulations on rockfish fish harvesting limits.
Answers to these questions could accomplish two things.
They can avoid reinventing the wheel. They could also allow for a more fully informed decision on whether or not this proposed new ferry system is the best and cost-effective program to help increase tourism and economic development in Maryland. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a proposed ferry service, funding grants, economic development, and tourism impacts, which are primarily matters of business and economic policy rather than pure local government administration.

title: Gas prices bounce back up 18 cents in Maryland
author: Staff Writer
content:
Gas prices bounce back up 18 cents in Maryland

 October 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 471
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have risen 17.7 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.23 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 3.7 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 28.9 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has declined 1.2 cents in the last week and stands at $3.54 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.75 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.89 per gallon, a difference of $1.14per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has risen 1.4 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.17 per gallon today. The national average is down 15.4 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 63.8 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
September 30, 2023: $3.52 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.81 per gallon)September 30, 2022: $3.43 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.75 per gallon)September 30, 2021: $3.08 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.18 per gallon)September 30, 2020: $2.22 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.18 per gallon)September 30, 2019: $2.54 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.65 per gallon)September 30, 2018: $2.79 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.87 per gallon)September 30, 2017: $2.49 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.54 per gallon)September 30, 2016: $2.24 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.22 per gallon)September 30, 2015: $2.23 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.28 per gallon)September 30, 2014: $3.31 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.33 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.24 per gallon, up 23.4 cents per gallon from last week's $3.01 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.25 per gallon, up 3.7 cents per gallon from last week's $3.21 per gallon.Hagerstown: $3.11 per gallon, up 8.4 cents per gallon from last week's $3.02 per gallon.
"Another week brings a mixed bag at the gas pump, with gas prices declining in slightly more than half of U.S. states while others have seen increases due to some refinery snags and maintenance that have emerged, temporarily delaying declines in some areas. Meanwhile, GasBuddy data shows 18 states with sub-$3 per gallon average gas prices, a count that should certainly rise over the next few weeks," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "While Hurricane Helene left feet of rain behind and some states are seeing challenges in getting gasoline to stations, the storm did not broadly impact fuel production. For now, with oil prices falling back below $70 per barrel, the national average may be a bit stuck in the low $3s until fall maintenance wraps up, which could help bring a sub-$3 national average later this fall."

title: APG Chesapeake hires new regional president
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
APG Chesapeake hires new regional president

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 519
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Orestes Baez, Adams Publishing Group's new Chesapeake regional president, is no stranger to APG nor the Chesapeake region.Baez started the new job Monday, Sept. 30, meeting employees at the Star Democrat in Easton. He will be traveling to APG Chesapeake offices in Chestertown, Chester, La Plata, California, Prince Frederick, Dundalk and Elkton for the rest of the week.
Baez was APG's Southern Wisconsin regional president from August 2020 through 2022. A decade before that, he lived on the western shore of Maryland as the CEO of the Maryland Pennysaver.
In 2010, Baez entered the news industry when he took a job with Tribune Publishing Company in Newport News, Virginia.
"I joined newspapers in 2010 and have been with them ever since," he said.
As regional president, Baez will oversee the Chesapeake market.
"I'm excited," he said about his new role. "Adams is a great company. They've been really good to me."
Baez — who won the first ever APG Regional President of the Year award in 2021 — said one of his favorite company memories is when the company asked him for his opinion and they supported him.
"And they let me go do that," he said. "That speaks volumes for the kind of culture that the company has."
Before taking on the new role with APG, Baez was the CEO of TravelHost, a publication connecting businesses with travelers. He said that during his time in the news industry, he's enjoyed getting to connect businesses with audiences that desire the products and services of those businesses.
"That's the creative part," he said. "That's the energizing part."
Baez, whose family immigrated to the United States as political exiles from Cuba, said he is a big fan of free speech.
"From that standpoint I think journalism plays a great part," he said. "I think journalism has evolved a lot, and we continue to evolve it along with what people want. I think we have to get smarter about how we write (and) what we write about because it is something that we have to eventually monetize to sustain."
APG CEO and President Mark Adams said in a news release that Baez brings "familiarity and experience" to this position.
"It's always rewarding when we can have an executive like Orestes return to our organization," he said.
When he's not working, Baez can often be found on the pickleball courts. The three-time national champ is currently playing on the pickleball Senior Pro Tour.
His love for pickleball blossomed after decades of playing tennis. Since picking up a tennis racket at the age of 9, he has won over 300 tennis doubles titles. While in college, Baez played tennis for Clemson University. He also coached the Clemson team while in graduate school there.
It wasn't until he was in his 50s that Baez's friend convinced him to give pickleball a try. Since then, Baez has gone from playing the sport recreationally to playing in tournaments.
As he settles into his new role on the Chesapeake, Baez is looking for houses in Annapolis with his wife, Donna. He said he is excited to contribute to the Chesapeake team.
"It's about removing obstacles and helping guide," he said about his role. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the appointment of a new regional president for a publishing company, focusing on corporate leadership and business operations, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Cannabis tax receipts reach new heights in Maryland
author: STEVEN JACOBS JR. Capital News Service
content:
Cannabis tax receipts reach new heights in Maryland

 October 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEVEN JACOBS JR. Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 243
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — A new report shows the state of Maryland collected more than $22.3 million in cannabis sales tax revenue between April and June – a 52 percent increase over receipts of the prior three months.As Marylanders take advantage of legalized personal use of cannabis over the age of 21, the recent spike shows the industry's potential impact on the economy, Comptroller Brooke Lierman said in a press release announcing the report.
"The market for cannabis continues to grow in Maryland and has shown capacity to create new jobs, new investment and new opportunities, particularly for areas that are marginalized and left behind by a changing economy," Lierman said.
Maryland voters approved a ballot referendum in 2022, supporting legal possession and use for people age 21 or older. Then the Maryland General Assembly passed the Cannabis Reform Act in 2023 and Gov. Wes Moore signed it into law that same year.
Now it's Lierman's job to collect the taxes and disperse them to different funds supporting public health, business assistance and other public purposes.
The new industry is growing, the report shows, and state officials see the potential for more public benefit.
For example, 5 percent of the quarterly sales tax revenues go to a fund helping small, minority-owned and women-owned businesses break into the industry.
"These revenue numbers are a clear indication of the potential for Maryland's cannabis industry to drive economic growth while prioritizing equity," said Audrey Johnson, executive director of the Office of Social Equity. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on cannabis tax receipts and their impact on state revenue, job creation, and economic growth, making Business/Economy the primary fit, with secondary relevance to Health (public health funding) and Race & Diversity (equity initiatives).

title: Chestertown antique electrical appliance museum sparks interest
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Chestertown antique electrical appliance museum sparks interest

 October 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 654
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Saturday, as residents and visitors to Kent County enjoyed the farmer's market on High Street, high school freshman Ryan Helgerman of Gaithersburg walked into Chestertown Electric, curious.The store's name might sound like a place to pay a utility bill, but what he found was something entirely different — a place where time, technology and culture merge.
In every corner there's something interesting to see, from Victorian-era clocks to a hand-crank vacuum cleaner.
Above Helgerman, spun a 105-year-old copper-plated ceiling fan, operating with fluid efficiently. A space heater from the early 1900's hummed in the corner, generating heat immediately.
Owner of the establishment, David Hoatson describes his shop as a museum where you can buy the items.
"It's like walking into the Smithsonian and being able to purchase a fossil," he said, grinning.
Helgerman pointed to what he thought, understandably, was a music box, which turned out to be a Little Edison high voltage coil from 1900.
Hoatson explained it was probably used as a generator for a spark plug in an old farm engine.
Beside that was a Carl Zeiss Carbon Arc lamp from the 1920s. That consists of two carbon rods of differing sizes that create a consistent flame when they touch.
The customer and shop owner had a great time deciphering its uses, browsing online for German words, trying to track the mechanism's origins. Hoatson is a knowledgeable guide to do so with.
As a mechanical engineer for 35 years, working at AAI corporation out of Cockeysville, throughout his career, he's conducted military simulations, working on computer graphics. He's worked on F-35 airplanes, spending much of his time on military bases.
For the past ten years he's been into sales, restoration and running his museum. After fixing up his first fan, an Emerson from 1918 he bought on eBay, he's had a steady stream of customers, learning as he goes.
He explained that when he disassembles an item he can see not only how it functions, but insights into the time and culture it was built in.
Case-in-point, Helgerman presented a light socket. There was nothing out-of-the-ordinary really, except it had a key hole on the side.
"So if somebody tries to unscrew it, they can't steal it," Hoatson remarked.
Light bulbs in the late 1800's were a day's wages for most people, and so like with anything valuable, protective measures were taken.
Another point of fascination was where old technology combined with new technology. For example Hoatson's Nixie tube clocks are all hooked to the internet.
"I'm using modern electronics using old tubes," Hoatson said.
The Nixie tubes were made in the '60s and '70s to put in computers and expensive electronics when they didn't have LEDs and LCDs. It was the only way people could do numbers, Hoatson explained.
These tiny clocks flashed the time of the day and date.
In the back room, a slot machine from the 1930s caught Helgerman's interest. While he tried his luck pulling the lever, Hoatson explained that inside the machine are separate shelves with varying thickness for the coins that drop down in mathematical sequence.
As the young man and store owner talked over inventions, Helgerman's father came in. He too was caught up in the intricate world of the museum. Not only are there inventions, but old maps of the region, Chestertown's history, documents from the 1800s and much more.
Helgerman told his father, "I'm fascinated by this stuff. What he's showing is some of the greatest minds of the 1800s. All of this is 130 to 150 years old, and it all works."
Hoatson shrugged.
"Alot of it just works without having to to fix it up. If I buy a 100-year old ceiling fan, there's probably a 95 percent chance it still runs," he said. He added he probably wouldn't have that luck with a 5-year-old one that has plastic parts and is imported.
Hoatson invited the father and son back, as well as the public, to see him at 324 Cannon St. every Saturday from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a local shop that operates as a museum and sells antique appliances, highlighting the owner's business activities, sales, and visitor engagement, which aligns best with the Business/Economy category.

title: Maryland revenues see 'slight positive adjustment'
author: STEVEN JACOBS JR. Capital News Service
content:
Maryland revenues see 'slight positive adjustment'

 October 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEVEN JACOBS JR. Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 236
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — State officials revised their estimate of general fund revenues upward this month, making what state Comptroller Brooke Lierman called a "slight positive adjustment."But the change is "not a dramatic revision," Lierman said. "Our economic performance has been really in line with our previous estimates."
Based on their analysis, the Board of Revenue Estimates submitted a revised estimate of general fund revenues for fiscal year 2025 of $25.1 billion and an estimate of $25.3 billion for fiscal year 2026 — a minor change, though a positive one.
"The Board and the Revenue Monitoring Committee will continue to meet and analyze revenue and economic trends in anticipation of December's estimates," the board said in its September letter to Gov. Wes Moore. The board updates its numbers three times a year.
"Today's presentation represents a moderate increase in our revenues, our economy remains stable, and we are not in a recession," said State Treasurer Dereck E. Davis, a member of the board. "And that's not a small thing to say. There have been predictions, and we've been able to largely avoid that, so to me that's good news."
Despite the positive news, though, the state continues to face massive budget challenges. The state's Department of Legislative Services fiscal said last January that Maryland will start running a structural deficit in fiscal year 2025 that will multiply nearly sixfold by fiscal year 2029, when it is projected to hit $2.93 billion. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Caroline Economic Development Launches New Website
author: Tom McCall
content:
Caroline Economic Development Launches New Website

 October 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 395
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Caroline County Economic Development has created a new website.Director Rob Zimberhoff helped to bring it to life. It is designed to better support the local business community.
"We worked with contractor Maven and Smith, who really built this new website for us. We put lots and lots of hours into considering how it would look, the message we are trying to send," Zimberhoff said.
He tailored the site not only for function but also for the people who could use the site.
The new site includes sections like relocate and expand, business planning and startup, key industries, and life and leisure. There are aerial photographs of available commercial real estate.
"We wanted it to be more useful for anyone doing business in Caroline County — new businesses that would like to come into Caroline County or businesses that are already here," he said.
He noted farmers and agricultural sector as being a focus of the new design.
"We have a lot of folks who are innovating in the industry. Really paying mind to best practices and environmentalism. Another one is manufacturing, they are some of our biggest employers," Zimberhoff said.
He said there is opportunity to grow with unfinished properties in Denton and Federalsburg. There is warehouse space that is not being used. He wants the county to grow without creating sprawl. He also looked at the retail sector, and empty storefronts indicate that there is room to grow.
"We wanted to make sure it was an improvement over the old site. Kendall (Teague) and I put a lot of time into the actual writing, into finding the right pictures and into making sure the messages were clear," he said.
He said he was excited about the new resources that are on the site and that they are helpful to the business community. Like workforce development and training to how to start your business to working with a lender.
"Another tool I am excited about is Resimplifi. It is driven towards commercial and industrial real estate. And agricultural real estate. It is a tool that produces a map and other data of all the properties that are available in Caroline County. It lists them in a way that is easy to find," Zimberhoff said.
He said Teague has been a huge help and the Caroline County Chamber of Commerce has helped by spreading the word.
To check out the new site, go to carolinebusiness.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Raging against the machine is a poor strategy
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Raging against the machine is a poor strategy

 October 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 835
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Starting in 1991 and still active today is an alternative rock band that named themselves Rage Against the Machine. That is not surprising since their musical messages consistently promote rage against the machine. For them, the machine is defined broadly as businesses and corporations.In the most recent strike by the International Longshoremen's Association, their public messaging strategy included rage against the machine. Longshoremen defined the machine much more narrowly as the United States Maritime Alliance, an industry trade association whose members are container cargo ship carriers, marine terminal operators and ports.
Among other member services, the alliance does labor contract negotiations with union leaders on a range of matters including wages and the use of artificial intelligence powered robots.
To generate support for their negotiations with the alliance on those two issues, the union leadership launched a rage against the machine messaging and negotiating strategy.
International Longshoremen's Association leaders regularly issued profanity-laced messages directed at container cargo ship carriers saying they are unappreciative of dock workers role in their success and are indifferent to the concerns of dock workers future in an ever-changing world.
The leadership also vowed their strike would continue until all their demands on wage increases and the future use of automation on the docks were met.
Despite that rage against the machine my way or the highway messaging, there were immediate and widespread concerns that a strike would cause enormous harm to America's economy, including more inflation and possibly an economic recession.
Even some union members in Baltimore expressed concern about a strike. They had just endured not working for two months after the Francis Scott Key Bridge collapse and closure of the Port of Baltimore.
Three days after the strike began the union president abruptly reversed course on his previous rage against the machine messaging and agreed to suspend the strike until Jan. 15, 2025.
He acknowledged a tentative agreement with United States Maritime Alliance on wage increases, which were only slightly more than originally proffered by the alliance, and a return to negotiate other outstanding issues.
The outstanding issue is a ban on artificial intelligence-powered robotic automation on the docks.
After pausing the strike, the union's leader issued the following statement: "The ILA is steadfastly against any form of automation — full or semi — that replaces jobs or historical work functions."
He also said in his statement that the preservation of historical work functions is "non-negotiable." Job security for members and resisting modern technology have been union priorities for decades. In 1977, the last time Baltimore dockworkers went on strike, they strongly opposed the introduction of another modern technology — large metal standardized shipping containers.
Despite their 1977 strike, the International Longshoremen's Association lost the battle against the use of containers. Containers are now standard operating procedure. Somewhat ironically, last year the Port of Baltimore set new records on handling multi-modal containers using longshoremen workers.
When a railroad tunnel expansion project is completed (scheduled for 2027), Baltimore will be well positioned to send even more containers by rail into the Ohio Valley and on to Chicago.
On the yet to be negotiated issue of a ban or limits on artificial intelligence-powered robotic automation on the docks, I predict the future will be a repeat of the 1977 outcome. More automation is imminent and inevitable for three reasons.
First, robots are more efficient and dependable for repetitive and routine jobs.
Second, there are decreasing numbers of individuals willing to work on the docks. Even with technological changes on the docks, dockworker jobs can still be dangerous, tedious, and dirty.
Third, the unions stance that "the preservation of historical work functions is non-negotiable" is a message that will not stand. Everything in life is negotiable. In a recent Baltimore Sun article, Will Brucher, a port labor expert at the Rutgers School of Management and Labor Relations, said "Protections are already in place. To keep labor relations smooth, the employers conceded that this was something that was negotiable. It's possible they [ILA] could put a stop on new automation, but what historically has happened is they have job protections around it."
For a view of the future of technology in supply chain management, look no farther than two massive Amazon warehouse fulfillment centers at Sparrows Point. They were built on the site of the former Bethlehem Steel plant, not far from where Baltimore dockworkers were striking and picketing. At one time, this plant was the largest steel plant in the world and was one of the largest employers in the Baltimore region.
Unable to compete efficiently it is now gone.
Today, at Sparrows Point, in indoor climate-controlled Amazon warehouses, robots are helping humans meet the order fulfillment demands of Amazon customers.
Going forward there are key lessons on messaging management that should be embraced by the International Longshoremen's Association leaders, other labor unions and many comparable organizations.
Raging against the machine has not been and will not be an effective messaging strategy in generating public support for your organization's goals whatever they may be.
Raging against the machine will likely diminish your value to and support from your constituents whoever they may be.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a labor strike, wage negotiations, automation, and its impact on the regional economy, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Electric vehicles not quite ready for mass markets
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Electric vehicles not quite ready for mass markets

 October 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 780
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Ford Motor Company, the second largest car maker in America recently announced it was making major changes in their production of electric vehicles, commonly referred to as EVs.Ford has put a hold on plans they announced last year to spend $1.8 billion to transform an assembly plant in Canada into a hub for electric vehicle manufacturing.
Now their plan is to shift production at that plant to Ford's gas-powered F-Series trucks which have been the best-selling truck lineup in America since 1977 and Ford's best-selling vehicle overall since 1981.
In its coverage of Ford's decision to pivot on EVs, the New York Times noted, "The move is the latest example of how automakers are pulling back on aggressive investment plans in response to the slowing growth of electric vehicle sales."
This decision by Ford comes with a measurable impact on its bottom line and on 2,700 auto worker jobs at their Canadian plant.
That plan alone will cost the company at least $400 million as they write down the costs for the manufacturing equipment they had put in place to build the EVs. Ford estimates the change in plans could ultimately cost them upward of $1.5 billion.
Those costs pale in comparison to Ford losing $4.7 billion on EV sales last year, which is approximately $40,525 per electric vehicle sold.
Ford's latest pullback from EVs is no surprise.
The economic reality is that Ford, other car makers and advocates for electric vehicles made unrealistic and unsustainable projections on consumer demand for EVs.
The two most likely factors for less than projected consumer demand are purchase price and reliability concerns.
The July 2024 edition of the Kelley Blue Book reports the average price for a new EV was $56,520, with some models costing more than $100,000.
Reliability is a concern due to a relatively limited number of EV charging stations.
Nationwide, there were 68,475 private and public charging stations at the beginning of this year, according to the U.S Department of Energy. While that's more than twice the number in 2020, it's still just a third of the number of gas stations and well below projections.
A 2023 survey by the Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research and the Energy Policy Institute at the University of Chicago reported that 77% of those polled voiced concerns about how they would charge an EV if they bought one.
This concern is not limited to potential EV buyers. Some current EV owners share it.
Earlier this year, the New York Times profiled a purchaser of a Ford F-150 Lightning EV. The purchaser said it was the "coolest vehicle he'd ever owned" and "it is unbelievably fast and responsive." He also said, "the technology is amazing." High praise indeed.
The problem for this otherwise enthusiastic EV owner was the EVs range or, more importantly, lack of range.
When the weather grew colder, this owner found that the distance his vehicle could travel fell dramatically. His faith in the $79,000 truck diminished to a point where he found himself wondering if he should sell it.
"People say 'range anxiety' — it's like it's the driver's fault," he told the Times. "But it's not our fault. It's actually they're not telling us what the real range is. The truck says it's 300 miles. I don't think I've ever gotten that."
Such observations are not a positive branding moment for electric vehicles or for Ford.
So, does all this news mean electric vehicles will never be more widely accepted?
In a word … no.
History is full of stories where the acceptance of new technologies grew slowly but steadily over time following initial acceptance by early adopters.
Early adopters are individuals who buy and try a new product or technology soon after it is available. Early adopters eagerly embrace change, are often (but not always) young, often (but not always) highly educated, and often (but not always) having robust disposable income.
While early adopters are among the first to purchase and use new products and services, they often become public opinion leaders over time.
Widespread public acceptance of their opinions can be accelerated when producers and marketers of a new technology listen to, accept suggestions from, and address legitimate concerns brought to their attention by early adopters.
Ford appears to be on track to do that. Their president and CEO recently said, "As the No. 2 brand in the U.S. for the past two years, we are committed to scaling a profitable EV business, using capital wisely, and bringing to market the right gas, hybrid and fully electric vehicles at the right time.
Ford currently anticipates the right time will not occur until 2027 when they plan to resume EV production at their Canadian Assembly plant.
For now, it is clear that electric vehicles are an idea whose time has not yet come. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses Ford's strategic shift away from electric vehicle production, financial impacts, market demand, and pricing—key business and economic issues rather than purely environmental or safety concerns.

title: 'Team effort' is what it takes to build and retain businesses in Kent
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
'Team effort' is what it takes to build and retain businesses in Kent

 October 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 912
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — In a recent interview, Jamie Williams noted that in Kent County, businesses are coming and going regularly."It's a churning process," she acknowledged.
For instance, Rock City Cafe's last day was Oct 12. Then Oct. 15, at that same location, 21536 Rock Hall Ave., Little Lemon Leaf Diner is advertising a hiring event, for kitchen and dining room.
Some new businesses moved in recently as well. Starbucks is now open for business, and It's Masala Time, an Indian restaurant at 3 Washington Square, had its soft opening on Wednesday, Oct. 2.
As director of Kent County Department of Economic and Tourism Development for 11 years, Williams sees this turnaround daily, offering support and creating opportunities for businesses to thrive.
While working with the Economic Commission, business owners and leaders in the community appointed by the county commissioners provide guidance and insight.
Their goals line up with the county's comprehensive plan: to retain and expand businesses while supporting start-up businesses.
With a hefty schedule to close out the week, Williams, highlighted some projects her staff is working on.
Millington Senior Housing: The Millington Senior Village is a project that will provide 52 one-story apartments for people age 62 and up.
The project is located on land once part of the Millington Elementary School property.
The county is working with Millington during the grant search process. If successful, they hope to build a community resource center, food pantry, church and daycare center, centralizing services in one location.
With all that activity, Williams hopes to have Delmarva Community Transit services to accommodate residential needs.
"The more density we have the more services we can build there," Williams commented.
Railroad Upgrade: Williams pointed out the Worton railroad system, services five companies and was in a state of disrepair for quite a while. The county had received funding from the state to fix the tracks in May of 2020.
Williams was happy to announce that in September 2024 that project is finally completed.
The fact that from the time they had received the funding to the actual repair was four years, she said, should give an indication to the public of how slow-going these processes sometimes take.
Brownfield Properties: Williams and staff has identified 12 brownfield properties — places contaminated and needing remediation.
Most of these properties, the director said, were dry-cleaning establishments, dealing with chemicals. One of these is in Chestertown, Admiral Cleaners, located across from the 7-Eleven on 212 Maple Ave.; a building that sits dormant with graffiti on the walls.
Williams asked, is it worth the county adopting a brownfield credit, a state program. Is it worth going through that kind of process to redevelop the properties?
They are seeking answers to those pressing questions.
Recreational Cannabis: Beginning July 1, 2023, individuals in Maryland at least age 21 could legally use and possess the personal use amount of cannabis. Licensing is issued by the State for those who aim to start a dispensary.
Currently, Williams said the county issued only one micro-license, for a cannabis dispensary in Millington.
According to earlier reports, the establishment is under Rahul "Rocky" Dutta and if meeting all the requirements, will be located in the vacant Truist Bank building at 400 Cypress Street.
In talking with Dutta earlier in the week, Williams reported everything is moving forward.
Short-term rental tax:The county has been working with the municipalities to collect short-term rental tax from properties where AirBnb's or Vrbo properties or other rentals of that nature are located.
Williams acknowledged that is an extensive process involving lots of moving parts.
She had worked with her administrative specialist Rose Osborn to locate the properties throughout the county. They purchased software to track these properties more efficiently as well as send out notices.
Now it seems like they are seeing positive results.
According to the July report, Williams said "64 percent of properties are in compliance."
The director expects higher in the future.
"We feel we're going to see the biggest impact after the September numbers."
Other than using the tracking software, they worked closely with the municipalities to coordinate their memorandum of understandings for short-term rental tax, so they are all on the same page.
The county collects the taxes monthly and remit it to the towns. The towns receive 90 percent of the revenue with 10 percent going to the county for administrative costs.
Even before they purchased the software, Williams and Osborn have been working steadily on this issue since November 2022.
She was thankful for the cooperation that occurred since then.
"Getting all five towns together is an example of what we need to be doing for a lot of other projects," she said.
Business Retention and Expansion: Williams maintained they have always responded to the needs of business owners. However, now, that attention and focus is being formalized as they launch their Business and Retention Visit Program, starting last week.
The department has reached out to 10 or 11 businesses so far, refining their data-gathering process and consulting with business owners.
They've been all over the county, visiting KRM Development, Hickory Stick and Blue Heron Oyster House to name a few.
The qualitative information they gather will be assessed and used to help the community.
All of this would not be possible without Economic Development Manager Katie Abbott, the Kent County Chamber of Commerce and many others, Williams noted.
"It takes a collaborative effort from everyone; that's how economic development happens."
As a team, they are helping businesses find their niche area to succeed in a region specific to rural concerns.
"We're not an area to put up a big distribution center," Williams said."We're here to promote businesses focusing on what's unique and special in Kent County." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Kent County's economic development efforts, business retention and expansion programs, and related government initiatives, making Business/Economy the most fitting category.

title: Maryland unions seek influence in election beyond membership numbers
author: KATHARINE WILSON Capital News Service
content:
Maryland unions seek influence in election beyond membership numbers

 October 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KATHARINE WILSON Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 1329
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — When Darlene Butler-Jones, a 66 year-old shop steward for Giant, walks into a store, people listen.Butler-Jones is part of a group of grocery store workers assigned by her union — United Food & Commercial Workers Union Local 400 — to explain the organization's political endorsements to her fellow employees.
As she walks through the store, talking to employees at cash registers and counters, Butler-Jones hears their concerns about fair scheduling, retirement, and dignity in the workplace.
"People want change," Butler-Jones said.
As Democrats and Republicans argue over which party truly represents working people and who will secure their vote, Maryland union leaders say it's not about party, it's about policy.
Capital News Service spoke to six Maryland-based union presidents and political leaders to better understand how union endorsements work and the impact of unions on politics in Maryland.
What the unions wantMaryland union leaders said they are focused on improving the lives of their members, which most said comes down to their ability to organize.
Donna S. Edwards is the president of the Maryland State and D.C. AFL-CIO, a federation of more than 50 unions.
To get union backing, Edwards said, politicians need to support the Protecting the Right to Organize Act, commonly known as the PRO-Act, and the Public Service Freedom to Negotiate Act, a bill to guarantee the right to organize for public sector employees.
The PRO-Act, a bill promoted by the labor movement, aims to protect the right to join and form a union by prohibiting common employer intimidation tactics and requiring employees represented by collective bargaining units to pay their fair share of representation fees.
This Congress, 263 Democrats, three Republicans and two independents sponsored the PRO-Act. The bill has not been put up for a vote in either chamber. The Public Service Freedom to Negotiate Act has seen no action.
To get an endorsement from the Maryland State and D.C. AFL-CIO, candidates must first fill out surveys detailing their stances on nearly every issue in some way related to labor. Then top candidates are interviewed by union members and leaders before a final selection is made.
The top three factors union officials making the AFL-CIO endorsements consider are the candidate's views on issues, viability and voting record, according to Kayla Mock, the political and legislative director for the local food and commercial workers union, which falls under the state's AFL-CIO.
Unions are focused on fundamental issues important to working people, like healthcare, child care, and the right to organize, Mock said. These issues, many union leaders say, typically favor Democratic candidates.
In the 2024 election, the Maryland State and D.C. AFL-CIO only endorsed Democratic candidates for Congress.
"I tell my members this all the time, please bring me a pro-labor Republican. I would love to talk to them. I would love to endorse them," Mock said.
While many major unions in Maryland endorsed Democrats for local and federal office, as they have continuously done for decades, this isn't true among all unions and union endorsements aren't always followed by rank-and-file members.
Maryland-based Teamsters Joint Councils 55 and 62 endorsed the presidential campaign of Vice President Kamala Harris, breaking from the national union's decision to not endorse a candidate. However, in a Teamsters member poll from July 24 to Sept. 15, 49.4% of Maryland members wanted the national union to endorse Trump, compared to 46.5% for Harris.
In the 2020 election, around 60% of union households voted for President Joe Biden, Axios reported.
Jason Ascher, the Mid-Atlantic Pipe Trades Association's political director, said he has some union members who will vote for former President Donald Trump regardless of what Ascher and other union leaders recommend.
This trend, particularly among the building trades, Ascher said, followed the 1994 implementation of the North American Free Trade Agreement — a pact among the United States, Mexico and Canada — that the Economic Policy Institute, a non-profit think tank affiliated with the labor movement, says led to the loss of thousands of union jobs.
The trade agreement, combined with social issues promoted by Democrats, pro-gun attitudes and the populism of Trump, created hard-line Republican voters within the union base, Ascher said. Now he and others are working at the local level to draw more of their union members back into voting for endorsed Democrats.
"It's a fight every day," Ascher said. "We have to convince our members, at least in the trades, that the Democrats are the ones helping us right now."
Ryan Whittington, the president of the Ocean City Career Firefighters Paramedics Association, leads one of a dozen first-responder unions endorsing the Senate candidacy of former Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan, a Republican.
When his union's board of directors decides to get involved in a state or local election, Whittington said, they open up a poll to every member of the union to select their preferred candidate. In the 2024 Maryland Senate race, Whittington said only two members of his union, which has more than 70 people, did not want the union to endorse Hogan.
"Within our local we have individuals who are Democrats, we have individuals who are Republicans," Whittington said. "For us, it's about looking at a candidate who is going to listen to the needs of our firefighters, our public safety officials, and make sure that they have our backs."
Who looks at union endorsementsWhile union members made up just 10.7% of the Maryland working population in 2023, union leaders say their impact stretches beyond their membership.
"We are members of the same communities that we're working in and living in. We're the next door neighbors," said Paul Lemle, the president of the Maryland State Education Association. "It's natural that people trust us."
Union popularity has seen record highs nationwide in recent years. In an August Gallup poll, 70% of Americans said they approved of labor unions.
Part of this increase can be attributed to younger Americans.
Around 88% of people under 30 supported unions in an August 2023 poll by the Democratic polling and research firm GBAO, conducted on behalf of the AFL-CIO.
Mock said she has seen first-hand a rise in young people embracing unions.
Her chapter of UFCW — which includes 35,000 workers across six states and the District of Columbia — held two successful union membership votes for cannabis dispensary workers within one week in Montgomery County, Maryland.
Mock, who was a delegate to the Democratic National Convention, said this attention from younger voters could be behind the Democratic strategy to boost the union vote.
"We're kind of the cool kids club," Mock said. "Democrats, very smartly, are going 'oh yeah, we actually do need labor.'"
In the 2022 statewide election, Maryland State Education Association members voted at a 24 percentage point rate higher than the rest of the state, according to the director of the union's political and legislative affairs, Samantha Zwerling. In every election, she said, politicians endorsed by the education association have more than an 80% chance of winning.
"Unions are inherently part of the democratic fabric of our society...That's what's meant by freedom of assembly and freedom of speech… they encourage participation and democracy," Lemle, the union president, said.
What unions want the public to know"Unions are not these big bosses. Look at me. I'm the union," Edwards, the Maryland State and D.C. AFL-CIO president, said.
The talkative, charismatic union leader was sitting in an emptying event space during the Democratic National Convention in August, showing her union friends in the Maryland delegation a photo of her holding a "Union Yes!" sign during the convention the night before.
Edwards, a social-worker by trade, grew up in a union home. She first joined a union while working for the Baltimore City Department of Social Services in the 1970s.
Her union leadership was able to get a pay raise for her unit of social workers — kicking off her passion for labor activism.
The union "is the only institution, in my view, that holds the line on a democracy in this country," Edwards said. "It allows for workers and their families to be involved in the political process, but it also gives you the financial security… to be able to be a contributing part of your community." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses labor unions, their political endorsements, and legislation affecting workers, which aligns most closely with economic and business-related news.

title: Carol's Kitchen brings food back to Dorchester airport
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Carol's Kitchen brings food back to Dorchester airport

 October 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 368
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — For those who enjoy entertainment while they dine, Carol's Kitchen has reopened in a new location: the Cambridge-Dorchester Regional Airport.During a ribbon-cutting ceremony hosted by the Dorchester Chamber of Commerce on Thursday, Oct. 17, community leaders congratulated the restaurant's owners, Carol Short and Grady Wilson.
"I wish you a lot of success," said Kevin Hill, chairman of the the Dorchester Chamber of Commerce board. "Congratulations on the expanded space. It's great to see this space reactivated."
Once Short cut the ribbon outside the restaurant, attendees of the event went inside to enjoy lunch with a view.
The restaurant, which was previously located on Glasgow Street in Cambridge, opened at the airport in early September. Short and Wilson said the new location offers a great view where they can serve up food the community loves at an affordable price.
Airport Director Steve Nuwer said the restaurant "brings life" to the airport, which he considers a gateway to Dorchester County. He said there are a lot of people from nearby states that fly to the airport just to have lunch.
"So it's a great opportunity for people that are not familiar with this area to come in and experience Dorchester County," he said about the airport. "The restaurant helps bring them in here."
Nuwer joked that having a restaurant so close to where he works isn't good for his health.
"But they've got really good food," he said.
Although the airport has had restaurants in it in the past, it has been without a restaurant since the beginning of 2022 when Katie's At The Airport closed.
Dorchester Chamber of Commerce President Bill Christopher said having a restaurant back at the airport is good because the airport is easy to get to and has great parking. Christopher said Carol's Kitchen serves up good portions of good food at a reasonable price.
"It's a good environment to be in," he said. "I think they'll do well."
Christopher called the restaurant "a natural draw" for people to come to the airport. He said sitting in the restaurant and watching planes take off could also spark career ideas for young people.
"Bringing them out so they can eat and see and start thinking, 'I might want to be a pilot someday,'" he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the reopening of a restaurant at a regional airport, highlighting its impact on local commerce, the Chamber of Commerce, and economic activity, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.
