title: Gas prices in Maryland continue rollercoaster ride
author: Staff Writer
content:
Gas prices in Maryland continue rollercoaster ride

 October 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 502
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 8.9 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.14 per gallon today, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 7.5 cents per gallon higher than a month ago and stand 22.0 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has declined 1.3 cents in the last week and stands at $3.56 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.77 per gallon yesterday while the most expensive was $3.89 per gallon, a difference of $1.12 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 3.3 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.13 per gallon today. The national average is down 6.2 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 39.7 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
October 21, 2023: $3.36 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.52 per gallon)October 21, 2022: $3.68 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.80 per gallon)October 21, 2021: $3.30 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.36 per gallon)October 21, 2020: $2.28 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.16 per gallon)October 21, 2019: $2.49 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.63 per gallon)October 21, 2018: $2.73 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.83 per gallon)October 21, 2017: $2.39 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.44 per gallon)October 21, 2016: $2.24 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.22 per gallon)October 21, 2015: $2.19 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.23 per gallon)October 21, 2014: $3.07 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.08 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.10 per gallon, down 11.2 cents per gallon from last week's $3.22 per gallon.
Washington, D.C.: $3.23 per gallon, down 2.9 cents per gallon from last week's $3.26 per gallon.
Hagerstown: $3.23 per gallon, up 4.0 cents per gallon from last week's $3.19 per gallon.
"The median U.S. price for gasoline has just slipped below the $3 per gallon mark for the first time since early 2024, while the national average price of gasoline has returned to decline as oil prices have begun to cool off after Iran's attack on Israel, due in part to sources saying Israel has agreed not to attack Iran's oil infrastructure," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "With the potential of an attack on Iran's oil infrastructure decreasing as a result, the risk calculus for oil is decreasing, and with continued economic weakness in China providing bearish sentiment, oil prices late last week slipped back below the $70 per barrel mark, opening the door for a longer decline to potentially return to the national average. I'm hopeful that the downward trend will continue again this week for a majority of Americans as we see the average price of gasoline start to make a targeted effort to fall below the $3 per gallon mark for the first time since 2021." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on gasoline price trends and market factors, which are primarily economic/business news.

title: Talbot County food pantries gear up for the holidays
author: Tom McCall
content:
Talbot County food pantries gear up for the holidays

 October 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 370
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — With the holidays approaching, Talbot County residents are preparing to hold food-centered gatherings, many with the help of local food pantries.Catherine Poe is the chair of the Talbot County Hunger Coalition, a network of members, providers and individuals working to end hunger and improve access to healthy, nutritious food. For the holidays, there is a big effort by the food pantries to provide festive meals.
"It is always so special. People line up long in advance because it is so unusual," Poe said.
Coordinating holiday plans for the food pantries begins months in advance, she said.
"The one (at the Senior Center) has already gotten their meals for Thanksgiving and Christmas. At Christmas it will come from The (Maryland) Food Bank," Poe said, describing the plan for one of the providers the organization works with.
Given the volume of food needed, the pantries get it at bulk prices and never buy from a supermarket. Sometimes donors help out.
"The other place is Mountaire Farms. It gives away thousands of free Thanksgiving meals. They are sending the Senior Center 100 boxes. All the pantries have to plan early where they are getting their meals from," Poe said.
They also get food from the Maryland Food Bank, a nonprofit hunger relief organization. Items from the food bank have to be purchased by the local providers, which Poe said gives citizens who want to help an opportunity to participate.
"We prefer cash (donations) because our money goes a long way," Poe said. "... The larger pantries spend about $7,000 a month, so they have to raise that every month."
St. Marks and St. Vincent dePaul food pantries use funds from their associated thrift shops to support feeding the community. Some other providers have grant writers to try to raise money.
Although the pantries take food from the public, it is more difficult to integrate it into their program than cash donations, Poe said.
Poe says the best bet is to cut a check to any of the nine food pantries in Talbot County — CarePacks, Talbot County Early Head Start, Brookletts Place, St. Michaels Community Center, St. Marks United Methodist, BAAM (Building African American Minds), Talbot County Local Care Team, WIC (Women Infants and Children) and The Talbot Family Network. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses food pantries, funding, donations, and economic aspects of hunger relief, which aligns best with Business/Economy among the given categories.

title: Bradford House Apartments under new management
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Bradford House Apartments under new management

 October 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 523
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Bradford House Apartments are under new management with a new principal owner.Nuveen — an asset manager and subsidiary of financial planning firm TIAA — has been made principal owner of the apartment complex on Race Street in Cambridge. Bradford House offers multifamily, subsidized housing for low-income individuals who are elderly or have special needs.
Paths Management Services, a subsidiary of Nuveen, will manage the property.
Over the past year and a half, residents have expressed concerns about the safety of the building, from bed bug infestations to call-for-aid systems not working to a lack of security.
In September 2023, the property — which was then managed by Cleveland-based company Millennia Housing Management — received a U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development inspection score of 30c. The score indicated health and safety deficiencies and other problems identified with building systems, the building's exterior and individual apartments.
In an email, Justin Henry with Paths Management said that since taking over, the company has begun making "significant repairs and improvements."
"Our top priority is residents' safety, so we currently are installing new security cameras, adding new indoor and exterior lighting, as well as updating the building's access system," Henry said. "We are working around the clock to ensure residents feel safe, secure and comfortable in their homes."
Bradford House resident and the complex's tenant association chairperson Linda Johnson said new management is friendly and putting in work to address problems on the property. Johnson, who has lived in the building since May 2000, said Paths Management Services has painted her apartment, put new lighting in the hallways and cleaned up the back stairwells.
"I can finally really smile," she said.
According to an Oct. 18 memo from Cambridge Assistant City Manager Brandon Hesson to the Cambridge City Council, Millennia is no longer responsible for the management of the apartment, but it will remain a "minority partner" on the property.
The memo says Millennia and its CEO Frank Sinito received a debarment order from HUD, which prevents the company from participating in any new business with HUD.
In an interview, Hesson said that while Millennia "grossly mismanaged" the property, the finger shouldn't be pointed at any one person. He said it's a partnership between ownership, management, the city and HUD.
"The way out of it is for us to get on the same page," he said. "That's all we're trying to do is remind each other that we all benefit, but the residents have to be able to live in a clean, safe environment."
In the memo, Hesson listed nine areas where progress is being made at Bradford House. Progress includes plans to be completed within 120 days, including completed repair of building's second elevator, commitment from management to do a complete repair of the roof, new contracts for security and security cameras, and advertisement of a service coordinator position.
Hesson said 13 of the building's units have been rehabbed and a plan is being made to address the building's remaining units.
"At this week's meeting, 48 open violations were reviewed, and half of those violations were closed and completed," Hesson said.
Weekly meetings between city code enforcement, HUD, management and ownership will continue, the memo stated. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the change of ownership and management of an apartment complex, involving an asset manager and HUD inspections, which aligns most closely with business and economic news, while also touching on local government and safety issues.

title: Robert Morris Inn restaurant closed for renovations
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Robert Morris Inn restaurant closed for renovations

 October 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Business 
 
 333
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — Financier Chesapeake Bar and Grill, the restaurant inside the Robert Morris Inn, expects to reopen sometime in November after temporarily closing for renovations.General manager Mike Willis said they hope to reopen Nov. 7, but it could be later than that.
The restaurant closed for renovations to the main dining hall about three weeks ago, Willis said. Renovations including redoing the ceiling and floor in the dining area to make it more modern.
"Just bringing it up so we can actually make it into a reception area for weddings or functions," Willis said.
Recently, the inn has come under new management. Willis said the inn's owner, David Snyder, has brought in Hambleton House Events and Catering.
"So we've come in with a new chef team — not necessarily a new chef — but a chef team and a new management team," Willis said.
Willis said he isn't sure why the change in management was made. Snyder could not be reached for comment.
During an Oxford Planning Commission meeting on Oct. 1, Snyder said the inn has faced economic challenges since he took ownership this past year. He told the Planning Commission that he is losing over $30,000 every month and said the current business is not sustainable.
Snyder asked the Planning Commission for a text amendment that would allow him to create luxury villas on the property, which he believes will help make the business profitable. Synder said he also believes having villas as an addition to the restaurant and inn rooms will increase the value of the property.
At the meeting, Snyder said he knows rumors about him and his plans for his business have been "swirling," but said he is "here to stay."
"I'm not giving up on this property," he said at the meeting.
The Planning Commission voted to have the town attorney draft an ordinance for a text amendment that the Planning Commission can consider at the next meeting. If the Planning Commission approves the text amendment, it will go to the Commissioners of Oxford for consideration. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily reports on a restaurant's closure for renovations, financial losses, and plans to add luxury villas, all centered on business operations and economic viability, making Business/Economy the best fit.

title: Water therapy is Chestertown’s healing business
author: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Water therapy is Chestertown’s healing business

 November 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 641
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — There is a relatively new small business in Chestertown that is combining the cutting-edge practice of sensory deprivation with the wonders and healing potential of water.Park Row Floats, located at 312 Park Row, has helped Kent County residents stress less and address certain ailments for more than a year now.
If the concept of sensory deprivation sounds harsh and uninviting, Mandi Silcox, the owner of Park Row Floats has dispelled that assumption with every tour she has given of her state-of-the-art facility since it opened in the spring of 2023.
Before she was giving these tours, Silcox had spent much of her career in education, teaching middle school in Kent County and then teaching and administrating at a private school in Delaware.
While teaching, Silcox had always contemplated owning a small business—someday, although she was uncertain what type of business it would be. And then, while vacationing a few years ago, she was introduced to a unique concept.
"My husband and I were on vacation, and he asked if I wanted to do a float. 'Do you want to do this float spa thing, this sensory deprivation thing? he said.'"
Silcox said she tacitly agreed in her effort to be open to new things. The couple did two floats at the same time for 90 minutes and then a 45-minute sauna.
"And in the sauna, I turned to my husband and said, 'This is what I want to do. I want to open a float spot. This is amazing.'"
Going from school-to-spa would not happen overnight. Silcox said she knew she needed comprehensive training and set out to do her research. She found an established and successful mentorship-oriented program and hit the ground running.
"I took a class on how to do the build out, how to do it safely, how to do it cleanly, how to do it so that the salt, which is super corrosive, doesn't eat apart your building," she said. Each float chamber utilizes 1,000 pounds of Epsom salts in its operation.
Her husband, Jay, a structural engineer, helped conceive the build-out, and Holman Building of Chestertown executed the plans.
Walking into the totally renovated space, there's a holistic, modern vibe. The facility is spotless, streamlined and light-filled.
Silcox provides each client with comprehensive, "pre-float" instructions and a run-down of cabin particulars to maximize the benefits of the float session, and she is ready to answer any and all questions about what customers might experience during and after the session.
Silcox has also schooled herself on the burgeoning research that is being conducted on the benefits of all the services she offers and is quick to share that upon request. Another question, she said she is happy to answer for prospective clients is how the facility's filtration systems work.
The system, which she said, is "very robust" and best-in-class, is designed specifically for float tanks, using a three-cycle filtration process, and an optimal micron filter. The water is then exposed to UV light and goes through an additional process where the water is injected with ozone.
"We have all these things combined to make sure that the water is perfect, and then we add an optional process where we add one-third of an ounce of 35% hydrogen peroxide to the water between every single client."
And at the end of every session, each client is invited to transition back to the real world by spending time in the facility's refreshing communal space, which Silcox calls the "plant room." This area is infused with natural light and offers a cozy respite with complimentary water and tea, and electrolyte beverages for purchase.
Silcox is pleased to report that feedback on her business model has so far been very positive, as more and more people are looking for ways to enhance their health and totally unplug from life's daily stressors.
"Everyone walks out of here asking, 'When can I do that again?'" she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily profiles a new local business (Park Row Floats) and its operations, making Business/Economy the best fit, while also discussing health benefits, placing Health as a secondary candidate.

title: Boys and Girls Club, Mace's Lane Community Center work on closing funding gap
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Boys and Girls Club, Mace's Lane Community Center work on closing funding gap

 November 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 568
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — With hopes to begin the third phase of a project to create the Mace's Lane Community Center, the Boys and Girls Clubs of Metropolitan Baltimore and community center are working to close a funding gap.When complete, the community center will host a Boys and Girls Club. The facility will have a gym, tech lab, game room and classrooms. It will also have a museum and cultural center to honor the area's African American history during and following segregation.
"We have a lot of work to do," Jeff Breslin, president and CEO of the Boys and Girls Clubs of Metropolitan Baltimore, said during a Dorchester Chamber of Commerce luncheon on Oct. 29. "We're still fundraising every single day."
With about $8 million raised so far, Breslin said there is a $4.5 million funding gap. He said they feel confident in getting $3 million of that funding and so they are pushing for the final $1.5 million.
Breslin said so far, the building — which is the vacant Mace's Lane High School — has had its roof and windows replaced and its facade updated. He said there have been remediation efforts inside, including asbestos removal.
"But really, we're just about shovel-ready to get the inside done," he said in an interview.
Breslin said the start of the project's third phase, which they hope to begin in early 2025, is dependent on funding.
The Rev. Keith Cornish said raising the remaining funds for the project will ensure "everyone wins."
"Every part of our society will be impacted," he said about the community center.
Cornish is board president of Mace's Lane Community Center, a nonprofit that was formed by the Good Shepherd Association and the Mace's Lane High School Alumni Association. He compared the Boys and Girls Club at Mace's Lane Community Center to fertilizer for the school system.
"When they come alongside and help the school system, everyone benefits," he said.
Breslin said across the country, every dollar invested in the Boys and Girls Clubs returns $10.32 in economic benefits to club members, their families and society. He said in Maryland, every dollar invested in the Boys and Girls Clubs returns $7.64.
Breslin said that since opening the Boys and Girls Club at Leonards Lane in Cambridge in 2021, there has been a 35% decrease in juvenile crime within 0.3 miles of the club. He said that percentage has been controlled for recent juvenile reform laws.
"Ultimately it just means that when kids have somewhere safe and predictable and hopeful to go, we know what it does for the community," Breslin said.
During the lunch, Breslin introduced Leonards Lane Club Manager Gabe Butler and the organization's Manager of Community and Youth Support Kentavius Jones.
Butler said when kids come into the club, they are given dinner and time for homework help and tutoring before going through Boys and Girls Club programming. Programs deal with health and wellness, career and workforce readiness, social emotional wellness, and more. After programming, the children are given time to "just have fun and play," Butler said.
Jones talked about the importance of focussing on social emotional learning. He said COVID-19 had a negative impact on the social emotional wellness of this generation of kids.
"So learning healthy connections, how to relate to people, how to express what you're thinking, what's going on — our kids are struggling with that," he said.
Those who are interested in donating to the Mace's Lane Community Center project can donate at bgcmetrobaltimore.org/donate or maceslanecc.org/. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on closing a funding gap for a community center, discusses fundraising amounts, economic impact of the Boys and Girls Club, and investment returns, making Business/Economy the strongest match.

title: Tilghman Island Day celebrates maritime Maryland
author: TIMOTHY LLOYD TILGHMAN
content:
Tilghman Island Day celebrates maritime Maryland

 November 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TIMOTHY LLOYD TILGHMAN | Section: News 
 
 596
 Words 

 Read News Document

 My recommendation is to drop anchor during the next Tilghman Island Day in October 2025. The Chesapeake Bay and Choptank River are the waterways that initially attracted settlers to the region seeking to establish themselves on the waterfront, participate in a marine trade and raise a familyTilghman Island Day is a unique maritime festival sponsored annually by the Tilghman Island Volunteer Fire Company. Tourists enjoyed a unique opportunity to experience the ambiance of maritime Maryland when skipjacks ruled the Chesapeake Bay. Small businesses, historic residences, a maritime museum, an elementary school, a post office and Dogwood Harbor coalesce to validate the hometown charm of Tilghman Island.
Saturday, Oct. 19, highlighted perfect sailing weather under sunny skies for visitors to walkabout the Tilghman Island neighborhood.
Tilghman Island Day celebrates Maryland's Eastern Shore watermen and their livelihood. Tilghman Island embodies the ongoing traditions of a nautical industry that thrives on Maryland's Eastern Shore.
Married couples, young families, groups of friends and single parties turned out in numbers to spend their afternoon enjoying all that Tilghman Island Day has to offer. The Tilghman Country Store provided a special menu in addition to real Maryland crabs. Besides seafood, there was a barbecue pit available in the rear of the park and a fresh squeezed lemonade stand.
Tourism, marinas, agriculture, crabbing and oyster harvesting exemplify the broader activities of Maryland's watermen community. Seafood dining and hospitality are major attractions. Tilghman Island is the picture-perfect weekend getaway destination. No hustle, no bustle, just appreciate the easy-going atmosphere of the close nit village. A splendid time was guaranteed for all.
Seth Foster was granted the island in 1659. Tilghman Island was recognized by Talbot County as Great Choptank Island in 1707. Other names included Foster's Island and Ward's Island before Matthew Tilghman obtained the island in 1741. Early industry on Tilghman Island showcased steamboat service and seafood harvesting employing watermen and establishing a vibrant maritime community.
The Chesapeake Bay was a hotbed of activity during the War of 1812. The British fleet was busy raiding and occupying colonial communities along the shorelines of the Eastern Shore. Tilghman Island itself was subjected to British military interference during 1813 and 1814. The Red Coats had erected a barracks on the island that was later abandoned. Bennett's Point 1813, Caulk's Field 1814 and James Island 1815 each experienced hotspots of engagement.
Later in the 1800s, Gen. Tench Tilghman purchased lands beyond the busy drawbridge that constitutes the locality representing the businesses and residences that signify Tilghman, Maryland. A distinguishing house construction known as the "W" is now a scarce structure on the island. Employment opportunities welcomed relocation to Tilghman Island following the Civil War.
My father drove me and my sister to attend the 1988 Tilghman Island Day celebration. I have returned to sightsee at Tilghman Island, St. Michaels and Oxford infrequently over the years. Specifically, I collect round iron postal cancellations from these post offices occasionally. I bought a couple of Tilghman Island postcards that now promote the date of 1752.
President Ronald Wilson Reagan visited the Tilghman Island Volunteer Fire House during a tour of Maryland's Eastern Shore on July 10, 1984. Residents speak fondly of the presidential visit and are happy to share their personal memories four decades later. Capt. Wade Murphy recalls three helicopters flew onto the island to obfuscate his arrival. Fifty local watermen attended the luncheon.
Consider visiting the village in August as bountiful monarch butterflies descend upon the island before migrating to Mexico. Several restaurants offer top-quality seafood and there are numerous choices to reserve a good night's rest. Tilghman Island scenery offers visiting guests an idyllic vacation. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a local maritime festival that promotes tourism, highlights local businesses, seafood, and the economic impact of watermen, making Business/Economy the strongest fit.

title: Local brewer collaborates with brewery to unveil beer for Waterfowl
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Local brewer collaborates with brewery to unveil beer for Waterfowl

 November 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 599
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Some people keep lists of potential baby names. Doug Greene keeps lists of potential beer names."I have a whole list on my phone of beer names," he said.
The Bird Nickel Brewing Company owner's passion for making beer started with a home brewing kit in 2009. Eight years later, Greene took a beer business course, and 10 years later, he incorporated Bird Nickel Brewing. In 2021, he graduated from American Brewers Guild, a brewing school in Vermont.
Although he's still looking for a brick-and-mortar brewery, Greene has done contract brewing, where he employs another brewery to brew beer for him. Through contract brewing, he has created brews with names like "Slick Calm Chesapeake Ale" and "Quite the Mixture."
Greene said the beer names often come from observation or overheard phrases. Slick calm, he said, is a term for when water is "smooth like glass."
Bird Nickel Brewing's latest creation — a limited edition collaboration with Salisbury-based Burnish Brewing Company and Waterfowl Festival Inc. — is "In Flight," a winter lager.
The beer will be released for the Waterfowl Festival so that attendees can sip on the limited edition brew while they throw back oysters and chow down on other Eastern Shore fare.
The lager has subtle notes of cinnamon, nutmeg and pear. Greene said different people might pick up on different notes.
"What we didn't want to do is overwhelm people with cinnamon," he said. "We want to make it enjoyable for everyone."
Waterfowl Festival Executive Director Deena Kilmon said the beer goes perfectly with hors d'oeuvres like oysters.
"Like when you're getting ready to eat dinner and you just really have something special to start," she said.
Greene, an Easton native, has "always wanted to do a beer for the Waterfowl Festival." The festival has been a part of his life for years, whether volunteering as a "duck sitter" in high school or walking the festival on the hunt for food trucks as an adult.
Greene's favorite memories of the event are walking down Harrison Street and seeing all the different vendors.
In the summer, Kilmon reached out to Greene about making a beer for the festival. This is the first year the festival is collaborating with brewers to make a special beer. The idea was one Greene had brought up to Kilmon years ago.
"When I became executive director in March, it was one of our first conversations about how we finally felt like it was the right year to launch it," Kilmon said.
Once Greene got Burnish Brewing on board, it was all systems go.
The label wrapped around the can is also a local effort. Maggii Sarfaty, an Easton artist, designed the label. On it, the festival's mission of conservation, education and research to protect local wildlife and habitats is written.
A portion of the proceeds from beer sales will go toward the Waterfowl Festival to fund education and conservation, Kilmon said.
Greene said having his beer at the festival is an important milestone.
"Especially for my business," he said. "And being able to create something for the festival instead of just being a resident or a ticket holder. I'm actually a part of it."
In Flight will be available at the festival's Premier Night on Nov. 7 in all the art pavilions. It will be free to VIP ticket holders while supplies last. Throughout the weekend, VIP ticket holders can request In Flight in the VIP hospitality suite. In Flight can be purchased at the new Duck Blind Bar located within the Avalon Theatre. Festival participants will also be able to sample the beer in the tasting pavilion located on Dover Street with the purchase of a tasting pavilion ticket. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a local brewer's business collaboration to create a limited‑edition beer for a community festival, highlighting product development, marketing, and economic impact, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Waterfowl Festival has economic impact of more than $3 million each year
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Waterfowl Festival has economic impact of more than $3 million each year

 November 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 503
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County Economic Development and Tourism Director Cassandra Vanhooser considers the Waterfowl Festival a crossroads between art, community and business."And some would argue —including I would argue — that those are the things that make Talbot County so strong and such a special place," she said.
During the festival's Impact Business Networking Breakfast Friday, the connection between art, community and business was in full force. Community members ambled the PNC Pavilion on Harrison Street, mingling with each other and gazing at art.
Waterfowl Festival Executive Director Deena Kilmon said the breakfast, hosted by The Arc Central Chesapeake Region and Talbot County Economic Development and Tourism, is a venue for the community and business leaders to meet and talk about the festival as well as what's going on in town.
"What economic development things are happening in the community, what's going to impact us coming up in the next few months," Kilmon said.
Kilmon called the relationship between the festival and local businesses "incredibly important."
"We're symbiotic," she said. "So if they succeed, we succeed and vice versa."
The three-day festival has an economic impact of more than $3 million each year, Kilmon said. It benefits hotels, restaurants, retailers and even local nonprofits.
"It's typically one of the biggest fundraising events of the year because a lot of the food vendors and people involved in the festival, they are nonprofits," Kilmon said. "And they're allowed to keep their proceeds, so it's extremely important to a lot of people."
Jonathon Rondeau, president and CEO of The Arc Central Chesapeake Region, said this is The Arc's fourth year sponsoring the breakfast event.
"As a provider that's focused on housing and services, we believe strongly in investing in the communities where we serve," he said. "And the Waterfowl being a signature event for the town that connects conservation and art and economic development, (it) aligns to the work that we do."
Addressing attendees of the breakfast Friday morning, Rondeau talked about the importance of that involvement in communities.
"And so we're incredibly proud to partner The Arc around this and to align the connection of art, conservation, economic development and, most importantly, community," he said. "In this day and age, that's what each of us are looking for."
The breakfast's keynote speaker, Carl Anderton, who is currently serving as the director of rural economic strategy in the Maryland Department of Commerce, talked about the importance of the business community. He called the opportunity to provide jobs a "generational blessing."
"When you employ someone, you're giving them an income, yes, but you're also letting that trickle down to the generations behind them," he said, "and it's just truly amazing."
Vanhooser thanked attendees for doing business in the county. She said it's the business community that makes the "wonderful things" that happen in the county possible.
"It's that private investment along with the public investment that builds the community," she said. "And it's the festivals like the Waterfowl Festival — the granddaddy of them all — that weaves that fabric of the quality of life that we all love so much." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the Waterfowl Festival's economic impact, business networking, tourism, and its benefits to local businesses, making Business/Economy the most fitting category, with Arts & Culture as a secondary theme.

title: Infrastructure spending needs to use common sense
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Infrastructure spending needs to use common sense

 November 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 730
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In late October, President Biden visited Baltimore to announce that the Maryland Port Administration will receive $147 million in federal funds for infrastructure improvements.During his visit, Biden did not acknowledge or address serious issues with another much larger federally funded infrastructure project in Baltimore.
That project is construction of a new $6 billion Frederick Douglass Tunnel in Baltimore for Amtrak, America's quasi-public rail passenger company.
The current tunnel is over 150 years old and is a major bottleneck on Amtrak's high-speed northeast corridor passenger rail service between Boston and Washington, D.C.
As a long-time, staunch supporter of Amtrak, I understand the need for this long overdue tunnel replacement project.
That said, I am stunned and disheartened by how much this project has been mismanaged.
In early October, Amtrak's Office of Inspector General released a scathing report on this project.
The mission of Amtrak's inspector general is simple and straightforward.
Conduct and supervise independent and objective audits, inspections, evaluations and investigations relating to agency programs and operations; promote economy, effectiveness and efficiency within the agency; prevent and detect fraud, waste and abuse in agency programs and operations.
Consistent with their mission, in the inspector general's report on the Baltimore tunnel project, they noted that Amtrak did not establish a program management structure early enough. As a result, they struggled to complete the necessary planning in scheduling, communications, document management and risk management for this project on a timely basis.
The inspector general criticized Amtrak's initial assignment for project management responsibility of a $6 billion dollar project to a single individual.
Eventually, the program team was expanded to seven members, but five told Office of Inspector General auditors that they were still overwhelmed by their workload.
Amtrak officials have since acknowledged staffing was insufficient and said the Capital Delivery team should have been staffed before it received responsibility for the program.
Amtrak later decided to hire a "delivery partner" to provide management and oversight, but that contractor wasn't engaged until the spring of this year. Amtrak officials agreed that the decision "should have been made earlier" to "maximize the benefits the delivery partner was intended to provide." As a result, the new contractor has to plan a management structure as it also prepares for construction.
The Office of Inspector General report made three recommendations:
Complete program management planning for the tunnel project.Establish processes to ensure the a project's management structure is established early enough to produce strong oversight for the life of the project.Establish processes to ensure program teams have sufficient staff before projects are assigned to the Capital Delivery department.
Amtrak management, in their response to the report, agreed with the recommendations and outlined how it is acting to meet those goals.
The inspector general's report concludes the project now "faces a significantly increased risk of cost overruns and additional delays as it proceeds into major construction." The report does not include projections for future cost overruns and additional delays.
On a $6 billion construction project, one thing is almost certain. Cost overruns and completion delays will likely be substantial. As a result, funds needed for other Amtrak service improvements to increase ridership and reduce their government subsidies will not be available.
I am sure this colossal mismanagement of federal funding by Amtrak is not unique.
Unfortunately, conventional thinking is public infrastructure projects completion delays and cost overruns are standard operating procedure. In other words, this is the way it has always been and the way it will always be.
That thinking needs to change especially when the federal budget deficit is at record levels, currently at $1.83 trillion and growing.
Former U.S. Sen. Everett Dirksen once observed, "A billion dollars here and a billion dollars there and pretty soon you are talking real money."
Many Americans are carefully monitoring their budgets and adjusting their spending habits on a regular, even daily, basis in order to pay their bills for basic living expenses.
Going forward, we need and deserve elected and appointed officials at every level of government to take appropriate steps to ensure funding for all government funded infrastructure improvement projects is spent efficiently and effectively.
They need to address the fact the current audit process is largely reactive, not proactive.
Concurrently, government project managers must be fully aware of and committed to best practice project management policies and procedures prior to and during large scale and complex infrastructure improvement projects.
It is common sense to help ensure things go right in the first place as opposed to learning what went wrong after the fact. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses federal infrastructure funding, cost overruns, and management of a large $6 billion Amtrak tunnel project, focusing on economic implications and government spending efficiency, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Dollar General opens in Trappe
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Dollar General opens in Trappe

 November 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 359
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TRAPPE — A Dollar General has opened in Trappe, bringing with it fresh produce, toys and essentials. The new store opened on Ocean Gateway near the U-Haul Moving & Storage earlier this month.The Dollar General is ready to serve new and established residents in Trappe who previously had to drive to Cambridge or Easton to secure groceries and other household goods.
The Dollar General's Public Relations team said the store believes in providing positive economic benefits including additional access to affordable products for customers; new job opportunities for local residents; generation of additional tax revenue for the town; and the ability to support local nonprofits, schools and libraries through the Dollar General Literacy Foundation.
"Dollar General is deeply involved in the communities it serves and is an ardent supporter of literacy and education through the Dollar General Literacy Foundation, which awards grants each year to nonprofit organizations, schools and libraries within a 15-mile radius of a Dollar General store or distribution center to support adult, family, summer and youth literacy programs," said an email from the Dollar General.
Though the Dollar General's Public Relations team stated that the store chain is not a grocer, there is a public investment in the health of "our hometown communities." Emphasizing the fresh produce stocked in more than 5,400 Dollar General stores.
The Dollar General was constructed by local entrepreneur Tom Mitchell, president of Delmarva Management Group and a Trappe business owner. Mitchell's previous business ventures include the Coffee Trappe, Cork & Bottle Trappe Liquor Store and Momma Maria's Mediterranean Bistro.
Mitchell said in a previous interview that he seeks to invest and add new businesses to the town in the upcoming years. Additionally, Mitchell said that the two lots next to the Dollar General are in discussion of new development, including a potential quick-service restaurant franchise.
The public relations team for the Dollar General said they are excited to invest in towns like Trappe and plan to employ approximately 10 to 15 employees in the upcoming months.
"As part of our mission of 'Serving Others,' we look forward to serving the Trappe community as a positive business partner and good community neighbor," the email from Dollar General said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Alpacas, lunch and learn for Caroline Women in Business
author: Tom McCall
content:
Alpacas, lunch and learn for Caroline Women in Business

 November 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 374
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PRESTON — Zen, mindfulness and alpacas brought over 20 female leaders together on Tuesday.The super soft animals followed the women, who were all armed with green feed buckets, around in a pasture at Outstanding Dreams Alpaca Farm. This was the site of lunch and learn for the Caroline County Women in Business.
It was a fun moment of delight to see and touch these creatures from the Andes.
"Look at them following her. This is hilarious," Tracey Snyder, director of the Caroline County Chamber of Commerce, said.
"We love the alpaca farm. This is the second time the chamber has been here. Women in Business meets quarterly. We're going to eat a sack lunch from the Culinary Center. We are going to do a little sip and shop and we have Michelle Hammond as our guest speaker. She is going to show us how to be a little more zen in our hectic lives," Snyder said.
Owner of Outstanding Dreams Alpaca Farm Phil Liske gave a talk on the animal's behavior.
After the animal interaction, it was time to listen to the keynote speaker, healer Michelle Boulden Hammond.
"We are talking about mindfulness today. It is a peaceful forum and how to handle stress today. Some spiritual message like how to learn about frequencies. Learn about how to get yourself grounded. We will learn stress management techniques," Hammond said.
She said it is even beneficial for the animals and their frequencies. She specializes in sound healing.
"We are going to do a little breath work. I have got my sound bowls. I got my tuning forks and I have my ocean drum. So I will give a little demonstration. I have a brass and I have a crystal bowl," Hammond said.
She also had a comment on the current moment.
"In these times of high stress, there is a lot of hostility. You have got to learn to get grounded and centered. Always reflect the negativity with the goodness," Hammond said.
One participant was Nikendra Bordley, who runs the hair salon Scalp Reveals in Federalsburg. She specializes in dreadlocks.
"I love it. It is a new experience," she said about the event Tuesday. "I have never seen alpacas. I have only known of llamas. I like seeing everybody getting together and the other Chamber members."
