llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a Chamber of Commerce‑organized lunch‑and‑learn event for women in business, focusing on networking, professional development, and mindfulness, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Garden Girl coming to downtown Rising Sun
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@ceciwlhig.com
content:
Garden Girl coming to downtown Rising Sun

 November 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@ceciwlhig.com | Section: News 
 
 313
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Look for Garden Girl to bloom on East Main Street in Rising Sun next year, incorporating its salads, soups, sandwiches and acai bowls the food offerings of Rise N Grind Cafe."I always go out and look for healthy options," said Natalie Vanderhoef, owner of Garden Girl, now under construction at the corner of East Main and South Queen Street. "I couldn't think of a better place than Main Street."
In fact, Rise N Grind is converting its outdoor patio to indoor seating and the seating at Garden Girl will be made available to the coffee shop customers, and vice versa.
"We'll still have outdoor seating but now we're building a porch on the Main Street side," said Angie Vanderhoef, owner of Rise N Grind and Natalie's mother. "We're growing the indoor space and we'll have 50 more spaces when you include the enclosed patio."
Natalie has been working at Rise N Grind since it opened in 2018 but this is her first restaurant.
"I have really learned from my mom's dedication to growing her business," she said. "But it's always been my dream to open my own business."
Construction to turn the office building into a restaurant began three months ago.
"We want it to feel like you're in a farmhouse ... like your great grandmom's kitchen," Angie Vanderhoef said the goal for casual dining. "With an updated interior but in a cozy home."
Natalie is getting ready to start shopping for vendors including searching for locally sourced food to use for her menu.
"We are also going to be having vendors in the building," Natalie said. "We want to support more local entrepreneurs."
Natalie expressed her gratitude for the support she is receiving even though her grand opening won't happen until January.
"I am getting support like no other," she said. "I am unbelievably grateful to the people and the town. Without them I would not be able to do this." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the opening of a new restaurant, its owners, construction, and local economic impact, which aligns best with the Business/Economy category.

title: Talbot Works Business Academy graduates 8 small businesses
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot Works Business Academy graduates 8 small businesses

 November 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 392
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A Talbot County initiative training small businesses and minority business leaders celebrated a graduation on Tuesday.The Talbot Works Business Academy, led by the county's economic development and tourism department, brought in eight small businesses for its second round of training in September. Following eight weeks of meetings and assistance, those businesses completed the academy.
Two business leaders spoke Tuesday at Talbot County Council, reflecting on how the academy helped them expand their ventures. Stefanie DiFiglia, founder of Two Tree Integrative Health, said "the program couldn't have come at a better time."
"I had grown pretty slowly, organically through word of mouth, and that only works until it doesn't," DiFiglia said. "I found myself in a situation where I had hired new staff and was really trying to figure out how to use them in the best way possible."
She said she feels she's in a "much better position now" than where she was before entering the program.
Anijah Wilson, owner of home health care service Libby's Loving Hands, also spoke to the council.
"We have had great benefit from this program," Wilson said. "I've learned a lot about numbers, marketing, laws, HR. And I'm so excited to see what comes from this, and grow my business and community."
The training program was created by Will Holmes Consulting, a Baltimore-based business management firm. Founder Will Holmes shared details of the program with the County Council.
"We focus heavily on cash flow projections as a foundation of the program to make sure that people understand their numbers so they can plan ahead when to hire people, when to expand and how much it will cost," Holmes said. "It helps them with their pricing. It helps them with understanding how to access capital."
Cassandra Vanhooser, Talbot County's director of economic development and tourism, said funding from the Maryland Rural Economic Development Fund helped launch the program, which graduated its first cohort of 15 businesses earlier in the year.
Vanhooser added that the Mid-Shore Regional Council is funding a third cohort this winter. She said the county contributed American Rescue Plan Act funds for cohorts in the future.
"I just want to say thank you again to the County Council, to all of you for your support," Vanhooser said. "(Council Member Keasha Haythe) especially, for your idea of bringing this to me. I think it's been five years but we got it done." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a county-run business academy that trains and graduates small businesses, highlighting economic development initiatives and funding, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic.

title: 'A full circle moment': Maryland entrepreneur makes childhood dream a reality
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com
content:
'A full circle moment': Maryland entrepreneur makes childhood dream a reality

 November 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com | Section: News 
 
 375
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There's a new place to grab a cup of coffee and something gooey and sweet in the northernmost reaches of Maryland's Eastern Shore and it's called Izzy's Coffee House.'Izzy' is Izabelle Upp, and she opened Izzy's Coffee House earlier this month in the former Little Lamb Cafe at 2728 Augustine Herman Highway in Chesapeake City.
Upp saw herself owning a coffee shop in 7th grade. Born and raised in Cecilton, she graduated from Bohemia Manor High School in 2016 and now has a degree in veterinary medicine. However, her mother commented she should own a coffee shop and then she noticed Little Lamb was closing.
"It was a full circle moment and now here I am," Upp said. "It was just one of those things that kind of happened."
Upp had help from family and friends to give the shop a new coat of paint and new decor including pictures of her as she grew up, and furniture from the family home.
"I wanted people to get a grasp of who I am," she said, adding, "I wanted to communicate that you can come here and everyone can feel like family."
That family feel includes using products from nearby businesses and giving shelf space to local entrepreneurs.
"I use regional bakeries in Middletown, Delaware and the breakfast sandwiches made fresh come from 410-Seafood," Upp said, referring to the eatery a few doors down. Lockbriar in Chestertown is where she gets honey and ice cream for the menu, but also has their pasta sauce for sale on the shelf.
In the short time she's been open Upp said it's been fun to share her coffee knowledge with her customers. She offers hot and iced coffee, with or without espresso and already has customers returning to order a specific flavor called The Cortado.
"It's an espresso shot and steamed milk," she said, explaining the unique flavor blend. "Our coffee is traditional and authentic."
Izzy's Coffee House is open 6 a.m. until 2 p.m. Monday through Friday and from 7 a.m. until 2 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. Use the Clover app to order in advance.
Find the menu online at: https://www.izzyscoffeehouseccity.com
Call 410-885-7012 for more information.
Speaking of menu, feel free to bring your canine companion because there's a Pup Cup on the independent local coffee shop's menu too. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article profiles a local entrepreneur opening a coffee shop, focusing on the new business, its operations, and its impact on the community, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Hundreds of laid-off miners mull their futures as winter begins
author: JACI WEBB Outlook Editor
content:
Hundreds of laid-off miners mull their futures as winter begins

 November 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JACI WEBB Outlook Editor | Section: News 
 
 1206
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Eric Giesick thought he hit the jackpot when he landed a job at Sibanye-Stillwater mine in 2011. Growing up in Billings, he and his family often camped at Woodbine Campground near Nye, and Giesick would watch the big trucks go rumbling down the mountain loaded with ore from the mine. He told his folks he planned to work there one day.The last 13 years at the mine have had a permanent impact on Giesick, now 49 and living in Columbus. There were good times, challenges with historic flooding in 2022, new mine owners to adjust to, and now this — the layoff of as many as 700 miners, including Giesick. Giesick's last day at Sibanye-Stillwater was Nov. 8. He picked up his gear and walked away just after sunrise that morning.
It came as somewhat of a relief. The months of uncertainty were over.
"I'm kind of sad. I'm going to going to miss being underground. Mining gets in your blood."
'Looking for people to blame'
Giesick joins hundreds of others who worked at the mine, all trying to figure out what the next step is. The Montana Department of Labor & Industry organized a rapid response information event the week of Nov. 12, which was when the layoffs were finalized, and experts in employment, education, training and insurance helped miners consider their next move. Sibanye-Stillwater mine announced in September that it was laying off up to 700 miners from its workforce of 1,900 miners.
Elizabeth and Mitchell Ramba, of Red Lodge, started their career with Sibanye-Stillwater right out of college. The married couple graduated from the University of Colorado in Boulder with geology degrees, and were excited to begin their careers in hard-rock mining in 2020. Their first day on the job was Nov. 2, 2020, and on Sept. 12, they were notified that their jobs were being eliminated.
"There has been a lot of mistrust and hate. You want to look for people to blame, but it's the market shifts and other factors. I don't think it was any individual's fault," Elizabeth said.
They built a life in the mountain town of Red Lodge, fell in love with Montana, and got hooked on mining. They each worked with a team of miners and went in to inspect the operation between the drilling and the blasting.
After taking a break to go back home to Ohio and visit their families, the couple will begin the process of looking for work, most likely in the mining industry. But there is one thing that holds them back.
"A lot of places that have mines aren't as pretty as Montana," Mitchell said.
New job, new mine
Giesick starts his new job Dec. 12 at the Montana Resources open pit copper mine in Butte, but that's 185 miles away from his family back home in Columbus. He'll cross the Continental Divide on his commute to work, and start a new chapter in open pit mining.
There were many good years working at Sibanye-Stillwater mine. Giesick enjoyed the work and forged friendships with miners from all over the world. Miners are a tight brotherhood and sisterhood, connected now mostly through social media.
Giesick and some of his carpool buddies gathered for one last Taco Tuesday at the 5 Spot bar in Absarokee on Nov. 12. Like other businesses in the area, the 5 Spot will suffer with the loss of hundreds miners and their families.
Giesick counted all the ways he felt the company mismanaged funds, including buying equipment that wouldn't fit the tracks, and his favorite: putting in heated sidewalks at the mine.
Angry miners have been spray painting derogatory messages toward some of the management on the walls of the mine. Giesick said that is why some miners were invited to leave early. He heard about the offer, and asked if he could leave a few days early as well. His last day was originally scheduled for Nov. 12.
Another job, another layoff
Dustin Stanfield started his job with Sibanye-Stillwater in July, after a contractor he worked for, Moran Mining and Tunneling lost their contract with the mine. He feels like he was hired to be laid off to protect another miner's position.
"There were several of us hired on so the miners with seniority could stay. It's just part of it," Stanfield said.
Stanfield knows about layoffs. Originally from Oklahoma where he started working in the oil fields in Texas and Oklahoma, he was transferred to Douglas, Wyo., where he worked in the oil fields for 11 years before he got laid off. At Sibanye, he drove the muck truck. He missed his work with Moran on the raise crew where he helped with blasting for a little over a year, but he did like driving the truck through the slippery tunnels.
Now Stanfield is stuck. he doesn't have the 3-5 years of mining experience to transfer to another mine, and he doesn't want to battle the elements again in the oil fields of Wyoming. He hopes to get some training for a new career path.
'I needed two more years'
Annette McFarland, of Columbus, was the chief mining engineer until the November layoffs. She has spent 32 years working in mining, the last five at Sibanye-Stillwater. She was near the end of her career.
"I needed two more years," McFarland said.
Months before she was informed in September that her job was gone, McFarland got nervous.
"In April, I put my property on the market and sold it in May."
She bought property in Byron, Wyo., and is building a house there as she continues to look for work. McFarland worries about agism as she navigates the application process searching for another job in mining.
"There is a camaraderie, a fellowship in mining. People who mine are the hardest working, most dedicated people I know. It's a high-risk job, and you're doing everything you can to make sure everybody goes home safe," McFarland said.
'It's just sad'
Betty Kilburn, of Livingston, worked as an underground operator at the Sibanye-Stillwater East Boulder Mine for 22 years. She took a voluntary layoff to save someone else's job.
"It was so fast. You had a job one day, you didn't know if you had one the next," Kilburn said.
She talked the options over with her husband, Paul Rugh, who is a salaried supervisor at the mine. Rugh kept his job.
"It breaks my heart, it really does," Kilburn said. "There are a lot of people living paycheck to paycheck. My husband said, 'Babe, we're not hurting as much as other people are. If you take this layoff, you can give somebody else a job that probably really needs it."
So that's what she did.
"Everybody is sad," Kilburn said. "Everybody is just going to be uprooted. Now you're splitting up families. The husband is on the road, and the wife is home raising the kids."
Dan Beluscak, president of the United Steelworkers Local 11-0001, said there are many fathers and sons, and husbands and wives, who work at the mine. It's a proud legacy that miners passed on to the next generation.
"We were promised that our kids' kids could work at the mine," Beluscak said. "What happens when half of us have to leave? It's the schools and the businesses that are going to hurt the most. We built up these towns of Absarokee, Nye and Fishtail. We've raised our kids here." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on large-scale layoffs at a mining company, the economic impact on workers and local communities, and the response by a state labor department, making it primarily a business/economic story.

title: Maryland chocolatier takes part in NYC. competition
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Maryland chocolatier takes part in NYC. competition

 November 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 618
 Words 

 Read News Document

 She may not have emerged as the overall winner of the recent Grow-NY Food and Ag Summit held recently in New York City, but Bon AppéSweet owner Thereasa Black is killing it on seemingly every other front from her Leonardtown chocolate shop.Bon AppéSweet uses simple, ethically sourced ingredients free of added sugar and artificial sweeteners to make date-sweetened chocolate products such as chocolate bars, trail mix, chocolate-covered almonds, raisins and espresso beans. The products are all organic, vegan and non-GMO.
The winner of the 10-week Grow-NY business development program and live pitch at the Grow-NY Summit, which was held in early November and offered a $1 million first prize, went to New York City's Unibaio, which offers naturally derived particles that trap the active ingredients of pesticides, fertilizers and phytosanitary, enabling them to penetrate plants more efficiently.
"Grow-NY finalists and symposium speakers brought their fresh ideas about strengthening our food system and building our regional economy to life at the summit," Grow-NY Program Director Jenn Smith said in a news release. "Anyone who wants to see solutions in the food and ag landscape can be a force for change."
Leonardtown-based Bon AppéSweet was one of 20 start-ups — among 312 applicants — in the competition, which awarded $3 million in total prize money to "advance innovation in food, agriculture, and sustainable technologies," according to a news release.
Black said the application process was "long and intensive" and added the two required trips to New York were "hectic."
But while there, the 44-year-old Leonardtown resident met with industry representatives to find a dairy manufacturer to partner with to start putting her chocolate syrup into milk.
"This is a whole new opportunity I can take advantage of," Black said.
Bon AppéSweet has a brick-and-mortar location in Leonardtown. Part of the business is Better Black Coffee, which is owned by Black and partner Justin Carter, while the other half is comprised of Black's Bon AppéSweet chocolate shop.
The idea for Bon AppéSweet came about when Black was looking for less sugary treats for her daughter, Isabella.
At the time, Black was making date-sweetened gelato and limiting the amount of sweets she gave her daughter. But, while on deployment — Black spent 14 years in the U.S. Navy and had five deployments and is currently in the Reserves — Isabella stayed with a relative and was fed sweets.
"Once they've had it, it's difficult to take [sweets] away from them, so I made a compromise and made the desserts that she loved with the ingredients that I love," Black said. "Because my ice cream needed chocolate, I needed to figure out a chocolate to put in it that didn't have sugar."
She said high-fiber dates with vitamins and minerals and natural sweetness were the food to use instead.
Everything changed during the pandemic when shipping companies could not guarantee next-day delivery, critical in the case of shipping ice cream.
When she won a competition with a local grocer and her chocolate products — which she learned to make through YouTube — began outselling better brands, she made a business decision.
"I pivoted to the chocolate because it was much easier to ship," she said, "and the rest is history."
An added benefit was that her daughter is allergic to soy, and regular chocolate has soy lecithin, so she wasn't even supposed to be eating it.
"When I made my chocolate, I used her as my taster because if she didn't like it," Black said, "obviously no one else was going to."
Bon AppéSweet products are now in more than 500 stores, including Walmart and Whole Foods.
"When people come up to you and say, 'Hey, Thereasa, I saw your chocolate in the store,'" said Black, who thanked her neighbors for their support. "It makes you understand what you're doing." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a local chocolatier's participation in a business development competition, startup growth, prize money, and market expansion, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Donations, events keep Operation Christmas Spirit running
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Donations, events keep Operation Christmas Spirit running

 November 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 325
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The smell of smoked barbecued beef and turkey brought people from all over Easton to partake in the Fresh Pit Beef/Turkey fundraiser on Monday afternoon.This event, catered by Jamie Petrides, raised money to benefit Operation Christmas Spirit, a holiday feast and gift giveaway for those financially struggling during the holiday season.
Operation Christmas Spirit is an annual event started by Lord "Scotty" Scott in the late 1970s. It has grown to serve over 1,000 people in need.
Scott Eglseder, president of Eglseder Wealth Management Group, said this event is dear to him because of the connection he developed with Scotty after his little brother Kurt Wilson Eglseder died in 2016.
"About two weeks after Kurt died, I was walking past his shop, and Scotty just looked at me with a kindness and sincerity that touches me all these years later, and he just says, I'm sorry about your brother, Kurt. And that just obviously stuck with me," Eglseder said.
Scotty died in 2020. Operation Christmas Spirit was revived by the Rotary Club of Easton in 2021, but due to lacking funds, it was expected to only provide for half of the people the program had in the past.
Elgseder said when he heard of the problems with funds he decided help. On behalf of his financial planning company, he pledged to the Rotary Club to post a dollar-for-dollar matching contribution in order to raise enough funds to serve the 1,000 people in need.
On top of the dollar-for-dollar matching contribution, Elgseder's organization has organized 15 events, including the Fresh Pit Beef/Turkey fundraiser. Since 2022, Elgseder has raised over $37,000 for Operation Christmas Spirit.
During the barbecue fundraiser, Elgseder's and his company presented a check for $6,200 the Easton Rotary Club for Operation Christmas Spirit.
"Doing this frequently, it doesn't solve the problem of why we have 1,000 people showing up, but it's a reminder to those of us that have that there are plenty of people who don't," Eglseder said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on fundraising, donations, and financial contributions by a local wealth management firm and Rotary Club to support a charitable program, which aligns best with the Business/Economy category.

title: Moore faces budget dilemma in upcoming session
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Moore faces budget dilemma in upcoming session

 November 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 896
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Almost immediately after Gov. Wes Moore was elected in 2022, political pundits in Maryland and beyond proclaimed Moore is destined to be a president of the United States.Moore, in turn, is doing what one would expect from a potential future presidential candidate.
He supported President Joe Biden for re-election until Biden pulled out of the race. He then threw his support to Vice President Harris. He traveled regularly to speak on her behalf. He gave a prime-time speech at the Democratic National Convention. He helped Democratic Sen.-elect Angela Alsobrooks defeat Larry Hogan in a race previously deemed critical to Democratic Party efforts to retain control of the U.S. Senate.
All these efforts may be overcome by events in Annapolis next year when the General Assembly is back in session.
Prior to adjourning they must approve a state budget and send it to Gov. Moore. Before that happens, the General Assembly will again engage in dialogue, deliberations, and decisions on unfinished business from the last session on state spending and tax increases.
Last session, a compromise was eventually reached on select tax increases, select fee increases, spending cuts, more state borrowing and drawdowns from the state's "rainy day" fund.
This compromise was approved over strong objections of progressive legislators who viewed this outcome as a temporary deal and a short-term delay on future decisions to reject spending cuts and approve tax increases.
Progressives maintain tax increases are essential for full funding of the Blueprint for Maryland's Future (the Kirwan Plan) and for a mass transit system extension in Baltimore.
As often happens in the General Assembly when state spending and tax increases are debated, those debates are overcome by events.
Next year this will be especially true given a recent bleak report from the General Assembly's independent Department of Legislative Services.
That report projects that Maryland is heading into a severe fiscal crisis that could be the worst in 20 years. The report projects a gap between state tax revenues and state spending that is more significant than the outlook the state faced during the Great Recession in 2008-2009.
Budget analysts suggest full funding for the Kirwan Plan is by far the biggest driver of the state's long-term budget problems. They note that starting in the 2028 fiscal year, about $2 billion for Kirwan needs are unfunded, a figure that grows to $3.2 billion in the 2030 fiscal year.
Complicating matters further is uncertainty about how much and when Maryland will get federal funds to replace the former Key Bridge in Baltimore.
Whatever the General Assembly does on the spending budget and taxes, Gov. Moore will have a major and highly visible role starting with submitting a proposed state budget in January. Following General Assembly approval of a budget bill, Moore can agree to it, make line-item vetoes or veto the entire bill. The General Assembly can in turn override those vetoes.
I predict another contentious General Assembly session as there are still deep divides on budget priorities and tax increases between Gov. Moore and the Democratic legislative leaders and progressive Democratic legislators who want tax increases now and who are increasingly unwilling to take no for answer.
Resolving these differences will be even more challenging with a president and Congress planning on significant cuts in federal spending and federal jobs. Both plans will reduce historical levels of federal money coming into Maryland.
Last week, a Baltimore media outlet published a response from the governor's office on two questions — Should Marylanders anticipate any tax or fee increases in the coming years? Does Gov. Moore plan to make any major spending cuts, and, if so, where they might be?
His office responded with this written statement: The budgetary challenges that Maryland faces are as tough as they've ever been, and while the challenges have been years in the making, Governor Moore is committed to continuing to work in collaboration with the dedicated leaders of the state legislature, including Senate President Ferguson and Speaker Jones to fix them. The Moore-Miller Administration has a high bar for increasing the tax burden on Maryland families, and the governor knows the next leg of the mission to address our fiscal challenges will be harder than the last. We will continue the work of prioritizing our expenses and reviewing our revenue model to determine how it aligns with our objectives. Marylanders have come to expect fiscal responsibility from the Moore-Miller Administration and the governor will continue to move forward into the next session with that at the top of his mind.
These are his words now.
The question is, what will his actions be next year and beyond?
I suggest voters should be ever mindful of an answer by Richard Nixon's presidential campaign manager after Nixon's election in 1972. When asked what to expect from the Nixon administration he replied, "Watch what we do, not what we say."
If voters do so that could be problematic for Gov. Moore in pursuit of a presidential bid.
Democratic primary voters may not embrace a Democratic candidate they see with a record of blocking or limiting progressive policy initiatives and higher taxes to pay for them. At the same time, general election voters may not embrace a Democratic candidate they see with a record of supporting progressive policy initiatives and higher taxes to pay for them.
In either case, voters may make voting decisions after deciding if what Gov. Moore said on his intended actions on government spending and tax increases matches what he actually did. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the state budget, fiscal challenges, tax policy, and spending decisions, which are core aspects of business and economic matters rather than sports, health, or cultural topics.

title: Thanksgiving meals are 29% more expensive from 2020
author: Mike Sunnucks
content:
Thanksgiving meals are 29% more expensive from 2020

 November 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks | Section: Food 
 
 278
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The cost of a Thanksgiving dinner is 29% more expensive from 2020, according to a new survey of holiday meal costs by the American Farm Bureau Federation.The Farm Bureau's annual Thanksgiving dinner price survey found holiday meal staples to serve 10 people total $58.08 nationally.
That is down from a record high meal cost of $64.06 in 2022 when the post-pandemic inflation wave was at its highest.
But holiday meal prices are still 24% higher than they were in 2020 in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic's economic and social shutdowns.
Thanksgiving meals cost $46.90 in 2020.
Those prices are based on 10 Thanksgiving food items such as turkey, cranberries and pumpkin pie ingredients.
But if the food list expanded to include potatoes, green beans and ham the average cost in 2024 is $77.34, according to the Farm Bureau.
The same 13 items cost $60.11 in 2020, according to the agriculture group.
That's a 29% rise.
Turkey prices have come down compared to 2023.
Inflation was a top concern of voters in the 2024 presidential election with economically stressed voters preferring now President-elect Donald Trump over Vice President Kamala Harris.
Overall, U.S. prices are up 22% since before the pandemic in 2020, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.
"While inflation has slowed down, it really hasn't slowed down enough to bring costs back down to these pre-pandemic levels. So it's really important to remember that our farmers and ranchers, like our consumers, are also dealing with inflation, so the cost of supplies to grow food has gone up, while USDA predicts that net farm income is going to be down nearly 25 percent compared to just two years ago," said Bernt Nelson, a Farm Bureau economist. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on rising Thanksgiving meal costs, inflation, and consumer price trends, which are core economic issues, while also referencing the Farm Bureau and farm income, linking it to agriculture but primarily to the economy.

title: Denton food pantry provides food for more than 1,000 families
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Denton food pantry provides food for more than 1,000 families

 November 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 354
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Aaron's Place, a food pantry and soup kitchen just northeast of downtown Denton, provided crucial meals, food and drinks to more than 1,000 families last week.On Thursday, volunteers stacked open trunks full of fresh fruit, vegetables, perishables, canned sodas, Thanksgiving desserts and, of course, turkeys. They began distributing the groceries just after 11 a.m., though cars were lined up hours in advance.
Aaron's Place Executive Director Cheryl Beulah said volunteers handed out food until around 7 p.m. Around 1,115 families were served, according to Beulah.
From seeing residents come into the food pantry every week, Beulah says "food insecurity is real." Mary Lou Russ, an administrative assistant at the food pantry, said the amount of need is "overwhelming."
During the pandemic, Beulah says they served around 2,500 people for the Thanksgiving giveaway, an all-time high. The work done by Aaron's Place, which is partnered with the statewide nonprofit Maryland Food Bank, hasn't slowed down at all since 2020.
According to Maryland Hunger Solutions, more than 6,000 Caroline County residents participated in the federal Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program in fiscal year 2022. 2020 census data shows 13.2% of Caroline County residents were below the poverty line, above the then-state average of 9%.
And according to a new survey of holiday meal costs by the American Farm Bureau Federation, the price of a Thanksgiving dinner has risen 29% from 2020. Beulah sees those rising food prices, and says it's a "challenging" time.
She said many of the residents in need, particularly during Thanksgiving and the holidays, are families and people from Caroline County. She also sees growing concern with hunger for the senior community.
Beulah said while discussions pertaining to food insecurity are important, action matters. In part, that's what drives her to lead the Denton food pantry and soup kitchen.
"That conversation's not putting food on that person's table," Beulah said. " … Your neighbors could be starving."
Aaron's Place's food pantry is open Tuesdays from 11:30 a.m. to 3 p.m., Wednesdays from 9:30 a.m. to 3 p.m., and the third Thursday at 11 a.m. in January, March, May, July, September and November. The soup kitchen opens on Tuesdays at Noon. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on food insecurity, poverty rates, and rising food costs, which are economic and social welfare issues rather than sports, education, health, or other listed categories.

title: Heartfelt hospitality is 'baked in'
author: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Heartfelt hospitality is 'baked in'

 November 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Business 
 
 1071
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Fall brings about the busiest time of year for Alicia Boyd, proprietor and head chef of Humble Hearts Catering & Events based in Queen Anne's County.With six years of experience as a small business owner, Boyd relishes this busiest of seasons catering weddings, baby showers and various autumnal celebrations.
Boyd is one of those people who goes about her business day with a genuine smile on her face and a sense of joy in her heart that resonates. She believes she's one of the lucky ones who gets to do what she loves for a living and happily shares that passion with others by sharing what she knows and continues to learn about food.
As she was preparing lunch in Queen Anne's at the Ruthsburg Community Hall — a chicken focaccia with her locally famous chimichurri sauce — she said the facility has been a godsend to her. It offers the key ingredient to the larger recipe for her small business, a licensed commercial kitchen, which she rents.
Boyd, 39, a wife and mother of two, has a culinary degree from Baltimore International College and some rich, Maryland-flavored roots.
"The reason why I'm here, the reason why Humble Hearts is a thing, is because our family grew up here. My family's originally from Virginia, and my grandmother moved down here with her children and she worked on the water," said Boyd. "My whole family worked in oyster houses and shucked clams … my grandmother, my aunt … they worked with the local watermen, and they would make the crab cakes and the oyster fritters and all those different things."
Hospitality, she said, was a way of life in her family, where everyone was welcome at her grandmother's table.
"Food has been my whole life being able to welcome people in, being able to connect with the community. That really has been my whole life," she said.
This extension of her formative years would eventually bring her to Chestertown, where she spent several years honing her skills in the catering departments of Washington College. She has also developed some solid working relationships through its vast network of professors, including Modern Stone Age Kitchen's Bill Schindler.
"While I was at the college, Bill was a professor there, and he was inviting me down to these intimate chef demonstrations," Boyd said. "He was having these different chefs come in from all over the world, and my heart was just jumping out of my chest."
Inspired by these experiences, Boyd felt strongly that after five years with the college, and a couple years of side catering hustles, she was ready to make the leap into catering full-time.
That was in 2020 and one month prior to the pandemic changing the way people would be living and eating. After making such a commitment, Boyd felt there were two possible responses: panic or pivot. Boyd and her team chose the latter.
"We started doing meal deliveries. We were doing deliveries from Cambridge and all the way to Annapolis. And that's what sustained us," said Boyd, who added they also saw this potential game-changer as an opportunity to make an impression and name for themselves in a business that was robust with established competition.
"So, we were coming in [to Ruthsburg Community Center] making meals and delivering everywhere. "For Mother's Day, we did brunch boxes that we were delivering to moms that had greeting cards in the boxes. They had a full-on brunch with a mocktail mixer. We did that for Father's Day, too. We did 'Sweet Success' graduation boxes with four different cupcakes for the kids that were graduating. We just were using ingenuity and grit to be able to say, 'we have to make it.'"
Boyd's approach and unique outreach was obviously successful, and she is happy that her team has been able to grow and build on that. And she is just as committed today to delivering those unique culinary experiences as she was back in 2020.
"I'm a creative and I like doing fun things with food. I like being able to see what's the farthest extent that I can go to with any food that I work with."
Case in point, her team regularly works with community-based organizations and resources to enhance her business's level of expertise and to check-in with the network of regional partners that the business has built. Last summer, Humble Hearts partnered with the Shore Rivers organization and Wildly Native Flower Farm in Chestertown to create a delicious sensory experience with edible flowers for the participants of a talk on the subject that the farm and Shore Rivers was sponsoring.
Boyd's out-side-of-the box, lunch box menu consisted of a focaccia with whipped basil ricotta and heirloom tomatoes accompanied by a fresh watermelon and aronia berry salad, showcased the topic in a deliciously creative way, much to the delight of the attendees.
Boyd said she spent hours with Wildly Native's owner, Liza Goetz, just walking through the vast plots of flowers to learn from Goetz which ones to work with and which to avoid. She revels in these learning experiences and seeks to take on others, so that she can also fulfill a role as a resource to the community that means so much to her.
"I am in this place where I want to learn more about what is out there in my field… so, I am at Cornell University right now working on a Food Product Development Certificate."
Once she acquires that knowledge, she said, she would like to be able to share what she knows with her network of businesses and farms who may be interested in bringing products to market.
In addition to continuing her education, raising her family, and managing a staff of nine on-call employees, Boyd also maintains key relationships with those in the community that have impacted her along the way. You can currently find Boyd already sharing what she knows as a guest chef back at Modern Stone Age Kitchen's Eastern Shore Food Lab where she teaches hands-on cooking classes.
Boyd said she has the utmost respect for the level of innovation and the business acumen she sees going on at Modern Stone Age Kitchen.
"I will call them with questions, or say, 'Can you please come look at this?' and when I have done that, they've been there," she said. And it's that sense of reciprocity that Boyd is ever grateful for and strives to emulate.
"I would not be able to do what I do every day without the community," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a local catering business, its owner’s entrepreneurial journey, community partnerships, and economic activities, making Business/Economy the most fitting category.

title: Holiday shoppers take to Easton's small businesses to invest in community
author: BROOKE ENSMINGER Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Holiday shoppers take to Easton's small businesses to invest in community

 November 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BROOKE ENSMINGER Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Business 
 
 449
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Locals and visitors supported small businesses by spending their Black Friday at local shops in downtown Easton.Caroline James from Washington, D.C., was visiting her parents in Easton and decided to check out the local shops Friday. She and her family wanted to try something different for holiday shopping this year.
"We were trying to do more thoughtful and more local stuff instead of just ordering online," James said. She said they wanted to spend their money in a way that would benefit the local community rather than filtering more money into corporations.
"If you want to live in a town that has so many thriving businesses, you have to put your money where your mouth is," James said.
Patricia Adkins, also from Washington, said she liked the unique selection from the shops in downtown Easton.
"We were here for Thanksgiving and decided after the dinner and enjoyment here to come and walk the streets of Easton," Adkins said. "We've heard good things about the shopping here in Easton. There are very unique pieces of furniture and clothing as well as handbags."
The local businesses in downtown Easton appreciate the customer support over the holidays and going into Small Business Saturday.
Barbara Ranson from Oxford owns Oxford Vintage & Trade, which recently opened its Easton location on Dover Street during the Waterfowl Festival.
"It benefits all of us to shop local," Ranson said. "We get to support local businesses and by doing that we ensure their sustainability and their longevity."
The local shops provide a unique variety of items that are unlikely to be found in brand-name and big-box stores.
"You can't find our things in the usual stores," said Diane Towers, co-owner of La De Da, a clothing shop in downtown Easton.
"All of the different stores bring a lot of different things into the town," Towers said. "We each have a different vibe so it makes it really nice as far as people shopping."
Local businesses depend on community support to keep them running. The holiday season is a great time to show support by purchasing gifts at local businesses, local business owners say. Many of the shops around town showcase beautiful festive decorations to get customers in the holiday season.
"We want to keep our small downtown alive and vibrant, and if you have individual owners of stores, they need the support of the community to survive," Kristen Dukes, owner of Cairn Antiques, said.
Shopping locally gives back to the community and helps the local economy flourish.
"We're the ones that are actually putting our money back in the community," Mark Greene, owner of Sailor, said. "Our money stays here, it doesn't go anywhere else."
Greene ended by sharing his traditional tagline: "Everything fits better in a small box." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on local small businesses, holiday shopping, and the economic impact of community spending, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Trump’s businesses, product pushes in overdrive as White House return nears
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Newspapers
content:
Trump’s businesses, product pushes in overdrive as White House return nears

 December 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Newspapers | Section: National 
 
 1772
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Trump guitars ($1,500), autographed Trump Bibles ($1,000), Trump sneakers ($499), Trump watches ($899), Trump digital trading cards ($99), signed Trump books ($499), Trump two-dollar bills ($29.99).The marketing and merchandising of President-elect Donald Trump, along with desired profits, have been on hyperdrive during the 2024 campaign, since his election victory over Vice President Kamala Harris and as he prepares to take office again in January.
Trump and his aligned businesses recently promoted new $199 fragrances for men and women called "Fight, Fight, Fight" (referencing the July assassination attempt), new guitars "some of them personally signed," as well as a new book from a publisher founded by his eldest son, Donald Trump Jr.
Trump is no stranger to business and real estate ventures, merchandising and product licensing deals centered on his brand.
Those past deals have included less successful or unrealized ventures such as Trump University, Trump Vodka and Trump Steaks, a television drama called "Trump Tower," a potential Broadway show called "The Trump Follies," various beverages, casinos and a weekly radio show called "Trumped," according to U.S. Patent and Trademark Office filings by the president-elect and his companies, such as DTTM Enterprises. Trump has also previously had modeling and talent agencies, published magazines, owned the Miss Universe pageant and the United States Football League's New Jersey Generals.
Real estateThose products are on top of Trump's longtime business bread-and-butter real estate ventures, including hotels, golf courses and office buildings.
The main driver of that has been the Trump Organization, which is currently headed by the president-elect's sons Donald Trump Jr. and Eric Trump.
Eric Trump also runs Trump Winery (which includes a hotel, wedding venue and cidery) in Charlottesville, Virginia.
The Trump Organization and Trump Winery did not respond to requests for comments on their business approaches during a second Trump administration.
The Trump Organization has announced deals this year for real estate developments (including golf courses, residences and hotels) in Oman, Saudi Arabia, United Arab Emirates and Vietnam.
Developments in the three Persian Gulf states are part of a partnership with Dubai-based Dar Global PLC. (The development firm is an arm of Saudi-based Dar Al Arkan Real Estate Development Company, which recently hired Rothschild & Co. to help it explore more deals.)
"We are thrilled to expand our footprint in the Middle East and bring the Trump standard of luxury to the region through our longstanding relationship with Dar Global," Eric Trump said in a statement on the venture earlier this year.
The Oman development totals $4 billion, while the deal with Kinh Bac City Development Holding Corp. in Vietnam is worth $1.5 billion, according to reports.
Trump's flagship Mar-A-Lago resort in Palm Beach, Florida, generated $56 million for Trump, according to financial disclosures filed this summer. Trump's golf courses in Florida and New Jersey have also hosted tournaments from the Saudi-backed LIV Golf Tour.
Trump has promised to end the Middle East war that ignited after the Oct. 7, 2023 attacks inside Israel and broker an end to the war between Russia and Ukraine after the former's 2022 invasion.
Social mediaTrump owns 57% of the shares in Sarasota, Florida-based Trump Media & Technology Group (Nasdaq: DJT). The company operates the Truth Social media platform and is launching a streaming platform.
TMTG, which launched in 2022, lost $363.2 million through the first nine months of the year on revenue of $2.6 million.
Company executives have said TMTG's trajectory is tied to Trump's reputation and popularity. Trump said after the election that he has "no intention" of selling his $3.5 billion stake in TMTG.
Trump's business deals and real estate ventures — large and small — worry watchdog groups and progressives frequently critical of the populist president-elect.
"By maintaining his business life during his time in office, he's giving business associates, investors and others leverage over him and his personal financial health. The American people need to know if President Trump is looking out for them or for his own financial interests," said Tony Carrk, executive director of Accountable.US, a liberal watchdog group.
Carrk wants Trump to distance himself from some of his business and real estate holdings while serving as U.S. president.
"He needs to divest," Carrk said.
He's concerned about the Trump administration's future intersections with Truth Social, which is publicly traded.
"Those seeking influence over Trump could theoretically buy up Trump media shares to support the stock price, which is a major source of Trump's estimated $5.6 billion fortune," Carrk said.
Trump Media and Truth Social officials have not yet responded to requests for comment.
Licensing dealsTrump and his family's more contemporary business deals include a slew of merchandise licensing deals between vendors and Trump entities such as CIC Ventures LLC and CIC Digital LLC.
Trump is the president, secretary, treasurer and corporate manager of those two Palm Beach, Florida-based entities. Details of the licensing deals are not disclosed, but Trump licensing entities generated $12 million in annual income for Trump, according to financial disclosures.
Trump-endorsed and licensed "God Bless the USA Bibles," marketed via music singer Lee Greenwood, now include a $1,000 version signed by the president-elect and a special $69.99 Inauguration Day Bible.
"GodBlessTheUSABible.com is not political, and has nothing to do with any political campaign. GodBlessTheUSABible.com is not owned, managed or controlled by Donald J. Trump, The Trump Organization, CIC Ventures LLC or any of their respective principals or affiliates. GodBlessTheUSABible.com uses Donald J. Trump's name, likeness and image under paid license from CIC Ventures LLC," the website reads.
Freedom Park Design and 16 Creative, which are both based out of the same offices in Alabama, are part of the distribution and marketing of the Trump Bibles and the new Trump guitars, respectively.
GetTrumpGuitars.com is operated by 16 Creative and offers Trump-backed guitars for $1,500, as well as autographed models for $10,500.
"These are the only guitars endorsed by President Donald J. Trump!" the website reads.
Gibson Guitars has sent 16 Creative a cease-and-desist letter over the Trump guitar's design, according to reports. 16 Creative, which has a.product disclaimer distancing the Trump guitars from Gibson on its website, has not yet responded to a request for comment.
Two Sheridan, Wyoming-based limited liability corporations — 45Footwear LLC and TheBestWatchesonEarth LLC — (which share the same address) are the marketers and distributors of Trump Sneakers and Trump Watches.
The sneakers are priced at as much as $499, and the watches as much as $100,000.
"45Footwear is not owned, managed or controlled by Donald J. Trump, The Trump Organization, CIC Ventures LLC or any of their respective principals or affiliates. 45Footwear uses Donald J. Trump's name, likeness and image under paid license from CIC Ventures LLC," the company said on its website GetTrumpSneakers.com.
In a lawsuit filed in Arizona earlier this year aimed at alleged counterfeit sellers, 45Footwear said it also had a sneaker product license through DTTM Operations LLC, a New York-based Trump entity.
Wyoming-based 45Footwear also operates GetTrumpFragrances.com with a licensing disclaimer on the website. GetTrumpWatches.com also has similar licensing deal language on its website.
Another popular item, Trump digital trading cards, are marketed and distributed by Utah-based NFT Inc. LLC via CollectTrumpCards.com. The company has a licensing deal with Trump's CIC Digital.
Orlando-based Unicorn Wealth LLC operates the ProudPatriots.com, a site that sells a host of merchandise, including coins and $2 bill emblazoned with Trump's face, as well as bobbleheads, ball caps and Christmas ornaments. The company says on its website it is not directly affiliated with Trump or his presidential campaign, but does not reference a licensing deal.
Trump gear was popular at campaign rallies and is offered by various vendors online.
None of the companies have yet responded to requests for comment or details about their deals with Trump.
Public information on the shell companies partnering with Trump varies. The Montana LLCs, for example, share a Sheridan, Wyoming, address with other shell companies, with a law firm listed as the contact.
Trevor Potter, founder and president of the Campaign Legal Center, a progressive watchdog group, promised oversight and scrutiny of the incoming Trump administration in a post-election statement.
"One priority in this respect will be to combat the public perception that officials are not held accountable for their unethical behavior," he said.
Melania Trump, who is returning as first lady, published a memoir titled "Melania" in October. She is selling a $90 Christmas ornament and a $195 digital photography collection at MelaniaTrump.com. Trump is also promoting a new book, "Save America," priced at $99 and $499 for a signed copy. The new book is from Winning Team Publishing. Donald Trump Jr. is one of its co-founders.
There will be more focus on another Trump family member's business ventures.
Invest
Ment fund
Jared Kushner, who is married to Trump's daughter, Ivanka, and served as a top White House adviser during a first Trump term, operates a $3 billion investment fund, Affinity Partners.
A big chunk of Affinity's funding — $2 billion — comes from the Saudi sovereign wealth fund.
That has drawn attention from U.S. Sen. Ron Wyden of Oregon and other Democrats.
Wyden (who currently chairs the Senate Finance Committee) and U.S. Rep. Jamie Raskin, D-Maryland (a frequent Trump critic and ranking member of the House Oversight Committee) wrote U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland in late October, asking that a special prosecutor be appointed to investigate Kushner's foreign business and investment dealings, including with the Saudis, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates, to see if they have violated laws governing those working on behalf of foreign governments and entities via the Foreign Agents Registration Act.
Wyden and Raskin said Kushner's investment firm has received $157 million in fees from foreign clients, including $87 million from Saudi Arabia.
"Mr. Kushner is simultaneously serving as a political consultant to former President Trump and acting as a shadow diplomat and political advisor to Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman and other foreign principals," Wyden and Raskin said, arguing Trump's son-in-law has not made needed FARA disclosures.
They argue Kushner still serves as a political advisor to Trump. The odds of a special counsel being appointed to on the matter are likely nil with Trump's election win.
Miami-based Affinity Partners has not yet responded to requests for comment. Earlier this year, Kushner defended his tenure in the White House and investment work after Trump's loss in the 2020 race.
Kushner and Ivanka Trump were not publicly involved with Trump's win over Harris. It is not clear what kind of roles, if any, they might have in Trump's new term.
But Kushner stirred some scrutiny earlier this year over the future of Gaza after the devastating Israel-Hamas war.
"Gaza's waterfront property could be very valuable if people would focus on building up livelihoods," Kushner said in March, according to the Associated Press.
Trump has named Charles Kushner (Jared Kushner's father) his pick for the U.S. ambassador to France.
Charles Kushner is the founder of the Kushner Cos. Trump pardoned Charles Kushner of tax evasion and witness tampering charges in 2020. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily details Donald Trump's commercial ventures, product licensing, real estate deals, and corporate finances, which aligns best with the Business/Economy category, while also touching on national political context.

title: Gas prices fall another 6.2 cents in Maryland
author: GAS BUDDY
content:
Gas prices fall another 6.2 cents in Maryland

 December 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GAS BUDDY | Section: News 
 
 474
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland fell 6.2 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.04 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 0.8 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 16.8 cents per gallon lower than a year ago."Millions took to the road for Thanksgiving, and while some regions, like the Great Lakes, saw gas prices rise just in time for travel, most of the nation saw prices hold mostly stable or decline slightly as the national average remains near the lowest level we've seen since 2021," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy.
The national average price of diesel has risen 1.1 cents in the last week and stands at $3.514 per gallon.
According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.65 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.79 per gallon, a difference of $1.14 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 0.6 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.00 per gallon today. The national average is down 7.7 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 23.2 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
December 2, 2023: $3.21 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.23 per gallon)December 2, 2022: $3.42 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.39 per gallon)December 2, 2021: $3.34 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.38 per gallon)December 2, 2020: $2.32 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.17 per gallon)December 2, 2019: $2.49 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.60 per gallon)December 2, 2018: $2.38 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.43 per gallon)December 2, 2017: $2.46 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.47 per gallon)December 2, 2016: $2.24 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.17 per gallon)December 2, 2015: $2.09 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.03 per gallon)December 2, 2014: $2.80 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.75 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.00 per gallon, down 8.2 cents per gallon from last week's $3.08 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.14 per gallon, down 5.5 cents per gallon from last week's $3.20 per gallon.Hagerstown: $3.04 per gallon, up 0.6 cents per gallon from last week's $3.03 per gallon.
"The weeks ahead should feature slight drops in gas prices in most areas, with over 100,000 stations now offering a gallon for $2.99 or less, which should stick around through the holiday shopping season," GasBuddy's De Haan said. "While the potential impacts from tariffs are something to watch, they would have no effect until late January, if implemented at all. For this week, all eyes will be on the previously delayed OPEC+ meeting on Thursday. If they begin to restore oil production, oil prices could soften to the mid-$60s." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on recent changes in gasoline prices, market trends, and factors affecting oil markets, which are primarily economic and business-related topics.

title: Talbot County business owners push back against potential hotel tax spike
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot County business owners push back against potential hotel tax spike

 December 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 784
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — During a public meeting at the Talbot County Free Library Tuesday, a number of business owners and managers pushed back on a proposed increase to the county's accommodations tax rate.Talbot County's current public accommodations tax rate, or hotel tax rate, is 4%, the lowest of any county in the state. The tax is levied on those staying in hotels or short-term rentals, collected by the business and then paid to either the county or one of three towns.
Easton, Oxford and St. Michaels collect revenues from such properties within one mile outside town limits. The county collects revenue from all other properties.
A potential increase to 6%, which would raise total revenue collected by around $1 million per fiscal year based on FY2024 numbers, requires approval from lawmakers in Annapolis.
Cassandra Vanhooser, director of economic development and tourism, and Judy Bixler, the Tourism Board chairman and Oxford-Bellevue Ferry captain, outlined the benefits of raising the rate to 6% for the county's marketing efforts, such as adding staff and being able to market more businesses individually.
However, local business owners had mixed reactions, with some "open-minded" but hesitant, and others in complete opposition.
Scott Wagner, owner of Oaks Waterfront Hotel in St. Michaels and a former Republican member of the Pennsylvania State Senate, said he wants to know where exactly the additional $1 million in revenue would be spent.
Wagner added that he doesn't "feel the love" from the county or its marketing efforts.
"Candidly, tonight, I can't support this tax, because I don't feel that Talbot County is supportive of our industry or at the Oaks," Wagner said. "You have not been supportive. Nobody's come out and visited us."
Vanhooser acknowledged Wagner's negative opinion of the tax as fair, but disputed his claim that the county doesn't support his hotel.
"We have sent you many travel writers. … We have sent international tour operators there," she said. "So it's not true that we haven't been to your property and we haven't supported you and marketed your property as one of our new assets. I will totally call you out on that one."
Easton, Oxford and St. Michaels have all voted in support of the tax increase, which Vanhooser and Bixler stressed is the first time in years has been the case.
Alfred Mercier, president of the Commissioners of St. Michaels, explained during the meeting why St. Michaels voted in favor of moving along with a hotel tax increase, noting its importance in funding services such as police and trash disposal.
"There's infrastructure that we have to support, and the accommodations tax is something that, it's a tax on transients that come from outside the town inside the town," Mercier stated. "I think that is the overwhelming reason why St. Michaels (and) the residents were in support of this."
Mercier added, "when it comes to an increase in a tax, if it's a destination location, people don't care. They really don't." Not all St. Michaels businesspeople and residents, though, agreed.
"I completely disagree with you Al," Travis Johnson, manager of the Old Brick Inn, responded. "My guests complain about rates. St. Michaels is very competitive."
Chad Hill, vice president of Hill Hospitality in Easton, was one of the "open-minded" representatives that spoke Tuesday. But Hill expressed that any increase in accommodations tax, which is passed onto the customers, will be substantial.
"Easton is a very low occupancy market, and it is a very, very … rate-sensitive hotel market," he said. "Two or three or four dollars is huge to slap on top of somebody's hotel bill. … Let's be careful not to be flippant that that doesn't make a difference. It makes a huge difference."
Hill, along with others, said they would like to see "transparency" and specifics of what the accommodations tax collected by the county funds more than just the marketing in general.
While no official decisions were made at Tuesday's public meeting, County Manager Clay Stamp told attendees that the County Council "is very interested" in what everyone has to say and is "all ears."
On Dec. 9, the Talbot County Council is expected to vote on whether it will send a letter to state delegates requesting they bring the tax legislation to the General Assembly this cycle.
At the end of the meeting Tuesday, Vanhooser said she thinks the county needs the increase "to stay competitive." The Talbot County Tourism Board had voted unanimously in favor of the increase.
"Regardless of what Mr. Wagner thinks, I'm appreciative of all of you who are my tourism partners," Vanhooser said, "and the work that you do, because it gives us a beautiful, wonderful, awesome destination to promote. I am proud of Talbot County, I think it is the premier destination in all of the state of Maryland and in the mid-Atlantic." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a proposed hotel tax increase, its financial impact on local businesses, and the debate among business owners, which aligns most closely with Business/Economy, while also involving local government decision‑making.

title: Possible major changes to Bay Bridge shared Wednesday evening
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
ANNAPOLIS — Picture a Bay Bridge with 10 lanes and a path for bikers and pedestrians. That was part of a vision shared by Maryland Transportation Authority leaders during an online open house Wednesday evening that included plans for bridge construction focusing on economic, environmental and accessibility impacts.
 But it won't happen soon. Construction is not expected to start until 2032, and the 10-lane bridge is just one of seven options under consideration.

title: Artificial intelligence won't replace reporters
author: MIKE SISCO The Daily Times
content:
Artificial intelligence won't replace reporters

 December 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SISCO The Daily Times | Section: Columns 
 
 429
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When I first received an invitation to attend a seminar concerning artificial intelligence in the newsroom, I had mixed feelings. There was a bit of excitement — I am a bit of a computer and technology geek, after all — about exploring some of the tools that are available. I was also a little wary. Most of us have read or have heard about some of the more cringeworthy attempts to bring AI into journalism, and I was more than a little hesitant to entertain the notion here at The Daily Times.Now that the course has completed, though, I came to a startling two-part revelation. The first phase of my resolution was pretty basic. These tools can help — a lot.
We've started experimenting with AI technology, focusing primarily on routine data processing tasks. Marriage reports, real estate transactions and business licenses are the kind of data-heavy work that has traditionally consumed hours of valuable reporting time. Now, they can be completed in a matter of minutes.
The second part of my personal revelation came after I spent more time experimenting with available tools — from programs that can help streamline your email inbox, create possible story outlines and reveal areas of inquiry to audio tools that can simulate human voices (and even clone your own voice) to read text. These tools can be scarily good. I cloned a snippet of my voice, read a two-sentence script and played it for my younger brother. He could tell the difference only after listening several times.
But here's the thought that began the second part of that revelation. As good as these tools are, they can never replace a living, thinking, feeling reporter. AI can immediately tell one of our reporters how much money agencies like The Empty Pantry Fund has raised over the past five years. It cannot, however, describe the dedication of its volunteers, or put into words the joy of being able to help out a neighbor in need.
So no, AI will not be writing our stories. It will not conduct interviews. It will not replace our reporters. They are our nerdy assistants, doing some of the more time-consuming data entry so reporters can focus on what matters most — getting out, talking to our neighbors, attending local government meetings and telling the important stories about our lives.
The future of journalism will be shaped by how we choose to implement new technologies. I think we're choosing a path that puts our community first, supports our journalists and ensures that technology serves our mission of delivering reliable, comprehensive local news coverage. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the impact of artificial intelligence on newsroom operations and reporting, focusing on tools that affect the business side of journalism. While not a perfect fit, Business/Economy best captures the industry and technology angle.

title: Maryland gas prices continue downward trend

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 8.8 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $2.95 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. title: It's Masala Time opens in Chestertown
author: Elizabeth Alexander Special to the Star Democrat
content:
It's Masala Time opens in Chestertown

 December 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Elizabeth Alexander Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Business 
 
 300
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — When Prateek Mohar and his brother Ankit emigrated to the U.S., they aspired to pursue prosperity and the "American dream" while sharing the delectable tastes of India in their very own restaurant.Graduates of the Institute of Hotel Management Dehradun, they worked for many years as chefs in India and around the world on cruise ships, learning first-hand what it takes to run an efficient and successful kitchen.
After numerous years of hard work and savings, the two 30-somethings from New Delhi searched the northeast region for places without Indian restaurants and landed on Chestertown as a ripe location to open their new venture.
Their new restaurant, It's Masala Time, recently opened in the Washington Square shopping center, offering a vast array of delectable Indian favorites.
Their signature dishes are the butter chicken and the Tikka Masala chicken, as well as clay oven tandoori specialties along with many vegetarian offerings.
Other delightful favorites include Shahi Korma-a cashew and coconut-based curry, the very hot and spicy potato based Vindaloo dishes, a sweet, sour and spicy mango-based curry, and Biryani — a fragrant delicacy of rice and meat or vegetables with raisins, almonds, cashews, cilantro and aromatic spices. Diners may request spicy or mild when ordering their dishes.
The interior ambiance is chic and modern with saffron-colored walls bedecked with canvas photos of foods from across India. The building itself was previously a rough empty shell, which the Mohar brothers helped to renovate into its elegant atmosphere.
Prateek's wife Vedika Patel and the men's father R.N. Mohar also work there, making it a family affair.
The restaurant is open seven days a week, giving locals ample chance to "dive into a world of spice" as often as they like. In addition, catering for up to 50 people is available, as is online ordering for take-aways at itsmasalatime.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Average gas prices continue falling in Maryland
author: GAS BUDDY
content:
Average gas prices continue falling in Maryland

 December 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GAS BUDDY | Section: State News 
 
 522
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 3.7 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $2.91 per gallon on Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland.Prices in Maryland are 26.5 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 18.5 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has declined 1.8 cents in the last week and stands at $3.472 per gallon.
According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.63 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.79 per gallon, a difference of $1.16 per gallon.
The falling prices may be coming to an end.
"As we edge closer to the end of the year, we're seeing momentum for falling gas prices weaken, which is typical as the national average generally bottoms out between Thanksgiving and Christmas," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "With oil prices rising back above $70 last week, gas prices may have less potential to drop much further, though there may be a second window of lower prices in January or February in some areas, but even that won't last long."
The national average price of gasoline has risen 0.8 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $2.98 per gallon today. The national average is down 7.5 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 7.1 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
Dec. 16, 2023: $3.10 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.05 per gallon)Dec. 16, 2022: $3.18 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.13 per gallon)Dec. 16, 2021: $3.31 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.32 per gallon)Dec. 16, 2020: $2.34 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.20 per gallon)Dec. 16, 2019: $2.45 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.56 per gallon)Dec. 16, 2018: $2.33 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.36 per gallon)Dec. 16, 2017: $2.43 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.43 per gallon)Dec. 16, 2016: $2.28 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.23 per gallon)Dec. 16, 2015: $2.02 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.01 per gallon)Dec. 16, 2014: $2.63 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.51 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $2.84 per gallon, down 5.5 cents per gallon from last week's $2.90 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.15 per gallon, down 0.5 cents per gallon from last week's $3.16 per gallon.Hagerstown: $3.00 per gallon, down 6.1 cents per gallon from last week's $3.06 per gallon.
"While several states saw gas prices cycle last week, marked by a big jump in prices after a large decline, those that did see hefty jumps should see prices drift a bit lower, potentially making a second run at the season's lowest prices," De Haan said. "The West Coast, including California, should continue to see prices drift lower, but with just a few weeks left in 2024, all attention turns to 2025. GasBuddy's 2025 Fuel Outlook, among the nation's most accurate fuel price forecasts, will be released in the coming weeks, offering motorists a glimpse into gas prices for the coming year."
