title: Board of Realtors installs officers for upcoming year
author: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS
content:
Board of Realtors installs officers for upcoming year

 December 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS | Section: News 
 
 418
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors gave a heart-warming farewell to its outgoing president while recognizing new leadership and the collective achievements of its members this past year.Shelby Roney, an associate broker with Benson and Mangold, ended her term as president of MSBR at the Oct. 22 ceremony held at Temple B'nai Israel in Easton, passing the gavel to Michelle Abplanalp of Rosendale Realty, who is taking up the leadership role for 2025.
Members who were honored at the event included Peter Stark with Benson and Mangold for Rookie Realtor of the Year. Gwen Eskridge, MSBR past president with Coldwell Banker Chesapeake, received the President's Award for her continuous contributions to the association.
Shontel Wilmer with Rosendale Realty was presented the Community Service Award, and Tom Draper with First Home Mortgage was named the Affiliate of the Year.
Ron Molock of Long and Foster was recognized with the Diversity, Equity, and Inclusive Award.
The Realtor of the Year award went to Megan Rosendale of Rosendale Realty, a past MSBR president and founder of Mid Shore Love's Down Payment Assistance Grant program. Rosendale also received citations from Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico).
Hugh Smith, broker of Coldwell Banker Chesapeake, was presented with the Life Achievement Award. This is the highest award the association gives and recognizes Smith's years of service to the community and to the real estate industry.
Cheryl Abrams Davis, 2025 president of Maryland Realtors, installed the directors, while Michael Rosendale, associate broker with Rosendale Realty, installed Abplanalp as the newly elected Mid-Shore Board of Realtors president.
Abplanalp has over 28 years of experience in real estate. Supporting programs and causes in Caroline, Dorchester and Talbot counties to increase education and professionalism is her focus.
Out-going president Shelby Roney received a citation from Easton Mayor Megan Cook, thanked those who helped her this past year and noted how this role helped her grow both personally and professionally. It was a year of industry changes and Mid-Shore Board of Realtors agents managed them well.
The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors 2024-2025 executive committee is Abplanalp; Roney; Shandell Green, MSBR president-elect with Douglas Realty; Petra Quinn, MSBR secretary with Realty Navigator; and Trey Quinn, MSBR treasurer with Fidelity First Home Mortgage.
The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors 2024-2025 directors include: Alex Archer with Real Broker, Andy Beaven with Wright Real Estate, Jenn Dudley with Title Excellence, Samantha Grimes with Chesapeake Real Estate Associates, Thornette Lee with Keller Williams Select, Mary Mabry with Keller Williams Select and Shontel Wilmer with Rosendale Realty.
For more news and information visit midshoreboardofrealtors.com.

title: Drive-through Chester Dunkin’ concept plan moves forward
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Drive-through Chester Dunkin’ concept plan moves forward

 December 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 612
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTER — A new, online order focused, cashless Kent Island Dunkin' Donuts franchise took the next tentative steps forward with Queen Anne's County Planning Commission's approval of a concept plan Dec. 12.Maritime Coffee LLC is proposing to administratively combine three deeded parcels to construct a 1,415 square foot Dunkin' Donuts fast food restaurant at 100 Olde Point Village, Chester, in the Town Center zoning district, according to Steve Johnson, senior planner.
Located on Kent Island at the corner of Route 50 and Cox Neck Road, the business will serve drive-through and walk-up patrons with no dine-in service or seating.
With the lack of indoor seating, the applicant also requested a reduction in 16 parking spaces from its required 33.
Noting the fast paced style of the establishment and no inside seating available, "If there's 36 cars on site, there's something wrong," Todd LaLumiere, Maritime Coffee LLC owner said.
Conservative estimates on the low end found drive-through capacities at approximately 120 vehicles an hour and, with roughly 11 parking spaces, online order capacity can handle an additional 132 patrons an hour, he said.
Altogether, the location could handle a combined total of approximately 252 potential patrons per hour, Davis said.
Mark Keeley, project manager at Traffic Concepts Inc. performed the traffic and queuing studies and noted queuing space was "more than adequate," to handle the volume.
With dual order boards, the proposed Chester drive-through has room for 30 queuing vehicles, which was more than other locations, he said.
Studying five Dunkin' locations in Anne Arundel County in 2019 during peak business times of 7 to 9 a.m. and 4 to 6 p.m, the highest queue from the order board was 13 vehicles, with an average being nine vehicles, Keeley said.
"We do 70% of our business by 11 in the morning," LaLumiere said. .
Anticipating "cannibalizing sales" to some extent from the existing location, LaLumiere said the proposed eastbound store will serve primarily as a backup for the existing westbound location.
Much of Dunkin's business, particularly after Covid has been through the drive-through, he noted.
The proposed location anticipates utilizing Dunkin's new drive-through model of separate payment and pick up windows for added efficiency during busy periods, according to LaLumiere.
Six employees are proposed to staff the location during peak hours with drive-through and online orders, and with no cash register inside, he said.
LaLumiere also did not foresee a lot of walkup foot traffic for the proposed location.
During the public comment portion of the Planning Commission meeting, Kent Island resident of 45 years, William Howe spoke out against the proposed Dunkin', stating his daughter owned the Fields of Heather Bakery in Chester's Rainbow Plaza — a business that already provides breakfast items and baked goods to the community.
Howe claimed visitors coming over from the western shore for the weekends would be the only ones benefiting from the new Dunkin'.
Traffic on Cox Neck and Postal Road are "horrendous," particularly on Sunday mornings, Howe said, and that the turning lane off Route 50 wasn't long enough to handle the influx, predicting traffic backups.
The Concept Plan approval was granted by the Commission, who cited the plans were consistent with the 2022 Comprehensive Plan.
Due to its model without dine-in seating, the location was found to generate less parking needs than county parking standards require and the requested reduction in parking was also granted.
The project includes a redevelopment of two existing office spaces and the property will be served by a private well and public sewer — 2.2 acres along Cox Neck Road will be dedicated to Queen Anne's County.
The Department of Public Works is in conceptual agreement with the proposals for stormwater treatment and the applicant will continue to work with them through the next phase of the project. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a new Dunkin' drive‑through business development and its approval process, making it primarily about a commercial venture, with secondary relevance to local government planning and traffic concerns.

title: QLarant Foundation: an Easton-based philanthropic organization with widespread reach
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
QLarant Foundation: an Easton-based philanthropic organization with widespread reach

 December 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Business 
 
 498
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Established out of a need to improve healthcare quality, QLarant Foundation has made part of its mission to provide nonprofit and grassroots organizations funds to better assist underserved communities nationwide.Over 20 years, the foundation has distributed an estimated $8 million to 145 nonprofits with grants ranging from $5,000 to $50,000. As the foundation continues to grow, its leaders are proud to have their Easton headquarters in support of the Eastern Shore communities.
Ronald Forsythe, chief executive officer of QLarant Foundation, said the QLarant company began in 1973 as a peer review organization for physicians in the healthcare field, and over time the company expanded beyond just quality improvement healthcare. Forsythe said the QLarant company has been one of the main contract holders with the Center of Medicare and Medicaid Services.
"We have expanded into program integrity, which is kind of the fraud, waste and abuse part of healthcare," Forsythe said. "And as we continued to work and grow our footprint, we also saw a need to be able to find a way to use the excess reserves that we had coming in, so we actually established the foundation to support emerging healthcare nonprofits in the area as well."
Amanda Neal, executive director of QLarant Foundation, said the foundation was launched over 20 years ago. Since its beginnings, its philanthropy efforts have been a part of the DNA of the organization.
According to Neal, the grants top out at $50,000 because that kind of money could really move the needle for a local nonprofit doing grassroots work.
"There's not a single nonprofit out there that isn't underfunded, overworked, doing good stuff and moving the needle in the communities that they serve," Neal said.
Previous grant recipients included Epoch Dream Center, a student and social-emotional wellness center; Food and Friends, an organization addressing health and food security challenges; and Horizon Day Camp, a free summer camp providing joy to children with cancer and their siblings.
According to Forsythe, the foundation goes out of its way to support Eastern Shore based nonprofits and the work they do for rural communities.
"There's a great benefit to making sure that you have an anchor tenant within the community, particularly on the Eastern Shore, where a lot of the businesses are geared toward agriculture, seafood or tourism," Forsythe said.
But as the foundation continues to expand throughout the United States, Neal says it continues to stay strong on the reason the foundation was developed: to support communities in need.
"Any time that you can invest in a nonprofit that is raising up individuals within our community," Neal said, "the ripple effect of that is just extraordinary, helping one person, one family, whether it's stopping bullying, or helping a new mother, or a young family connect with services. The ripple effect of helping just one person always has a benefit for the community."
QLarant Foundation's current 2025 grant period opened on Dec. 2 and runs through Jan. 16. Eligible nonprofits from the states of Maryland, Washington, Texas, Florida and Georgia are can apply. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a philanthropic foundation’s grantmaking activities, financial impact, and its role in supporting nonprofits, which aligns most closely with Business/Economy. Health is a secondary theme due to the foundation’s origins in healthcare, while Education is less central.

title: Major subdivision approval moves Bay Bridge Marina development forward
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Major subdivision approval moves Bay Bridge Marina development forward

 December 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 371
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Bay Bridge Marina LLLP received preliminary and final major subdivision approval for a proposal to create commercial lots and residential duplexes at Pier One Road in Stevensville Dec. 12.The applicant is proposing a major subdivision to create five new commercial lots and 28 duplex lots on a 40-acre property within the Airport Protection and Kent Island Gateway zoning districts on the western edge of Kent Island, just south of US 50, according to Doug Summers, associate planner.
Located within the Chester-Stevensville Growth Area, the property is also designated as an enterprise zone and priority funding area, Summers said.
The site is located completely within the critical area with intensely developed area designation and is partially located within the 100-year flood plain, he said.
The typical 300-foot shore buffer was reduced to zero by the Planning Commission in 1989. No steep slopes, woodlands, or endangered wetlands or species are located in the vicinity, Summers said.
The property will be served by public water and sewer.
With the existing beach club and restaurant, the project is posed to be an "attractive mixed-use community that really blends in well with adjacent properties," according to Alan Hyatt, counsel to Bay Bridge Marina LLLP.
The project has undergone several iterations over its years of planning, he said.
The property will not have public roadways but easements and maintenance expenses will not fall to the public, Hyatt said.
The Department of Public Works is in support of the proposal, determining that existing and proposed road designs meet the public road standards for the pavement sections, according to Hyatt, Utilities will be privately owned, with no utility easements required.
Environmentally speaking, the project will include a significant number of plantings as well as new stormwater management techniques, Hyatt said.
At public comment Jay Falstad of the Queen Anne's Conservation Association encouraged the Planning Commission to insist all development plantings be native species.
"Planting native is important for promoting local biology," he said.
The commission approved Bay Bridge Marina's preliminary and major subdivision request, finding it consistent with the Queen Anne's County 2022 Comprehensive Plan and zoning and subdivision regulations.
The commission also agreed with the applicant's request for the elimination of 35 feet frontage requirements for nonresidential lots for improved traffic flow, pedestrian connections and overall site design. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a development project, subdivision approvals, zoning, and commercial/residential planning, which are core aspects of business and economic activity, with secondary relevance to local government processes and environmental considerations.

title: We'll soon see how high the bar is on taxes
author: Staff Writer
content:
We'll soon see how high the bar is on taxes

 December 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 775
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Next month the Maryland General Assembly convenes in Annapolis for a 90-day session.All indications are the discussions, deliberations and decisions on the state budget will be drawn out and divisive.
The reason is simple.
Recently the General Assembly's bipartisan Affordable Spending Committee received a most sobering report on the state's current and projected fiscal conditions.
The report included some of the worst state budget revenue and expense projections since the state endured pandemic lockdowns.
The committee staff is currently projecting a budget deficit of $3 billion. That amount is even larger than the one a reported several weeks ago, which was then $2.7 billion.
All the debate on the budget will include a wide range of key players with starkly different and strongly held opinions on the best way to address projected short term and long-term deficits.
At this point, the most likely options include spending cuts, fee increases, tax increases, revisions to the Blueprint for Maryland's Future (the Kirwan Plan) and maintaining or increasing the flow of federal dollars into Maryland.
With a new Republican president and Republican majorities in both houses of Congress, it is almost a given that federal dollars flowing into Maryland from jobs, and funding of huge infrastructure projects such as the Red Line mass transit expansion in Baltimore and Amtrak tunnel rebuild, also in Baltimore, will run dry.
One exception is final bipartisan Congressional and White House approval of full federal funding for rebuilding and replacing the Key Bridge in Baltimore. Beyond that one-time massive level of federal aid, such outlays are gone at least for the next four years and maybe forever.
Despite all the above news, Gov. Wes Moore has repeatedly said he has a "high bar" for tax increases. He more recently stated that he supports revisions to the Kirwan Plan including, but not limited to, delays in the current schedule for full implementation.
Moore has also said regularly that Maryland must attract more higher paying jobs to Maryland and must stem the number of high-income taxpayers leaving Maryland.
To do that, Moore has issued executive orders prefaced with the following messages:
"Maryland has an opportunity to change the trajectory of the downward decline that our state's economy has experienced over the past several years. For Maryland to win the decade, we must be clear-eyed about the impediments to growth, develop strategies to deliver short-term and long-term sustainable success, and create the climate that is necessary for businesses and talent to grow and relocate in our state."
His executive orders create a Governor's Office of Business Advancement, a Maryland Coordinated Permitting Review Council, a Certified Sites Program and a Governor's Economic Competitiveness Subcabinet.
His orders also provide for a government-loaned executive program; an all-of-government approach to supporting priority industries and sectors; the Department of Commerce to coordinate economic development, marketing, and branding efforts with local governments; directing a comprehensive review of the Business Tax Credit; Financial Assistance and Incentive Programs; and a review of Certain Business Licensing Programs.
Maryland Senate President Bill Ferguson has been less direct in his opinions on tax increases.
Ferguson has said, "We are going to have to look at revenues in certain areas because when we look at the budget overall, the gap cannot be accomplished by cuts alone." Ferguson has echoed Moore's position that a decision on tax increases will have a high bar for his support.
The current views of Moore and Ferguson put them at odds with two high ranking and influential leaders in the House of Delegates — Majority Leader David Moon and Appropriations Committee Chair Ben Barnes.
Both are unapologetic progressives who believe strongly that substantial state tax increases are long overdue. They oppose suggestions to delay or revise the implementation of schedules or mandates in Kirwan, including mandates opposed by some local school boards.
Del. Barnes took a page from the messaging book of Gov. Moore and Senate President Ferguson by saying he has a "very high bar for any rollback of education reforms."
I predict when all is said and done, the Democratic super majorities in the General Assembly along with Gov. Moore will reach agreement on and approve a mixture of spending cuts, tax increases, fee increases and revisions to Kirwan.
I also predict the Republican minorities in the General Assembly will continue efforts already underway to strongly oppose tax increases.
As always, the minority will have its say, and the majority will have its way.
The General Assembly's regular session ends in April. Barring any subsequent special sessions, only then we will know how Gov. Moore chose to define a high bar on tax increases.
Eventually, we also will know how that choice impacted his political future that many believe includes a run for president, assuming he is reelected to a second term as governor. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses state budget deficits, tax policy, and economic development initiatives, which are primarily economic and business matters rather than purely local government operations or broader national news.

title: Local residents embark on Eden Town Brewing, the first Caroline County brewery
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Local residents embark on Eden Town Brewing, the first Caroline County brewery

 December 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 687
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Caroline County's first brewery is under construction, and it's being led by two local residents and business owners.Matt and Sarah Dahl are bringing Eden Town Brewing Company to the corner of Eighth and Gay streets in Denton. Ground was broken earlier this year, and Matt Dahl says he hopes the brewery will open sometime in 2025.
The more than 8,000-square-foot project is an exciting one for the Dahls and also their first major business venture.
"It's kind of one of those things you talk about but it never happened," Matt Dahl said. "It kind of just kept coming up. Sarah, my wife, she had had her eye on this property for a while. She was like, 'That would be like the perfect place to do one.'"
After living in North Carolina for five years, they moved back to Denton, Sarah Dahl's hometown, where they reside now with two sons, James and Luke. But their time in the South left a lasting impression — particularly due to the brewery scene.
"Where we lived in Raleigh, there were breweries everywhere," Matt Dahl said. "And people loved going to them. It was kind of the heyday of breweries.
"We moved up here and said, 'Oh, it would be cool if we could build a brewery in Denton.'"
Eden Town Brewing harkens back to the town's previous name before it was shortened to Edenton, then Denton. It will have a brewing production facility and a brewmaster, Matt Dahl said, along a large taproom, patio and event space.
He hopes they can work with local food trucks on a rotation basis or even find a full-time partner.
The property was bought from the owner of the former Nuttle Lumber warehouse. The Dahls had to go through a zoning amendment process with the town before construction could begin.
Denton Mayor Abby McNinch said they presented at several Planning Commission and Town Council meetings, adhering "to all our planning and zoning requirements as any other business would."
"I am excited. They are great people," McNinch said of the Dahls. "They've done their research well, they have. They're not doing this lightly."
Matt Dahl said while other potential properties for the brewery wouldn't need the zoning changes, placing the business in town was a priority for him and his wife.
"One of our primary motivations was to bring something to town," he said. "There's already a lot of stuff out on the highway. So this is in town. Even if it was going to take longer, we'd rather have it be in town."
McNinch said she appreciates that aspect of the venture and the fact that the Dahls are town residents who care about the community as a whole, not just starting a business.
The brewery will be in close proximity to Denton's Market Street, which is host to many local businesses, including popular restaurants. Matt Dahl envisions the brewery anchoring the side of town across from the Market Street hub once it opens.
Denton's mayor is excited for the possibility of growth in the area near Gay Street. Eden Town Brewing has the makeup of a "cornerstone project" for what McNinch says is an "underdeveloped" part of town.
"To bring an area alive again is really exciting," McNinch said. "And yes, that it's walkable. It will highlight an area of our town that hasn't been highlighted in a long time."
"One of the things that we are very proud of is our sense of community," the mayor continued. "And I think that the model that they've presented, and how it's not just a place to go drink beer, but the whole concept, it's going to be great for that community aspect, I think."
Matt Dahl said the brewery will have a wide range of options available, including beer, cocktails, wine and non-alcoholic beverages. Thus far, reception from locals has been great, he said.
"The town, council (and) the town staff have all been super supportive and excited about it," Dahl said. "We really have had nothing but positive feedback on the idea. Now we just have to keep that excitement going for another year until we're actually open."
To stay up to date on Eden Town Brewing Company's progress, visit edentownbrewing.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the launch of a new brewery, detailing the entrepreneurs, investment, zoning approvals, and expected economic impact on the town, making Business/Economy the primary focus.

title: The Meyer Plan: Governor-elect plans Delaware zoning reform, financing for cheaper housing
author: Nick Stonesifer Spotlight Delaware
content:
The Meyer Plan: Governor-elect plans Delaware zoning reform, financing for cheaper housing

 January 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Nick Stonesifer Spotlight Delaware | Section: News 
 
 1390
 Words 

 Read News Document

 With three weeks until Governor-elect Matt Meyer takes office, he will assume the role at a time when housing in Delaware is more expensive and harder to build than in recent decades.New housing growth has exploded in Delaware after the pandemic, but most are priced at $400,000 or more, well above affordability for the median household, and increasingly targeting a growing number of new arrivals and retirees.
Meanwhile, the overall state housing market has also risen in cost, reaching a median sale price of about $388,000 in November – about 5% higher than a year ago and almost 50% higher than five years ago.
The booming price of real estate has subsequently led to workforce shortages, especially in Sussex County where the effects are more acute.
That's led lawmakers around the state to begin trying to tackle the issue, and this summer the General Assembly passed multiple bills in an effort to lower housing prices and ease availability.
Meyer has also proposed his own plans to accommodate the needs of a rapidly expanding state and emphasize consistent regulations across all three of Delaware's counties.
The plan to address affordability and housing is broad and covers issues from preventing homelessness to supplementing affordability. His full housing affordability plan can be accessed here.
Yet one theme is consistent in the plan: it starts before projects break ground.
Zoning reform
At the top of Meyer's plan are zoning reform proposals that would allow for more density in development codes and create a more diverse housing stock. He would also push for more accessory dwelling units (ADUs), which are smaller housing options already built on an established lot, and higher-density options.
In a seven-bill package put forward last session by State Sen. Russell Huxtable (D-Lewes), one bill would have allowed property owners to build one ADU on their properties without going through local government approvals. It would have also compelled those governments to enact laws that allow ADUs under 1,000 square feet to be built.
The bill was the only one of the seven bills to not see a vote before the end of the legislative session.
Meyer's plan doesn't expand on how he'd achieve this other than saying he'd direct the Office of State Planning Coordination (OSPC) to work with local governments to encourage zoning reform.
For those unfamiliar with the planning process in Delaware, OSPC is usually one of the first hurdles developers overcome. Developers will take their proposals before the Preliminary Land Use Service, better known as PLUS, which is run by OSPC.
In those meetings, multiple state agency leaders outline code or environmental roadblocks in projects before they go to the county for more intense scrutiny.
While its recommendations to the developers are only advisory, OSPC plays a key part in targeting growth across the state. But in similar fashion to its recommendations on projects, its targeted growth areas are also recommendations.
Mike Riemann, the president of the Delaware Home Builders Association, explained that zoning density is low in the state, meaning it's harder to build more homes on specific lots depending on its zoning district.
Riemann pointed to a recent ordinance adopted by New Castle County that would allow "pocket neighborhoods," or dense neighborhoods of single-family lots, in areas targeted for growth, but situated on difficult-to-build parcels.
But Riemann said incentivizing growth is difficult when the regulations for developing in a rural area and an urban area are similar like they are now.
Lowering construction costs
Next in his plan, Meyer would try to bring down the cost of building a home in Delaware. According to the plan, he'd "relax regulations" for affordable housing developments, create a faster approval process for those projects, and waive certain fees and taxes.
One piece of that plan is to create a new state program called the "New Housing Production Fund," which would subsidize projects in a similar fashion to current federal tax credit programs that affordable housing developers rely on.
Rich Przywara, the CEO of the Todmorden Foundation, an offshoot of the Woodlawn Trustees that develops affordable housing, praised this idea, saying it makes building much easier.
A new state fund would allow developers to have access to low-financed construction loans, meaning less money spent on interest, he said.
The waiver of fees and different taxes is also an idea he'd want to see move forward. Currently, Przywara said outgoing Wilmington Mayor Mike Purzycki waived many different permitting fees on affordable housing projects across the city.
"You still have to apply for the permit, you still have to post your permit, but [Purzycki] waived the fee," Przywara said. "That's one less thing I have to pay for upfront and borrow money for."
While much of Meyer's plan is targeted at creating more incentives for affordable housing, it's impossible to ignore an increased growth of single-family homes downstate.
Estimates from the Delaware Home Builders Association say it can cost up to $474,000 to build a single new, 2,400-square-foot home in Sussex County. A third of those costs, according to Riemann, simply boils down to time.
The cost of land, the interest on owning that land, as well as carrying costs on a single plot of land begins to add up the longer it takes to get a home built.
Two ways that Riemann said the state could get homebuilding costs lower across the state is reducing the time needed for approvals and allowing for higher lot densities.
Lowering that approval time at the state level could mean streamlining state agency reviews from the Departments of Transportation and Natural Resources and Environmental Control – two of the biggest hurdles for developers – to make them more predictable for builders to save time, without compromising the integrity of a project.
"You don't have to sacrifice the integrity of the regulatory requirement because it's efficient," Riemann said. "And that is a mindset that I think we need to have as a state."
In the final weeks of his time as a county executive, Meyer vetoed a New Castle County Council ordinance that would have increased a fee on new construction projects to go toward services like fire departments and emergency medical services.
His reasoning boiled down to trying to keep housing costs in the county low at a time when the market is becoming harder to break into.
"Now is not the time to increase the cost of housing in New Castle County," Meyer wrote. "This county is facing an unprecedented housing crisis, not only for the most vulnerable among us, but also for so many working families across our community."
Yet multiple county council members saw the veto as an acquiescence to developers' desires.
Affordable housing
When it comes to the Meyer plan on affordable housing, it includes a wide-sweeping analysis of areas to be improved upon.
Jim Purcell, a director with the Milford Housing Development Corporation (MHDC), said one part of affordable housing that's overlooked is thinking it needs to be all about building new units. In his eyes, there should be equal attention paid to repairing the current housing stock, and therefore preventing the unnecessary loss of available units.
"We've got a tremendous amount of substandard housing, which simply needs a little TLC, but there are a lot of costs that go along with that," Purcell said.
The MHDC specializes in affordable housing development and emergency home repair. It also owns multiple rental communities across the state.
Purcell said he believed support of alternative housing like ADUs or tiny home villages allows people to find housing options that don't exceed 30% of their income. But he said in Delaware, it's more common to see people spending above that monthly benchmark, especially in urban and rural areas.
For all his proposals, there are some who like the governor-elect to take a more progressive stance on housing.
Shyanne Miller, a Wilmington affordable housing advocate with the H.O.M.E.S. Campaign, said she would have liked to see Meyer's plan include rent stabilization, which would limit how much a landlord could increase their rent each year.
She added that Delaware needs one, unified state housing agency that can focus on all of the state's housing issues in the governor's Cabinet. Currently, there are five public housing authorities operating across the state, with Wilmington, Dover and Newark operating their own.
The Delaware State Housing Authority (DSHA) is often in a tricky position to make decisions regulating rent since they are also landlords for Kent and Sussex counties, Miller said.
"I'm hoping that he'll consider taking the advice of people to just be ready to start a housing agency [on] day one," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses housing affordability, zoning reform, construction costs, and state financing—issues centered on the housing market and economic policy rather than sports, health, or cultural topics.

title: Budget, Blueprint, energy are top issues for Shore legislators this session
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Budget, Blueprint, energy are top issues for Shore legislators this session

 January 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: General Assembly 
 
 710
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As Eastern Shore legislators prepare to cross the bridge and return to Annapolis for the first day of the Maryland General Assembly's 2025 legislative session on Wednesday, the state's budget is top of mind."It's just a tough time right now, and we're going to have to be very cautious and very thoughtful of the citizens and the impacts that our citizens are feeling," Del. Jay Jacobs (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline) said in an interview with the Star Democrat.
The state is facing a predicted $2.7 billion budget deficit in fiscal year 2026. Jacobs said when it comes to the budget process this year, he thinks everything will be on the table. "The devil is in the details," he said.
"We're certainly — on the Shore — fiscal conservatives concerned with any cost increase, any tax increase or any cost toward citizens," Jacobs said.
Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said he hopes state Democrats realize that some state goals, such as the Blueprint for Maryland's Future and some climate initiatives, are unrealistic and need to be reexamined.
"So I hope there's some reality checks," he said.
Del. Jefferson Ghrist (R- Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline) said the state has overspent. He said although House leadership seems to be ok with raising taxes to balance the budget, the governor might not be "comfortable" with that.
Ghrist said he expects to see a "clash" in the Democratic Party regarding the budget.
Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) sees this legislative session as a "defining" one for Gov. Wes Moore (D).
"He's going to have to balance this out within his own party," Mautz said about Moore. "Because the policies that are in place now that have caused these economic problems largely come from the Democratic Party and Democratic leadership."
BLUEPRINT FOR MARYLAND'S FUTUREThe Blueprint for Maryland's Future is another issue that legislators on the Shore expect to be one of the top issues this legislative session.
The Blueprint — a plan passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 2021 that aims to improve student outcomes and education quality across the state — has garnered some concern across the state due to funding challenges.
Hutchinson said that with a budget shortfall, the state should be "pulling back" on the Blueprint. He said the plan has "been devastating" to counties across the state.
Jacobs said he thinks this legislative session will result in adjustments to the timeline of certain Blueprint goals.
"I don't think that they're going to do away with Blueprint by any means," he said. "I just think that there may be some changes in the timeline of different parts of it."
Mautz said "something has to happen" with the Blueprint. He said he isn't sure if legislators will create bills "to address the damage that's been done" or create bills that put pauses on the plan.
ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENTFrom solar energy to electric vehicles, Eastern Shore legislators see energy and environment issues as important heading into this legislative session.
Ghrist called the state's renewable energy goals "virtually impossible to achieve." He said he has concerns about who is controlling where solar energy systems are being placed in the state. He plans to put out "several" bills that address solar energy.
"Our number one industry is agriculture and it's being threatened right now by solar," he said.
Jacobs said he has heard that there have been some "serious conversations" about expanding nuclear energy in the state. He said he hopes state leadership and legislative committees that deal with energy issues will look more into nuclear energy and figure out if it's a direction the state should be going in.
When it comes to electric vehicles, Hutchinson said he doesn't think the state has the capacity for its electric vehicle initiatives.
"There's not enough power stations to be able to charge them," he said. "And based upon what I'm hearing from our local dealers, there's not a market for them and they want to stay with combustible engines."
Hutchinson said he expects a lot of debate this session.
"And again, I hope that we see some reality coming that we can't continue to afford to spend and that we have to make sure we address this $2.7 billion short fall that's going to get worse and worse each year if we don't do anything today," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the state budget deficit, fiscal policy, and economic implications of legislative decisions, making Business/Economy the most fitting category, with Education and Environment as secondary themes.

title: Acero 506: curating personalized gifts for the Eastern Shore
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Acero 506: curating personalized gifts for the Eastern Shore

 January 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Business 
 
 466
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Dayana Ocampos is in the business of bringing joy to the communities around her.Ocampos, owner of Acero 506, said her jewelry and gift store is an avenue for creativity and personalized gifts for everyone in the Eastern Shore.
Acero 506 has opened its doors to the public. Residing on Elliot Street, this new store provides curated gifts and jewelry to all those searching for one-of-a-kind items for their loved ones.
Ocampos, native to Costa Rica, moved to the Eastern Shore from New Jersey with her husband Brayam Herrera and young daughter about four years ago. Back in Costa Rica, Herrera and she were auto mechanics and had a shared love of working with their hands.
Ocampos said it was always a dream of hers to open her own business where she can connect with and talk to tourists and community members alike.
"I love talking to people. I love making connections with people," Ocampos said. "I've always worked in occupations that center people and service to fulfill their needs. I feel that I've been called to share and help curate objects that bring people together."
Herrera said his wife, as an artist and a creator, goes above and beyond for all her customers.
"It's really impressive for me what she got going on," Herrera said. "A couple years ago, she made and accomplished a goal, and everything came with a lot of effort, of course, but it turned out to be bigger than I thought. She's been working really, really hard to have this, and she's so happy to have it. It's her first business here, and it's not easy. It's really, really, really tough, really hard, a lot of work. But she made it. And now she has this store, and she deserves it."
According to Herrera, Ocampos started making customized gifts a couple of years ago. She began with research and quickly put her knowledge to action.
After a few years, what was once a hobby developed into a full-fledged business that quickly outgrew her workplace in their home.
Now with an established location for her business, Ocampos has been met with an array of support from her community.
Victoria Gomez Lozano, deputy director for the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center, said supporting Latino-owned businesses on the Eastern Shore is a core mission of the center. For Gomez Lozano, as the Latino population continues to grow, it has become more and more important to support economic growth within the community.
"First of all it was an honor that ChesMRC was invited to the Acero 506 inauguration," Gomez Lozano said. "It was a pleasure and important for ChesMRC to be there because that is an accomplishment of our mission, 'empower people from different cultures to become successful and engaged members of our community.' Dedication and hard work shows us a great story of success." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the opening and operation of a new jewelry and gift store, highlighting entrepreneurship, local economic impact, and business growth, which aligns best with the Business/Economy category. It also mentions Latino ownership and multicultural support, giving secondary relevance to Race & Diversity.

title: New reality, ‘can of worms’ or real estate play?: Trump looks at U.S. Postal Service privatization
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
New reality, ‘can of worms’ or real estate play?: Trump looks at U.S. Postal Service privatization

 January 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: News 
 
 977
 Words 

 Read News Document

 President-elect Donald Trump's return to the White House has given new vigor to conservative efforts to privatize the U.S. Postal Service.Some conservatives have long wanted to privatize the U.S. Post Office, citing its financial losses spurred by retirement obligations and a changing competitive landscape with delivery and parcel services from Amazon, FedEx and UPS.
Efforts to privatize the Postal Service will have to overcome worries about impacts on smaller and rural communities and what happens to (and who might benefit from) USPS' vast real estate holdings from small town post offices to valuable properties in big cities and affluent areas.
The Postal Service has more than 33,000 locations nationwide with more than 235,400 delivery routes. It leases some space from private real estate groups and owns more than 8,500 properties.
Those owned properties comprise more than 195.6 million square feet of space, according to USPS' latest annual report to Congress. The USPS real estate portfolio sits on more than 836,100 acres of land nationwide.
Jesus Salas, a finance professor at Lehigh University (who has examined the prospects of privatizing the U.S. Postal Service) said some of its real estate holdings "are very valuable" including in big cities such as New York.
"That's significant value. Those are good locations," Salas said.
Trump, whose business fortune and public notoriety have been driven by his real estate development ventures, renewed USPS privatizing chatter last month during a post-election press conference from his estate in Florida.
"There is talk about the Postal Service being taken private, you do know that — not the worst idea I've ever heard," Trump said. "It's a lot different today between Amazon and UPS and FedEx, and all the things you didn't have. But there is talk about that. It's an idea that a lot of people have liked for a long time. We're looking at that."
USPS lost $9.5 billion in fiscal year 2024 on $79.5 billion in revenue and lost $6.5 billion on $78.2 billion in revenue in fiscal year 2023. The fiscal year 2024 losses reflect declining traditional mail volumes, USPS CFO Joseph Corbett said in a USPS announcement in November.
Postmaster General Louis DeJoy, who was appointed by Trump in 2020, has been undertaking a $40 billion restructuring effort that has worried some rural lawmakers over plans to reorganize mail processing and deliveries.
Chris Edwards, an economist and fiscal policy analyst for the conservative Cato Institute, favors privatization, citing similar efforts in Japan and Germany.
"I think that they have to wake up and face reality," Edwards said, pointing to USPS financial losses.
From a business and efficiency perspective, the USPS does not need all of its more than 31,000 post offices, according to Edwards.
"Some of them only get like only one or two customers per day," Edwards said, noting those are not just rural locations.
He points to other countries where mail services are offered at grocery stores as a potential alternative.
Edwards also argues younger generations are less and less reliant on mail and that a privatized USPS could go to every-other-day deliveries instead of its currently mandated 6 days per week.
"The world has changed," he said.
But Salas is not sure there is a political appetite to close local post offices across the country, noting the potential for problems if hometown post offices were to be closed by some new corporate parent.
"Trump's base is in the rural areas," he said.
In Montana, for example, federal lawmakers have objected to USPS plans to move mail processing from Missoula and Spokane, Washington.
Opposition from lawmakers from both sides of the aisle to local post office closures as well as other operational challenges makes Salas question how much political capital Trump might expend on the matter.
"I think it is a big can of worms," Salas said.
Postal workers unions representing many of USPS' just under 640,000 workers — along with direct mail and other groups and industries that still rely on traditional mail — are also poised to oppose a privatization push which will have to navigate narrow GOP majorities in Congress.
Some Democrats and advocates on the political left also are opposed to privatization of the post office and other federal agencies.
"The USPS is the nation's lifeline, ensuring delivery to every corner of the country. We cannot allow it to be dismantled, sold off, and handed over to Wall Street billionaires for profit," said Robert Reich, a liberal economist and former U.S. Labor Secretary.
"Privatization would increase costs, reduce access, and be an utter disaster," he said.
Going to every-other-day deliveries isn't necessarily good for business and USPS, and Washington still needs to figure out mammoth retirement obligations that have been a financial albatross, according to Salas.
USPS had previously covered the health care costs of retirees — which financially burdened its bottom line.
"The USPS is still performing poorly — in great part because of the retirement obligations it has toward the employees (related to health and pension). Some of those concerns have fallen because of the 2022 regulation that forces USPS retirees to opt into Medicare Part B first," Salas said. "There are still huge holes in the retirement-related liabilities (upwards of $100 billion)."
Privatization and potential sales of real estate and land holdings could help alleviate some of that burden, but it is still an obstacle to overcome.
Salas said privatized post offices would likely be treated like a regulated utility with government oversight of its operations and prices, although he does worry about how assets would be privatized.
Edwards is more optimistic about the odds of some sort of privatization in a second Trump term and with a Republican Congress.
The Cato analyst is also hoping for some unlikely allies in the push.
"There are green arguments," Edwards said.
Trump could rescind Biden administration efforts to convert more USPS vehicles to electric.
But Edwards said the groups concerned about climate change should also welcome efforts to make deliveries more efficient and reduce USPS' real estate footprint.
"31,000 locations — It's just a waste of energy," Edwards said.

title: Brighter Christmas Fund provides holiday gifts for almost 500 kids
author: Staff Writer
content:
Brighter Christmas Fund provides holiday gifts for almost 500 kids

 January 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 340
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The 41st annual Brighter Christmas Fund raised over $60,000 this holiday season as part of its yearly effort to bring joy to children on the Mid-Shore.The effort's main focus was to help Santa provide children in need presents to open during the Christmas season.
"As a challenging economy played a big role in contributions in 2024, I was surprised and very grateful that so many local individuals stepped up to provide help to our community's children," said Orestes Baez, regional president of APG Chesapeake, which oversees The Star Democrat. "Of course, we wish — and I know our donors do as well — we could help more and more each year, but we are thankful for the support of so many. Truly heartwarming."
This holiday season, the Brighter Christmas Fund helped 495 children receive holiday presents. This included 126 children in Caroline County, 114 children in Dorchester County, 73 children in Kent County, 34 children in Queen Anne's County and 148 children in Talbot County.
The 2024 Brighter Christmas Fund raised $64,126.42 to go to local families in future years.
The Star Democrat donates all the fund's administrative operating costs.
From late October through the end of January, The Star Democrat published stories daily about families in Talbot, Caroline, Dorchester, Queen Anne's and Kent counties who were struggling to provide a Christmas for their children. These stories were the only way The Star Democrat solicited donations for the Brighter Christmas Fund.
The Brighter Christmas Fund is a nonprofit charity which helps families in need on the Mid-Shore,
Donations may be sent to The Star Democrat, 29088 Airpark Dr., Easton, MD 21601. Donations also may be made online via credit card or PayPal at brighterchristmasfund.org. Click the "Donate" button. Donations are tax-deductible.
The administrative costs for the Brighter Christmas Fund are covered entirely by The Star Democrat and APG Chesapeake, so 100% of donations go to families in need. For more information about the fund, call 410-200-1884.
Those sharing the spirit of giving with others this holiday included:

Anne Riordan.

title: Eastern Shore legislators return to Annapolis ready to tackle budget
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Eastern Shore legislators return to Annapolis ready to tackle budget

 January 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: General Assembly 
 
 623
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — As Eastern Shore legislators returned Annapolis for the first day of the 2025 General Assembly Wednesday, they brought goals of keeping taxes from increasing and a readiness to work with those across the aisle to ensure that."I think it's going to be an interesting session where everything's on the table, and I have a good feeling — I like to be an optimist — that we're going to work together more this year on behalf of Marylanders," said Del. Jay Jacobs (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline) in an interview with The Star Democrat.
Throughout the first day of the 2025 legislative session, the state's budget deficit was a leading topic of discussion. The state is facing a predicted $2.7 billion budget deficit in fiscal year 2026. Gov. Wes Moore (D) needs to submit a balanced budget proposal to the legislature by Jan. 15.
For Maryland's Republican legislators, which includes almost all of the Eastern Shore's legislators, the budget is the number one concern.
During a Wednesday morning media event held by the General Assembly's Republican leadership, Eastern Shore legislator and Senate Minority Leader Stephen Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline) said that the governor had announced his budget proposal would address $2 billion of the $2.7 billion deficit. Hershey said the remainder of the deficit would need to be addressed by the General Assembly.
"And that can either be done through additional cuts or through revenue enhancements and increases," Hershey said. "The Republican Caucus stands firm that we are not going to be supporting any type of tax or fee increases at all."
After saying that Democratic policies are the reason for the state's fiscal situation, Hershey said Republican legislators "stand ready to work with (Democrats)."
"We will offer vigorous debate," he said. "At the same time, we will look for compromise in situations that we can. But we are optimistic that we will be able to find a solution that balances the budget without adding any additional taxes or fee increases."
In her speech to the House of Delegates, Speaker Adrienne Jones (D-Baltimore County) said she knows there's be a lot of discussion about the state's "fiscal limitations."
"And there should be," she said. "We can't deny our difficult fiscal reality. But instead of talking about what our budget can't do, I'd like to talk about what it can do. Most importantly, our budget has the power to protect the most vulnerable Marylanders."
Several Shore legislators voiced that the state's budget dilemma may put Republicans, who only make up about a third of the state's legislature, in a better position to negotiate for their goals.
Jacobs said he thinks the Republicans and Democrats are going to have to work together "to some degree." He said he thinks finding compromise might be easier this year compared to past years as a result.
"I think a lot of us agree on not taxing the citizens any more," Jacobs said.
Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said the session isn't going to be an easy one for Republican legislators.
"But I do think we'll be listened to," he said. "And I'm looking forward to some hardy debates on the floor about some of these issues."
Del. Jefferson Ghrist (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline) said he thinks this could be the "most contentious" legislative session that he has been a part of in the last decade.
"I'm hoping that we can persuade the leaders that be in the State of Maryland that we're not going to raise taxes this session," he said.
At the Republican leadership media event Wednesday morning, House of Delegates Minority Leader Jason Buckel (R-1B, Allegany County) said that Republican legislators are ready to come up with "constructive ideas" to address the budget deficit.
"We cannot tax our way to prosperity," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the state budget deficit, fiscal policy, and legislative actions to address economic issues, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Governor will not push beer and wine sales, he says
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Governor will not push beer and wine sales, he says

 January 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 400
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Gov. Wes Moore (D) made a strong push for beer and wine sales in grocery stores in Maryland last month. But he changed his stance before the Maryland General Assembly convened for the start of this year's legislative session."This is not going to be one of my administration's priorities," Moore said to The Daily Record's Eye on Annapolis summit just a few hours before legislators gathered for the opening day of the 2025 General Assembly.
Talbot County is the only county in Maryland where beer and wine can currently be purchased at a grocery store. Maryland is one of five states where the sale of beer and wine is not permitted in grocery stores and similar establishments. Other states include Alaska, Delaware, Minnesota and Rhode Island.
Last month, Moore told news outlets around the state that he would push legislators to pass a bill permitting beer and wine sales in grocery stores during this year's General Assembly.
Even when Moore pushed, legislators from the Eastern Shore believed a potential bill on the matter would be overshadowed by state money matters.
"We have a $2.7 billion deficit this year, and I would think that the governor would have more important things to be worried about than beer and wine sales," Del. Chris Adams (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said.
Both Adams and Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said this issue has come up every year they have been in office.
"I'm on the committee jurisdiction for alcohol," Adams said. "Our committee has heard this bill in years past, and we've not supported it because it would be devastating to small business owners that many of which are in my district and here on the Eastern Shore and have been very vocal about their concerns about this kind of legislation."
What has stopped this bill in the past, the legislators said, is the effect competition beer and wine sales in grocery stores will create for small business owners.
"Even in Talbot County, where they sell beer and wine and even liquor in grocery stores. If you speak to those vendors that are liquor stores, they will tell you that while they've been able to survive, that those grocery stores are an economic competitor to them," Mautz said. "So the idea that, well, this works in Talbot County, or works throughout the state, I think is a big assumption as far as not putting these stores out of business." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the governor's decision on legislation affecting beer and wine sales in grocery stores, focusing on economic implications for small businesses and state budget priorities, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Gov. Moore orders state to tighten its belt — but bigger cuts are coming
author: JACK BOWMAN Capital News Service
content:
Gov. Moore orders state to tighten its belt — but bigger cuts are coming

 January 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JACK BOWMAN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 261
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Gov. Wes Moore signed an executive order Friday directing his administration to scour the state's spending for waste and inefficiency, with a goal of producing $50 million in savings.Moore announced the effort, called the Government Modernization Initiative, two days after promising to propose a budget with $2 billion in cuts, an attempt to address a projected $3 billion deficit.
"It's finding the breakage in the systems and fixing them so we're not papering it over in more expensive ways later on," Moore said of the initiative in a Friday announcement.
The initiative is aimed at finding inconsistent or unnecessary spending throughout state government, fixing "things that have long been broken."
Moore went on to mention inefficiencies including under-utilized state vehicles and inconsistently-priced technology and equipment that, if addressed, could save the state $50 million "this year alone."
Chief Performance Officer Asma Mirza and the performance cabinet will spearhead the effort. Elisabeth Sachs, a longtime nonprofit and state and local government leader, will also contribute to the project.
Boston Consulting Group will also be brought on to aid in the analysis. In a pay-for-performance contract approved in October, the state will pay the firm, one of the "big three" in strategy consulting, a 20% share of the savings achieved, with a maximum payout of $15 million.
The study will begin this year, with a goal of implementing changes by fiscal year 2026, which begins in July.
"We know the challenges that exist," Moore said. "It's created a chance for this team to show what we're made of, because we will address it, and Maryland will grow." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Salisbury fine metal artisans prepare products for inauguration
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Salisbury fine metal artisans prepare products for inauguration

 January 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Business 
 
 529
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On the workshop floor of Salisbury Inc., skilled men and women work attentively and proficiently under dozens of American flags. In their hands are sleek trays, cups and other products receiving careful changes under heavy machinery.Each person, in protective gear, carefully works to create countless commemorative products engraved with Americana symbols for the upcoming inauguration of President-elect Donald Trump.
More than 600 products were sent to Washington earlier this week, where they were received by members of Trump's team as part of a longstanding tradition at Salisbury.
The company has a rich history of providing engraved commemorative gifts for presidents and other government officials.
For over 30 years, Salisbury has crafted engraved pewter trays, picture frames, jewelry boxes and 700 other products showing appreciation for the country.
In preparation for the 2025 inauguration, the Salisbury team has been crafting items featuring Trump's signature and other symbols of the presidency.
Joseph Bernstein, sales manager for Salisbury, said they are proud to continue the tradition of pewter work.
"Pewter in itself has a rich history," Bernstein said. "Paul Revere was a pewter smith. Pewter was brought over from England to America, and we made it our own. So we have a rich tradition of making pewter smithing in this country.
"It is, in itself, Americana. They're valuable keepsakes and commemoratives that can be passed down for generations."
Bernstein said the company started crafting items for politicians during the Ronald Reagan presidency. During his time in office, Reagan had his presidential seal with his and first lady Nancy Reagan's signatures turned into Americana products.
Since then, the company has made similar products for U.S. senators and representatives, other presidents and for commemorative events.
The products being prepared with engraved signatures will have several uses, Bernstein shared. Some of the products are in preparation for the president-elect, who, according to Bernstein, purchases the products from Salisbury with donations and uses them as gifts and for personal use.
During Trump's last term in office, his team would order between 50 to 100 pieces from time to time, sometimes putting in orders for additional products when he was traveling to visit other leaders nationally and internationally.
Additionally, different organizations will purchase the products to use for events.
According to Bernstein, Salisbury's products are in no way a political statement, and the company has gone out of its way to stay out of politics due to polarization. The company is proud to serve Republicans, Democrats and other parties "all with the same respect."
For Bernstein, appreciation for Americana goes beyond political lines. He shared that julep cups, a drinking vessel traditionally used to serve mint julep, is his favorite type of product. Bernstein describes it as "if you were drinking from a fine leaded crystal, just one of those things that enhances the experience."
Overall, Bernstein said as they prepare for the inauguration of President Donald Trump, the company is working hard to provide its best products and is excited to continue to serve every political representative in the future.
"Salisbury has been around since 1979, and we are proud to be, to serve, we are proud to be on the Eastern Shore and commemorated, and proud to be a small part of commemorating our American heritage," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a local company's production of commemorative metal goods for a presidential inauguration, highlighting its operations, sales, and economic activity, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Maryland gas prices drop 2 cents over past week
author: GAS BUDDY
content:
Maryland gas prices drop 2 cents over past week

 January 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GAS BUDDY | Section: State News 
 
 458
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 2.1 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.10 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 14.2 cents per gallon higher than a month ago and stand 3.9 cents per gallon higher than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has increased 3.7 cents in the last week and stands at $3.525 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.39 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.79 per gallon, a difference of $1.40 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 1.1 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.02 per gallon Monday. The national average is up 0.9 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 3.2 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
Jan. 13, 2024: $3.06 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.05 per gallon)Jan. 13, 2023: $3.28 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.26 per gallon)Jan. 13, 2022: $3.24 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.31 per gallon)Jan. 13, 2021: $2.44 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.37 per gallon)Jan. 13, 2020: $2.54 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.58 per gallon)Jan. 13, 2019: $2.21 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.24 per gallon)Jan. 13, 2018: $2.54 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.53 per gallon)Jan. 13, 2017: $2.37 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.34 per gallon)Jan. 13, 2016: $1.94 per gallon (U.S. Average: $1.95 per gallon)Jan. 13, 2015: $2.27 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.11 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.09 per gallon, down 3.1 cents per gallon from last week's $3.12 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.11 per gallon, down 1.8 cents per gallon from last week's $3.13 per gallon.Hagerstown: $3.08 per gallon, down 1 cent per gallon from last week's $3.09 per gallon.
"It's been a relatively quiet week for the national average price of gasoline, with little overall movement. However, colder weather has pushed diesel prices higher and could also impact gasoline prices if refiners face disruptions," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "While gas prices haven't shifted significantly yet, oil prices have climbed to their highest level since October, driven by President Biden's new sanctions on so-called dark vessels, which have slowed countries like Iran's ability to sell oil. This could soon lead to more noticeable increases in gas prices. Seasonally weak demand may help soften the impact of any increases for now, but with refinery maintenance season just weeks away—when refiners typically reduce gasoline production—motorists should be prepared for the spring rally to kick off." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Queen Anne's economic outlook shows 19% surge in businesses, population gains
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Queen Anne's economic outlook shows 19% surge in businesses, population gains

 January 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 777
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — Celebrating the new year with progressive mindsets and forward thinking, the Queen Anne's County Economic Development Commission hosted its first economic outlook to highlight the county's progress and challenges and unveil strategic plans for the future at the Kent Island Resort Jan. 9.Along with a breakfast buffet and networking, Queen Anne's County Economic and Tourism Development (QACETD) and the Economic Development Commission welcomed regional stakeholders and business leaders to explore economic growth, community development, and public services and sustainability to shape local tourism and business development.
Providing an economic development forecast and historical legacy of the area, QACETD Director Heather Tinelli noted Queen Anne's is the fastest-growing county on Maryland's Eastern Shore and the second-fastest growing in the state.
In 1970, Queen Anne's County had a population of about 18,000.
In 2001, the population was 41,000 and 50,000 by 2019. By 2028, the population is expected to be around 55,000, she said.
Moving forward, the largest industries in the county look to include wholesale trade, government, education, manufacturing and food services, according to Tinelli.
Agriculture and maritime industries continue to be foundational aspects of the county's economy and history that will always be supported, she said.
Highlighting key performance indicators, Tinelli noted year to date, Queen Anne's County has had approximately $30 million in commercial property sales and $77.8 million in new commercial construction. In 2023, the county had the fifth-highest per capita income in the state, she said.
The county saw a 19% growth in businesses overall in 2024, and Commissioner Patrick McLaughlin noted it is the resiliency of residents and local businesses taking risks that keeps the county thriving with jobs and revenue.
"You are the engine of our county, you create the jobs," he said.
Panels of experts led discussion on key economic development topics, including providing an overview of the recently adopted Queen Anne's County Economic Development Five-Year Strategic Plan.
Five priorities of the economic development commission include: maintaining a sense of community and enhancing quality of life; championing the increase of accessible workforce housing; diversifying and expanding transportation; facilitating business growth and attraction; and elevating tourism throughout the county.
Tackling infrastructure, housing, health care and education, another panel discussed the county's achievements, challenges and opportunities facing core priorities.
QACETD in partnership with Queen Anne's County Public Schools (QACPS) has implemented career development programs for students and established Direct Work Experience Curriculum. More than 145 businesses have provided career awareness learning opportunities through classrooms, career fairs, field trips and directed work experience.
QACETD continues to coordinate apprenticeships and internship opportunities for high schoolers in fields such as culinary, engineering, technology and trades with partnerships with QACPS career coaches.
Realtor experts led another roundtable addressing different types of future development in the county including commercial, residential and real estate and alignments with broader regional goals of infrastructure, housing and economic growth.
The demand for housing is strong in Queen Anne's County, with the median price of housing at $543,000, said Barry Waterman of Waterman Realty.
The demand for office space is shifting away from just cubicles and more toward flexible and smaller spaces including lounges to both serve as an incentive to bring people into the office and address remote work, according to Mason Popham, commercial realtor.
County accomplishments include 4-H Park improvements, Kent Island branch library expansions, public sewer extensions and supporting local nonprofits, County Commissioner Chris Corchiarino said.
Future plans and developments of the region include supporting the state-of-the-art regional hospital, finalizing plans for a new Bay Bridge crossing, ratifying an agreement for the mid-shore regional detention center and expansion of pedestrian trail systems, Corchiarino said.
Jack Wilson, county commissioner and recently appointed Maryland Association of Counties (MACo) president, noted MACo is the largest lobbying group in the state and ensures rural counties have a voice across all jurisdictions.
From a legislative side, Wilson noted state budget shortfalls come from the Blueprint for Maryland's Future. MACo focuses on senate or house bills that directly affect the fiscal or autonomy of counties such as mandated policies or spending, he said.
The state is in a huge budget deficit going into the legislative session, and the governor has stated economic development as a priority to increase revenue, Wilson said.
Economic development takes into account who is moving to the area and what amenities and services resources are needed to continue to be a thriving community, Tinelli said.
Legislative leaders are now noting the crucial role economic development plays, and it is imperative to have tools to continually support these incentives, she said.
Queen Anne's County gets the best of both worlds, according to Tinelli, with an economy that more mirrors Western Shore neighbors while enjoying a quality of life that is all Eastern Shore.
For more information about QACETD and the Economic Development Commission, visit choosequeenannes.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Queen Anne's County's economic outlook, business growth, commercial development, and strategic economic plans, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Moore hopes to make Maryland the quantum capital of the world
author: JACK BOWMAN Capital News Service
content:
Moore hopes to make Maryland the quantum capital of the world

 January 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JACK BOWMAN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 444
 Words 

 Read News Document

 COLLEGE PARK — Gov. Moore is pledging to make Maryland the "quantum capital of the world," proposing a significant investment into the industry of super-fast computing amid a budget crisis in the state.Speaking at the College Park headquarters of IonQ, a leading quantum computing company, Moore said Tuesday he believes quantum is one of the industries in which Maryland has a competitive advantage, industries that could help grow an economy he said has been stagnant for too long.
"I refuse to have, in this moment, with the talent we have in the field, for Maryland to be a state that is just simply going to manage decline," Moore said. "Maryland, if we grow, we win. We're going to grow."
In his address to the crowd, which included representatives from IonQ, the University of Maryland and other industry leaders, Moore announced a $27.5 million investment in the new "Capital of Quantum" initiative. Moore described the project as a joint venture between the state, the University of Maryland, IonQ and "other partners in the quantum computing space."
Moore described the goal of the investment as a simple one: "to make Maryland the capital of quantum of the world."
The announcement of the initiative follows a week of financial volatility in the quantum industry. Stock for IonQ and other companies in the field have seen dramatic rises and falls over the past several days after figures like Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang and Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg questioned the idea of quantum computing being ready in the near future.
Despite this, Moore believes investing in the industry is a good short-term bet, and an even better one in the long-term.
"I think this is actually a smart bet for our GDP growth early," Moore told CNS in a gaggle with reporters, "and I think it's an incredibly smart bet for our long-term prospects of having something that Maryland can really pride itself on as having one of the leading spaces in the industry."
Quantum computing, a rapidly-emerging industry in the technology space, involves using quantum mechanics to produce answers to problems far faster than current computers can. The applications of such technology are wide-ranging, including artificial intelligence, pharmaceutical research and cybersecurity.
"Quantum computing doesn't just bend reality," Lt. Gov. Aruna Miller said at IonQ headquarters. "It redefines it, solving problems in ways we never, ever thought possible."
Along with the focused spending in quantum computing, Moore also announced a larger $750 million investment in "economic growth and workforce development," with a focus on leveraging the assets that Maryland has to grow the state's economy.
"Oftentimes," Moore said, "we have been asset-rich and strategy-poor. We haven't prioritized the areas that need to be prioritized. Well, today that changes." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
