title: Mid-Shore residents face sharp energy bill spikes despite modest rate increase predictions
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content:
Mid-Shore residents face sharp energy bill spikes despite modest rate increase predictions

 January 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 840
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Delmarva Power customers across Maryland's Eastern Shore are reporting dramatic increases in their utility bills, with some seeing their December charges double or triple despite the company's October prediction of an estimated 3% rate hike.Delmarva Power, a subsidiary of Illinois-based Exelon Corporation, provides electric service to 208,000 Maryland customers throughout the Eastern Shore, as well as in Delaware.
The utility operates in a unique market position where regional energy consumption significantly exceeds local production capacity, forcing reliance on out-of-state power generation.
"Maryland and Delaware use a lot more energy than those states are able to produce, necessitating the purchase of out-of-state generated energy," said Zach Chizar, senior communications specialist with Delmarva Power.
The cost of purchased energy remains a supply and demand situation, Chizar said.
Delmarva Power's cost structure differs from nonprofit cooperative companies like Choptank Electric, which operates under a different business model as a member-owned utility.
A Queen Anne's County resident who tracks daily usage through Delmarva's monitoring system reported paying premium rates between 6 a.m. and midnight, with lower rates only available during overnight hours. On Kent Island, another customer struggling with tiered billing discovered they were being charged higher rates after exceeding baseline usage levels, a pricing structure designed to encourage conservation.
"Tier 2 electric charges refers to a higher electricity rate applied when a customer exceeds a certain baseline usage level," the Kent Island resident explained. "Essentially, it's a higher price for electricity once you use more than a set amount within a billing cycle."
In Betterton and surrounding Kent County, customers have shared documentation showing projected January costs approaching 200% higher than their November charges, even after implementing energy-efficient upgrades. These increases far exceed Delmarva Power's projected rise from $144 to $147 for average monthly residential bills.
The rate structure breaks down into several components: a distribution rate of $0.069815 per kilowatt-hour, which covers 87% of distribution costs for average customers, a monthly customer charge of $9.19, and a supply cost of $0.09961 per kilowatt-hour as of January 2025. An additional EmPOWER surcharge of $0.0085 per kilowatt-hour is also applied, based on monthly consumption of 900 kilowatt-hours.
The utility's cost structure is divided between distribution and supply charges. Distribution involves the infrastructure costs of moving electricity from power plants like Dominion Energy through transmission lines and substations to end users. Supply charges reflect the actual cost of purchasing energy plus administrative fees — costs that are particularly significant for for-profit utilities like Delmarva Power.
The company's last rate case in 2022 established a multi-year rate plan, with 2025 marking the conclusion of the federally approved three-year distribution rate increases. This regulatory framework has shaped the utility's pricing strategy, though Chizar indicates future rates remain unsettled but trending upward.
Some customers report receiving conflicting information about the causes of rate increases. "Delmarva is claiming new regulations put in place by state government officials and the Governor are forcing them to purchase more electricity from out of state," one customer said. Another reported receiving notice that their third-party supplier would no longer serve Maryland due to new state regulations.
Customer frustrations extend beyond rate increases. Residents report estimated bills not being corrected to reflect actual meter readings, particularly affecting seasonal properties and homes temporarily disconnected from utilities. Some existing customers have received unexpected demands for security deposits ranging from $800 to $845, an issue Chizar was not able to immediately address.
A lack of knowledgeable help only adds to the frustration felt by a Federalsburg woman who saw her December bill hit $786. Reaching out to customer service and explaining they had recently replaced their home's windows to more energy efficient ones, she was told regarding the rising bill "I don't know what else to tell you." She fears her next bill will only be higher.
One former power company worker raised concerns about the lack of real-time usage monitoring for consumers. "The power company is in the position of only having their side where the consumer can't respond with actual usage," he said. "As consumers, we don't have real-time knowledge of how many amps our appliances are using."
Delmarva Power has expanded its assistance programs in response to mounting customer concerns. The company's new Assistance Finder tool, accessible through customer accounts, helps identify suitable financial assistance and bill management programs. The utility also offers a Time of Use Rate option, allowing customers to opt for lower rates during off-peak hours.
Additional assistance options include:
Payment arrangements with flexible terms.Budget billing to spread costs evenly throughout the year.Energy assistance programs for income-qualified customers.Free home energy assessments.Rebates for energy-efficient equipment upgrades.
"We want to be unearthing any stone that might help customers save any energy they can," Chizar said. He encourages customers with unusual billing situations to contact Delmarva's customer care team at 800-375-7117.
The company recommends several energy-saving measures, including setting thermostats to 68 degrees when health permits, utilizing natural sunlight for heating during the day, and maintaining heating equipment regularly. According to Delmarva Power, lowering the thermostat by just one degree can reduce heating costs by up to 5%.
Customers seeking additional information about energy conservation and assistance programs can visit delmarva.com/WaysToSave. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on utility rate hikes, billing structures, and consumer financial assistance, which are primarily economic and business-related issues rather than sports, health, or cultural topics.

title: Brandon Yost is reinvesting in St. Michaels one sub at a time
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Brandon Yost is reinvesting in St. Michaels one sub at a time

 January 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Business 
 
 449
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — Brandon Yost did not have plans to open a Subway. He was originally looking to buy a house in St. Michaels when his real estate agent told him the Subway in town was up for sale and suggested he take a look at it.In an attempt to provide affordable and quick meals to the residents of St. Michaels, Yost, a graduate of St. Michaels Middle High School, has taken over ownership of the sandwich shop with the intent to reinvest in his community.
According to Yost, the previous owner was ready to retire and had been operating the store for about five years.
"Initially I said, 'No way. This isn't my cup of tea. I'm not going to do it,'" said Yost, who has a background in commercial insurance brokerage.
He changed his mind after sitting in the restaurant and watching the people coming in for a meal.
"It was a lot of local people, a lot of high school teachers and things that I hadn't seen in a while, policemen, firemen, just people I really resonate with," he said.
With new ownership will come changes for this sandwich store, including changes to store hours and days of operation.
Yost said the previous owner would open the store for only a few days out of the week. Yost plans to have the store open seven days, expand the menu and grow the Subway team.
Bruce "JR" Burkhardt, a school guidance counselor at St. Michaels Middle High School, said he used to coach Yost when he was at the school. Burkhardt describes Yost as not only a three-sport athlete but also a hardworking and intelligent person.
Burkhardt said he enjoys seeing graduates of St. Michaels come back as adults and give back to their community, whether it be owning a business, helping with a nonprofit or volunteering in the community.
"The thing that makes small towns special is that sense of community and everybody supporting one another and giving back, especially down here in St. Michaels," Burkhardt said. "The community is heavily involved in the school and helping one another, whether it's a family that is in need, or sponsoring the local baseball team, or whatever it is. It's great to see everybody pitch in and help one another."
Yost said reinvesting in the people of St. Michaels through affordable meals has been the biggest motivator in taking over ownership, and he hopes he can provide a space for locals to enjoy.
"Obviously, I wanted to make money like anybody," Yost said. "You buy business to make money, but at the same time I really wanted to give back to the locals and have a good resource for them to go and eat at an affordable meal." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a local entrepreneur acquiring and expanding a Subway restaurant to serve the community, which is clearly a business/economic story. Education is mentioned only incidentally through the subject's school background.

title: State's budget could come at small biz expense
author: MARY D. KANE Maryland Chamber of Commerce
content:
State's budget could come at small biz expense

 January 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARY D. KANE Maryland Chamber of Commerce | Section: Columns 
 
 683
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Gov. Wes Moore's newly released fiscal year 2026 budget presents a paradox for Maryland's economic future. While the governor rightly prioritizes economic growth and job creation, his proposed tax policies threaten to undermine these objectives.As a business leader deeply invested in Maryland's prosperity, I've watched countless businesses weather economic uncertainties while remaining committed to our state. These community cornerstones — local restaurants, family-owned retail shops and businesses you rely on daily for energy, health care, construction and essential services — form the backbone of Maryland's economy.
Now, they face a new challenge: a slate of tax proposals that could make it harder for them to survive and provide critical services to every Marylander.
The governor's budget proposal includes personal income tax increases, but this isn't just about wealthy individuals paying more. In Maryland, 99.5% of businesses structured as pass-through entities — LLCs, sole proprietorships, partnerships and S-corps — pay taxes at individual tax rates.
Under the governor's plan, small businesses could be forced to pay higher tax rates, which will increase the cost of goods and services upon which every Marylander relies. Additionally, when we raise these rates, we're effectively telling a small business owner in Baltimore, a growing HVAC company serving multiple counties or a family restaurant in Annapolis to think twice before expanding.
The budget proposal also includes combined reporting — a volatile and complex tax policy that would force businesses operating across state lines to navigate an intricate maze of compliance requirements. This impacts businesses of all sizes — from restaurants to retail shops that cross state lines — and multiple studies suggest the policy could result in the state losing revenue.
Beyond being an administrative burden, combined reporting discourages investment in Maryland when we most need to attract and retain businesses. Importantly, Maryland already has tools like the 2004 "add-back" rule, which, if fully enforced, would achieve similar goals without introducing new burdensome policies.
Some might argue these measures are necessary for fiscal responsibility. But true fiscal responsibility means creating conditions where businesses grow, generate more revenue and create more jobs — naturally expanding our tax base. The governor's budget gets this partially right. Its provisions for streamlining regulations, improving permitting processes and investing in critical industries like ports, manufacturing and cybersecurity are commendable.
But that positive step forward would be undermined by tax policies that discourage growth, investment and economic opportunity.
Among the 50 states, Maryland is currently the third most expensive to do business in, ranks 37th for business friendliness and 46th for business tax climate. Our job growth statistics are equally concerning — we rank 49th for overall job growth and 48th for three-year compound growth as of July 2024. Maryland already ranks 44th nationally in new business applications and has experienced the sixth-slowest growth in new business formation since 2019. Finally, we're losing existing residents at an alarming rate, ranking 46th in domestic migration.
These are warning signs. Adding new tax burdens would further discourage entrepreneurs from choosing Maryland as their launching pad, disincentivize existing businesses from expanding, and more quickly drive workers to our neighboring states.
As other states aggressively compete for business investment and talent, Maryland stands at a crossroads. We can either create an environment that welcomes growth and innovation or sacrifice long-term prosperity for short-term revenue gains.
The good news is that this budget proposal is just the beginning of the conversation. As the proposal moves through the legislative process, we have an opportunity to work together — business leaders, lawmakers and the administration — to craft a final budget that truly serves Maryland's future. The path forward requires careful consideration of alternative approaches: creating economic opportunity through growth-oriented policies, simplifying our tax code and empowering small businesses are achievable goals that we should all share.
Maryland's future prosperity depends on making our state a destination of choice for businesses and families. We can achieve fiscal stability without sacrificing economic growth. But first, we must recognize that squeezing more from our existing businesses will harm Maryland's economy.
The stakes are too high to get this wrong. Let's work together to ensure Maryland's budget supports, rather than hinders, the economic growth we all seek. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the state budget, tax proposals, and their impact on small businesses and the broader economy, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Mid-Shore legislators express concern over tax hikes in governor’s budget proposal
author: Konner Metz
content:
Mid-Shore legislators express concern over tax hikes in governor’s budget proposal

 January 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 793
 Words 

 Read News Document

 With the state facing a significant deficit, some Mid-Shore legislators are raising concerns that the governor's proposed budget may negatively impact local constituents and businesses.In his fiscal year 2026 budget proposal presented Wednesday, Gov. Wes Moore (D) suggested both tax cuts and increases, as well as spending cuts, to tackle the state's looming $3 billion budget gap.
Moore's proposal lays out two new tax brackets for high-income households: a 6.25% rate for those who make more than $500,000 and a 6.5% rate for those who make more than $1 million.
Meanwhile, it consolidates the state's bottom four tax brackets and doubles the standard deduction on tax returns, two measures expected to provide tax breaks to Marylanders, Moore says. The governor plans to reduce corporate taxes "to entice more businesses and drive growth."
But local legislators aren't fully on board with Moore's plans to offset the deficit. Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) shared his reaction after watching Moore's live press conference on Wednesday.
"My initial reaction was a little jaw-dropping," Hutchinson said. "I felt like it was a little bit of smoke and mirrors on the way that he was presenting the budget."
Hutchinson says while lower corporate taxes look "nice on the surface," he's most concerned for local small businesses with the new tax brackets.
"That's where it's really going to hurt the small business owners because they pass through a lot of their small businesses through their personal income taxes," Hutchinson said. "So it's going to be detrimental, actually, to small businesses in my opinion."
Del. Sheree Sample-Hughes (D-Dorchester, Wicomico) noted Moore's proposal to eliminate the inheritance tax as a positive. However, she's worried some of the spending reductions will burden counties, such as the expectation that counties will supplement proposed state reductions in teacher retirement funding.
Hutchinson and Del. Jeff Ghrist (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) both likened Moore's tax hikes for the wealthy to tax increases seen under former Gov. Martin O'Malley (D).
Sample-Hughes and Ghrist are worried the tax increases will drive Marylanders elsewhere, specifically the "half-millionaires" and above.
"One of my fears is is that if we continually tax the upper bracket, they're going to … move to Delaware or move to other neighboring states," Sample-Hughes said.
"The folks who have the money, they reinvest in the economy with their wealth," Ghrist said. " … We're just shooting ourselves in the foot is what we're doing. It's terrible economic policy."
Hutchinson is optimistic the tax cuts in the lower brackets may help local residents, but he shares the other legislators' worries about the increases for wealthy residents.
"I think a lot of the local residents on the Shore will have a positive effect on the change to the lower tax bracket," Hutchinson said. "But my fear is sometimes we rob Peter to pay Paul. While we'll all stay because we love it and we want to be here, again, those high-income earners have the opportunity to go multiple places when there's a tax increase on their personal income tax."
MOVING FORWARDSince the Democrats have a firm majority in the legislature, some Republicans understand that there's limited ability to push forward their spending and tax policies.
"There's really not much we can do. We're outnumbered two to one," Ghrist said. "The only thing we can do is inform the public about what's going on, inform the public about what these impacts are going to be."
Ghrist believes it will "be an ugly session for taxpayers."
He and Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) say a better way to address the budget gap would be to find savings in government efficiency efforts.
"I look for things that are consensus ideas," Mautz said. He believes this year's budget will undergo more scrutiny than recent ones and potentially see "significant changes" during the legislative session.
Hutchinson says Republicans will be "very vocal," adding that some of his Democratic colleagues have their own concerns about the budget proposal.
"What was laid out on Wednesday — I am sure — is not going to be the final version that we see when we move forward in early April," Hutchinson said. "And we will be having a lot of debates over this issue. It is the number one issue."
Sample-Hughes said it's important for legislators to comb through ways in which government agency cuts can help reduce the budget gap. She wants to see that diligent work done before counties assume any more of the burden.
As for tax increases on Marylanders, Sample-Hughes is hoping that can be avoided given the current economic landscape.
"That's not something I'm supportive of because I know that the constituency is already grappling with a lot of financial burdens," Sample-Hughes said.
A final version of the state's 2026 budget must be passed by both chambers of the Maryland legislature before the end of this year's General Assembly in April. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the governor's budget proposal, tax changes, and their impact on businesses and the state economy, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic.

title: CWDI Board of Directors appoints 2025 officers
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
CWDI Board of Directors appoints 2025 officers

 January 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 336
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. Board of Directors isn't changing much for the year of 2025."Because our board (is) so new, our current officers just agreed to stay on for another year if that was acceptable to the board," Board President Angie Hengst said in an interview with The Star Democrat Friday.
Hengst will remain president for 2025. She said it feels good to be able to continue to serve in the role.
"I feel like I was very new when I became president last year," she said. "So now I feel like, after having another year with the board under my belt, and with our new relationship with the city and the county going forward, I'm feeling very optimistic about this year. And I think we have some really exciting things that are going to be coming soon."
Board member Mike Frenz will take on the role of vice president. Hengst said she nominated Frenz to the role during the board's meeting on Jan. 15 because he is one of the "longer-standing" board members on a board where half of its current members are new.
The vice president position was previously filled by Shay Lewis-Sisco, who resigned from the board after being elected to the Cambridge City Council in October.
Frenz, who is the executive director of the Maryland Stadium Authority, was appointed by the governor to the CWDI board in 2018. He could not be reached immediately for comment.
The board will keep Frank Narr as its treasurer. However, instead of Narr being the secretary-treasurer, the role will be split in two and new board member Natalie Chabot will take on the secretary position.
Hengst said her goal as president for 2025 is to increase community engagement.
This past week we had a really great kind of open dialogue," She said. "Almost more like Q&A-style, instead of just public comment, with some of the public that was (at the meeting). And I thought that was really productive. So I'm really looking forward to more of those exchanges this year." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
