title: Chesapeake Fire & Ice Festival brings economic boost to Easton in slow months
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Chesapeake Fire & Ice Festival brings economic boost to Easton in slow months

 February 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 647
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — For the fifth year in a row, Easton will host the Chesapeake Fire & Ice Festival on Feb. 14 and Feb. 15.The Easton Economic Development Corporation, which puts on the annual festival, believes the event will help with the economic shift that typically happens after the holidays.
"So in any town between the end of the Christmas shopping season and then the real pickup of tourism in May, it's pretty flat," said Holly DeKarske, executive director of Easton Economic Development Cooperation. "So events like ice festivals have been created in multiple towns during this time to try to drum up some traffic and get people down to eat, get down people down to shop."
The Fire & Ice event, presented by Preston Automotive Group, is a free, family-friendly, two-day festival featuring a trail of ice sculptures, some of which are interactive, and a slew of other programming.
"There are over 60 ice sculptures that are spread around town, from the Market at Dover Station, to downtown, to Talbot Town (Shopping Center), to the Academy Art Museum," DeKarske said.
The first night of the festival will have a Valentine's Day block party featuring live musical performances, fire pits, live ice carvings and a ice bar with beverages from Delmarva Craft and Lyon Rum in the Fire Pavilion, located at 41 South Harrison St., from 5 p.m. to 9 p.m.
The event will feature a new attraction this year, Ice Lab's paintball station.
"Ice Lab is gonna set up a little target shooting gallery, single shoot with paintball guns. It is at a gigantic ice target," DeKarske said.
Downtown of Easton will feature icy art from the carvers at Ice Lab and music.
There will be ice skating at 11 S. Harrison St., free for all ages, on both days of the festival. Cascading Carlos will be juggling fire in Thompson Park from 5 p.m. to 8 p.m. on day one and noon to 4 p.m. on day two.
On Saturday, Feb. 15, there will be a children's Ice House at the Waterfowl Building, located at 40 S. Harrison St. The house will feature free craft projects, games, hot chocolate and more.
There will also be free live musical performances from Anna Burgess, DJ E Shore, Poppy Blue Eyes and Jayla Elise.
Local restaurants and retailers will offer specials, exclusive cocktails, sales and limited-edition treats throughout the weekend, according to Easton EDC.
For the stores and restaurants that will offer sales during the event, it will give them a chance to get more customers in for the weekend and spike sales during the quietest economic time of the year.
"It could be the release of, people are getting in their spring line," DeKarske said. "Some people are running sales to clear out some of their winter clothing that they have that type of stuff. And then our restaurants have different specials going on with special drinks they created just for the event, or special meals or appetizers, that type of thing."
Easton EDC expects around 8,000 people to come to town for the event this weekend.
"The data that we pulled from this, we bring in about 8,000 people over that day and a half," DeKarske said. "So that's a huge impact from a normal day. It also brings in hotel stays. We have a lot of people coming in to stay at the local hotels and spending the weekend. So they're here to visit, not just Easton, but they'll go check out the rest of the county."
Easton EDC believes the event will continue to grow each year because organizers will add something special and different each year.
"We just continue to try to add a little something special, different to it each year and increase the format and reach of it," DeKarske said. "Making sure that we're reaching all the outer points of our Main Street district and our arts and entertainment district."
For more information on the event head to discovereaston.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Chesapeake Fire & Ice Festival's role in boosting local commerce, tourism, and sales, highlighting economic impact and business development, making Business/Economy the most fitting category.

title: Community, vendors cut the ribbon on The Market at Dover Station
author: Konner Metz
content:
Community, vendors cut the ribbon on The Market at Dover Station

 February 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Life 
 
 352
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A revitalized property in Easton officially cut the ribbon to celebrate its first phase of development and a flourishing new marketplace.Dover Station LLC is a project led by local developer Sevan Topjian and his wife, Keri. Its marketplace, The Market at Dover Station, brought together many local vendors and Easton community members Thursday for a ribbon-cutting ceremony.
So far, more than 100 artists, artisans and vendors are involved with The Market at Dover Station. It's become a destination for goods, services and antiques.
Keri Topjian, who manages the market, said the feedback from the Easton community has been "incredibly positive."
"I have people walk in that cry," Topjian said. "They either cry, they get the chills or they start pinching themselves and dancing."
Dover Station sits on a Dover Road property that was formerly Easton Wholesale Grocery, built in 1912. It was recently a roofing supply center and fell vacant before Sevan Topjian began the revitalization process.
Sitting along the Rails to Trails and in an accessible area of town, the property, he felt, presented the perfect opportunity for a central hub tailored toward Easton residents and visitors alike.
"It is such an honor to work on this beautiful building," he wrote. "We really wanted to showcase the incredible craftmanship of previous generations and to create a retail destination in town that features its original charm."
Keri Topjian says anchor vendors such as The Zebra Gallery and Savington & Hill Floral Co., among others, have helped kickstart the marketplace as a local shopping destination.
Speaking to a large crowd Thursday, Sevan Topjian encouraged the community to come up with creative, interactive ideas for events and collaborations at the marketplace.
Already, the market is bringing businesses and people together. Keri Topjian said it's reminded some people of European markets and others remark that "'this is what Easton needs.'"
"There's a crazy amount of connections that happen here," she said. "There's a lot of cross-collaboration among artists and artisans. There's just a lot of positive energy in the building."
The Market at Dover Station is open Monday through Saturday from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. and Sunday from Noon to 4 p.m. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the opening of a new marketplace, vendor participation, and local economic development, which aligns most closely with Business/Economy. It also highlights artists and artisans, giving secondary relevance to Arts & Culture.

title: Attorney general's housing lawsuit will backfire
author: RAJSHREE AGARWAL
content:
Attorney general's housing lawsuit will backfire

 February 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: RAJSHREE AGARWAL | Section: Columns 
 
 709
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It's no secret that, to quote an early internet meme, "the rent is too damn high." Maryland ranks as the sixth-most expensive state in the country, with a median monthly rent of $2,277.In such cases, it is important that our political and legal leaders focus not on finding a scapegoat but on actually fixing the problem.
On Jan. 15, Maryland Attorney General Anthony Brown filed a lawsuit against a property management software and analytics company that Maryland property owners use to, among other things, help determine the value of their rental units.
His suit has faced significant criticism from a broad coalition of Maryland residents, including economists, housing experts and civil rights advocacy groups. And for good reason.
Software doesn't drive up rents. It is merely a tool to analyze the supply and demand in local housing markets and make recommendations based on that analysis.
Blaming software when rents rise is akin to blaming your local meteorologist every time it snows.
Brown's lawsuit ignores fundamental principles from Econ 101 and the importance of "information diffusion" for markets to operate efficiency, when everybody has all the relevant facts.
Imagine a man is having a yard sale. He finds an old baseball in the attic with a signature that reads "Cal Ripken Jr." Who's that? He doesn't know. Probably just some neighborhood kid. $1 seems like a good price. And sure enough, it sells almost immediately.
Or recall the Seinfeld episode in which George Costanza overpays for a car because the dealer tells him its previous owner was Jon Voight. George assumes he means the Hollywood star, but a quick glance at the old registration reveals that the car actually belonged to a dentist named John Voight.
In both cases, the lack of relevant information led to distorted prices.
The best way to avoid that is to make sure all market participants know what they're buying or selling and how much other people are willing to pay for it. When it's harder to access that information, it forces buyers and sellers alike to rely on guesswork. You might come out ahead in a particular transaction (like George's car dealer or the guy who bought the baseball), but on a larger scale and a longer timeline, inefficiency in markets leads to the misallocation of resources. And that leaves everyone worse off.
This principle seems obvious, but seems to be missed by Brown, and also by the U.S. Department of Justice, and several attorney generals in other states who initiated lawsuits since last August against the same property management software company and expanded it to include rental management organizations for collusion and price gouging.
It's true that rental managers who use the software often end up charging similar rents for similar units. But that is because the software is providing a view into the underlying factors that determine rent.
This is similar to two people standing 10 feet apart from the person holding up a sign, and giving the same answers on what they read. It is not an evil conspiracy but equal access to the relevant information. The lawsuit's solution is akin to gouging their eyes out.
These reckless lawsuits don't just hurt the property management software and the rental management organizations by taking up their valuable time and energy. They hurt renters too.
Diffusion of relevant information diffusion doesn't only make prices higher — it makes prices more responsive. If other rental managers are overcharging, it creates a lucrative opportunity to undercut them. And a good software algorithm would advise just that. In fact, research suggests that landlords who use pricing software are more likely to lower rents as market conditions improve.
Brown accuses the software of "making it hard for Maryland renters to put a roof over their heads." But the algorithms are not the enemy. If the goal is lower housing costs, the solution is to increase supply by building more housing.
Government leaders may want to consider loosening zoning laws, repealing rent control ordinances (which discourage new construction in key markets like Montgomery County), and streamlining the permitting process. These common-sense solutions will address the root causes–the software is just a mirror held up to the broken housing market.
Concealing the evidence rather than addressing the problem is like a mechanic who turns off your check engine light without bothering to fix your car. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses housing market economics, rent pricing, and a state attorney general's lawsuit affecting property management software, focusing on economic policy and market dynamics, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.

title: New Burger King expected in Easton in spring
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
New Burger King expected in Easton in spring

 February 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 196
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A new Burger King is coming to U.S. Route 50 in Easton.According to an email from Burger King's public relations team, the restaurant is expected to open in Easton this spring. The email stated that the new restaurant will replace the establishment's current Easton location on 8192 Ocean Gateway, which is between Jiffy Lube and Walgreens.
The new restaurant is currently under construction. It will be located at 8518 Ocean Gateway, which is just north of Royal Farms.
Easton Town Planner Lynn Thomas said the new Burger King received site plan approval from the Easton Planning Commission and should offer an improved design.
In August 2021, the project received subdivision approval from the Planning Commission. The Commission voted to approve the restaurant's site plan, architecture and parking waiver request during a meeting the following month. According to meeting minutes from the September 2021 meeting, architect Robert Zappulla said plans for the new restaurant's look took inspiration from Easton's downtown. He said they wanted to make it look like a Burger King was placed in an existing building in Easton.
Thomas said he does not know what Burger King's plans for the location on 8192 Ocean Gateway are. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Taxpayers will leave Maryland
author: Staff Writer
content:
Taxpayers will leave Maryland

 February 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 119
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In his budgetary submission to the Maryland legislature now in session, Gov. Moore recommends raising the tax rate for families earning $1 million or more and lowering the estate tax threshold from $5 million to $2 million. This seems to be a short-sighted punitive act against Marylanders who have worked hard, sacrificed much, and already pay more than their " fair share" of state tax dollars.In addition lowering the estate tax threshold will lead to a new group of thousands of taxpaying citizens exiting the state in an effort to preserve some inheritance for their families and contributions to their favorite charities.The result of this forced diaspora will only increase the tax burden on those left behind.

title: Egg prices hit record highs and are expected to go higher
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
Egg prices hit record highs and are expected to go higher

 February 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: Local News 
 
 1161
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Nick Rodgers knows the pain of record-high egg prices as much as anyone.Rodgers is co-owner of Main Street Overeasy, a popular breakfast and lunch restaurant in Bozeman, Montana.
Rodgers said he buys eggs by the case. And he buys lots of cases.
"We get 150 eggs in a case," Rodgers said.
He said last year a case cost $60.
"This year, they are now $127 per case," Rodgers said.
That doubling of prices added an additional $1,300 in egg costs to the Montana restaurant's narrow weekly bottom line.
"We have pretty narrow margins. That is rough," Rodgers said.
In response, the Bozeman eatery has added a 95-cent extra charge on dishes with eggs.
Other restaurants have raised prices because of higher eggs prices. Earlier this month, the Waffle House breakfast chain initiated a 50-cents-per-egg surcharge on its dishes.
In Cheyenne, Wyoming, Mike Moriarty owns the Epic Egg restaurant. He's feeling the pain.
"Our egg costs have risen over 200% since February 2024," said Moriarty, who also has Epic Egg locations in Colorado.
The eatery has put a temporary 8% extra charge on egg dishes.
"At this time, we have implemented a temporary surcharge on egg entrees to help offset excessive egg costs instead of updating and reprinting menus," he said.
STICKER SHOCKEgg prices have almost doubled since January 2024, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics and St. Louis Federal Reserve Bank.
They reported the average price for a dozen eggs as $4.95 in January. That is up $2.52 in January 2024.
But consumers across the U.S. are seeing egg prices higher than the $4.95 average. Some stores are running low on less-expensive eggs, leaving shoppers with prices more in the $6 and $7 per dozen range.
A persistent and impactful bird flu outbreak that started in 2022 has resulted in close to 160 million birds culled, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.
There were more than 308 million egg-laying hens in the U.S. in 2022, according to the Egg Producers Council. In 2023, there were 9.4 billion broiler chickens and 218 million turkeys processed nationally, according to USDA.
Dan Karney, an economics professor with Ohio University, said egg prices could continue to rise this year with the continued impacts of the highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI).
"The USDA's prediction is that egg prices will increase by 20.3% during 2025, and egg price increases could get as high as 45.3% within the year," Karney said.
Expensive eggs are part of hotter-than-expected inflation confronting President Donald Trump, who promised to lower prices during the 2024 presidential campaign.
January inflation figures show high prices are still a challenge, with consumer prices 3% higher and wholesale prices 3.5% higher than a year ago. Both were higher than expected by economists.
Trump has also acknowledged his push for tariffs, including 25% levies on aluminum and steel, could raise prices.
Overall, U.S. prices are up 24% from the end of 2019, before the COVID pandemic's resets and ensuing inflation, according to Bureau of Labor Statistics.
That makes it tough for restaurant owners to raise prices on customers, Rodgers said.
"I don't want to put more on the customers than I have to," he said.
Karney said market conditions drive egg prices, and that the Trump administration can look at policies and monitoring of farms to help cut into outbreaks.
But Trump's and Elon Musk's austerity and expected GOP deregulation pushes might not lend themselves to more government oversight of farms, critics of the administration contend.
"Action on bird flu will require fully staffed, fully funded federal agencies, with a broad and urgent mandate to increase on-farm testing and PPE (personal protective equipment), as well as vaccine development and distribution," said Rebecca Wolf, senior food policy analyst for Food & Water Watch.
The progressive group worries about job cuts and other rollbacks at the USDA and other agencies, as well as the further proliferation of large factory farms.
'HUGE NUMBERS'Animal welfare activists are concerned that large-scale poultry farms help proliferate the bird flu outbreaks with their scale and conditions.
There have been bird flu outbreaks and mass cullings at large U.S. farms with hundreds of thousands of birds, as well as ones involving 2.6 million, 1.8 million and 1.4 million chickens, according to the USDA.
"You are dealing with a huge number of animals," said Zach Strong, director and senior attorney for Animal Welfare Institute's farmed animal program.
Strong said America's larger "factory farms" can potentially be breeding grounds and more at risk for the avian flu "largely because of the higher number of animals in confined settings."
AWI and other animal welfare advocates also want more attention paid to how millions of chickens and turkeys are being culled.
Strong said one preferred method entails shutting down and sealing ventilation and air systems inside large hen houses until the birds die from overheating.
The ventilation shutdown process can sometimes take hours.
That has resulted in some farms completely sealing ventilation systems and using heaters to turn up the hen house temperatures to 120 to 130 degrees to cull the poultry.
"It's horrific," said Amber Canavan, vegan campaign project manager for People for Ethical Treatment of Animals.
She worries about large farms fostering the outbreak with their large capacities and conditions.
"These are absolute breeding grounds for disease," said Canavan, hoping that more Americans look at vegan food options, including for eggs and protein.
The U.S. produces more than 90 billion eggs annually, with Americans eating more than 280 eggs (more than 23 dozen) annually per capita, according to the Egg Producers Council and Statista.com.
Strong said some farms are using nitrogen foam to cull chickens, which works faster and can be less painful.
He noted the poultry farmers have been financially reimbursed for chickens and turkey culled.
An analysis by Sentient Policy in January found poultry and egg farmers, including some large agri-businesses, have received $1.46 billion in avian flu reimbursements from the U.S. government.
'A BIG PROBLEM'Austin Spies, who has a farm with 1,000 egg-laying hens in Preston, Maryland, said his family's operation has not had any bird flu outbreaks or cullings.
Spies said he and his brother shift their chicken flock's pasture around every couple of days (at most) to help their health.
"They're not over top of their manure. That can be a big problem," he said.
Spies said the rotational grazing entails temporary fencing and moving the birds.
"I think it's becoming more popular," he said.
Some farmers using rotational and more traditional, smaller farming models are using guard dogs to protect against foxes and other predators.
Back in Montana, Rodgers said he also has some experience with poultry and egg farming. He said the challenge to the rotational model is how to do something like that in large-scale farms.
Moriarty said farming rules in states such as Colorado are not helping prices or the replenishment of flocks.
"In addition to the bird flu issues, Colorado has mandated 100% cage-free eggs, which has decreased egg supply (and is) driving prices up," he said.
Spies said he and other farmers continue to navigate post-pandemic inflation, including for feed.
He said the price of chicks has increased, with other farmers looking to replenish flocks and increased interest in backyard farms.
"I heard it's doubled," the Maryland farmer said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on record-high egg prices, their impact on restaurants and inflation, and economic factors driving the market, making Business/Economy the strongest match, with Agriculture as a close secondary theme.

title: State should hit brakes on mileage user fees
author: DAVID REEL
content:
State should hit brakes on mileage user fees

 February 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 851
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Since the Maryland General Assembly convened for a 90-day session last month, the state budget has been the focus of intense attention, an intense focus that generally occurs later in the session.Projected state budget deficits have driven early debates on spending cuts, tax increases, personal income and business tax adjustments, fee increases and "rainy day" fund transfers.
Given the challenges in reaching consensus on the governor's proposed $67.3 billion budget, and majorities in the House of Delegates and the Senate, these debates have been and will continue to encounter unexpected twists and turns.
Last week, Maryland Senate President Bill Ferguson speaking about a new challenge said lawmakers will likely have to look for "several hundred million more dollars" in additional cuts or taxes to cover anticipated decreases in federal funds coming to Maryland.
Despite these challenges, a balanced budget as mandated by the state constitution will most likely be approved by the General Assembly and sent to the governor for his approval just before or at midnight when the General Assembly adjourns on April 7.
If that does not happen, the governor will need to call for a special session for a budget approval for the first time since 2012.
Another state budget issue that will be challenging but which has not yet received much attention is long-term funding for the state's $21.2 billion six-year transportation trust fund.
This fund provides capital investment funding for the Maryland Aviation Administration, Maryland Port Administration, Maryland Transit Administration, Motor Vehicle Administration, State Highway Administration and The Secretary's Office, as well as Maryland's investment in the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority.
Currently, almost a third of the transportation trust fund's annual revenue comes from a 46.1-cent per gallon gas tax, a tax that is automatically adjusted based on the rate of inflation.
There are increasing concerns that even with future annual automatic gas tax rate increases, it is not a long-term reliable revenue source for the transportation trust fund.
There are three driving trends leading to the gas tax reliability concerns: less gas consumption due to improved fuel efficiency of new gas-powered vehicles, increasing use of electric and hybrid vehicles, and less driving by those working from home who seldom or never drive to or from work.
The Eastern Transportation Coalition (ETC), a partnership of 19states and the District of Columbia focused on connecting public agencies across modes of travel to increase safety and efficiency. is proposing mileage-based user fee.
ETC has already done a four-month user fee demonstration pilot in Maryland with voluntary participation of more than 170 drivers.
In their analysis of the Maryland pilot results, the ETC concludes, "in general," drivers would have paid the same amount with a milage-based user fee as they would have with the gas tax.
They do not elaborate on how they define "in general."
The response to the ETC proposal from the Maryland Department of Transportation is "MDOT continues to partner with the Eastern Transportation Coalition on the work that the coalition is doing to learn more about the feasibility of MBUF as a sustainable transportation funding option for the future, but has no next steps planned at this time."
I suggest the transportation department's non-committal for next steps at this time is very appropriate.
There are a wide range of unanswered questions on the ETC demonstration pilot results specifically and the MBUF concept in general, that need to be addressed before user fees are given serious consideration as an alternative to a gas tax.
How reliable are ETC conclusions that mileage-based user fees and gas tax driving costs are close to equal?
Are those conclusions applicable statewide in Maryland, especially on the Eastern Shore where long commutes to Annapolis, Washington and Baltimore are common?
If the goal is increasing revenue for the transportation trust fund, why replace one revenue source for another with no net gain on revenue?
Will 170 drivers reporting positive pilot demonstration with a user fee experience from voluntary driver surveys generate enough political support for legislative approval of a statewide user fee when there are over four million licensed drivers in Maryland?
What are the projected long-term trends on sales of gas efficient vehicles?
What are the projected long-term trends on sales of all electric vehicles?
What are the projected long-term trends on sales of hybrid vehicles?
What are the projected long-term trends on work from home workers?
Complicating matters on this issue is another gas tax related proposal reducing the mass transit operating expense subsidies paid from the state transportation trust fund.
Under current law, 50% of the transportation trust fund goes to pay those subsidies since fares cover less than 10% of the total operating costs of mass transit systems.
The question is: will the General Assembly and governor approve a new mandate that at least 35% of the operating costs of a mass transit system must be covered by fare revenues, and just as with the gas tax, fares must be adjusted regularly based on the rate of inflation.
Until all of the above questions are answered, going slow on any replacement of the current gas tax system with a mileage-based user fee system is necessary, prudent and realistic. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses state budget deficits, tax policy, and funding mechanisms for transportation infrastructure, which are primarily economic and fiscal issues rather than local government operations, public safety, or cultural topics.

title: Gas prices down from last week, last month, last year
author: Staff Writer
content:
Gas prices down from last week, last month, last year

 February 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 491
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 8.8 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.09 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 17.0 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 28.4 cents per gallon lower than a year ago."While most of the country has experienced a relatively quiet week for gas prices, the West Coast has seen rapid increases— a trend that should slow in the coming days," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "Although the surge remains isolated to the West for now, refinery maintenance will soon begin in other regions, and with the transition to summer gasoline blends underway, prices in most areas are likely to start rising in the weeks ahead."
The national average price of diesel has increased 0.8 cents in the last week and stands at $3.632 per gallon.
According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.77 per gallon Sunday, while the most expensive was $3.85 per gallon, a difference of $1.08 per gallon. The lowest price in the state yesterday was $2.77 per gallon while the highest was $3.85 per gallon, a difference of $1.08 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has risen 2.2 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.11 per gallon Monday. The national average is unchanged from a month ago and stands 16.5 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
February 17, 2024: $3.38per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.28per gallon)February 17, 2023: $3.29per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.38per gallon)February 17, 2022: $3.55per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.51per gallon)February 17, 2021: $2.60per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.57per gallon)February 17, 2020: $2.37per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.44per gallon)February 17, 2019: $2.28per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.31per gallon)February 17, 2018: $2.53per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.52per gallon)February 17, 2017: $2.28per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.28per gallon)February 17, 2016: $1.74per gallon (U.S. Average: $1.71per gallon)February 17, 2015: $2.27per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.26per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.04 per gallon, down 12.3 cents per gallon from last week's $3.16 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.24 per gallon, up 4.4 cents per gallon from last week's $3.20 per gallon.Hagerstown: 3.26 per gallon, up 0.9 cents per gallon from last week's $3.25 per gallon.
"The national average has inched higher, driven primarily by sharp gas price increases on the West Coast, where refinery maintenance and outages have created a ripple effect in neighboring states, pushing prices higher in many communities," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "Meanwhile, oil prices remain subdued in the low $70s as President Trump works on a potential peace deal between Russia and Ukraine— an event that, if realized, could have significant implications for oil markets in the months ahead." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on recent changes in gasoline prices, a market and economic issue, making Business/Economy the most appropriate category.

title: State of State ignores Eastern Shore realities
author: JOHNNY MAUTZ
content:
State of State ignores Eastern Shore realities

 February 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JOHNNY MAUTZ | Section: Columns 
 
 452
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Gov. Moore's recent State of the State address painted a rosy picture of Maryland's future, but as your state senator, I need to be straight with you about where we really stand.Maryland currently ranks 43rd in economic outlook and faces a staggering $3 billion deficit that could balloon to $7 billion by 2030. This crisis wasn't created by Gov. Hogan or the Trump administration — it's the predictable result of expensive, unfunded policies and overregulation pushed through by the Democratic supermajority in Annapolis.
The most glaring omission from the governor's hourlong speech? The crushing cost of living hitting Eastern Shore families right now, especially those sky-high utility bills. His solution is to raise taxes on businesses and high earners, but we all know those costs always find their way down to workers, consumers, and our local businesses.
Let's break down what's really happening in Annapolis:
Instead of cutting wasteful programs, the governor wants to raise taxes and increase spending. Maryland already has one of the worst tax burdens in the country. His budget talks about job creation but ignores how businesses keep fleeing to states with lower taxes and fewer regulations.
The governor doubled down on the Blueprint for Maryland's Future — a massive unfunded mandate our counties and state can't afford. His proposed $1.6 billion in savings falls woefully short when we're facing a $4 billion annual shortfall to implement it.
Rather than working to control costs, the state has unleashed almost universal increases for licenses and other fees, accompanied by aggressive property tax assessment increases. Aspirational environmental mandates are being reenforced rather than reexamined, while they continue to drive costs. This includes their enormous impact on agriculture in comparison to the meager and in many instances, unmeasurable benefits. Meanwhile, the economy on the Chesapeake Bay has been strangled by poor management strategies that range across the board from the blue crab fishery to migratory waterfowl.
Here are a couple immediate actions to cut costs: eliminate thousands of funded, vacant positions; repeal costly mandates in the Blueprint that have not been implemented; cut wasteful spending like the Red Line Study and mass transit; and stop the new $2 billion annual payroll tax for paid family leave. Finally, there must be some incentive for agencies to save money rather than exhaust budgets to ensure they are funded in the following year.
Meanwhile, crime is a very real problem in Maryland and while ending recidivism is essential, the lack of attention and urgency over repeat offenders is alarming. The Eastern Shore way has always been practical and commonsense, there are options that support economic growth, environmental and educational improvement, and promote public safety without breaking the bank. That's what we should be supporting — not costly mandates from Annapolis. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The column focuses primarily on Maryland's fiscal deficit, tax policy, budget priorities, and economic impact on businesses and families, making Business/Economy the strongest match.

title: Maryland gas prices for week drop another 9 cents
author: GAS BUDDY
content:
Maryland gas prices for week drop another 9 cents

 February 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GAS BUDDY | Section: Local News 
 
 474
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 9.1 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.00 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 30.8 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 31.9 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has increased 1.6 cents in the last week and stands at $3.648 per gallon."As we inch closer to March, the typical March madness will eventually take hold, so motorists may want to enjoy the slight decline while it lasts," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "While I don't see an abrupt spike in the national average just yet, we're likely to see upward movement in the weeks ahead."
According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.48 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.75 per gallon, a difference of $1.27 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 3.8 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.08 per gallon Monday. The national average is down 4.4 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 18.2 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
Feb. 24, 2024: $3.32 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.26 per gallon)Feb. 24, 2023: $3.21 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.33 per gallon)Feb. 24, 2022: $3.58 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.57 per gallon)Feb. 24, 2021: $2.69 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.67 per gallon)Feb. 24, 2020: $2.45 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.47 per gallon)Feb. 24, 2019: $2.35 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.39 per gallon)Feb. 24, 2018: $2.49 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.51 per gallon)Feb. 24, 2017: $2.28 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.28 per gallon)Feb. 24, 2016: $1.70 per gallon (U.S. Average: $1.71 per gallon)Feb. 24, 2015: $2.32 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.31 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $2.93 per gallon, down 10.4 cents per gallon from last week's $3.04 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.19 per gallon, down 5.6 cents per gallon from last week's $3.24 per gallon.Hagerstown: $3.13 per gallon, down 12.3 cents per gallon from last week's $3.26 per gallon.
"With the sharp gas price increases on the West Coast now fading, the national average has dipped slightly over the past week. While some areas are seeing increases, others are experiencing stability or even slight declines, as the bulk of the seasonal transition has yet to significantly impact gasoline prices — certainly good news for motorists," said . "Oil prices have remained steady in the low $70s, but we continue to monitor key developments, including ongoing talks between the U.S., Russia and Ukraine on a potential agreement."

title: Delmarva Power customers attend event seeking answers for high bills
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Delmarva Power customers attend event seeking answers for high bills

 February 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 576
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — Filing into the Kent Island Library meeting hall, disgruntled, frustrated and confused power customers sought information on rising bills during a public meeting held by Delmarva Power Tuesday.In light of recent electric bills increases, the open house gave customers the opportunity to discuss with one-on-one consultation forums about accounts, as well as payment plans, budget billing and energy efficiency programs, according to Amber Burruezo, regional communications manager for the power company.
"We want to be transparent and communicate with customers," Burruezo said.
Delmarva Power customers across the Eastern Shore are reporting dramatic increases in their utility bills, with some seeing their charges double or triple despite the company's October prediction of an estimated 3% rate hike.
Delmarva Power, a subsidiary of Illinois-based Exelon Corporation, provides electric service to 208,000 Maryland customers.
At the event energy engineer Dave Tancredi, presented resources and assessments on energy usage savings. He sais little things can add up to impact increases in electricity, including a simple hot water leak.
The 2024-2025 season has also seen colder temperatures than in prior years, which Tancredi said could impact power bills. The number one issue the engineers see at customer homes is heat pumps, he said.
Temperature settings can also affect an electric bill, according to Tancredi. He recommended setting the thermostat to 78 degrees in the summer and 68 degrees in the winter.
Delmarva Power offers programs such as home energy evaluations, and customers can compare their rates with their neighbors at the Delmarva Power website.
Attending the event as a customer, Jim Hynson, a former Delmarva Power employee of 30 years, noted how the company has changed. Delmarva Power is now an Exelon company, along with Pepco Holdings.
Overall, Hynson said he was satisfied with the information he received and remembered Delmarva Power fondly as a company to work for.
Other customers were less satisfied with the event, expecting more overall discussion on the bill rate increases.
"What metric is Delmarva using to decide what's affordable?" asked Amanda D'Onofrio of Centreville, who noted as a military spouse, cost of living allowances couldn't keep up with the rates.
D'Onofrio considered the event merely a covering of energy savings basics that most people were familiar with. She felt the company neglected larger questions including regulating energy monopoly.
Delmarva putting forth installment plans and cutting late fees does not address the underlying issue that customers are simply unable to afford their bills, D'Onofrio said. She wanted to see freedom of choice for consumers and an increase in transparency.
Jan Debrew of Stevensville considered her electric bill "extreme" and couldn't fathom why it had recently skyrocketed. Debrew stated she had a friend on the western shore with a different provider and a much larger house but a lower electric bill charge. "It should be at least equal," she said.
Debrew was hopeful to utilize new tactics to reduce the bill, noting she didn't consider herself to have other options for providers in the area.
Lucy Mitchell, of Chester, said the event was "somewhat helpful" to get an explanation of her $700 electric bill breakdown. Mitchell learned what pools the most electricity in a home, but she was already performing "low hanging fruit" energy savings, and at 80 years old, she was not in the market for high-end items such as new windows and installation.
According to Burruezo, about 30 to 40 customers RSVP'd for individual consultation ahead of time. The event had been rescheduled from Feb. 12 due to inclement weather.
More information about Delmarva Power can be found at delmarva.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on rising electricity bills, utility company policies, and consumer cost concerns, which are primarily economic and business-related issues rather than sports, health, or other categories.

title: Trump can break laws, but not laws of economics
author: RICK SCHIMING
content:
Trump can break laws, but not laws of economics

 March 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: RICK SCHIMING | Section: Columns 
 
 657
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "Madmen in authority, who hear voices in the air, are distilling their frenzy from some academic scribbler of a few years back."This quote by the famed British economist John Maynard Keynes helps us understand Donald Trump's fascination with tariffs. For all practical purposes, Trump is a mercantilist, following the scribblings of a discredited group of economists from the 18th century.
Mercantilists had a few basic ideas about how a nation could become wealthy. A nation should accumulate as much gold and silver as they could through trade and exploitation. A nation should strive to restrict imports from other nations as much as possible to achieve a positive balance of trade.
Mercantilists viewed the world as a zero-sum game where the only way for your nation to win was for other nations to lose. The goal of the nation was to be as self-sufficient as possible, producing as many goods and services within its own borders as possible. Colonies were especially helpful in providing goods and services, and especially raw materials, to the mother country.
Trump truly is an unrepentant mercantilist. He has a fascination with gold. He is always talking about a golden age for American. His Trump Tower condo, Mar-a-Lago, and now even the Oval Office look like they were decorated by King Midas. He even sells gold sneakers.
Like all mercantilists, Trump is deeply disturbed by trade deficits. He sees them as theft perpetrated on the U.S. economy by other nations, requiring punitive tariffs on the offenders.
He also is captivated by the idea of colonies. Canada, Panama, Greenland and now even Gaza are viewed by Trump as possible colonial acquisitions.
The problem is that days of mercantilism as a rational understanding of how the world works are long over. We now know better. Believing in mercantilist thought today is the economic equivalent of being a member of the Flat Earth Society.
Basic economic principles tell us that nations should no longer strive to be self-sufficient. The goal now for each nation is to do what they do best and trade for the rest. Trump can break a lot of laws, but he can't break the laws of economics.
The sensible and efficient thing for us to do is to produce those goods and services in which we have a cost or technology advantage and then use those goods and services to trade with other nations for the goods and services in which they have a production advantage.
When trade occurs, it is not a zero-sum game but rather an exchange in which both trading nations win. Indeed, expanded global trade since World War II has enriched wealthy and poor nations alike. This trade expansion has proven to be one of the greatest international anti-poverty programs the world has ever seen.
So, what would be the economic impact of Trump's continual obsession with mercantilism and tariffs?
We will certainly see higher prices in the U.S. for a whole variety of imported goods and services. The Fed will be reluctant to lower interest rates if inflation increases. U.S. tariffs are a tax on U.S. consumers. Even worse, it is a regressive tax with lower income families feeling a greater burden of the higher prices.
U.S. production will slow as our companies face less demand for our products internationally as other nations will impose tariffs on our exports. Higher unemployment will result. The U.S. economy could face the worst of all possible worlds: higher prices and higher unemployment rates. Clearly, no one wins a trade war.
The best-case scenario?
Tariff policy becomes in the second Trump term like infrastructure week was in the first term — lots of talk but ultimately little meaningful or sustained action. Unfortunately, this scenario seems increasingly unlikely now as new tariffs on steel and aluminum have been announced and other reciprocal tariffs are in the works.
But whether it is the best case or the worst case or somewhere in between, Trump is the proponent of a discredited academic theory that puts our economy in peril. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is an opinion column analyzing trade policy, tariffs, and economic theory, which directly relates to business and economic issues.

title: More nuclear power in Maryland? Probably yes
author: DAVID REEL
content:
More nuclear power in Maryland? Probably yes

 March 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 835
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Forty-five years ago this month, a nuclear reactor at the Three Mile Island electric power generating station in central Pennsylvania experienced a partial nuclear meltdown.It is the worst accident involving nuclear power generation in American history. On the International Nuclear Event Scale it is rated as a Level 5 event — an "accident with wider consequences".
One of those wider consequences was a dramatic and long-lasting shift on the public perception on the safety and feasibility of nuclear power plants, even with post TMI design and operating improvements for new plants.
Despite those improvements, some concluded that the TMI accident and how it was mismanaged initially marked the beginning of the end of nuclear power as a source for electric power in America.
Ultimately, the accident did not result in the demise of the U.S. nuclear power industry, but it did halt its historic growth.
Fast forward to today.
Unexpected and extraordinary increases in electric bills are a huge issue throughout Maryland.
They are generating extensive media coverage and widespread expressions of public concern and even outrage.
The levels of media coverage, public concern and public outrage on electric bills are greater than that generated by proposals under consideration in the General Assembly to revise state taxes, increase state fees and cut state spending in order to balance the state budget.
Former U.S. Sen. Everett Dirksen once said: 'When I feel the heat, I see the light."
Presently, the heat is being felt by elected public officials at all levels of government including members of the General Assembly.
Based on that heat they are increasingly open to a wide range of electrical generating options that could result in lower electric bills.
One option was succinctly captured in a recent headline for a Capital News Service article — "Craving more energy, Maryland looks to nuclear power."
That "craving" recently has led to a four-bill package of legislation in the General Assembly.
One of the bills proposes a procurement framework to support the development of both traditional nuclear power plants and small modular reactors in Maryland.
If and when that occurs, any new traditional reactors would join the Calvert Cliffs nuclear power plant in Calvert County.
Owned and operated by Baltimore based Constellation Energy since it became operational in 1975, Calvert Cliffs is Maryland's only traditional nuclear power plant. It is also the largest nuclear power plant on the East Coast. It generates about 40% of all electric power used in Maryland, an amount equal to that generated and imported from outside of Maryland.
Support for increased use of nuclear power in Maryland is not universal.
Jorge Aguilar, a regional director at Food and Water Watch, a national environmental advocacy organization, has said, "Maryland should be alarmed that state leaders want to build out these astronomically expensive and dangerous nuclear plants in Maryland to meet the state's energy needs. These plants would be expensive to build and produce hazardous nuclear waste. Maryland should be pushing the grid operator to approve renewable energy projects faster. I think Maryland leaders really need to double down on truly clean energy, like wind and solar, as well as batteries. Not nuclear."
That message is likely to resonate with many of the progressive members in the General Assembly. It is not likely to resonate with the Freedom Caucus in the State House.
That caucus is suggesting the following changes in Maryland's energy — reopen closed coal-fired electric generating plants, keep open currently open coal-fired electric generating plants scheduled for closure, stop "EmPOWER Maryland" fees on electric bills, repeal or revise the state law that requires higher margins of clean energy to be used statewide and reduce spending $180 million dollars on a state climate department.
While this approach of the Freedom Caucus may be helpful in increasing public awareness of the caucus and their proposed energy agenda, it will not move the needle with the governor or the steadily increasing numbers and power of progressive legislators in Annapolis.
Regardless of the levels of support or opposition to more nuclear power, there are two realities that will determine its impact on higher electric bills for now and in the future.
The first reality is the 90-day General Assembly session ends on April 7, 2025.
Between now and then, the Governor and General Assembly leaders will be fully engaged in efforts to secure consensus and a majority of votes on a balanced state budget.
The second reality is, even with new policies on approving and encouraging greater use of nuclear power, the schedule for building and opening new nuclear power plants is a long one.
The period from proposal, approval, building, and opening can range from six years to 12 years. Construction time alone for the Calvert Cliffs plant was seven years.
Accordingly, nuclear power will not provide immediate or short-term lower electric bills.
What is urgently needed is the governor and General Assembly leadership to reach agreement on all the underlying causes of higher electric bills and then reach agreement on short-term and long-term solutions.
On the question of more nuclear power plants in Maryland, the answers are — probably yes, but not a given, and most certainly, not soon. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses legislative proposals, cost implications, and economic impacts of expanding nuclear power to address high electric bills, making Business/Economy the most fitting category.

title: Cambridge Main Street announces Spring Fling event
author: CAMBRIDGE MAIN STREET
content:
Cambridge Main Street announces Spring Fling event

 March 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CAMBRIDGE MAIN STREET | Section: News 
 
 423
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Spring is in the air, but long before the change of seasons, Cambridge Main Street Inc. began working on their premier fundraising event — their annual Spring Fling.The 2025 Spring Fling, scheduled for Saturday, April 26, from 5:30-11 p.m., will be held at a new venue this year — The Packing House, located on Dorchester Avenue, in Cambridge, and once part of Phillips Packing Company.
"We are thrilled to be partnering with Cross Street Partners, the brilliant minds behind the revitalization of The Packing House, to host this year's Spring Fling, in such a historic Cambridge landmark." says Christina Wingate-Spence, executive director of Cambridge Main Street. "Our organization strives to celebrate the rich heritage and revitalization of Cambridge, so we welcomed the opportunity to host this annual event, in a space that plays a vital role in our community's industrial history."
Spring Fling has a full schedule, including hors d'oeuvres and dinner, featuring the "Tastes of Main Street," with several Cambridge eateries preparing dishes for the specially curated menu; live and silent auctions; and live music performed by Party Fowl Band, a Delaware-based band with a following across Delmarva, Baltimore and Washington D.C.
Tickets for the event are available at $95 per person. Cambridge Main Street has several sponsorship levels available for area businesses and individuals wanting to support the event.
"Spring Fling is Cambridge Main Street's largest fundraiser each year," Wingate-Spence said. "As a non-profit organization, we rely heavily on the generous support of our community to assist us in fulfilling our mission. The proceeds from Spring Fling, and all of our events, make it possible for us to bring more events and festivals, live music and entertainment, and opportunities for beautification to Downtown Cambridge — all of which allow us to support our small businesses, merchants, eateries and galleries."
According to Wingate-Spence, Downtown Cambridge businesses are playing a large role in the annual event, including RaR Brewing, which is providing craft beverages for the event, and Vintage 414, whose team is volunteering their time to organize and man the bar, and is creating a signature cocktail for Spring Fling.
"We are so appreciative of the support we receive from Downtown businesses, not just for Spring Fling, but for all of our events, throughout the year. Everything we do is for the betterment of the Cambridge Main Street District and to best support those businesses, who have chosen to make Downtown Cambridge their home," she said.
For additional information about Cambridge Main Street's upcoming Spring Fling event, sponsorship opportunities or to purchase tickets, visit DowntownCambridge.org or email office@DowntownCambridge.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
