title: 'Nothing better': Land surveyors shed light on profession's unique draw
author: Konner Metz
content:
'Nothing better': Land surveyors shed light on profession's unique draw

 March 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 684
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — Five years ago, Grant Foster didn't know much about the field of surveying.After graduating from college and completing an internship in an office, he was looking for a change in pace. That's when he took a job as a surveyor at Lane Engineering in 2022.
"I fell into it, and I loved it," Foster said.
Foster, 24, has been a crew chief for two years. Instead of a 9-to-5 office job, he's in the field working on construction sites and properties across the Mid-Shore.
Land surveying includes a wide variety of field work, often at construction sites and homes, such as denoting property boundaries, measuring land or locating utilities.
Local leaders in the industry say the demand for surveyors is high, particularly for young surveyors. Jeff Hubbard, Lane Engineering's chief of surveys, said there's a limited number of surveyors overall, making their time especially valuable.
As development on the Mid-Shore increases, that demand only rises. Surveying on the Shore comes with its unique challenges, Hubbard notes, from property lines meeting with the Chesapeake Bay to ensuring environmental regulations are followed.
Hubbard, who represents Eastern Shore counties on the board of the Maryland Society of Surveyors, said surveying "has always had a marketing issue."
"When kids go to school, they don't think about becoming surveyors," Hubbard said. "They think about becoming engineers. They think about becoming doctors, lawyers."
But for those who do find the field, it's sometimes a perfect fit. Heinlein enjoys that his job has him working in nature and with animals.
"Any kid who likes the outdoors, it's almost the perfect job for it," Heinlein said. "You are outside all the time, seeing gorgeous views."
TECHNOLOGY
Hubbard has been in the field since 1974 and has been a licensed land surveyor since 1986. He's seen surveying change drastically due to technology — compasses, rulers and protractors have been replaced by geographic information systems that can store and analyze points on a map.
"The ability to digitize all that has been a game-changer for the survey industry," Hubbard said. "Today, those same people are out there locating the same things, but we don't have to pull a tape to find out how far away we are."
Once field surveyors gather the data, licensed surveyors work their magic inside, creating maps, designs and drawings often necessary for construction approvals from local agencies or commissions.
But two-dimensional, paper drawings haven't gone away yet, Hubbard says.
"At the end of the day, we still work in a world where the counties (and) approving agencies still are using paper," he said.
He hopes that Lane Engineering can continue to prioritize technological advancements, though some of that is limited based on what agencies require.
Foster said technology initially captivated him when he began the job years ago.
"It will never be boots on the ground," Foster said. "So, yes, technology helps us do our jobs better, but I don't think it'll ever take the surveyor out of the field."
"This isn't going anywhere," crew chief Michael Mitchell said. "It's one of the oldest professions, and it's going to be necessary going forward. Whenever there's civil engineering going on, you're going to need surveyors to implement it."
UNIQUE FIELD
At Lane Engineering, field crews often work at multiple sites in a day. The crew chief and a survey technician work together in what they say is an independent job.
Mitchell, who's been in the field for more than five years, enjoys that aspect.
"There's a lot of autonomy that goes with the job," Mitchell said. "I'm given a task. I come out here, and I figure out what I think is the most effective way to get it done and it's up to me. I kind of get to call the shots out here within reason."
Earlier this month, Mitchell was at Gannon Range in Easton, a construction site for a housing development coming to Matthewstown Road. He was marking the buffer area for where utility lines could be run.
Playing a role in important construction work is a neat part of the job to Mitchell.
"You see a lot of development and you're like, 'I remember when that was a field,' and now we're driving down the road," Mitchell said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the land surveying profession, job demand, career paths, and industry trends, which aligns best with Business/Economy. It also references interactions with local agencies, placing Local Government as a secondary relevance.

title: Sophisticated yet approachable is concept behind new Betterton beachside restaurant
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Sophisticated yet approachable is concept behind new Betterton beachside restaurant

 March 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 589
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BETTERTON — Situated where the Bay meets the Sassafras River, the restaurant of the same name will be opening late spring.Over the years the property at 12 Ericsson Avenue had its share of owners with unique visions, from an Irish-themed bar, to a beachside restaurant with quick-service menu items and karaoke night, but this one could be the boldest yet.
Beginning in June, Chef Paul Edward and his wife, Caroline Benkert, will offer dinner nightly, a prix fixe menu to "20 souls" Wednesday through Saturday at 6:30 p.m. at Sassafras.
Edward explained, "Whatever is caught that day we're going to prepare. This early spring, we are looking forward to Chesapeake blue crab, spawning rockfish, foraged morels, forest herbs and greens and rhubarb and asparagus."
He mentioned he has local watermen, hunters and farmers helping him prepare this food and complete his vision for the establishment.
"Our focus will be wild caught seafood from the Bay, water fowl during hunting season, foraged fruits and vegetables and hyper-seasonal produce from local farmers," Edward said.
He has ambitious plans for his cuisine. Having just put down the gravel in the parking lot, already downstairs there is fresh fish hanging, a humongous yellow-fin tuna and jumbo fluke dangling from rope, cooling.
A quick glance around the chef's work area, tells you everything will be freshly made and prepared using homemade spices and herbs. He even makes his own kombucha, a fermented drink containing probiotics that may support gut health and improve digestion. Even the flour and corn flour is not store-bought.
Edward reflects on a time in the distant past, how people prepared food before modern conveniences and heavy processing methods.
"I think back to the time when fish was roasted over fire and corn was made into batter and baked over coals and the smoke of oak perpetually perfumed," he said.
He and Benkert will deliver these types of meals in elegant fashion to no more than 20 diners in a supper club setting, an old idea, revitalized after COVID-19 lockdowns when people looked to connect again through food and cozy atmosphere.
Diners step into a rustic yet tasteful setting that feels familiar with old, well-kept homes on the Eastern Shore. The floors are wood from this area, but burned in a Japanese style. There is a fireplace now, then the long chef's table, (where the bar used to be) with fine, vintage china purchased from a Crumpton auction which creates the familiar feel of a waterfront home.
Edward describes it as "modern Chesapeake cookery."
With 20 years experience owning the BlueBird-Baltimore, winner of the "Best of Baltimore" Readers' Poll for cocktails in 2018, 2020, 2021 and 2022, they are excited for this next project, a restaurant based on their understanding of food, nutrition and optimal health. Edward said he has ideas similar to Modern Stone Age Kitchen, to which owner Bill Schindler, is a friend and will be one of his first dining guests.
The property overlooks the beach, and as people are drawn to the Bay when the weather gets nicer, Edward and Benkert are hoping to build a consistent clientele.
"Our guests will experience the Chesapeake Bay, this ancient and beautiful body of water, through an intimate feast unlike any they've had before."
April dates are now available, with May reservations open soon for a first peek at the intimate Chef's Counter. Six seats will be open for a prix fixe, multi-course seafood forward menu. At an additional charge, are abbreviated alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverage pairings or a quaint menu of potations by the glass.
To learn more or make a reservation visit https://www.restaurantsassafras.com/. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the opening of a new restaurant, detailing its owners, menu, and business plans, which aligns most closely with Business/Economy.

title: Queenstown Bank unveils Cambridge branch plans at event
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Queenstown Bank unveils Cambridge branch plans at event

 March 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 242
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Queenstown Bank unveiled its plans to build a permanent location in Cambridge during its annual Farmers Appreciation Lunch Thursday."I have always had a desire to bring the Queenstown Bank culture of banking down to Dorchester," said Queenstown Bank Chief Risk Officer and Chief Administrative Officer Tracy Whitby-Fairall after unveiling a rendering during the event to show what the branch will look like.
Whitby-Fairall said the branch will be located at the old Dairy Queen on U.S. Route 50. She said the company is still in the planning stages of the project.
"We have received concept approval from the city," she said. "We are in final stages of final approval for the building."
Currently, the bank has a temporary Cambridge branch location on the corner of Dorchester and Maryland avenues. Whitby-Fairall said Queenstown Bank knew it would be at that location temporarily.
"Now to show our commitment to the county, we have purchased the lot to build a permanent location here in Cambridge," she said. "(We're) super excited to bring the Queenstown banking style back to a local hometown area as we do throughout the Shore from Queen Anne's, Caroline, Talbot and now Dorchester."
During the event, Queenstown Bank President and CEO Kevin Cashen said the bank has made a "big commitment" to Dorchester County residents with this project. He said the bank expects to break ground on the permanent Cambridge branch in late summer or early fall.
"We look forward to being here," he said.

title: 'Gigantic costs': Trump auto tariffs to drive up car prices, repairs expenses, insurance premiums
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
'Gigantic costs': Trump auto tariffs to drive up car prices, repairs expenses, insurance premiums

 March 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: Business 
 
 1103
 Words 

 Read News Document

 President Donald Trump's 25% tariffs on foreign-made automobiles and auto parts are expected to significantly raise prices for cars and auto repairs.Some estimates from industry analysts expect car and truck price hikes of between $5,000 and $12,000 per vehicle under Trump's tariff regime.
Brian Moody, senior editor for Autotrader and Kelley Blue Book, said automakers could raise prices across the board to lessen sticker shocks for certain models.
"We estimate prices can go up anywhere between three and 25%. Most likely auto makers will try to spread that out across some of their vehicles that are made both inside and outside the U.S. so to reduce shock to the consumer if this goes through," Moody said.
Carmakers and parts suppliers are already dealing with Trump's 25% tariffs on steel and aluminum and 20% tariffs on all Chinese goods.
"It's reasonable to expect that vehicle prices will rise, which presents an added challenge to an industry that is already grappling with ongoing affordability concerns," said Jessica Caldwell, head of insights for Edmunds.com Inc. (an automotive research firm).
Michigan-based Anderson Economic Group LLC estimates Trump's 25% tariffs will increase new car prices $4,000 to $10,000 for gasoline-power cars and trucks and as much as $12,000 for electric vehicles manufactured or outfitted parts outside the U.S.
An analysis of the tariffs by Anderson said the Trump regime "will impose a gigantic set of costs on consumers."
Another analysis by TD Economics pegs a $5,000 price increase for cars impacted by Trump's tariffs.
A number of industry analysts see Tesla as a winner from Trump's tariffs. Elon Musk's electric automaker produces its U.S. stock at plants in Texas and California.
"Tesla wins, Detroit bleeds," wrote wealth management firm Bernstein senior auto analyst Daniel Roeska in a Thursday note to clients, according to CNBC. The Bernstein analyst projects Trump's auto tariffs to total $100 billion and add $6,250 to car prices.
Musk, a top Trump backer and who runs Trump's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) austerity measures, said in a social media statement.
"Important to note that Tesla is not unscathed here. The tariff impact on Tesla is still significant," Musk said in social media statement on his X platform.
Car prices are already high.
According to Edmunds, the average sale price for a new vehicle was $47,373 in February. The average sale prices for used cars and trucks was $25,005.
According to the White House, approximately 16 million vehicles were sold in the U.S. in 2024 with roughly half of those imports.
The White House said among domestic vehicles between 50% of 60% of their parts and components were foreign sourced.
Industry analysts expect new car sales to dip when potential tariff price jumps are felt and there could be upward pressures on used cars with higher demand and higher prices across the marketplace.
The potential for higher prices for cars comes as U.S. consumer sentiment slides and Wall Street investors worry about the tariffs bringing higher prices, disrupted supply chains and slower economic growth.
"The increased demand for used cars that tariffs might bring could impact used car prices down the road. Used car prices almost always follow new car prices," Moody said.
HIGHER REPAIR COSTS
Trump's tariffs will also increase the prices of auto repairs and car insurance premiums, according to industry analysts.
"Many vehicle parts are sourced globally, which would increase repair costs for car owners, and reconditioning costs for dealers. Insurance premiums will also likely increase as any accidents involving new parts will see increased costs as well," Caldwell said.
Car insurance costs are already up across the country since the pandemic. They could increase more with higher prices for imported aftermarket auto parts and components due to the tariffs, according to PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP (PwC).
Jonathan Smoke, chief economist at Cox Automotive, an Atlanta-based research group, says the Trump tariffs could increase car prices by 10% and if they are extended more broadly to globally-sourced parts that "inflation would surge in maintenance and repair and insurance, which vehicle owners are already struggling to handle."
Moody said "anyone who thinks they might have a major repair in the near future should probably make an appointment to get their car looked at soon."
Trump announced the tariffs March 26.
"The 25% tariff will be applied to imported passenger vehicles (sedans, SUVs, crossovers, minivans, cargo vans) and light trucks, as well as key automobile parts (engines, transmissions, powertrain parts, and electrical components), with processes to expand tariffs on additional parts if necessary., White House said in a statement.
Vehicles and parts from Canada and Mexico under a 2018 trade deal negotiated with Trump "will be given the opportunity to certify their U.S. content and systems will be implemented such that the 25% tariff will only apply to the value of their non-U.S. content," according to the White House.
Trump wants to bring back auto and other manufacturing to the U.S. and has been promising more tariffs on other countries and industries on April 2.
"If they are made in the United States, there is absolutely no tariff,' Trump said. He said the tariffs are encouraging investments in the U.S. "Business is coming back to the United States so they don't have to pay tariffs."
Trump also said he favors tax and interest deductions for purchases of American-made cars. He has also warned U.S. automakers not to raise their prices, according to the Wall Street Journal.
The United Auto Workers (UAW) backs Trump's tariffs, criticizing decades of free trade policies that created global supply chains.
"We applaud the Trump administration for stepping up to end the free trade disaster that has devastated working class communities for decades. Ending the race to the bottom in the auto industry starts with fixing our broken trade deals, and the Trump administration has made history with today's actions," said UAW President Shawn Fain.
The UAW said there are under-utilized car and truck plants in Ohio, Michigan and North Carolina that could accommodate increased domestic production.
Industry analysts said Trump's tariffs will lead car dealers and automakers to get rid of customer incentives, which could add to affordability challenges and potentially fewer moderately priced models and trims.
"This is difficult news for an industry already staring down an affordability problem," said Erin Keating, an executive analyst with Cox.
"Affordable new vehicles are already few and far between — there are only 27 vehicles available with prices starting below $30,000, four of which have already been discontinued: the Chevy Malibu and Nissan Versa ending production this year and the Nissan Altima on the chopping block. Many are sourced from Mexico, Japan and South Korea. Tariffs of 25% or more at the border change the dynamics drastically — pushing prices higher on average by $5,300. Last year, these models made up 13% of all vehicles sold in the U.S." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses Trump-imposed auto tariffs, their impact on car prices, repairs, and the broader economy, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Shaping the landscape: pandemic pushes fiber access
author: Konner Metz
content:
Shaping the landscape: pandemic pushes fiber access

 March 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 792
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When Amberly Kuebel opened her child care business last fall, operations were smooth, but she often noticed screens were slow to load or conference calls would drop.Nestled in a Stevensville business park, Kids Landing Playcare didn't have high-speed broadband access when it opened just before Thanksgiving. But by December, that changed.
Discovering internet deserts across the Eastern Shore and being able to fill those voids has been one of the more positive results of the COVID pandemic.
Choptank Electric Cooperative and its subsidiary Choptank Fiber provided Kids Landing Playcare with broadband access. Now, Kuebel says everything from internet speed to system security has improved.
"Knowing that all of that has been taken care of is just peace of mind," Kuebel said.
Since the pandemic's onset, broadband expansion has been a hot button topic. Maryland has an Office of Statewide Broadband that aims to connect all residents, while local providers have worked furiously since the pandemic to extend services. Need still exists, though, predominantly in rural areas.
Timothy McGaha, Choptank Electric's vice president of technical services, said the pandemic "turned up the temperature on the desire" for broadband infrastructure as parents worked remotely and children attended school online.
"We heard all those stories of people saying, 'I have to take my kid to the McDonald's and sit in the parking lot so they can do their work because schools are closed,'" said Valerie Connelly, Choptank Electric's vice president of government affairs and public relations.
"The whole team really tried to find a way to do it as quickly as we possibly could," Connelly said.
PEOPLE HELPED
Marty Bollinger, an Easton Utilities customer, has been back and forth between Washington, D.C. and Claiborne for a number of years. He said internet access was a "real problem" during the pandemic when both of his children were in school.
But recently, Easton Utilities and its Easton Velocity service connected Bollinger's Claiborne residence, which he says has made a huge difference.
Easton Velocity's Connect Talbot initiative has reached 1,900 subscribers since 2021, according to Easton Utilities communications director Kelly Simonsen.
"I have had exceptional support from Easton Utilities on this," Bollinger said. "I am really impressed with their people. They're very professional, very responsive."
Colin Campbell's parents, Neil and Barbara, live in rural Wicomico County and had an access gap the size of the Grand Canyon, their son said. It impacted their ability to be on conference calls or attend public meetings on Zoom.
Choptank Electric extended broadband fiber to their house around six months ago.
"They did everything they possibly could to serve our area as quickly as the red tape would allow," Colin Campbell said of Choptank Electric.
At Kuebel's Stevensville Playcare, broadband has made a difference not just in internet speed, but also business. With reliable internet, Kuebel can now accommodate multiple parents for co-working sessions, where parents work in-house as their children are cared for in the room next door.
The internet improvements have led the business to staff more employees since more parents and children are showing up, Kuebel said.
CHALLENGES
As residents nationwide clamored for high-speed access during the pandemic, Easton Utilities and Choptank Electric both began their respective broadband efforts in 2021. Providers have faced unique challenges.
Simonsen says Easton Utilities, a nonprofit, is bound to follow the criteria laid out in the grants it receives.
"We cannot jeopardize the grant funding, and likely any future grant opportunities, by serving a property that has not been specifically dedicated for service," Simonsen wrote.
Funding from the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 has supported many state and county initiatives, such as the Maryland Emergency Broadband Benefit, which provided $15 subsidies to households for internet costs. That program shut down in 2024 due to a lack in funding.
Colin Campbell, a West Ocean City resident, says broadband access is a "systemic issue" on the Eastern Shore that predates the pandemic.
"Even if we're talking about 2005, 20 years ago, in my opinion it's still as critical as electricity," he said. "Because how are you supposed to be a student?"
"The fact that this continues to be this struggle where private industry has to continue to fight to get grant money ... is fascinating to me," he added. "In 2025, we're still having this conversation."
The underserved and rural areas that remain unconnected are the "toughest and most expensive" projects, McGaha says.
"While the temperature has been turned down from a big portion of our membership and the people on the Shore," McGaha said, "there's still those people that are left (that) are the most expensive and most difficult to get to."
This April will be Choptank Fiber's four-year anniversary of its first customer. The 5,000-customer mark has since been reached. Choptank Electric leaders say they're excited to embark on the next four years of providing crucial broadband coverage to more Eastern Shore residents.
"We're still early in this," McGaha said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on broadband infrastructure expansion, its impact on local businesses and the regional economy, and mentions utility companies and grant funding, aligning most closely with Business/Economy.

title: Pushing too far
author: Staff Writer
content:
Pushing too far

 March 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 130
 Words 

 Read News Document

 According to news reports, Gov. Moore is recommending an increase in Maryland's capital gains tax and an increase in the personal income tax. In each instance, the increase will only be for higher levels of income. Of course, such a tax will primarily affect those with the largest stake in the state's economy.In contrast, Canada's new prime minister recently announced he will not propose or support an increase in Canada's capital gains tax. While this may not seem especially perspicacious since the Canadian capital gains rate is already at 50%, it certainly does recognize a limit to what is economically sensible. It's wishful thinking but would be nice, therefore, if Canada's experience helped educate Gov. Moore and Maryland about the pitfalls of pushing the private sector too far.
ART CECIL
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Cannabis dispensary coming to Caroline County
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Cannabis dispensary coming to Caroline County

 April 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 463
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — Owners medical and recreational cannabis dispensary Caroline Pharma hope the dispensary will bring access to cannabis closer to home for Caroline County residents."There's a lot of medical card holders around here," Owner Amar Kalidindi said. "They only have one location within an hour and a half here, and that one location has wait times of hours, so here we are the second location in the Mid-Shore. So we'll provide great service to people, nice parking, nice friendly atmosphere, great staff. We will keep it local."
As counties and municipalities iron out the details of how to implement state legislation legalizing recreational cannabis use and sale, cannabis businesses have struggled to gain necessary approvals on the Mid-Shore.
Caroline Pharma will be the first dispensary to open in Caroline County since recreational marijuana was legalized in 2023.
"We are very thankful for the Town of Federalsburg council and town administration for approving us to open this dispensary in this town," Kalidindi said.
Caroline Pharma, located right next to Cantners Pharmacy, hopes to provide a safe and fun experience for guest interested in recreational cannabis use, the owners said.
"A lot of that stuff now they're buying on streets is laced with something, and and people are dying from it," Owner Eric Willis said. "Where like if he comes in here, the worst case scenario is you go home and if you take too much or smoke too much, you're either going to eat the whole house out of all the food or going to go to sleep and wake up next morning and live."
Caroline Pharma's owners believe cannabis can have medical benefits. Willis' father had pancreatic cancer and was prescribed a marijuana regimen, which helped him endure the cancer. Willis' father is in remission.
Kalidindi, a pharmacist, has seen medical benefits from cannabis since cannabis has been made legal in the state.
"There's a few products that we dispense that have marijuana in the pharmacy," Kalidindi said. "A lot of people that have uncontrollable seizures... when they were put on these medicines, their seizures have come down from like 10 to 15 episodes to two episodes a month."
"So it greatly benefits people with epilepsy, cancer, anxiety, pain, sleep disorders, nervousness, a lot of conditions like that. I've seen it in the medical field and I've seen it on the professional side how great and beneficial it can be."
All Caroline Pharma products are state-certified and organic. The business plans to
Caroline Pharma plans to mandate all state laws and regulations, the owners said. To enter the premises, a person must be 21 or older, unless they have a medical card that is issued by an authorized physician and state certified.
Caroline Pharma is still waiting for final approval from the state but expects to be open by late spring or early summer. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily reports on the opening of a new cannabis dispensary, focusing on business operations, market demand, and economic impact, while also mentioning health benefits and local government approvals.

title: Maryland gas prices jump 16 cents in past week
author: GAS BUDDY
content:
Maryland gas prices jump 16 cents in past week

 April 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GAS BUDDY | Section: State News 
 
 514
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have risen 16.1 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.17 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 18.7 cents per gallon higher than a month ago and stand 39.3 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has increased 0.9 cents in the last week and stands at $3.558 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.39 per gallon yesterday while the most expensive was $3.89 per gallon, a difference of $1.50 per gallon. The lowest price in the state Sunday was $2.39 per gallon while the highest was $3.89 per gallon, a difference of $1.50 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has risen 2.7 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.11 per gallon Monday. The national average is up 2.2 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 39.7 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
March 31, 2024: $3.56 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.51 per gallon)March 31, 2023: $3.39 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.48 per gallon)March 31, 2022: $3.79 per gallon (U.S. Average: $4.22 per gallon)March 31, 2021: $2.79 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.87 per gallon)March 31, 2020: $2.03 per gallon (U.S. Average: $1.95 per gallon)March 31, 2019: $2.65 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.69 per gallon)March 31, 2018: $2.67 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.66 per gallon)March 31, 2017: $2.32 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.32 per gallon)March 31, 2016: $2.08 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.06 per gallon)March 31, 2015: $2.37 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.41 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.17 per gallon, up 17.7 cents per gallon from last week's $2.99 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.21 per gallon, up 9.0 cents per gallon from last week's $3.12 per gallon.Hagerstown: $3.07 per gallon, up 18.4 cents per gallon from last week's $2.89 per gallon.
"We've seen the national average inch up for the second straight week, but with renewed refinery issues on the West Coast, gas prices there are likely to jump 10 to 35 cents per gallon over the next couple weeks. Meanwhile, motorists in the Northeast should consider filling up soon, as the final step in the transition to summer gasoline is just a couple of weeks away— and with it, a likely increase in prices," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "As we head into April, Americans should expect gas prices to rise, with a peak that could occur in mid-to-late April. While average prices remain well below last year's levels, we'll likely begin to catch up, with prices expected to increase in most— if not all—states over the next few weeks. Continued uncertainty around whether tariffs will be implemented on April 2 could also impact pump prices, setting the stage for a volatile period for American drivers." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on recent changes in gasoline prices, a market and economic issue, making Business/Economy the most appropriate category.

title: Eat Sprout moves to new location in downtown Easton
author: Konner Metz
content:
Eat Sprout moves to new location in downtown Easton

 April 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 313
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Eat Sprout owners Ryan and Emily Groll have aimed to be centrally located in Easton since opening their cafe and bakery in 2018.Friday, they met that goal, opening the doors of their new downtown location at 22 N Harrison St.
"We've wanted to be downtown now for years, just to be a little bit more ingrained in the roots of Easton, and have a place for people to sit inside, outside and have public restrooms," Ryan Groll said.
Town leaders and customers got their first look at the new shop after Friday's ribbon-cutting ceremony. It features indoor and outdoor seating as well as parking for customers. The cafe is relocating from its Aurora Street building.
But that location will remain, the Grolls said. The main production area at Aurora Street, previously attached to the cafe, will expand, allowing the bakery some extra flexibility.
Eat Sprout offers local and organic food and drinks, including scratch-made bread and bowls. In addition to Easton, it has shops in St. Michaels and Annapolis, including one in the Statehouse.
Eat Sprout's Easton location opened in 2018. Seven years in, the move to be closer to Easton's downtown core is already paying dividends, Ryan Groll says.
"It exceeded our expectations for sure," he said. "From the volume of people, the exposure and what kind of feedback that we're getting from the guests."
Groll said the new space is more purposeful and thought out in terms of spacing, storage and products. The ambiance and indoor seating will make a huge difference in the customer experience, he said.
The business has already noticed customers encouraging family, friends and co-workers to come see the new space and try it out.
"They're not just coming in to shop for themselves," Groll said, "but now they're meeting a friend there to enjoy a coffee and a snack or a meal and then grabbing what they need to take to go." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a local cafe and bakery relocating to a new downtown location, focusing on the business's operations, expansion, and customer impact, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Maryland lawmakers push for new power plants
author: RACHEL McCREA Capital News Service
content:
Maryland lawmakers push for new power plants

 April 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: RACHEL McCREA Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 1385
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As energy issues take center stage in Annapolis, lawmakers are pushing to build new energy generation projects in Maryland.Regional supply-demand issues and a coming leap in energy prices have lawmakers concerned about consumer energy costs and reliability. They're considering measures to build new energy as they try to lower costs for Marylanders, work around regional grid issues and make the state more self-sufficient.
"All of us are concerned about the prices," said Del. Lorig Charkoudian, a Democrat from Montgomery County. "All of us are working really hard to figure out how to alleviate the impact on ratepayers."
Bills introduced this session would promote building more in-state energy projects, including natural gas, nuclear, renewables and battery storage. These bills come even as some experts doubt that Maryland really needs to build more energy production right now.
What's driving this push for new in-state energy?
Incoming data centers and manufacturing have boosted demand across the multi-state regional grid. Electrification is also a factor.
The regional grid operator has warned of the possibility of a capacity shortage by the middle of next year.
Reliability issues might be a growing concern, but the more urgent issue with this supply-demand mismatch is affordability.
"Currently, there is sufficient generation and supply to keep the grid reliable, but the cost has skyrocketed," said Abe Silverman, an assistant research scholar at Johns Hopkins University's Ralph O'Connor Sustainable Energy Institute.
Delays in getting new energy projects up and running are contributing to this strain. A huge backlog of projects have been waiting for approval to plug into the grid, but that process has "imploded," Silverman said.
Called the "queue," the approval process was designed to handle hundreds of large projects like natural gas, nuclear, and oil. Thousands of smaller renewable energy projects have overwhelmed the queue recently, Silverman said, causing wait times to jump from two years up to five.
Projects have to deal with other roadblocks like siting and permitting, local opposition, and supply chain issues once they are approved. The regional grid operator is implementing reforms to deal with the queue.
On top of that, energy prices for 2025 and 2026 shot up last summer. Ratepayers wouldn't begin to feel the impact until June.
PJM holds a "capacity auction" each year, where they pay generators in exchange for the promise that power plants will be around to produce energy when needed. In the summer of 2024, capacity prices at the auction for the entire grid went from $2.2 billion to $14.7 billion, a 800% increase.
A report from the Office of People's Counsel, which represents Maryland's residential ratepayers, estimates that the average residential BGE customer would see an extra $16 on their monthly electric bills because of the auction. Allegheny Power System customers (including Potomac Edison customers) will see an $18 increase, Delmarva customers will have a $4 increase, and Pepco customers will pay an extra $14 per month. The increases will hit after June 1 of this year.
"They're making decisions that are harming our constituents, harming our ratepayers, harming our communities," Charkoudian said. "And so again, we're here kind of going 'Okay, so, like, what's within our control? What are the things we can affect even though we can't affect, directly, these markets that are driving up prices for our consumers?'"
A spokesperson from PJM wrote that almost all of its meetings and voting are public. PJM doesn't make a profit, he said, and its directors cannot have financial stakes in members of the organization. It has over one thousand members belonging to different sectors like generation, transmission and distribution, as well as customers and consumer advocates.
"PJM favors no fuel or technology," he wrote. "We do not plan generation; we study projects requesting to interconnect to the grid for their impact on reliability and to make sure they can deliver electricity throughout the region. Nearly all the projects we are studying — and the 50,000 (megawatts) we have cleared to build — are renewable."
He wrote that auction prices were high this year because of increased peak load predictions, power plant retirements, and market reforms.
What solutions to these issues are legislators considering?
At a very basic level, there are three basic ways to address these energy issues, Silverman said: generate more, import more or use less. The state could build more energy generation, build more transmission lines or work to cut back on usage.
It's up to policymakers to decide which solutions to use and how, and a number of bills are backing option one: building new power in Maryland.
Democratic leadership is sponsoring a legislative package that would promote building new natural gas, nuclear, and other types of "dispatchable energy." Gov. Wes Moore's energy bill also supports new nuclear, which would be funded by ratepayers. Charkoudian is the lead sponsor on legislation that would support building more energy storage, provide clean energy credits for nuclear, and incentivize solar. It also supports relicensing the state's only nuclear power plant.
Meanwhile, a bill enjoying bipartisan support in the Senate would take a hard look at Maryland's current energy policies. If it's passed, a team of experts would have to find a way for the state to cut back on imports and increase in-state energy generation.
Maryland needs to "reverse course" on its energy policies and prioritize energy reliability and affordability, said bill sponsor Chris West, a Republican from Baltimore and Carroll counties.
"If I can get that (bill) through, I will be a happy camper," he said.
Maryland currently imports 40% of its electricity from out of state.
"I don't want to say that there aren't legitimate concerns about relying on power imported from other places, but the reality is … that Maryland has long imported portions of its generation," People's Counsel Lapp said. "Generally, it's ranged around 40%, but sometimes goes up and sometimes goes down."
But it can be more cost-effective if energy doesn't have to travel as far between where it's produced and where it's consumed, said Adam Dubitsky, the consulting state director for the Maryland Land & Liberty Coalition.
Existing plants in Maryland could have cut imports in half in 2023 by producing more in-state energy, Lapp said, but that would have been more expensive for them than imports.
How much more in-state energy does Maryland need?
None, at least not immediately, according to the Office of People's Counsel.
"What we're finding is that there is not an immediate reliability crisis to address," Lapp said.
He said there could be reasons to build more energy in Maryland, like meeting clean energy goals, but the state isn't seeing the same demand growth from data centers as other areas. The only similar concern in Maryland would be the coming retirement of a power plant, but PJM is building a new transmission project to make up for the loss of energy. A study from the Office of People's Counsel found that the transmission will be enough to make up for the loss and even provide more capacity without needing to build more power in Maryland.
"Based on current forecasts, assuming there is overall enough supply to meet PJM's demand, Maryland should be in good shape," Lapp said. "If PJM as a region falls short, you know, Maryland could fall short. But that's not a Maryland-specific problem." It would be expensive and unrealistic for Maryland to build all the energy the grid is demanding, he said.
West, the sponsor of the task force bill, is worried about potential brownouts, blackouts, and expensive imports if the grid doesn't have enough energy supply.
When asked to choose between paying for new generation in Maryland or facing blackouts and pricey imports, "I think you'd find the people of Maryland say, 'we think we'd rather bite the bullet and generate it locally,'" West said.
Charkoudian said the idea of blackouts was "absolutely inaccurate." Higher prices are on the horizon because of the capacity market, but not blackouts, she said.
The reality, Silverman said, is that PJM has less surplus power than it used to. There's still enough to keep the lights on, but the safety buffer has shrunk.
"I would say we're in the yellow zone, not the red zone," he said.
Meanwhile, he said, consumers are in a financial crisis.
"Energy poverty is a real thing in the United States, and as we sort of balance the need to talk about climate change and … other localized environmental issues, we also need to talk about customer affordability, because that also has really profound impacts on people's quality of life," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on legislative proposals, market pricing, and economic impacts of building new power plants, making Business/Economy the most fitting category, with secondary relevance to Environment (energy sources) and Public Safety (grid reliability).

title: Gay’s Seafood opens new location in Easton
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Gay’s Seafood opens new location in Easton

 April 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 245
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Gay's Seafood opened a new location on North Washington Street in Easton.The family-owned establishment opened in 1915 and has been in Talbot County since.
"My Grandfather's Uncle started in 1915 down on the water," Rennie Gay, owner of Gay's Seafood, said. "We sold seafood, crabs and stuff until last year, and then we closed that location."
The new Gay's Seafood and Deli location sits at the site of the former Old Mill Deli, which has been vacant for over a year.
"I'm running up here at the Old Mill Deli location," Gay said. "We transferred it into Gay's seafood and Deli, and we got a floor line deli on one side and a full seafood on the other side."
Gay said he is excited for the new location. The establishment will offer sales each day of the week by making announcements via the business' Facebook page.
"It's very nice," Gay said. "... I got a nice location here. People are coming and going, and right now we're new. The deli is doing fantastic, and the seafood will pick up as as the crab season's just beginning, so that'll be a good too."
During Friday's lunch rush, customers raved about the service and food.
"The service and the food was really good," customer Caroyln Swann said. "It's my first time here, and it's just opening, but he's done a wonderful job. I had fish, and it was delicious. I'm going to bring all my friends, so yeah, we'll be back." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the opening of a new location of Gay's Seafood, a family‑owned restaurant. This is a business development story, making Business/Economy the most appropriate category.

title: Oxford residents celebrate Oxford Bellevue Ferry's new owner
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Oxford residents celebrate Oxford Bellevue Ferry's new owner

 April 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 465
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — Oxford residents came out to the blessing of the Oxford Bellevue Ferry, where they met new owner Jim Andrews this past Friday.It was one of the first opportunities residents had to meet the new captain, who will be at the helm of one of the town's most notable landmarks.
"I mean you can't even believe, it's just wonderful," Andrews said. "This is such a great opportunity, an incredible vessel, just an incredible history and you can see all the the members of the community come out to to well-wish and and to get started on a new season. So, I pinch myself every day, it's awesome."
The Oxford Bellevue Ferry is America's oldest privately owned ferry. Its original ownership was established in 1683. As its name implies, the ferry provides transportation services for vehicles, bicycles, motorcycles and passengers between the incorporated town of Oxford and the historic working community of Bellevue.
Previous owners Tom and Judy Bixler sold the fleet to Andrews this past February and will be enjoying retirement, but they still will be helping out with the ferry when they can.
"I won't lie to you, It's bitter sweet," previous owner Tom Bixler said. "It's a wonderful day knowing that we've got the perfect successor. A gentleman who's highly professionally trained and has great business sense. It's exciting, but it's an end of an era. I got the privilege and the honor to own the ferry, I'm only one of three owners in 90 some-odd years."
In their 24 years of ownership, the Bixlers are proud of how they brought the ferry forward.
"The fact that I think we brought the ferry forward so that she can go another 100 years," Tom Bixler said. "There was a time there it was getting harder and harder. We got some great cooperation from the state, the county, but the key here is the fact that community supports it so well and the people of Maryland, I mean it's an icon, so we're very fortunate."
Residents brought food items and beverages to the docks to toast the new captain and celebrate the history of the ferry.
The Rev. Kevin Cross conducted the Blessing of the Fleet and wrote a song to help introduce Andrews.
Papers with the lyrics were printed out and residents sung along while Cross flung holy water around the vessel.
After Andrews was introduced, he presented the previous owners with an oar, which symbolized retirement.
"Our relationship, it transcends past past the commercial buyer seller, and we're just partners in maintaining and supporting the ferry," Andrews said. "So we couldn't be more pleased with our friendship and relationship with the Bixlers."
When asked if he had a message for Talbot County residents, Andrews said, "be so thankful that you live close to Heaven here in Talbot County and come ride the ferry." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the sale and new ownership of a historic ferry, highlighting business aspects, local economic impact, and community interest, making Business/Economy the strongest fit.

title: Maryland gas prices continue trending upward
author: GASBUDDY
content:
Maryland gas prices continue trending upward

 April 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GASBUDDY | Section: State News 
 
 493
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland rose 8.7 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.25 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 31.2 cents per gallon higher than a month ago and stand 35.2 cents per gallon lower than a year ago.The national average price of diesel has increased 3.6 cents in the last week and stands at $3.594 per gallon.
According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.89 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.79 per gallon, a difference of 90.0 cents per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has risen 10.6 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.21 per gallon Monday. The national average is up 13.2 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 35.6 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
April 7, 2024: $3.60 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.57 per gallon)April 7, 2023: $3.50 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.58 per gallon)April 7, 2022: $3.74 per gallon (U.S. Average: $4.14 per gallon)April 7, 2021: $2.78 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.87 per gallon)April 7, 2020: $1.99 per gallon (U.S. Average: $1.89 per gallon)April 7, 2019: $2.68 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.74 per gallon)April 7, 2018: $2.67 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.66 per gallon)April 7, 2017: $2.35 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.39 per gallon)April 7, 2016: $2.06 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.04 per gallon)April 7, 2015: $2.35 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.38 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.25 per gallon, up 8.5 cents per gallon from last week's $3.17 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.20 per gallon, down 0.4 cents per gallon from last week's $3.21 per gallon.Hagerstown: $3.24 per gallon, up 17.0 cents per gallon from last week's $3.07 per gallon.
"While the national average price of gasoline saw its largest weekly gain of the year, it likely won't last long, as oil prices have plummeted amid growing concerns about the global economy following the U.S. announcement of some of the most significant tariffs in over a century, along with OPEC+ restoring oil production faster than anticipated," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "In addition to falling oil prices, the stock market has dropped sharply, and the risk of a recession has increased — raising the likelihood of reduced global energy and oil demand, which is sending prices lower. As a result, motorists can expect gas prices to begin falling nearly coast-to-coast, with oil now at its lowest level since the early days of the pandemic in 2021. If tariffs aren't scaled back soon, the national average could fall below $3 per gallon in the weeks ahead, with no clear indication of how long it might stay there as market volatility persists." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses gasoline price trends, market dynamics, tariffs, and recession risks, all of which are economic and business-related topics.

title: 'Penguins not Putin'?: Trump leaves Russia off tariffs list as some GOP lawmakers push bans on Moscow's metals imports
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News
content:
'Penguins not Putin'?: Trump leaves Russia off tariffs list as some GOP lawmakers push bans on Moscow's metals imports

 April 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News | Section: News 
 
 1012
 Words 

 Read News Document

 U.S. President Donald Trump's high "Liberation Day" tariffs include 185 countries across the globe — but not Russia.Trump's tariffs regime includes U.S. geopolitical allies such as the European Union, Japan, South Korea and Israel.
They also include India, Brazil, South Africa, Haiti, Thailand, Iran and China (which is poised for a potential full-scale trade war with the U.S) as well as far-off obscure places including Norfolk Island in the South Pacific, the Diego Garcia military base in the Indian Ocean and the penguin-inhabited Heard and McDonald Islands near Antarctica.
Trump's tariffs, which he is now pausing for 90-days at a 10% rate except for China after stressing out stock and bond markets, do not, however, include Russia.
That's not lost on Trump's critics who see the U.S. president as too friendly and fraternal with Russian President Vladimir Putin and too adversarial with the EU and NATO allies (including Canada).
Trump responded to a question Monday on why he's not tariffing Russia.
"The reason we are not talking about tariffs with Russia is because we are not doing business essentially with Russia because they are in a war," Trump said.
Those sentiments were previously echoed by White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt and Trump economic advisor Kevin Hassett.
"There's obviously an ongoing negotiation with Russia and Ukraine and I think the president made the decision not to conflate the two issues," Hassett told ABC News Sunday.
Ukraine faces a 10% import tax under Trump's tariff regime.
There are U.S. and European sanctions on Russia stemming from its 2022 invasion of Ukraine. But according to the U.S. Trade Representatives office, Russia imported $3 billion worth of goods and raw materials into the U.S. last year.
The U.S. has a $2.5 billion trade deficit with Russia, according to USTR. Under the formula used by the Trump administration to levy import duties, Russia could have seen a 42% tariff.
Russia ranks among the top 65 countries importing goods and materials into the U.S, according to Trading Economics.
Russia has more U.S. imports than Sri Lanka, which was facing a 44% U.S. tariff, as well as Serbia (37% tariff), Laos (48%) and Myanmar (44%) before Trump announced his pause and retreat to a 10% rate.
While some Russia products have been restricted by war sanctions (which Trump has hinted at easing as part of his efforts to forge a ceasefire in Ukraine), there have continued to be precious metals and rare earths imports into the U.S.
Russia's exclusion has salience in one U.S. state, in Montana, where GOP lawmakers supportive of Trump want to see prohibitions on Russian metals and rare earths imports until the end of the war in Ukraine contending they are hurting the state's mining industry.
Montana is the only U.S. state where platinum and palladium (which is used to make catalytic converters) are mined.
Russia is a top exporter of the metals as well as other rare earths.
Sibanye-Stillwater Ltd. (a South Africa-based mining conglomerate) operates two platinum and palladium mines in Montana and laid off 640 of its statewide workforce (40% of its footprint) late last year.
The mining company blamed Russia dumping for a contemporary drop in palladium prices.
Sibanye-Stillwater is backing a bill put forward by Montana's four Republican members of Congress to ban Russian imports of palladium, platinum and other metals and rare earths including zinc, copper, nickel, braggite and ruthenium until the war ends.
U.S. Sens. Steve Daines and Tim Sheehy and U.S. Reps. Troy Downing and Ryan Zinke, all Republicans, introduced the Russian import restrictions bill Feb. 28.
That was the same day as Trump and Vice President J.D. Vance argued with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy at the White House calling him ungrateful for U.S. war aid after he told them not to trust Putin, citing Russia's 2022 and 2014 invasions.
Trump, who has also imposed 25% tariffs on automotive, auto parts, steel and aluminum imports (including from Canada and Mexico, could have impacted Russian trade flows with his "Liberation Day" import taxes.
Downing said in a statement that existing Ukraine war sanctions serve as tariffs against Russia. but that he wants to see Congress and Trump approve the legislation.
"America's existing sanctions regime already serves as a tariff against Russia. Targeted import bans like the Stop Russian Market Manipulation Act would put meaningful pressure on the Kremlin and improve outcomes for Montana miners. I'll be pursuing every available legislative avenue to see this bill enacted into law as soon as possible for my constituents," said Downing, a freshman Republican whose district includes the Montana mines.
Daines also said he supports Trump's goals of more balanced trade flows and increasing U.S. manufacturing.
"I've been in close contact with the White House to share Montanans' concerns, and I share President Trump's goal of ending unfair trade practices and increasing Made-In-America manufacturing and production. In the Senate, I'm fighting for ways to expand market access for Montana producers and businesses overseas and will always always support Montana farmers, ranchers and businesses," Daines said.
The Trump tariffs have stirred worries about higher prices, slower growth, trade wars and a potential recession. The president and his economic team argue the import taxes will "re-industrialize" the U.S. via increased domestic manufacturing while settling inequitable trade scores.
The U.S. administration is indicating Trump is willing to deal with Japan, South Korea and other countries. But China and the EU are tougher situations to resolve.
Trump has struck friendly tones toward Putin and Russia since taking office. The U.S. president has said he trusts Putin and has joined Russia in opposing Ukraine joining NATO.
Trump has said his goal is to the end the war in Ukraine, but the U.S. also voted with Russia on United Nations resolutions and against Kyiv and Europe regarding the third anniversary of the 2022 invasion.
Trump previously said tariffs and more sanctions could be issued against Russia as part of efforts to stop the Ukraine war.
But Russia and two of its war allies, North Korea and Belarus (which also face sanctions), were not on the sandwich board displaying Trump's tariffs.
"They've actually put tariffs on penguins but not on Putin," said Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-New York, on the Trump import taxes on Antarctic islands and not Moscow. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on trade policy, tariffs, and their impact on industries and the economy, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy category.

title: 'Changed my life': Talbot County celebrates 14 graduates of business academy
author: Konner Metz
content:
'Changed my life': Talbot County celebrates 14 graduates of business academy

 April 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 474
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County graduated 14 small business owners from an eight-week program that focuses on growing small and minority-owned businesses.The Talbot Works Business Academy honored its third cohort of graduates at Tuesday's County Council meeting. Two participants explained how the program has made an impact on their businesses.
Jen Wagner, an Easton mosaic artist, said the courses offered her an opportunity to take a step up — even in her 21st year as a small business owner.
"I'm at a pivotal point in my career," Wagner said. "I've experienced a lot of success, but I'm ready to take it to the next level."
"It completely changed my life," she said of the program. "I needed people that I could trust to look at things with a fresh pair of eyes. The mentorships were the most important things to me, to be able to talk to experts from legal, from accounting."
Nolan Laguna of Laguna Floor Care, in his fourth year as an entrepreneur, said the academy gave his four children the opportunity to watch him develop as a business leader.
The training program was created by Will Holmes Consulting, a Baltimore-based business management firm, and its founder Will Holmes. The Talbot County Economic Development and Tourism office and its director Cassandra Vanhooser spearheaded the effort.
During the academy's courses, participants learned about organizational infrastructure, growth planning, human resources and legal practices, and financial documentation.
Vanhooser thanked the County Council for funding cohorts of the business academy through American Rescue Plan Act dollars. The Rural Maryland Council funded the third cohort, she said.
"Your investment sends a strong message: that Talbot County believes in its entrepreneurs and is willing to back that belief with action," Vanhooser said.
Of the third group's 14 members, Vanhooser recognized a common theme of courage.
"It takes guts to step out on your own, to embrace risk and to believe in your vision enough to pursue that in the face of uncertainty," she said. "These individuals rose to the challenge."
Last year, the Talbot Works Business Academy graduated its first two cohorts. Vanhooser said of all businesses who have taken the academy to date, there have been 11 new employees added, three businesses expanded and two participants launching second businesses.
"Here in Talbot County, we know that small businesses are the heartbeat of our local economy," Vanhooser said. "They create jobs, bring innovation and build the character of our towns and communities."
The 14 graduates honored Tuesday were: Olamide Adejumo, Motivar Consulting; Maria Bowser, In Vein Phlebotomy; Ann Casamento, Easton Advanced Aesthetics; Amanda Cook, Tilghman Island Baking Company; Jair Devereaux, JusJai2; Johanna Duke, Southern Jo's Kitchen and Bar; Nolan Laguna, Laguna Floor Care; Pamela Limberry, Care Partner Perfection; Kristen Lycett, Phillips Wharf Environmental Center; Jeffrey Mathias, Mathias Marine Services; Monika Mraz, Doehrn Tea Company; Demar Mundy, DM Trucking; Lamont Powell, The Powell's Trash Removal Service; and Jen Wagner, Jen Wagner Mosaics. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a county-run business academy that trains and graduates small business owners, highlighting economic development and entrepreneurship, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Jake Day visits Caroline County to discuss economic development and housing
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Jake Day visits Caroline County to discuss economic development and housing

 April 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 465
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Jake Day, the state's secretary of housing and community development, visited Caroline County as part of his tour through the state Wednesday.While in Denton, Day spoke with businesses owners, development officials and county officials and conducted a walking tour of downtown to identify places where state money could be leveraged.
While talking with business owners and development officials, constituents voiced concerns about connecting with the right state department or program to receive the help they need with funding and repairs. Day believes that Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development could help bridge that gap of communication.
"I'm not here today to tell you the Maryland Department of Housing Community Development is going to solve every economic challenge you have on the county hand," Day said to constituents. "We can be a piece of the puzzle. We're a part of the equation. We can say, we'll bring our colleagues in from MDOT, we'll bring our colleagues in from the MBE, let's get them in the room."
While the department is not the main provider for all state grants, it has helped provide Choptank Electric Cooperative with a great amount of funding.
"Choptank Fiber has acquired about $18 million dollars in grant funding through DHCD. We completed those grants in a very timely fashion. We continue to do deployment throughout the county," said Matthew Teffeau, manager of government affairs and economic development for Choptank Electric Cooperative.
In addition to $18 million in funding for broadband, the department has provided 37 rental units and about $10 million in financing for avoidable housing from 2020 through 2024.
After the conversation, Day participated in the walking tour through downtown Denton, visiting multiple business.
The purpose of Day's tour around the state is to engage county leaders and municipal representatives to show how the state can collaborate with counties in the areas of housing, community and economic development, and small business support through grants and other programs.
"I love doing this," Day said. "Today is an opportunity to meet directly with entrepreneurs, banks, chamber of commerce, business owners, mayors, Main Street managers, and county commissioners and have a conversation with them about their aspirations and their needs."
"Our agency is best suited to help these communities with their visions," he continues. "We don't tell them what their visions are, we don't tell them what to aspire to, we serve their visions."
Day spent about 20 minutes at each business, looking around and learning more about downtown Denton. Town of Denton Mayor Abigail McNinch thanked Day for all the help the DHCD has provided to Caroline County.
"We are so excited because for him to see the projects that DHCD has worked on and has helped us accomplish and also look forward to projects that he and his department can help with, it's invaluable, we're really excited," McNinch said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on state-led economic development, housing initiatives, and grant funding for local businesses, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic, while also involving county officials (Local Government).

title: Only bilingual law firm in Kent County celebrates 1 year
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Only bilingual law firm in Kent County celebrates 1 year

 April 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 489
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — The First Friday event of April brought friends, neighbors and visitors to downtown Chestertown. Some of those stopped by the law offices of Campbell and Furneisen to celebrate the company's one-year anniversary.Partners Bridget Campbell and Ivette Furneisen were both nominated for Eastern Shore's 2024 Women to Watch. And according to their website, Furneisen is "one of very few Spanish-speaking lawyers on the shore, and possibly the only native Spanish-speaking. It continues, "Furneisen has quickly gained a reputation as a friend to Hispanics and other immigrants in the area, helping with traffic and family court, visas and applications for citizenship."
Furneisen said this anniversary is a significant celebration due to that distinction.
Over sparkling beverages and catering courtesy of Happy Chicken, and while balancing conversation with friends and well-wishers, Furneisen shared why she feels like her work is more vital than ever.
It started, she said, 15 years ago. In her native country of Spain, she was working for a nonprofit doing immigration work. She extended that realm of her expertise by studying law at George Mason University. Ultimately, she and her husband, who worked for American Airlines, discovered Kent County.
Now a year in to running her own practice advocating for Spanish speakers, she expressed concern for her clients, some of whom had been detained by immigration police being caught in offenses such as traffic violations.
These incidences, she said, are why she decided to pursue law further.
"Everyone deserves representation. It doesn't matter if you're rich or poor," Furneisen stated.
She takes a lot of cases from the public defender's office for those who normally could not afford a lawyer.
"Now, I can be an advocate for them. And not just in the courts. I really care," she said.
The other half of the firm is Bridget Campbell. She handles family law, real estate, business formation and other practices.
Like her legal partner, Campbell is grateful to be representing Kent County. With both of them working jointly, they cast a wide net of services.
Some of the most rewarding work is representing children as a best interest attorney, Campbell said. It is her job to advocate for children, give them a voice, and from those assessments, persuade the judge to act in the children's best interest.
This involves talking to the parents, the therapists and the children, being present for them in their time of need, Campbell said. As a mother of three boys, this is very near to her heart as she reflects on her time studying law at Villanova, before attending Washington College.
Originally born in Pennsylvania, she has established roots here after studying law at Villanova and attending Washington College. She is president of the Kent County Humane Society, dedicated to promoting animal welfare, "preventing unnecessary pain and suffering for domestic companions in the community."
Both attorneys see themselves reaching beyond their law profession to help those in need.
"Ivette and I find a way to give back to the community every way we can," Campbell said.
