title: Market puts the spotlight on industrious worms
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Market puts the spotlight on industrious worms

 April 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 546
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Each Saturday morning at the Chestertown Farmers Market, customers can find a refreshing variety of items from produce to baked goods and handwoven crafts. They can also find worm castings if so obliged.Samantha Arcand, owner of Arcand Wrigglers Worm Castings based out of Centreville, is selling her castings to Chestertown customers for the first time .
She defined worm castings as just worm manure, which is highly beneficial for the garden, and one of the few types of manure that can be spread over plants safely without going through a cold composting, also called freezing, process.
The castings resembles black soil, which she sells in a bag for $10.
The process of using worm manure as compost, known as vermicomposting, involves feeding worms food scraps, which the worms then turn into nutrient-rich organic fertilizer.
Arcand started this business last spring, going full time, leaving her job at Target in Kent Island to pursue her passion for vermiculture.
As a hobby farmer over 20 years, she unlocked the magic of castings when feeding the worms to her pet turtles. Over time, by using the worm castings in her garden, her plants grew healthy and numerous.
"My garden just exploded," Arcand said. "Right now, I have two freezers full of cucumbers."
She uses two breeds of worm for the castings: red wrigglers, a very common worm, and European nightcrawlers.
The worms are happy too — not an easy task to accomplish. They live in an enclosed garage, with an air conditioner and heater to maintain the temperature at a comfy 65 degrees. Any subtle change to that and the worms look to bail out.
Within the garage, she keeps the worms inside big wooden flow bins about 2 feet deep. The worms are fed a combination of worm chow, a mix of horse, chicken and livestock feed, and most excess waste from Arcand's garden.
"They get all the fruits and veggies, and everything we don't eat," Arcand said, who stressed the importance of keeping in mind to balance the acidity.
With this very natural diet, she guarantees the nutrient analysis of her product.
Worm castings will not burn up plants like other fertilizers, Arcand says. She tells customers worm castings are rich in micronutrients: sulfur, iron, zinc, calcium and copper; and provide macronutrients: potassium, nitrogen, phosphorus. Research, she added, has shown worm castings enhance seed germination, plant growth, flowering and fruit production.
Arcand offers this information in instructional videos on Tik Tok. Last week for instance, Arcand demonstrated online what the best kind of bedding to use when raising worms is.
In addition to Chestertown, you can find her at markets in Centreville, Kent Island, and soon in Makers Market in Georgetown, Delaware. You can also get her products on Amazon, Ebay or at arcandwigglers.com.
What is next for Arcand's business? Much like worms do, Arcand would like to see her business multiply.
She wants to sell the worms as well as their "dirt," but she pointed out she needs to get up to 1 million worms to start selling them. She is well on her way, daily spotting the multiple little golden orb eggs worms leave behind.
In the meantime, gardeners will enjoy using this product, Arcand said, and the plants will enjoy feeding from it. As her mottos states, "Let us feed your plants so that they can feed you." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a small entrepreneur selling worm castings and expanding her vermiculture business, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic, while also relating to Agriculture.

title: Talbot is a 'thriving' market during time of 'great uncertainty,' Fed branch president says
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Talbot is a 'thriving' market during time of 'great uncertainty,' Fed branch president says

 April 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 567
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond President and CEO Tom Barkin compared navigating the country's economic future to driving in the fog. But he said Talbot County is one market that seems to be thriving."It's one of the markets that does seem to be thriving in an area of great uncertainty," he said in an interview before the 2025 Talbot County Business Appreciation Summit.
Hosted by the Talbot County Department of Economic Development and Tourism and the Talbot County Economic Development Commission, the Business Appreciation Summit included a keynote speech from Barkin and the presentation of Community Impact Awards to a variety of businesses and individuals.
The awards are presented to businesses, nonprofits, community projects and individuals that have made a significant impact in the county, according to the Department of Economic Development and Tourism.
Before awards were presented, Talbot County Council Member Keasha Haythe said companies can be judged based on their products and services. "But one can also judge a company on the impact their people have on their community," she said.
Recipients of the Community Impact Awards included Bluepoint Hospitality, Building African American Minds, Walter Chase, The Oaks, Port Street Commons and University of Maryland Shore Regional Health.
The county, Town of Easton and Easton Utilities were all recognized alongside Shore Regional Health for the project to build a new hospital in Easton, which is expected to open in spring 2028.
"It's important to point out that this award is the result of a massive group effort of years of hard work and dedication," Easton Mayor Megan Cook said.
Shore Regional Health President and CEO Ken Kozel acknowledged the journey to building a new hospital on the Mid-Shore hasn't been easy. The project has been more than two decades in the making.
"But we've persevered, we've been persistent and we've tried to work our hardest to achieve this goal," he said. "And it's because of each one of you in this room that has helped us get this far. So we're humbled, we're grateful and we're also excited about what the future holds for health care in this community."
KEYNOTE SPEECH
During the event's keynote address, Barkin spoke from his point of view about economic uncertainty. He said even though the numbers that have come in so far this year "have barely moved" since the end of 2024, federal government policy has "taken center stage" and led to falls in business optimism and consumer sentiment.
"The scale and the pace of change seems to have created a sense of instability," he said.
During his speech, Barkin made a point to discuss what is known when it comes to the economy and where things are headed. He said the country is headed toward:
More tariffs.Lower net migration.An extension of the 2017 tax cuts.Deregulation.Lower growth in government spending.Efforts to promote traditional energy sources.
What is yet to be determined, Barkin said, is how far these efforts will go and what the final outcome of the efforts will be.
"Or as I've been saying, we're on the road. It's foggy. We know the direction. We're just not sure about the destination," he said.
Barkin said the Federal Reserve is driving through the same fog as businesses and consumers. He said the labor market is still in a good place and inflation is above target.
"If conditions start to shift, we're well-positioned to adjust," he said. "But until that — like businesses and consumers — we're just waiting for the fog to clear." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a Federal Reserve official discussing economic uncertainty and highlights a local business appreciation summit, awards to businesses, and economic development initiatives, making Business/Economy the strongest fit.

title: Shore legislators worry about tax hikes, energy, education in the wake of General Assembly
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Shore legislators worry about tax hikes, energy, education in the wake of General Assembly

 April 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 802
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Maryland General Assembly session officially ended Monday night. Lawmakers fought through a very tough fiscal year budget, which had some significant impacts for Eastern Shore communities, legislators said.Members of the Eastern Shore delegation stressed budget difficulties loom over state lawmakers, who spent much of this year's session tackling an over $3 billion deficit.
"I think the session was not a good session," Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said. "We've just made Maryland a very expensive, more expensive than it was, and it's going to make us less competitive in the region.
"If you believe that economic competitiveness is in fact a priority, I think that it is, and I think that by raising taxes and fees, both at the state level and then forcing the locals to also increase their fees and taxes is a double whammy."
Maryland lawmakers passed a balanced budget Monday, concluding their spring session after months of grappling with the deficit. The final budget included about $2 billion in cuts and about $1.6 billion in tax hikes.
"I think we left frustrated that we had to raise taxes $1.66 billion and there was no regard to wanting to really seriously cut expenses from the state budget," said Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico).
Eastern Shore Delegation members believe after this year's session, the Shore will see lasting effects both fiscally and in several key industries.
Solar
One of the biggest concerns for the Mid-Shore this budget session has been solar energy.
A renewable energy bill aimed at increasing generation of energy within the state by promoting solar energy production was passed by both chambers of the state legislature.
Some Eastern Shore Delegation members feel provisions added to these bills during legislators' deliberations supersede counties' authority regarding solar permitting and regulation.
"It undermines all the work that the counties have already done to try to facilitate where and how to put solar," Mautz said. "It includes a new assessment for planting solar, which is going to raise energy costs."
Hutchinson echoed this sentiment, saying, "It falls on deaf ears that the Democrats from Montgomery and Prince George's county all think that they know how the quality of life is here on the Eastern Shore."
Utility bills
House Bill 1035 and Senate Bill 937, known collectively as the "Next Generation Energy Act," include plans to reduce energy bills and address shortfalls by modernizing the state's energy infrastructure and incentivizing in-state energy production.
Eastern Shore Delegation members believe this effort to get the cost down lacked the immediacy rate payers need to address bill hikes.
"We have not addressed the number one complaint I received when I arrived in January," Hutchinson said, "rate payers calling to say that their electric bills are astronomical. We put legislation forward to try to lower utility bills, and again, it falls on deaf ears."
Education funding
The Blueprint for Maryland's Futue, the state's education improvement and funding initiative through 2032, originally outlined an increase in teacher collaborative time, during which teachers are not in classes and can plan, grade or meet with students individually. But with adjustments made in the state's budget to combat the deficit, funding to implement the change has been postponed.
The Blueprint also sustained several other cuts and freezes that impact county finances. Multiple Mid-Shore county school boards have had to make budget cut decisions and potential layoffs in response.
"So let me take Dorchester County, for example," Hutchinson said. "They pushed down the teachers' pensions. They pushed down the Blueprint. They pushed down other mandates that the state usually paid for, but now it's all the county, they have to pay for (it)."
"The school board is short about $5 million. They just eliminated summer school," he said. "They're looking at having to lay off student support personnel. They say we want to create a world-class education. Yet you look at the results of what's happening in Maryland and say that doesn't make sense."
Potential special sessions
While the 2025 session has ended, Mautz doesn't believe discussion is officially over.
As the federal government continues to shift funding priorities, state legislators may need to reconvene to address any impacts this has on the balanced budget, he said.
"Counties are probably going to have to raise revenue through taxes and different things," Mautz said. "The federal government is probably going to continue to reduce spending. Then there's a high likelihood that we're going to have a special session."
"So we would have to go back to Annapolis again to address any changes that that come from federal spending reductions. Just as the federal government is reducing its spending, the state is doing the same thing to the counties, and so where all this ends, it seems to be, taxpayer, taxpayer, taxpayer.
"Everybody should know it's very hard to predict how this is all going to play out, but I don't think the discussion about the budget is is officially over." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on state budget decisions, tax hikes, fiscal deficits, and economic competitiveness, which align most closely with Business/Economy. It also touches on local government impacts and education funding, but the primary emphasis is on economic and budgetary issues.

title: Maryland faces runaway spending, weak economic growth
author: JOHNNY MAUTZ
content:
Maryland faces runaway spending, weak economic growth

 April 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JOHNNY MAUTZ | Section: Columns 
 
 565
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The 2025 session of the General Assembly wrapped up at midnight on April 7, and I need to be straight with you — they just approved one of the largest tax increases in Maryland history.When Gov. Wes Moore was elected, he inherited a $5 billion surplus. Now, just three years later, we have accrued a $3 billion deficit.
I stood my ground and voted no on this budget.
Let me be clear: Our fiscal problems aren't because you aren't paying enough taxes. The problem is runaway spending and weak economic growth. The so-called "Blueprint for Education" simply costs more than we can afford, and the state keeps adding more employees, agencies and departments. These new taxes and fees will only drive businesses and jobs away from Maryland.
I know many on the Shore are struggling with inflation and skyrocketing energy costs. It's even tougher for folks who rely on government assistance for energy, food and housing — many of these programs have been cut or face reductions.
Making matters worse, the state pushed many costs down to our county governments while authorizing increases in local income taxes (the "piggy-back tax"). This creates pressure for counties to either raise these taxes or hike property taxes to meet state mandates.
Most of these mandates come from the Blueprint for Education. Despite our efforts to provide relief to local jurisdictions, all we got was a three-year freeze on "collaborative time" for teachers. Not nearly enough.
Our Eastern Shore has become a target for out-of-state solar developers. They see our flat, affordable farmland and Maryland's generous renewable energy standards as an opportunity. Despite united opposition from all Eastern Shore legislators, outside interests pushed through legislation to fast-track solar projects here as their "solution" to energy costs.
Two harmful solar bills passed this year: SB931, the "Renewable Energy Certainty Act," gives the Public Service Commission new power to approve massive projects and override our local zoning decisions. SB909, the "Energy Resource & Adequacy Planning Act," creates yet another government office within the PSC (funded by your utility bills) to make energy policy recommendations. I fought against both bills because they trample local control and ignore the true value of our agricultural land.
There were a few bright spots on public safety.
The General Assembly finally made possession of stolen firearms a felony. Legislation also passed allowing parole consideration for seniors and those convicted between ages 18-24 after serving 20 years — but the Parole Board must still approve any release.
Our top local priority — funding for the new Eastern Shore Regional Medical Center — received $20 million in the governor's budget to continue construction of this critical facility that will replace the aging Easton Memorial Hospital.
After years of trying, we finally amended the permanent revocation law for commercial watermen. Violations of oyster laws will still result in revocations, but watermen will now have a path to petition for reinstatement so they can apply again to work on the water.
We also approved an important pilot program for Dorchester County that allows private sector resources to review well and septic permits — a critical function often delayed in our local health departments.
And small towns with less than $100,000 annual revenue will now be exempt from costly legislative audits — a win for many Eastern Shore communities.
But make no mistake — our budget troubles aren't over. With federal spending cuts on the horizon, we may face a special session before 2026. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on state budget deficits, tax increases, and their impact on economic growth and businesses, making Business/Economy the most fitting category.

title: 'Devastating': Small businesses sue Trump over tariffs
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
'Devastating': Small businesses sue Trump over tariffs

 April 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: National 
 
 1059
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A group of small businesses — including a wine and sake importer, industrial manufacturer and fishing gear and tackle e-commerce firm — are suing President Donald Trump over his tariffs, challenging his use of an emergency law to impose taxes on imports.Texas-based Liberty Justice Center filed a federal lawsuit in the U.S. Court of International Trade on April 14 on behalf of five small businesses impacted by Trump's "Liberation Day" and other tariffs.
The lawsuit challenges Trump's authority to invoke tariffs under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA).
Trump is the first U.S. president to invoke tariffs under the 1977 emergency powers law.
The lawsuit argues Trump lacks the authority to issue his across-the-board, worldwide tariffs without approval by Congress.
Trump has cited flows of fentanyl (an illegal synthetic opioid) into the U.S. for imposing 20% tariffs against China and threatening Canada and Mexico with 25% levies.
Trump cited trade deficits for his "Liberation Day" country-by-country tariffs. The tariffs were originally as high as 49% but have been reduced to 10% during a 90-day pause instituted by Trump after worries about financial markets.
'NO ONE PERSON'The Liberty Justice Center argues longstanding trade deficits don't constitute an emergency and some of the countries in Trump's tariffs don't even have trade surpluses with the U.S.
"IEEPA does not authorize the President to impose across-the-board tariffs—it does not even authorize tariffs at all; and even if the IEEPA did extend such power to the President, that would be an unconstitutional delegation of Congress's power to impose tariffs," the Texas group said in a statement.
"No one person should have the power to impose taxes that have such vast global economic consequences," said Jeffrey Schwab, senior counsel at the Liberty Justice Center. "The Constitution gives the power to set tax rates—including tariffs—to Congress, not the President."
Trump is imposing a 145% tariff on China (with current exemptions for smartphones, computers and other electronics and technology components). There are also 25% U.S. tariffs on imported cars, auto parts, aluminum and steel imposed under separate trade protocols.
"If starting the biggest trade war since the Great Depression based on a law that doesn't even mention tariffs is not an unconstitutional usurpation of legislative power, I don't know what is," said Ilya Somin, co-counsel a law professor, at George Mason University.
China has imposed 125% tariffs on U.S. goods in response to the Trump import taxes.
The White House pushed back against the lawsuit.
"Never Trumpers will always oppose him, but President Trump is standing up for Main Street by putting an end to our trading partners—especially China—exploiting the U.S. His plan levels the playing field for businesses and workers to address our country's national emergency of chronic trade deficits," said White House spokesman Harrison Fields.
'TARIFF CHAOS'The small business owners who are part of the suit say the tariffs are raising costs and hurting their operations.
"This is devastating to our ability to operate and support the farmers and producers we work with around the world," Victor Owen Schwartz, owner of VOS Selections, which imports wines, spirits and sakes.
Trump previously threatened 200% tariffs on European wine and liquor imports but has not followed through on that.
Conventionally, U.S. administrations have gone through more lengthy trade regimens, that require additional approvals, to institute tariffs.
Dan Pastore, president and co-founder of FishUSA Inc., a Pennsylvania-based e-commerce firm specializing in fishing tackle and gear, said his company sources its products from markets such as South Korea, Kenya, China and Canada and has had to hold up production flows because of the tariffs and their uncertainty.
"Instead of focusing on growing our business, creating more jobs in our region, and developing new products that our customers want, we are spending countless hours trying to navigate the tariff chaos that the President is causing for us and all our vendors," said Dan Pastore, President and co-founder of FishUSA. "It takes years working with factories to design and build our products, and we cannot just shift that business to the U.S. without starting the whole process over again."
Other plaintiffs include Utah-based Genova Pipe which makes piping and relies on Asian resin imports.
"With limited domestic sources, we rely on imports to meet our production needs. The newly imposed tariffs are increasing our raw material costs and hindering our ability to compete in the export market," said Andrew Reese, president of Genova Pipe, which also has manufacturing plants in Washington, Michigan and other U.S. states.
Earlier this month, the New Civil Liberties Alliance also sued the Trump administration over the tariffs on behalf of a Florida business owner also challenging the use of presidential emergency powers.
'MAIN STREET, NOT WALL STREET'Trump and his economic advisors argue the tariffs will settle longstanding trade inequities and bring manufacturing to the U.S.
The White House said in a tariffs announcement that current trade inequities have "undermined critical supply chains; and rendered our defense-industrial base dependent on foreign adversaries."
The tariffs fight is also pitting Trump's push for continued American hegemony over the international economy versus a more globalist system with multinational supply chains and the ever-increasing economic importance of China.
"I'm proud to be the President for the workers, not the outsourcers; the President who stands up for main street, not Wall Street; who protects the middle class, not the political class; and who defends America, not trade cheaters all over the globe," Trump said earlier this month defending his tariffs regime.
The United Auto Workers union backs Trump's auto manufacturing tariffs hoping they will boost domestic productions.
The pro-Trump America First Policy Institute also backs the tariffs.
"President Trump made a clear and strong statement on 'Liberation Day': countries will no longer take advantage of the American market with unfair trade practices that have hollowed out our manufacturing base, depressed wages, and threatened our national security," said Robert Lighthizer, chair of AFP's Center for American Trade.
'DIFFICULT TO CHALLENGE'The U.S. Constitution gives Congress the power over tariffs and taxes. But the legislative branch has increasingly deferred to the executive branch over trade policies.
There are efforts by Trump critics in Congress to take tariffs back. Trump has promised to veto a bill if it passes.
Some legal analysts agree with the challenges. Others see the court deferring to executive power related to the emergency powers law.
"It would appear that the power the president utilized to impose tariffs under IEEPA is very nearly absolute and difficult to challenge," said Achyuth Anil, an international trade policy researcher with the University of Sussex in Britain. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a lawsuit by small businesses against presidential tariff policies, highlighting economic and commercial impacts, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy category, while also being a national-level news story.

title: Choptank Fiber celebrates 5,000 connection milestone
author: CONTRIBIUTED
content:
Choptank Fiber celebrates 5,000 connection milestone

 April 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CONTRIBIUTED | Section: News 
 
 272
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Choptank Fiber, a subsidiary of Choptank Electric Cooperative, has connected over 5,000 customers with reliable and affordable high-speed internet on the Eastern Shore of Maryland since its first connection in 2021.With nearly 2,000 miles of distribution fiber laid, service is now available to more than 12,000 locations.
"We are of course proud of these accomplishments, but more importantly we are celebrating that Choptank Fiber has stuck to its mission of serving our unserved rural electric cooperative members and reinvesting profits back into infrastructure development," shared Mike Malandro, president of Choptank Fiber and CEO of Choptank Electric Cooperative.
Taylor Hall had Choptank Fiber installed at his house outside of Preston this January after struggling to find reliable internet for 17 years.
"As primarily a teleworker, I've been astonished at the difference Choptank Fiber speeds make in my daily work," Hall said. "I'm able to get into remote tools, which require a good connection that I wasn't always able to reach with previous Wi-Fi providers. Online meetings are better, and my wife can access the internet and stream movies without having to schedule around my job."
Using the cooperative principles that are at the core of its business, Choptank Electric Cooperative created Choptank Fiber to deliver reliable and affordable internet service to families and businesses throughout its service territory where current providers wouldn't build, the cooperative said in a press release.
The broadband subsidiary was formed after a vote by Choptank Electric Cooperative members to become member regulated passed in 2020.
"Our commitment remains stronger than ever; to keep you connected to what matters most, now and for generations to come," Malandro said.
Visit choptankfiber.com for more information. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Expert: Gas prices may have hit peak for year
author: GAS BUDDY
content:
Expert: Gas prices may have hit peak for year

 April 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GAS BUDDY | Section: State News 
 
 486
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 6.4 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.19 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 21.5 cents per gallon higher than a month ago and stand 48.7 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has decreased 4.8 cents in the last week and stands at $3.546 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.81 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.79 per gallon, a difference of 98.0 cents per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 8.2 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.13 per gallon Monday. The national average is up 7.8 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 46.9 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
"For now, the good news is that gas prices typically reach their yearly peak around April 10, so we may have already witnessed 'peak pain' at the pump for 2025," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "As refiners near the end of seasonal maintenance and supply begins to rise — and with the changeover to summer gasoline nearly complete — it's increasingly likely that gas prices have already hit their high for the year."
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back ten years:
April 14, 2024: $3.68 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.60 per gallon)April 14, 2023: $3.59 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.65 per gallon)April 14, 2022: $3.67 per gallon (U.S. Average: $4.06 per gallon)April 14, 2021: $2.76 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.86 per gallon)April 14, 2020: $1.95 per gallon (U.S. Average: $1.82 per gallon)April 14, 2019: $2.73 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.83 per gallon)April 14, 2018: $2.69 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.71 per gallon)April 14, 2017: $2.41 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.41 per gallon)April 14, 2016: $2.09 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.10 per gallon)April 14, 2015: $2.38 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.38 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.17 per gallon, down 8.0 cents per gallon from last week's $3.25 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.16 per gallon, down 4.8 cents per gallon from last week's $3.20 per gallon.Hagerstown: $3.22 per gallon, down 2.8 cents per gallon from last week's $3.24 per gallon.
"After oil's sharp drop over the last couple of weeks — driven by concerns over the impact of U.S. tariffs and OPEC+ restoring production faster than expected — gasoline prices have posted a notable weekly decline, with nearly every state seeing prices fall," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "While I do expect gas prices to continue trending lower, any abrupt change in the current tariff situation could eventually bring the decline to a halt." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Women to Watch event recognizes 212 leaders
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
Women to Watch event recognizes 212 leaders

 April 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 409
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Shawna Payne issued a reminder to more than 100 people gathered in the Avalon Theatre April 9 — "You have been chosen."The phrase was a call to action. Despite any self-doubt, Payne said, those gathered in the theater that evening were there to celebrate their own accomplishments and honor their potential to initiate positive change.
In the crowd were some of more than 200 nominees for this year's Women to Watch magazine, an annual publication by APG Chesapeake recognizing the contributions of women to Mid-Shore workplaces and communities.
The women, who were nominated via an online portal by coworkers, friends, spouses and loved ones, represented a wide swath of Mid-Shore change-makers.
"It was a wonderful evening to celebrate the power, success and perseverance of women to watch in the Mid-Shore," said Orestes Baez, regional president of APG Chesapeake. "Everyone had a great story to tell and a great energy to share. APG Chesapeake did a wonderful job putting all the pieces together. We are thankful for the opportunity to share it with the public."
The event marked the launch of the fifth Women to Watch magazine, a preliminary printed version of which was unveiled at the Avalon that evening. The magazine will be inserted into the Star Democrat and available online April 23.
Payne, who works through her nonprofit The BE Academy to empower women entrepreneurs, is one of 14 women featured in this year's edition. She was the first of three speakers to offer advice to those gathered April 9.
Yixin Qiu, co-founder of Apollo's Dream Foundation and a technical project manager for Qlarant, shared how she has worked to generate positive change in the Eastern Shore community that welcomed her as an immigrant a decade ago. Qiu helped found a nonprofit aiding senior citizens with digital literacy.
Jackie Wilson, senior vice president at Burke and Herbert Bank, shared advice for women experiencing change or uncertainty in their careers. She encouraged women to embrace change and rely on their expertise and the expertise of their teams to navigate challenges.
"What an uplifting evening," said Betsy Griffin, APG Chesapeake general manager for sales and marketing. "It was great to see Mid-Shore women connecting and networking with other leaders. We are honored to provide a refreshing evening celebrating these women who serve in the community and excel in their workplaces. The friends, husbands, business associates, sons and daughters also all came out to join in for these special moments. This was especially nice to see."

title: New business tax not fully thought through
author: DAVID REEL
content:
New business tax not fully thought through

 April 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 772
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On the last day of the 2025 Maryland General Assembly session, a majority of General Assembly members and Gov. Moore finally agreed on a $68 billion state budget package.The agreement includes approximately $2 billion in budget cuts, and a wide range of new taxes, tax increases, new fees and fee increases.
Taken together, the tax and fee changes are projected to generate approximately $1.8 billion in new state revenue.
One new tax that is the largest single source of projected new state revenue is a 3% business-to-business sales tax for services provided by information technology providers.
Current projections are this new tax will generate approximately $482 million in new revenue.
The key words here are current and projections.
Achieving a balanced state budget for an entire fiscal year may be wishful thinking.
There is no guarantee if and when all the revenue from the new IT services sales tax will come in as projected.
Del. Ben Barnes, chair of the House Appropriations Committee, was asked if he was confident about the projected revenue from this new sales tax.
He did not answer the question directly. Instead, he said, "We are super confident that the final budget compromise turns a massive structural deficit into a positive structural balance."
It remains to be seen if that super confidence will hold until the end of the upcoming fiscal year.
Complicating matters is that between now and July 1 of this year, the Maryland comptroller's office will have to issue regulations to implement the new IT service sales tax.
Senate Budget and Taxation Committee Chair Guy Guzzone has already acknowledged, "It's very complicated [the new IT service sales tax] and the comptroller will be figuring out how exactly that implementation occurs."
Maryland Senate President Bill Ferguson has said that he expects there will be a bit of a delay in the implementation of the regulations.
The budget bill compromise includes a trigger for a special session to address the impact of any future Trump administration decisions that further reduce the historic and substantial flow of federal dollars into Maryland.
Largely missing during all the debate and deliberations on Annapolis leading up to the approval of this new IT service sales tax was greater consideration of what-if questions.
What if greater consideration would have been given to estimates from the Cybersecurity Association of Maryland, that this new tax could result in IT service companies leaving Maryland?
What if this scenario is already being confirmed?
Maryland State Del. Brian Crosby is the owner of an IT services firm formerly based in Maryland. During a recent speech on the House floor, he told his House colleagues in anticipation of this new IT service sales tax being approved, he had already decided to move his IT service business from Maryland to Virginia.
When asked later about how the new sales tax could impact his business, Crosby said, "All I can say is that within a year, we'd be bankrupt."
Jacob Stokes, president of a 50-employee IT and software development company based in Columbia echoed that sentiment. He has said, "We're going to have to leave the state. That's our only option."
What if greater consideration had been given to concerns raised by the Maryland Chamber of Commerce? The Chamber has suggested, "Once Maryland starts taxing services, whether it's tech, legal, marketing or accounting, it becomes easier to expand these taxes to other sectors down the line."
They further suggest, "Today, it's tech services. Tomorrow it could be any other service upon which Maryland businesses and consumers depend."
What if greater consideration had been given to reports on all the businesses that have already have or are considering transferring their incorporation from Delaware due to what they perceive to be a hostile business climate there?
The current list includes Facebook, Walmart, AMC, Madison Square Entertainment, Pershing Square Capital Management, Simon Property Group, Dropbox, Meta, Trip Advisor and Roblox.
What if final action on any tax legislation would be contingent upon the Maryland comptroller providing legislators a report with details on the regulations and compliance standards for any new taxes, tax increases, new fees and fee increases?
That would help avoid the consequences of accepting the thinking of former U. S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi: "We have to pass the bill so you can find out what's in it."
What if this new IT service sales tax, coupled with legislative leaders rejecting Gov. Moore's proposal to reduce the corporate net income tax, derails Moore's goal to reverse Maryland's sluggish economic growth by reducing tax and regulatory burdens on businesses?
Going forward, Maryland is best served when every policy decision maker in Annapolis has a commitment and an opportunity to consider what-if questions which in turn helps ensure no final decisions are made using a deeply flawed "ready-aim-fire" approach. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a new state business tax, budget implications, and impacts on companies, which aligns directly with economic and business issues.

title: 'Devastating': Small businesses sue Trump over tariffs
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
'Devastating': Small businesses sue Trump over tariffs

 April 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: News 
 
 1058
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A group of small businesses — including a wine and sake importer, industrial manufacturer and fishing gear and tackle e-commerce firm — are suing President Donald Trump over his tariffs, challenging his use of an emergency law to impose taxes on imports.Texas-based Liberty Justice Center filed a federal lawsuit in the U.S. Court of International Trade on Monday on behalf of five small businesses impacted by Trump's "Liberation Day" and other tariffs.
The lawsuit challenges Trump's authority to invoke tariffs under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA).
Trump is the first U.S. president to invoke tariffs under the 1977 emergency powers law.
The lawsuit argues Trump lacks the authority to issue his across-the-board, worldwide tariffs without approval by Congress.
Trump has cited flows of fentanyl (an illegal synthetic opioid) into the U.S. for imposing 20% tariffs against China and threatening Canada and Mexico with 25% levies.
Trump cited trade deficits for his "Liberation Day" country-by-country tariffs. The tariffs were originally as high as 49% but have been reduced to 10% during a 90-day pause instituted by Trump after worries about financial markets.
'NO ONE PERSON'
The Liberty Justice Center argues longstanding trade deficits don't constitute an emergency and some of the countries in Trump's tariffs don't even have trade surpluses with the U.S.
"IEEPA does not authorize the President to impose across-the-board tariffs—it does not even authorize tariffs at all; and even if the IEEPA did extend such power to the President, that would be an unconstitutional delegation of Congress's power to impose tariffs," the Texas group said in a statement.
"No one person should have the power to impose taxes that have such vast global economic consequences," said Jeffrey Schwab, senior counsel at the Liberty Justice Center. "The Constitution gives the power to set tax rates—including tariffs—to Congress, not the President."
Trump is imposing a 145% tariff on China (with current exemptions for smartphones, computers and other electronics and technology components). There are also 25% U.S. tariffs on imported cars, auto parts, aluminum and steel imposed under separate trade protocols.
"If starting the biggest trade war since the Great Depression based on a law that doesn't even mention tariffs is not an unconstitutional usurpation of legislative power, I don't know what is," said Ilya Somin, co-counsel a law professor, at George Mason University.
China has imposed 125% tariffs on U.S. goods in response to the Trump import taxes.
The White House pushed back against the lawsuit.
"Never Trumpers will always oppose him, but President Trump is standing up for Main Street by putting an end to our trading partners—especially China—exploiting the U.S. His plan levels the playing field for businesses and workers to address our country's national emergency of chronic trade deficits," said White House spokesman Harrison Fields.
'TARIFF CHAOS'
The small business owners who are part of the suit say the tariffs are raising costs and hurting their operations.
"This is devastating to our ability to operate and support the farmers and producers we work with around the world," Victor Owen Schwartz, owner of VOS Selections, which imports wines, spirits and sakes.
Trump previously threatened 200% tariffs on European wine and liquor imports but has not followed through on that.
Conventionally, U.S. administrations have gone through more lengthy trade regimens, that require additional approvals, to institute tariffs.
Dan Pastore, president and co-founder of FishUSA Inc., a Pennsylvania-based e-commerce firm specializing in fishing tackle and gear, said his company sources its products from markets such as South Korea, Kenya, China and Canada and has had to hold up production flows because of the tariffs and their uncertainty.
"Instead of focusing on growing our business, creating more jobs in our region, and developing new products that our customers want, we are spending countless hours trying to navigate the tariff chaos that the President is causing for us and all our vendors," said Dan Pastore, President and co-founder of FishUSA. "It takes years working with factories to design and build our products, and we cannot just shift that business to the U.S. without starting the whole process over again."
Other plaintiffs include Utah-based Genova Pipe which makes piping and relies on Asian resin imports.
"With limited domestic sources, we rely on imports to meet our production needs. The newly imposed tariffs are increasing our raw material costs and hindering our ability to compete in the export market," said Andrew Reese, president of Genova Pipe, which also has manufacturing plants in Washington, Michigan and other U.S. states.
Earlier this month, the New Civil Liberties Alliance also sued the Trump administration over the tariffs on behalf of a Florida business owner also challenging the use of presidential emergency powers.
'MAIN STREET, NOT WALL STREET'
Trump and his economic advisors argue the tariffs will settle longstanding trade inequities and bring manufacturing to the U.S.
The White House said in a tariffs announcement that current trade inequities have "undermined critical supply chains; and rendered our defense-industrial base dependent on foreign adversaries."
The tariffs fight is also pitting Trump's push for continued American hegemony over the international economy versus a more globalist system with multinational supply chains and the ever-increasing economic importance of China.
"I'm proud to be the President for the workers, not the outsourcers; the President who stands up for main street, not Wall Street; who protects the middle class, not the political class; and who defends America, not trade cheaters all over the globe," Trump said earlier this month defending his tariffs regime.
The United Auto Workers union backs Trump's auto manufacturing tariffs hoping they will boost domestic productions.
The pro-Trump America First Policy Institute also backs the tariffs.
"President Trump made a clear and strong statement on 'Liberation Day': countries will no longer take advantage of the American market with unfair trade practices that have hollowed out our manufacturing base, depressed wages, and threatened our national security," said Robert Lighthizer, chair of AFP's Center for American Trade.
'DIFFICULT TO CHALLENGE'
The U.S. Constitution gives Congress the power over tariffs and taxes. But the legislative branch has increasingly deferred to the executive branch over trade policies.
There are efforts by Trump critics in Congress to take tariffs back. Trump has promised to veto a bill if it passes.
Some legal analysts agree with the challenges. Others see the court deferring to executive power related to the emergency powers law.
"It would appear that the power the president utilized to impose tariffs under IEEPA is very nearly absolute and difficult to challenge," said Achyuth Anil, an international trade policy researcher with the University of Sussex in Britain. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a lawsuit by small businesses against presidential tariff actions, discussing trade policy, economic impacts, and legal challenges—core aspects of business and economic news.

title: Rock Hall’s Bun Run raises $6,000 for rescue rabbits
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Rock Hall’s Bun Run raises $6,000 for rescue rabbits

 April 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: News 
 
 350
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROCK HALL — The Eastern Shore Rabbit Rescue and Education Center hosted its fifth annual Bun Run on Saturday, April 19, raising both funds and awareness for abandoned pet rabbits.The event, held in Rock Hall for the first time, drew 56 in-person participants and nine virtual registrants, raising approximately $6,000 to support the nonprofit's mission.
The 5K kicked off at 10 a.m. with participants taking a scenic route that included views of the Chesapeake Bay, Swan Creek and the harbor. Participants could walk or run at their own pace, and medals were awarded to the top finishers in four categories: adult male, adult female, youth male, and youth female. Each category winner received a free entry to the Savage Race obstacle course in Kennedyville.
The medalists included:
Youth female first place: Phoebe Fritz of Chestertown (fifth overall).Female adult first place: Margaret Randolph of Millington (fourth overall).Youth male first place: Jonathan Smith of Berlin (first overall).Adult male first place: Chris Blanchard of Rock Hall (second overall).
Rescue President Cora Dickson, who also participated, thanked the community for its support and shared in welcoming remarks from Rock Hall Mayor James Cook.
The Bun Run raised awareness about the large number of rabbits abandoned after being purchased on impulse during the Easter holiday. The event is part of the organization's ongoing efforts to highlight the importance of long-term commitment and specialized care for rabbits.
The Eastern Shore Rabbit Rescue and Education Center, established in 2014, has placed nearly 500 rabbits in new homes, and the Bun Run is an essential fundraising effort for the organization, which spends most of its funds on veterinary expenses, including spaying, neutering, and vaccinations.
This year's event also featured fundraising competitions. The top fundraising team in the business category was Brampton 1860 of Chestertown, which raised $500, and the top individual fundraisers, each with $300, were Cora Dickson and William Fielder.
The Bun Run, initially organized as a virtual event in 2021 during the COVID-19 pandemic, has continued to grow, with in-person events in Salisbury and now Rock Hall.
More information about the Bun Run and how to support the rescue's efforts is available at esrrec.org/bun-run. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a fundraising run organized by a nonprofit rescue and education center, highlighting money raised, fundraising categories, and financial support for veterinary care, which aligns most closely with Business/Economy.

title: Denton becomes first American Discovery Trail Town, hopes to draw tourists
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Denton becomes first American Discovery Trail Town, hopes to draw tourists

 April 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 627
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The American Discovery Trail has made a landmark of Denton.The town has been designated as the first town in the American Discovery Trail, a coast-to-coast path across the USA connecting people with rural and urban areas, wilderness, desert, mountains and forests.
"I think the American Discovery Trail is unique. It's amazing," Peter Schoettle, American Discovery Trail secretary, said. "The United States, we're blessed with a number of phenomenal outdoor trails. The American Discovery Trail is unique in that it's from coast to coast ,from the Atlantic to the Pacific. No other trail does that."
In the beginning of April, Denton held a ceremony to announce the trail town designation at the town's welcome center.
The American Trail Society came up with the idea for the program to allow towns to become American Trail Discovery towns.
"We started this program of saying, 'let's give more recognition to some neat little towns along the way,'" Schoettle said. "This would benefit the towns, and it would benefit the trail, and so we announced this program of becoming a trail town."
While the process of being claimed as a trail town was not easy, Denton worked hard to get it done.
The first step Denton completed was forming a committee dedicated to the trail.
"Originally, we produced a proclamation a couple years ago, and I think as a staff and as a council, I think we thought that's all we had to do," said Scott Getchell, town administrator. "But they came back a couple years ago and said they that we needed to adopt a resolution stating that we are a trail town."
After adopting a resolution, the town also needed to complete a memorandum of understanding and an application to be approved as an official trail town.
"When they complete those steps, we give them the award, or the title of American Discovery Trail Town," Schoettle said. "And Denton is the very first in the whole country, and so that's amazing. I mean that's unique. Being first, it's like winning a gold medal in the Olympics."
One of the main reasons the program was started is to highlight smaller towns and bring tourism to those areas.
"I think it's fabulous," Schoettle said. It's a win-win situation. I really hope it helps put Denton on the map. They're a great town, and when hikers plan on doing the Discovery Trail, they will say, 'Well, wait a minute, I should plan to stay overnight in Denton.'
"They will use their restaurants, use their hotels or motels, and give them a little economic boost and more publicity. So, I hope they get a lot more visitors."
Denton believes the exposure from the American Discovery Trail will help local businesses.
"Long term, I think it's great," Getchell said. "It's going to take a little while to take off I'm sure, but I think long term, were going to be known around the country as being a trail town. People that do a lot of hiking and things like that, they're going to be mapping our town as a place, as a resource on their journey... We spoke to different businesses and they're put up stickers on the doors so somebody walking through here knows that that's a trail town business."
While the American Trail Society created the program for towns, Schoettle believes Denton deserves all the credit for its initiative to get everything in the application process done.
"I think the town deserves a lot of credit," Schoettle said. "You always need volunteers to do these things. Scott Getchell, the town administrator was a key player. Abby McNinch, the mayor, and the town council, they passed that resolution more than a year ago. That was a big step forward that showed this town really wants to get known and supports the trail, they deserve all the credit." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on Denton's designation as an American Discovery Trail Town and the expected tourism-driven economic boost, highlighting business benefits and local development.

title: False bravado on tariffs threatens Talbot County
author: JIM BRUCE
content:
False bravado on tariffs threatens Talbot County

 April 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JIM BRUCE | Section: Columns 
 
 422
 Words 

 Read News Document

 President Trump's abrupt announcement of tariffs of 145% on Chinese imports provoked them to impose retaliatory tariffs of 125% on U.S. goods exported to China.This jeopardizes our $300 million in exports to China from Maryland's 1st Congressional District, including from all of Talbot County and the rest of the Eastern Shore.
China is hardly blameless on tariffs, but the tragedy for our farmers and businessmen is that our president and our congressman brought on themselves this latest threat to the future exports of Talbot County and the Eastern Shore. Worse, Trump's foolish bravado on tariffs is turning to desperation.
Recall that just after President Trump levied a massive 104% import tariff on Chinese goods, he bragged on April 9, at a mega-fundraiser, "These countries are calling us up, kissing my ass to negotiate deals on tariffs. They are dying to make a deal… [saying], Please, Sir, make a deal. I'll do anything, Sir."
Trump thus portrayed initiating a call to the U.S. to negotiate tariffs as a demeaning, obscene act by our trading partner. This mocking and senseless incivility to all our trading partners, including China, explains why China's commerce ministry said on the next day that China is open to dialogue with the U.S. on tariffs, but it must be based on "mutual respect." Doubling down on the insult, Trump then insisted that the Chinese president must call first for negotiations to begin.
You need not be an expert in tariffs to know that the importance of respect — saving face — is deeply embedded in Chinese culture. Any real U.S. negotiator on any subject would know this. It further confirms that Trump hatched his chaotic and amateurish tariff plan on the fly without careful planning.
China has called, not to urge the U.S. to negotiate the tariffs, but for the U.S to capitulate and "completely cancel" Trump's reciprocal tariffs. While Trump says that President Xi has called him and trade negotiations with the Chinese are underway, China denies it, calling it "fake news."
Trump is learning just how dependent our economy is on trade with China for, to name a few, sales of Boeing jets and rare earth metals for our high-tech industries.
What's at stake for Talbot County is no small matter. In 2022, our farmers and businesses in Maryland's 1st Congressional District exported over $300 million in goods and services to China. China's retaliatory tariffs of 125% now imperil our exports. Yet our Congressman Andy Harris simply endorses Trump's turbulent tariffs, despite the threat to agriculture, e.g., soybeans, and other businesses in his district. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the economic impact of tariffs on Talbot County's exports, highlighting effects on local businesses and farmers, which aligns most closely with Business/Economy, with Agriculture as a secondary focus.

title: Things to remember if buying or selling this spring
author: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS
content:
Things to remember if buying or selling this spring

 May 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS | Section: Real Estate 
 
 524
 Words 

 Read News Document

 If someone is buying or selling this Spring, they may have noticed a few new ways of doing things since the last time they went through this process, noted Michelle Abplanalp, president of Mid-Shore Board of Realtors.There are several real estate changes that went into effect in August related to showing homes and compensation.
For buyers, a written buyer agreement is now required. Buyers and their Realtors will need to reach an agreement regarding how the agent will be paid for their services and put it in writing before seeing a home. "However, don't get hung up on signing this agreement," Abplanalp said. "This agreement can be specific. It can be to see one specific home, it can be for one day or one week, whatever you negotiate."
Before signing this agreement, buyers should ensure it reflects the terms they have negotiated with their Realtor and that they understand exactly what services will be provided and how much these services will cost, the Board of Realtors said.
The buyer agreement must include four items:
A specific and clear disclosure of the amount or rate of compensation the agent will receive or how this amount will be determined must be stated.
The compensation rate must be objective and stated as an amount, a flat fee, a percentage, or an hourly rate. The compensation cannot be open-ended.
The agreement prohibits the Realtor from receiving compensation for services from any source that exceeds the amount or rate agreed to by the buyer.
The agreement must note that the Realtor fees and commissions are fully negotiable and not set by law.
These written agreements apply to both in-person and live virtual home tours but do not apply to open houses or inquiries about services. The home seller may agree to offer compensation to their Realtor, or the seller can offer to assist with closing costs or home inspections.
For home sellers, the offers of compensation (when a seller or a seller's agent shares compensation with a buyer's agent) cannot be shared on Multiple Listing Services. MLSs are local marketplaces used by both buyer and seller agents to share information about homes for sale. Offers of compensation are still an option but are now communicated off the MLS should a home seller choose to pay the buyer's agent fee.
Sellers may consider doing this as a way of marketing their home or making their listing more attractive to buyers.
Per Abplanalp, whether buying or selling, the Realtors compensation or fees remain fully negotiable and are not set by law. Realtors have agreed to abide by the Realtor Code of Ethics and to provide clear and transparent discussions with their clients about compensation.
"What's important to know is these practice changes provide consumers on both sides of a residential transaction with additional choice and transparency," Abplanalp said. "It helps to have this discussion upfront so there are no misunderstandings. I have found that my clients appreciate knowing what I will do for them, what services I provide, and at what cost."
The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors mission is to advocate for its members and the public to preserve the right to own, transfer and utilize real property. For more information, visit midshoreboardofrealtors.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses recent changes in real‑estate transaction practices, buyer agreements, and realtor compensation, which are primarily economic and business matters rather than sports, health, or other categories.

title: Easton named host of second ever Maryland Main Street Conference
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton named host of second ever Maryland Main Street Conference

 May 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 301
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Downtown Easton will welcome hundreds of local and state leaders this October for the state's second ever Maryland Main Street Conference.The Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development, and its Secretary Jake Day, announced Easton as the host site during Day's tour of the town Wednesday.
The conference aims to bring stakeholders and local leaders together to network and discuss improvement efforts for Maryland's historic and downtown streets and neighborhoods.
This year's conference is slated for Oct. 7 and 8.
Easton Economic Development Corporation Executive Director Holly DeKarske said in a press release that the town is "honored" to host.
"Conferences like this play a crucial role in the ongoing success of the Main Street initiative," DeKarske said. "It's essential for us to celebrate our victories while also sharing our challenges, as this helps us learn from one another. Together, we can foster growth and nurture the next generation of Main Street leaders, paving the way for vibrant downtowns and thriving communities."
DeKarske said at a town meeting in March that the town sent a request for proposal to the state in hopes of being chosen as the conference's host.
"You need to make sure you have enough hotel rooms and places for them to eat because they have you go back out to town over those two days," DeKarske said in March. " ... It's a really good opportunity for us."
In 2024, Frederick hosted the inaugural Maryland Main Street Conference, which was a one-day event attended by more than 400 people.
Day said in a press release the conference is an opportunity for economic developers to learn how best to invest in Maryland's historic centers.
"The Town of Easton is a prime example of the payoff of that investment, and I'm so excited to recognize them as the host of this year's conference," Day stated. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a town hosting a state‑level conference focused on downtown revitalization and economic development, highlighting the role of local leaders and the economic impact on the community, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.

Townhomes go up at Lakeside at Trappe
