title: 'Canaries in coal mine' are chirping loudly
author: DAVID REEL
content:
'Canaries in coal mine' are chirping loudly

 May 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 833
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For almost a century, between the late 1890s until 1986, coal miners relied on canary birds rather than fellow miners to detect increasing levels of colorless, odorless carbon monoxide and other toxic gases in the mines that could sicken or even kill humans.While mechanical sensors have long since replaced canaries in mines, the term "canaries in the coal mine" is still a metaphor for an early warning system to alert people of impending negative, even catastrophic outcomes, if they do not make necessary and timely changes.
Recent news reports on three "canaries in the coal mine" scenarios that merit serious consideration by Gov. Moore and the leadership of the General Assembly.
The first are reports published in Maryland Matters that recent decisions on the state budget made by a majority in the General Assembly and by Gov. Moore have not gone unnoticed by three major public finance credit rating agencies — Fitch, Moody's and S&P Global Rating.
In the world of government finance, the ratings from these firms are of paramount importance.
They determine the interest rates on bonds issued by states to fund budgets in addition to revenue received from taxes and related revenue sources. The higher the states bond rating, the lower the interest rate on bond repayments.
While these bond agencies reaffirmed the currently in place highest credit rating for Maryland, AAA, two did so with concerns.
Moody's downgraded the state's fiscal outlook from stable to "negative," citing looming structural deficits driven by state funding for the Blueprint for Maryland's Future also known as the Kirwan Plan.
In its report, Moody's wrote, "The negative outlook incorporates difficulties Maryland will face to achieve balanced financial operations in coming years without sacrificing service delivery goals or adding to the weight of the state government's burden on individual and corporate taxpayers."
This is the first time since 2011 that Moody's has issued a negative outlook for Maryland.
Their report notes, "The outlook revision was driven by expected structural imbalances and planned depletion of General Fund surplus and budgetary reserves by about 60% from fiscal 2023 through fiscal 2025, which threatens to undermine performance relative to peers."
In their report, S&P Global Ratings, expressed concerns about deficits and costly programs. Those concerns led them to grade Maryland nearly in the middle of its rating system — a grade that would typically equate to a credit rating just below AAA. But the agency gave the state the benefit of the doubt citing its history of fiscal management.
The second "canary in the coal mine" are reports from the General Assembly's nonpartisan legislative budget analysts. They are projecting that by next year, the state's projected structural budget deficit — the gap between projected expenses and expected revenues — will grow to $1 billion. In fiscal 2027, the last year of Moore's term, it grows to $1.3 billion. A year later, it more than doubles to $3 billion.
The third "canary in the coal mine" are recurring reports from Delaware about businesses moving or planning to move their business incorporation domicile from Delaware.
The latest to do so is Affirm Holdings Inc., a publicly held American technology firm that handles financial services for merchants and shoppers. Affirm is one of at least 20 major companies citing a hostile Delaware business environment as the reason for their decisions.
Affirm joins Facebook parent company Meta, Walmart, Tripadvisor, The Trade Desk and Roblox.
In the face of all this news, one has to question the impact of a recent compromise reached by the leadership of the Maryland General Assembly and Gov. Moore on a final state budget and state tax package.
That compromise did not include a proposed reduction in the corporate net income tax but did include a new 3.5 % sales tax on information technology service providers.
A spokesperson for Gov. Moore has said the governor is still optimistic going forward, saying the governor "remains confident" in the state's fiscal position following the news on the three credit ratings. He also said the governor will work with lawmakers on "long-term structural solutions" that balance revenues with priorities.
State Senate Budget and Taxation Chair Guy Guzzone is also optimistic. He was quoted in a Maryland Matters article, "I know we can figure it out, and we will figure it out. Whatever the circumstances, whatever the economy gives us, in a broad sense, we'll use our tools, and we'll be thoughtful, and we'll come up with, I believe, good solutions."
Time will tell if the current news from Delaware projected deficits and credit rating concerns will be included in future dialogue and deliberations on state spending and state revenues which in turn will help ensure fully informed decisions will be made on future state budget decisions in Annapolis.
We are likely to know very soon.
The final approved state budget bill requires a special legislative session later this year to address unexpected impacts in Maryland on more reductions in federal government spending.
If and when that occurs, I suggest Marylanders deserve thoughtful consideration of the current canaries in the coal mine as well as unexpected others yet to be made known. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Maryland's state budget, credit rating concerns, structural deficits, and corporate tax policy—issues centered on fiscal health and economic conditions, which align most closely with the Business/Economy topic.

title: National small business week slated for May 4 through 10
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
National small business week slated for May 4 through 10

 May 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 369
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — National small businesses week is slated for the first full week in May.May 4 through May 10, the Talbot County Chamber of Commerce encourages all residents to support small businesses in Talbot County.
"Nowadays it's so easy, Amazon, and Instacart and all this stuff in the age of lone click shopping, supporting small business I think is more important than ever," said Amy Krenier, president of Talbot County Chamber of Commerce.
"I think it's an important choice for our residents to make in order to keep our Eastern Shore communities vibrant, thriving. In a small community, business owners aren't just business owners, they're our neighbors," she said.
Talbot County has 1,478 established businesses and 4,537 Non-employer establishments, according to Census data. Non-employer establishments would be considered contractors, freelancers, consultants and entrepreneurs.
According to the U.S. Small Business Administration, a small business determined based on both numbers of employees and the average revenue. Many local businesses fall in this category, local economic authorities said.
"They're community leaders, they're our friends," Krenier said. "You can get things so easily nowadays, shipped right to your door. But, what you can't get is, that feeling you get when you walk into a store and they know your name and they know your order or you see people around you know, the person's your kids soccer coach or lacrosse coach."
Cassandra Vanhooser, the county's director of economic development and tourism, credits county residents for their "great entrepreneurial spirit."
"We have so many great things going on," Vanhooser said. "Small Business Week gives a chance to really celebrate that entrepreneurial spirit and the can-do-it attitude that our businesses have. It's just incredible.
"I think what our small businesses bring to our community, they really formed the foundation of our business community. So it's it's hugely important."
Kreiner and Vanhooser both want residents to remember to support small business not just one week, but every week.
"Supporting small businesses is supporting our community, it's supporting our way of life," Krenier said. "It's what keeps our whole community strong, connected, vibrant and you're strengthening your relationships.Everybody's sad when one of our businesses goes out, well that's because it meant something to people. Even if it wasn't where you shopped, It meant something to us." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on National Small Business Week, promoting local small businesses and economic development, which aligns directly with the Business/Economy topic.

title: 'Beautiful moments deserve beautiful flowers': Three Little Buds Floral blooms
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
'Beautiful moments deserve beautiful flowers': Three Little Buds Floral blooms

 May 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 443
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Believing that "beautiful moments deserve beautiful flowers," Molly Busick, of Church Hill, is the owner and lead designer of downtown Centreville's new florist. Filling Liberty Street with the scent of fresh flowers and cheerful community in time for the season's first First Friday, Three Little Buds Floral held a ribbon cutting ceremony May 2.After 13 years as a registered nurse, Busick took a leap to follow her passion for design and into an entirely new field and Three Little Buds started in 2022 as a full-service floral design studio focused on weddings and events.
With her background in nursing and healthcare management, Busick said connection and caring for others has always been at the forefront of her heart, and combining that with a love of design, Three Little Buds was born.
"For as long as I can remember, I've been drawn to design, the beauty in details, the power of a well-crafted space, and the emotions it evokes when it all comes together," she said.
As a family affair, Three Little Buds' namesake comes from the family's three girls, and Busick's husband Craig serves as the right-hand man, she said.
Inspired by the natural beauty of flowers, a love for people, and the joy of being part of life's biggest moments, the foundation of Three Little Buds is "rooted" in creativity and precision, ensuring that each piece is a reflection of an individual's unique vision.
"It's been both a challenge and a joy, and one of the greatest gifts has been showing our three daughters that it's never too late to chase your dreams," Busick said.
Three Little Buds is proud to source seasonal blooms from local flower farms whenever possible, while also working with wholesaler Delaware Valley to bring in unique flowers from around the world, she said.
Owning a business is not always a bed of roses, but putting the "rose" in Rosie the Riveter, Busick is blazing a path forward for women entrepreneurs.
"This industry is tough. It takes grit, grace, and a whole lot of hustle. But I wouldn't trade it for anything. I'm beyond grateful to be here, building something beautiful, one little bud at a time," she said.
The florist shop is designed as a cozy place to feel at home and includes a flower bar where customers can create their own bouquets as well as various apparel and gifts, according to Busick.
"Whether it's a wedding, birthday, celebration, or farewell, flowers mark meaningful moments in life and I feel honored to play a small role in helping people express love, joy, and remembrance through our designs," she said.
Three Little Buds Floral is located at 100 N. Liberty Street. More information can be found at threelittlebudsfloral.com 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article profiles the opening and operation of a new florist shop, focusing on the owner’s entrepreneurial journey, business model, and local economic impact, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Shop ‘till you drop: Could Trump upend, reset the age of the insatiable American consumer?
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
Shop ‘till you drop: Could Trump upend, reset the age of the insatiable American consumer?

 May 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: Business 
 
 1083
 Words 

 Read News Document

 No one spends like Americans.Could U.S. President Donald Trump change that with his tariffs regime?
By leaps and bounds, the U.S. is by far the world's largest consumer market totaling $19 trillion annually, according to federal data.
America has 4% of the world's population but more than 31% of consumer spending, according to the World Bank. Consumers account for two-thirds of the behemoth U.S. economy.
Trump is an unlikely messenger for a pullback on Americans' vociferous consumer appetites.
Trump has long been a standard bearer for American capitalism; marketing and hawking everything from Bibles, watches and vodka to sneakers, ball caps and golf gear to his MAGA aficionados. The Trump Organization's hotels and golf courses depend on tourism and spending by the affluent.
But his tariffs aimed at bringing back manufacturing to post World War II levels in the U.S. and to 'Buy American' could also raise prices and reduce supplies of globally sourced consumer goods such as toys, clothing, footwear and jewelry.
Trump has quipped that Americans might not miss some imported items, especially from China which currently sees a 145% tariff from Trump on most goods.
"You know, somebody said, 'Oh, the shelves are going to be open,'" Trump said, from the White House last month. "Well, maybe the children will have two dolls instead of 30 dolls. So maybe the two dolls will cost a couple bucks more than they would normally."
Trump followed that up during an NBC interview alluding to American consumerism.
"I'm just saying they don't need to have 30 dolls. They can have three. They don't need to have 250 pencils. They can have five," Trump said.
A pullback of U.S. consumer spending would be a sea change for hosts of industries and supply chains.
The U.S. accounts for 3% of the world's kids.
But America buys 40% of the world's toys (most of which are manufactured in China).
That's just the tip of America's ravenous consumer appetite.
Pick a consumer category — cars, boats, cosmetics, wine, fragrances — and the U.S. is likely the largest market globally.
The next closest overall consumer market is China at $7 trillion despite having more than four times the population as the U.S.
American consumer spending has been insatiable and almost limitless compared to the rest of the world.
Trump's tariffs regime — and current trade war with China — has already dampened consumer confidence.
The Conference Board and University of Michigan have both reported significant dips on consumer sentiment since Trump took office and announced his tariffs aimed at bolstering U.S. manufacturing and settling past inequitable trade scores.
The former's consumer gauge shows expectations at a 13-year low.
"Consumer confidence has deteriorated in the early months of 2025," said Piyush Puri, founding partner of Mercurius Media Capital (MMC), a California-based consulting firm.
Puri said there is "pervasive pessimism" about jobs, income and financial situation in sentiment surveys. "At the same time household debt is at record highs," Puri said.
The New York Federal Reserve Bank reports American household debt sits at a record $18 trillion. That is up from $14 trillion at the end of 2019 before the COVID-19 pandemic and its ensuing inflation wave.
Puri said he can see consumers putting off bigger purchases — such as cars which face 25% levies for imported vehicles and auto parts — and turn to bargain brands for everyday items.
Deidre Popovich, a business professor at Texas Tech University, also sees consumers bargain hunting and comparing prices.
But she doesn't foresee a marked, societal pullback from American consumerism.
"It's tempting to think that tariffs will 'reset' American overconsumption but behaviorally, that's unlikely. U.S. consumer culture is built on habit loops, emotional spending, and identity-driven purchases," Popovich said. "Tariffs may change what people buy, or where they shop, but the general desire to consume isn't going anywhere."
She said consumers at large are displaying "financial dissonance."
"This behavior reflects deeply ingrained consumption habits along with a psychological response to stress," she said, noting continued U.S. consumer spending despite record debt loads and economic skepticism before and after Trump's election. "More specifically, when people feel anxious or uncertain, spending can become a way to assert control or maintain a sense of normalcy."
But others see potential for "new normals" with shopping, especially from more cash-strapped households, as Trump persists with his tariffs and other countries respond with their own levies.
Some Americans could also potentially awaken to spending habits and how many material things they actually need.
George Carrillo, CEO of the Hispanic Construction Council advocacy group, said if tariffs result in higher prices, slower growth or both (i.e. stagflations) that could "influence more conscious consumption habits, as shoppers weigh the necessity of every purchase."
"While America's role as a global consumer powerhouse isn't disappearing overnight, tariffs and mounting financial strain are undoubtedly nudging long-standing behaviors in a new direction," he said.
Consumers, especially working class and middle income households are already stretched with prices up 24% overall since February 2020 and before the COVID-19 pandemic and its ensuing inflation wave.
Consumer watchdog Michael Podolsky said American shoppers have already been frustrated by price hikes following Trump's tariffs announcement and the "lack of transparency" regarding pricing in general.
"Skepticism toward brands is growing among shoppers, with some believing companies are using price hikes as an opportunity rather than a necessity," said Podolsky, CEO and co-founder of PissedConsumer.com.
Trump personally called Amazon chairman Jeff Bezos last month to complain about a report the e-commerce giant could list tariff costs next to some prices. Amazon said the disclosure idea was just being considered and would not come to fruition.
"The instances with price increases due to tariffs may soon lead to heightened public frustration as well as continue reshaping purchasing habits, with more consumers refusing the products affected by tariffs," Podolsky said. "Some shoppers report that they have already delayed purchases or canceled services altogether."
Trump was elected, in part, due to voters' frustrations with high, post-pandemic prices during the Biden administration.
Trump contends inflation has cooled, including with gas prices averaging $3.15 per gallon (down 13% from a year ago), according to AAA.
But Puri said if product categories and store shelves have fewer options, that will allow the remaining product makers, including from the U.S., to potentially raise prices with less competition.
Carrillo said Trump's trade pushes have thrown consumers and small businesses for a loop.
"The president initially promised relief from rising costs, but tariffs have taken us on a roller-coaster ride, forcing Americans to adjust to the reality of higher prices while being asked to 'stay patient,'" Carrillo said. "Adding to the frustration, the administration has shown resistance to companies like Amazon making the impacts of tariffs more transparent to consumers." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the impact of Trump’s tariff policies on American consumer spending, pricing, and the broader economy, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Federal lawsuit fights striped bass restrictions
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Federal lawsuit fights striped bass restrictions

 May 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 623
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROCK HALL — Striped bass season begins on the Chesapeake Bay May 16 amid mounting tensions between fishing industry groups and regulatory agencies.A federal lawsuit has been filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia by fishing industry organizations bordering the Atlantic Ocean and its inland waterways.
Adding to the regulatory conflict, an executive order from President Donald Trump aiming to restore local fisheries' freedoms could potentially overturn the Fisheries Commission's previous regulations.
Previous lawsuits, persisting problems
Captain Rob Newberry, chair of Delmarva Fisheries Association, and Brian Hardman, chair of the Maryland Charter Boats Association, are leading the charge against current Maryland state regulations, particularly those concerning striped bass.
In March, their previous lawsuit against the Fisheries Commission reached the Supreme Court, which denied a hearing of the case.
"The fight is far from over," Newberry said. He claims the commission and state agencies are shortening the fishing season, reducing the size of removable fish, lowering commercial quotas and limiting recreational fishers on charter boats to one fish per day.
The new federal lawsuit expands beyond state agencies to include the U.S. Department of the Interior, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, U.S. Department of Commerce, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission and several environmental groups and natural resource agencies along the coast.
The suit targets agencies including the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission, which coordinates conservation and management of coastal fish species in 15 states along the Atlantic.
In a press release, Newberry expressed frustrations shared by many in the fishing industry. "For too long, our industry has allowed this obscure Interstate Compact (ASMFC) founded in 1942 to help furnish the food supply behind the war effort, to transform itself into a power-hungry partnership with massive support from federal government agencies which apparently think that fish are more important than people," he said.
The coalition of plaintiffs includes the Delmarva Fisheries Association.
Executive Order
On April 17, Trump signed an executive order titled "Restoring American Seafood Competitiveness," vowing to end the monopoly of foreign seafood exports and make the U.S. the world's dominant seafood producer. The order also calls for investigation of the same policy makers that Newberry's coalition is suing.
Regulatory agencies maintain that restrictions are not intended to harm commercial fisheries but to preserve them.
At numerous conferences, including the most recent, these agencies cited insufficient Atlantic striped bass populations based on Marine Recreational Information Program data from computer models. Their restrictions, they say, aim to address this shortage.
Many in the fishing industry dispute these claims. Newberry said striped bass stock across the entire Mid-Atlantic region "has never been more plentiful."
Captain Willy Hatch, president of the Cape Cod Charter Boat Association, questioned the scientific methods used to determine stock shortages.
"One major flaw in the claimed science behind this regulation is the NOAA's Marine Recreational Information program being used to estimate recreational and for-hire catch data, which has been found to be grossly overestimating recreational catch," Hatch said.
Economic impactMarc Berger, head of the East Coast Fishing Coalition, warned about broader economic impacts of fishing regulations.
"These actions threaten not only the present viability of our businesses but also the long-term sustainability of the for-hire sector of the fishing industry," Berger said. "The ramifications extend beyond our industry, impacting hotels, restaurants, tackle shops and other merchants relying on our operations to sustain their livelihoods."
North Carolina Watermen United expressed similar sentiments: "We stand in solidarity with our fellow watermen in our opposition to the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission."
The group noted fishermen are struggling within the bounds of regulations on several species, including southern flounder, red drum, striped mullet and spotted trout.
"The socio-economic hardships put on not only our captains, crew, and families but our entire coastal communities when agencies continue to handcuff these watermen is immeasurable," the organization stated. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a federal lawsuit by fishing industry groups over striped bass regulations, emphasizing economic impacts on the fishing sector, related businesses, and regional economies, making Business/Economy the most fitting category.

title: Chestertown chocolate shop continues under new owner
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Chestertown chocolate shop continues under new owner

 May 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 321
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A cherished staple of the downtown Chestertown landscape, Bespoke Chocolate is beginning a delicious new chapter with the recent sale and transfer of ownership.The cozy, fragrant storefront that has long delighted locals and visitors will keep doing so under new owner, Kurt Douglass, Chestertown resident of almost five years.
Douglass appreciates what the previous owner brought to the establishment and will carry on that tradition of handcrafted treats and heartfelt service.
"We will maintain the same passion for quality and community that helped make the business a local treasure," Douglass remarked.
The continuance of the business is great news for many, he stated. Over the years, the shop has built a loyal following, becoming a must-visit destination during strolls around town and a favorite stop during the holidays, First Fridays, and summer festivals, Douglass mentioned.
News of the sale sparked a wave of support from the community, he said, with customers expressing relief, joy, and excitement and filling social media feeds. He said the shop's inbox was full with congratulations and shared memories.
Douglass appreciates the loyal support. "Customers cherish their signature truffles to seasonal specials, offerings which reflect both craftsmanship and care— earning praise not just for the sweets, but for the welcoming atmosphere. The continued presence of the chocolate shop is a sign that Chestertown's heart beats strong with small-town resilience and sweet traditions."
Douglass will maintain that essence while making a few small changes in the coming months; thoughtful, incremental modifications—guided by customer input and suggestions from the shop's dedicated Chocolatiers Club members.
"These changes aim to enhance, not replace, the magic that has always defined the experience," Douglass said. "In the words of one longtime customer, 'It's not just about chocolate. It's about care, craft, and community.' We're thrilled to see it continue to thrive."
The chocolate shop's story continues—rooted in tradition, inspired by community and ready for what's next.
Stop by to check out what is happening at 207 S Cross St./ website: https://www.bespokechocolate.net/. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the sale and continued operation of a local chocolate shop, focusing on ownership change and business continuity, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Department of Commerce unveils new Montana brand in Miles City
author: Hunter Herbaugh Miles City Star
content:
Department of Commerce unveils new Montana brand in Miles City

 May 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Hunter Herbaugh Miles City Star | Section: News 
 
 700
 Words 

 Read News Document

 While the World Famous Bucking Horse Sale hit full stride in Miles City on Friday, it wasn't the only thing taking off, as the Montana Department of Commerce unveiled a new brand for the state on the first full day of the event. Coming as the first new brand for the state in over a decade, the new look is aimed at embodying the spirit of the state and its people, encapsulating the entirety of Big Sky Country from east to west.The event was held with all the fanfare it could muster, with Miles City and Custer County representatives standing alongside Department of Commerce leadership and Gov. Greg Gianforte, who is swinging through Miles City for his annual trip to the Bucking Horse Sale and his yearly 56 County Tour.
Unveiling the new brand, DOC Chief Marketing Officer Mitch Staley said the launch of this new look is aimed at honoring Montana's character and history, and letting the rest of the world know it as well.
"It's a realignment with what has made Montana what it is with the brand that our state uses to promote the great things, the people and our stories — not only here in Montana, but all across the country and the world," Staley said. "This brand helps to represent us to visitors who come here, it will help us attract new businesses by promoting our economy, and also, it helps promote and uplift the businesses that are here already."
While promoting business is a major aspect of this new look for Montana, a large part of it is also aimed at the people, be those the people currently living in the state or those looking to come in and call it home. Gianforte emphasized this during his comments, saying his hope is that the new brand will get even those who have lived here all their lives to go out and rediscover what makes Montana special.
"For the first time in 16 years, we're re-introducing Montana to the world, and we're doing it by shining a spotlight on the people who make this place so great. Our new brand centers on the stories of real Montanans; of family ranches and veterans, small business owners, families and community leaders. Their voices, their experiences, their Montana."
And of course, there's no other appropriate way to introduce a new Montana brand to the world than with a classic truck. Unveiled during Friday's launch, the new brand was emblazoned on the side of 1968 Chevy C-10 pick-up. The design is inspired by Montana's classic license plate, with a horizontal line in the colors of the setting sun breaking into the silhouette of rugged mountains to one side, representing the western side of the state, transitioning into a flat line that then rises into the visage of hills and cap rocks at the other end, representing the eastern side of the state, all set to a sky blue background.
As Staley describes it, the truck is a billboard on wheels advertising the state.
"This truck will be at all of our booths across the state Through the summer, we'll have several events... It's really a way to get this in front as many Montanans as we can rather than have one billboard, one static ad somewhere," he said.
The new brand also includes a new website aimed at improving the travel experience through Montana for visitors and residents alike, including updated road maps.
Meanwhile, Gianforte described the brand as not only a testament to the state and its people, but also, in his personal opinion, a testament to the dream that Montana represents.
"Montana is recognized globally as America. It really is the heart of America. We have incredible outdoor adventure opportunities, but even more important are the people of Montana; the grit, the independence, the work ethic," he said. "This brand is about telling the story of the people of Montana in a way that not only brings people here to visit, but, maybe, they come here to pursue the American dream."
The new brand, along with the truck, will be hitting the road this summer with a schedule of appearances set to be posted to the Department of Commerce website in the near future, according to Staley. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the Montana Department of Commerce unveiling a new state brand aimed at promoting tourism and attracting new businesses, which is primarily an economic development initiative rather than a purely governmental or public‑notice matter.

title: Markets vote daily on Trump's trade policy
author: RICK SCHIMING
content:
Markets vote daily on Trump's trade policy

 May 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: RICK SCHIMING | Section: Columns 
 
 738
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In a sense, each business day is election day for the U.S. economy. Holders of U.S. stocks, U.S. Treasury bonds and U.S. dollars around the world make their trades and cast their dollar votes based on how they feel about the strength and sanity of US economic policy and the health and stability of American democracy.While widely publicized and widely followed, the U.S. stock market is the narrowest view of the health of the economy, essentially a vote on the future health of about 5,000 corporations that are listed on the major stock exchanges (NYSE and NASDAQ). The average daily dollar trading volume is around $300 billion. A falling stock market indicates that investors believe that profits will decline in the future for these corporations due to falling demand for their products and/or rising costs of production.
Less reported and less well-known, the US Treasury bond market and the foreign exchange currency market provide a more important and meaningful vote on the state of the economy. The dollar votes cast in these markets are huge compared to the stock market. The Treasury securities market has a daily trading volume of nearly $1 trillion while in foreign exchange market, the average trading volume in dollars is over $6 trillion.
Let's first look at the market for U.S. Treasury securities. The 10-year bond has long been the most widely held and safest financial asset worldwide because it has been backed by the absolute guarantee of the U.S. government never to default on this obligation. Typically, in times of economic distress around the world, investors increase their demand for these bonds, which raises their price and lowers their interest rate.
The foreign exchange market is where foreign currencies are traded daily. Investors around the world buy and sell U.S. dollars for their own respective currencies. A rising U.S. dollar internationally means that foreign investors want to hold dollars because of the strength and stability of the economy. A strong dollar reflects the role of the dollar as the central reserve asset and means of payment in the world economy.
In short, when the U.S. is seen as strong economically, U.S. Treasury interest rates fall and the value of the dollar rises. When the U.S. is seen as weak, Treasury interest rates rise and the value of the dollar falls.
What has happened in these markets recently? Investors worldwide are fleeing all U.S. assets (stocks, Treasuries, and the U.S. dollar). This reflects an increasing distrust of our future economic health in the face of chaotic policy choices. Faith and confidence in the U.S. economy is disappearing as tariffs and other poor policy choices by the Trump administration slowly but surely erode international confidence in the United States.
For someone who wants to be seen as a winner, Trump is losing almost every day in the stock, US bond and foreign exchange markets. Trillions of dollar votes by investors around the world are being cast against Trump's stewardship of the economy and his economic policies.
Unfortunately, he isn't the only one who loses. We all do.
Higher interest rates for Treasuries means both costlier interest payments on the national debt leading to fewer federal funds available for other priorities and to bigger federal budget deficits in the future. Higher interest rates on Treasury bonds dictate higher interest rates across the US economy. Anyone paying interest on any debt is hurt by weakness in the US Treasury market.
A weaker US dollar internationally also costs US consumers. A weaker dollar means that it costs us more dollars for us to buy goods and services from overseas. This puts even more inflationary pressure on our economy especially when combined with the inflationary pressure of increased tariffs.
The worst-case scenario of higher and wider tariffs? Falling stock prices, higher bond rates and a weak U.S. dollar could slow economic growth, increase unemployment and raise inflation. In other words, stagflation. The latest GDP figures already show a shrinking economy since Trump took office in January.
These big three financial markets are casting their dollar votes against Trump and his reckless and incoherent stewardship of the economy. When Trump moves to increase tariffs, these markets tank. When he backtracks on his tariff policies, the stock market soars. Doesn't this say volumes about the stupidity of his trade policies?
It is a humiliating defeat for him and a loss for all of us. Unless or until his policies change for the better, the resulting pain to US consumers will continue. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses stock markets, Treasury bonds, foreign exchange, tariffs, and overall economic policy, which directly relates to business and economic matters.

title: Waterfowl Festival concerned about losing funding
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Waterfowl Festival concerned about losing funding

 May 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Business 
 
 583
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — After President Donald Trump proposed eliminating the National Endowment for the Arts, organizations like the Waterfowl Festival began to worry about their future.According to the festival's Executive Director Deena Kilmon, more than just the future of the festival is at stake. Without expected funding, the maintaining the historic armory building, continuing the William A. Perry Scholarship Program, and fundraising for wildlife and habitat conservation are uncertain, Kilmon said.
The festival, one of Talbot County's largest economic drivers, has been in operation since 1971.
"We had independent auditors tell us that about 30,000 people were downtown during the festival last year," Kilmon said. "You have the thousands of community residents that just enjoy all the free stuff, you know, the music and the parties, and then we have about a thousand volunteers that come over, which includes about 200 student volunteers every year."
According to Kilmon, last year's festival filled all the hotels in Talbot County and three surrounding counties. "Every restaurant was full Thursday, Friday, Saturday night. No one had any room anywhere, so we don't know the ultimate economic impact, but we know it's large," she said.
The Waterfowl Festival applied for several grants this year in fear federal and state art funding gets cut.
Those grants include the Maryland Historic Trust Grant to target crucial repairs on the Armory building, fix ADA accessibility issues, and simply maintain the historic building that hosts nonprofit organizations for a small fee and is open to the public at no cost.
Easton Mayor Megan Cook said it's important for the Waterfowl Festival to remain in the town and she would like to keep the organization as the steward to the building.
"It would be great to keep them in the Armory because that building anchors our downtown, and since it is such a community space, it's important to keep it open to the community," Cook said.
"Waterfowl have been the stewards of that building for a number of years, they take great care of it. You know, it would be a tragedy, a true loss for the town if that building went dark," Cook later said.
The Maryland Heritage Areas Authority grant would allow the Waterfowl Festival to re-open the stage and host even more artists and speakers.
"Those are all the things we would love to do if we could bring the building up to modern safety standards," said Kilmon. "But again, that's outside of our mission of supporting conservation and wildlife habitats across the nation. That's what we do for real, but this is just something that we feel like as stewards of the building, it's the right thing to do."
The festival will learn about its state and federally funded grants by the end of the fiscal year in June. In the meantime, Waterfowl Festival staff are preparing to make changes.
Currently, children do not have to pay to attend the festival or participate in many activities like soap carving and the fishing derby. That may change if the grants are not awarded.
The festival has raised over $6 million for conservation and wildlife preservation over the years and supported secondary education for student volunteers known as "duck sitters." Last year, the festival raised $24,000 for scholarships, awarding each student $2,000.
Kilmon said a one-year deficit would not kill the festival, but if it continued, they'd have to take extra measures.
"You know, we'd have to start, I hate the word downsizing, but what I'll say is, making the footprint of the festival smaller, right? And offering less free opportunities for education," Kilmon said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the festival's funding challenges, grant applications, and its role as a major economic driver for the region, making Business/Economy the most fitting category.

title: Maryland's largest coal mine changes hands
author: PAUL KIEFER Capital News Service
content:
Maryland's largest coal mine changes hands

 May 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PAUL KIEFER Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 931
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland's largest active underground coal mine changed hands last month after the mine's previous operator, Canadian firm Corsa Coal, filed for bankruptcy and auctioned assets to pay creditors.The new operator, Pennsylvania-based Rosebud Mining Company, will not inherit the dozens of delinquent fines levied by the federal Mine Safety and Health Administration (MSHA) for safety violations at the Casselman mine in Garrett County, Maryland.
A Western District of Pennsylvania Bankruptcy Court judge approved a $15 million bid from Rosebud to acquire two underground mines in March, though Corsa's creditors delayed finalizing the sale in hopes of attracting a higher bid.
In a declaration filed with the court in January, Corsa President Kevin Harrigan attributed his company's financial troubles in part to an unpredictable market. "Economic uncertainty, inflationary pressures and corresponding monetary policy controls" pushed coal prices below Corsa's mining costs in 2024, Harrigan wrote, straining the company's ability to cover looming debt payments.
Corsa did not respond to a Capital News Service request for comment by press time.
The company issued layoff notices to 93 employees at the Casselman mine on March 13 — a majority of the more than 100 people working at the mine as of 2024, according to MSHA records.
Rosebud hired 50 former Corsa employees after the acquisition, most of whom remain at the Casselman mine.
The mine produced roughly 660,000 tons of coal in 2023 — a relatively small output compared to the largest mines in neighboring Pennsylvania and West Virginia, but more than twice the output of the next-largest mine in Maryland in the same year.
The Casselman mine yields metallurgical coal, used to heat blast furnaces for steel production.
While the market for thermal coal, used to generate electricity, has dwindled in the face of competition from cheap natural gas and renewable energy sources, the metallurgical coal market is relatively insulated from those pressures.
"There is still a very strong need for metallurgical coal," said Allegany Coal & Land Co. President Steve Jenkins, whose western Maryland company leases property to small coal operators.
And although coal is not a renewable resource, Jenkins noted that Maryland's coal seams are far from expended. "It's just a matter of how much is accessible in the regulatory environment," he said.
But like any commodity, the metallurgical coal market experiences price fluctuations, including an ongoing supply imbalance that pushed prices below Corsa's mining costs.
Harrigan's declaration makes no mention of delinquent MSHA fines, and the total amount left unpaid to the agency — just under $25,000 — is relatively minor compared to other obligations, including $21.3 million in debts acquired by purchasing or leasing mining equipment, parts and fuel.
Those unpaid fines stem from a range of safety violations, including several flagged by MSHA as "reasonably likely to result in a serious injury or illness."
In October 2024, for instance, MSHA inspectors issued a $5,000 fine to the Corsa subsidiary operating the Casselman mine for allowing coal dust to accumulate, creating a fire or explosion hazard — one of more than 80 fines issued to the operator for the same violation since 2019, records show.
On the same day, inspectors also fined the company $2,400 for failing to provide adequate firefighting infrastructure for Casselman miners. Both fines remain delinquent, although Corsa paid other fines issued later the same year.
A bankruptcy attorney representing Corsa did not respond to a CNS inquiry about why those delinquent fines were not listed as liabilities in the company's initial bankruptcy filing.
But Wes Addington, executive director of the Appalachian Citizens' Law Center, said MSHA doesn't pursue unpaid fines as aggressively as other federal regulatory agencies. The center is a nonprofit law firm based in Whitesburg, Kentucky, that represents coal miners and their families on black lung and safety cases and advocates on environmental issues related to coal extraction in the region.
"I'm skeptical (about) how much energy the government is going to put into trying to collect those fines," he said, given MSHA's track record of allowing mines to continue operating with thousands of dollars in delinquent safety violation fines.
The change in ownership at the Casselman mine comes as some mine safety advocates like Addington raise alarms about the risks created by an increasingly feeble MSHA.
An analysis of public data published by the Appalachian Citizens' Law Center in March indicates that MSHA has lost roughly half of its coal mine inspection staff in the past decade.
Federal law requires the agency to inspect surface mines at least twice and underground mines at least four times annually.
Tony Oppegard, a former mine inspector who previously served as an adviser to the MSHA administrator under President Bill Clinton, told Capital News Service that he doubts the agency will be held to those standards in the current political climate.
"In years past, if MSHA was having a hard time making their twos and fours, there would generally be an oversight committee in the House and or the Senate who would call them in and want an explanation," he said. "With the current Congress, I don't know if they'd even care."
The Trump administration's decision in March to close dozens of MSHA field offices, including several in Pennsylvania and West Virginia, compounded those concerns.
"Consolidating offices will reduce emergency response efficiency by placing inspectors farther from mining sites, making it more difficult for them to respond quickly in the event of a mine disaster," said Erin Bates, the communications director for the United Mine Workers of America. "With an already limited workforce, stretching inspectors even thinner will reduce oversight effectiveness and compromise miner safety."
Workers at the Casselman mine are not unionized, and Maryland mines are served by an MSHA office in Morgantown, West Virginia that is not slated for closure. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily discusses the sale of a coal mine, bankruptcy, market pressures, and economic implications, which aligns best with Business/Economy, while also touching on safety violations and environmental aspects.

title: Tariff effects not seen in Port of Baltimore yet
author: DARANEE BALACHANDAR Capital News Service
content:
Tariff effects not seen in Port of Baltimore yet

 May 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DARANEE BALACHANDAR Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 648
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BALTIMORE — It is still too early to gauge the impacts of President Donald Trump's widespread tariffs on imported goods on the Port of Baltimore, despite other ports experiencing changes."We expect to see impacts with our container business, especially from China," said Richard Scher, director of communications for the Port Baltimore, in a statement to Capital News Service. "But those impacts will likely not show until June."
Ting Long Ding, operations management and business analytics professor at the Johns Hopkins Carey Business School, told CNS that larger ports, like the Port of Los Angeles and the neighboring Port of Long Beach, would experience a much more significant drop in imports compared to the Port of Baltimore because the general volume of imports at the southern California ports is much greater.
Los Angeles and Long Beach also are geographically closer to China, the second-largest source of U.S. imports, and other Asian and South Pacific nations.
On May 12, the United States and China reached an agreement to lower tariffs. Under the new deal, the United States will reduce tariffs on goods imported from China from 145 percent to 30 percent, while China will lower its tariffs on American imports from 125 percent to 10 percent.
"It is important to note that even with this China agreement, tariffs are much higher overall than they were at the beginning of the year," said John Murphy, senior vice president at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, in a statement issued after the U.S.-China trade talks. Businesses, including small enterprises, are trying to manage with the disruptions and growing costs, Murphy added.
"We continue to urge the Trump Administration to prioritize tariff relief for businesses and families, and to address foreign trade barriers as it negotiates with other countries," Murphy said.
"Ultimately, the impact of tariffs on the Port of Baltimore and all ports will depend on the length of time that the tariffs are implemented in addition to the decisions of shippers to send their products to the U.S.," Scher said.
Last year, the Port of Baltimore was the second-biggest importer of automobiles in the United States. It lost its first place due to the Francis Scott Key Bridge collapse, which paused operations at the port from March to July last year.
Baltimore's port is one of the only ports in the country to have equipment and facilities to handle and store roll-on/roll-off cargo like fully assembled cars, motorcycles and trucks.
The Port of Baltimore also receives other imports like nuclear reactors, boilers, machinery, aluminum, iron and steel, according to U.S. Census data.
Some auto manufacturing customers that ship into U.S. ports, including Baltimore, are holding their vehicles at the port of entry, while others are adding import fees or absorbing the tariffs, Scher said.
Rep. Johnny Olszewski (D-Maryland) told CNS the tariffs are another setback for the Port of Baltimore, which still is recovering from the bridge collapse.
"It's challenge after challenge after challenge, except this one is completely avoidable. There's no reason for the president to need to propose these tariffs," Olszewki said. "There's been no good reason expressed to members of Congress or the American people about what the real purpose of a tariff is."
The congressman said he has not received any complaints or concerns related to the tariffs from individual port workers.
The International Longshoremen's Association, which represents Baltimore's port workers, endorsed Trump in last year's election. ILA President Harold Daggett in January credited Trump with helping the union obtain a new contract with stronger provisions against automation. He called the president "one of the best friends of working men and women in the United States."
The ILA said it had no comment on the tariffs for now.
Ding said the tariffs would impact port workers and truck drivers in the long run.
The Port of Baltimore is an economic engine that would have a direct and indirect impact on all the sectors and workers supporting it, Ding said.
"It's an entire ecosystem," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the impact of federal tariffs on trade volumes at the Port of Baltimore, referencing economic consequences for businesses, imports, and the regional economy, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Gas prices rise nationwide, drops in Maryland
author: GAS BUDDY
content:
Gas prices rise nationwide, drops in Maryland

 May 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GAS BUDDY | Section: State News 
 
 481
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 3.9 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.08 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 4.0 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 45.5 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has increased 2.9 cents in the last week and stands at $3.502 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.69 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.79 per gallon, a difference of $1.10per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has risen 6.1 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.14 per gallon Monday. The national average is up 1.9 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 41.0 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
May 19, 2024: $3.53 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.55 per gallon)May 19, 2023: $3.44 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.52 per gallon)May 19, 2022: $4.59 per gallon (U.S. Average: $4.60 per gallon)May 19, 2021: $3.05 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.04 per gallon)May 19, 2020: $1.95 per gallon (U.S. Average: $1.90 per gallon)May 19, 2019: $2.76 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.84 per gallon)May 19, 2018: $2.91 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.92 per gallon)May 19, 2017: $2.32 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.35 per gallon)May 19, 2016: $2.26 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.27 per gallon)May 19, 2015: $2.66 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.71 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.02 per gallon, down 7.4 cents per gallon from last week's $3.09 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.15 per gallon, up 5.1 cents per gallon from last week's $3.10 per gallon.Hagerstown: $3.24 per gallon, unchanged from last week's $3.23 per gallon.
"Gasoline prices jumped in over three-quarters of U.S. states over the last week, as oil prices surged following former President Trump's decision to reduce tariffs and strike new trade deals — moves that inspired optimism that a major tariff-induced economic slowdown might be avoided," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "In addition to gains in price-cycling markets, rising oil prices — fueled by economic optimism and tightening gasoline inventories — contributed to broader upward pressure on prices. While Americans are still seeing significant savings compared to a year ago, that gap has narrowed as oil prices have rebounded. As we approach Memorial Day, GasBuddy is preparing to release its summer travel survey results and issue a gas price forecast for the season. For now, motorists can expect one of the most affordable summers for hitting the road since the pandemic, with gas prices tracking at some of the lowest inflation-adjusted levels in years." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Moore signs two energy bills, including debated solar legislation
author: Konner Metz
content:
Moore signs two energy bills, including debated solar legislation

 May 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 515
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Gov. Wes Moore (D) signed two prominent energy bills into law on Tuesday, bills largely opposed by Eastern Shore Republicans during this year's Maryland General Assembly.Senate Bills 931 and 937 were part of an expansive energy package lawmakers wrestled with this session. While Moore vetoed the package's third bill, due in part to budgetary reasons, he put pen to paper for the others.
The Renewable Energy Certainty Act, or SB931, aims to increase the state's solar generation by streamlining the regulatory process for solar projects. Specifically, it provides the Maryland Public Service Commission with approving authority for projects under the 2-megawatt threshold.
Tuesday, Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore City) said the legislation creates "a clear path forward for solar and battery storage projects to eliminate local barriers and allow local government to join in community solar programs."
"It is essential that we have more affordable and cleaner, Maryland-made energy," Ferguson said.
But Eastern Shore legislators, as well as county representatives, don't see it the same way.
Republican legislators unsuccessfully pushed for Moore to veto the bill amid concerns it strips away local control over solar project approvals and places too much authority at the hands of the Public Service Commission.
Caroline County Commission President Travis Breeding said it will override the county-instituted 2,000-acre solar cap.
Per the legislation, the Public Service Commission can grant solar project approvals on up to 5% of land designated for agriculture and forests. County leaders say the amount of land prone to solar development could quadruple.
"It's going to change the landscape, it's going to change the look of the county," Breeding said in an interview, citing concerns on food production and agricultural jobs. "It's going to change our economy."
Breeding noted the commissioners are "pursuing solutions at the federal level" in the form of reaching out to Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md.). Breeding hopes there can be federal restrictions on solar project subsidies so developers "cannot offer these lucrative deals to entice landowners."
SENATE BILL 937
The Next Generation Energy Act, or SB937, focuses on ratepayer relief after a winter of skyrocketing energy bills — a trend Ferguson said was a "wake-up call" and not just a "temporary spike."
Ferguson noted $200 million will go toward ratepayer refunds — an average of $80 per household, Ferguson said, split between winter and summer payments.
The bill looks to increase in-state generation by trimming permitting processes as coal and oil plants reach their ends.
"We know that older coal plants and oil plants are being retired based on private action, and we have not built up enough alternative energy to fill it fast enough, and so the General Assembly had to act," Ferguson said.
Del. Chris Adams (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said the bill's framework doesn't do enough to incentivize nuclear energy or in-state generation. Adams and other Republicans have also disagreed with Democrats on the premise that the bill provides necessary relief to ratepayers.
"Maryland is still ... dependent on other states to bring us energy," Adams said in an interview last week. "It's expensive, and that sole political decision is what's creating the ratepayer difficulties that we're experiencing and will experience moving forward." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on state energy legislation, ratepayer refunds, and economic impacts of solar and other energy projects, making Business/Economy the strongest fit, with Environment and Local Government as secondary relevant topics.

title: The Arc Central Chesapeake Region rebrands to Fello
author: Konner Metz
content:
The Arc Central Chesapeake Region rebrands to Fello

 May 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 412
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Arc Central Chesapeake Region announced Wednesday it is rebranding to Fello, a name the organization hopes to build a distinct identity under.As part of the change, Fello will no longer be affiliated with The Arc Maryland or the nonprofit's national arm.
President and CEO Jonathon Rondeau said in an interview Tuesday that the name change aims to reflect the organization's "evolution of growth." Rondeau said the nonprofit is serving people all across Maryland and that the brand shift will best reflect that.
"The idea of Fello is that we are fellow citizens, we're fellow neighbors," Rondeau said. "We connect with each other. … We're about lifting up the communities we're in."
The nonprofit serves people with intellectual and developmental disabilities across the majority of the Eastern Shore and in Anne Arundel County. It was founded in 1961.
In Easton, a number of affordable housing projects had been pursued under The Arc Central Chesapeake Region name, some of which are still in the works. Last year, the organization opened the Port Street Commons, a mixed-use building with nine apartment units and office headquarters.
The Arc Central Chesapeake Region previously had two subsidiaries for housing management and community development: Chesapeake Neighbors and Chesapeake Community Development. Under Fello, those subsidiaries will remain. For brand purposes, they'll be jointly presented as Fello Communities.
Rondeau said Fello's history as a longtime chapter of The Arc isn't taken for granted.
The Arc's national organization dates back to the 1950s when it was first organized by parent groups in Minneapolis. It has chapters across the country, including Maryland's chapter and many local chapters within the state.
"Being part of The Arc and a national movement is a really important part of our history, and we would've never gotten here without that," Rondeau said. "But at some point, we all grow up."
In a press release, Fello stated it serves over 4,000 Marylanders in Anne Arundel County and the Eastern Shore. There are over 650 employees, nearly 100 housing units and 43 properties, the release stated.
Those services won't go away due to the name change, Rondeau said.
The Fello president noted the nonprofit's Board of Directors and top executives had been discussing the name change for a couple years. Once they began transitioning in recent months, the excitement has been "contagious," Rondeau said.
"I think there's also excitement of really being able to have our own brand that feels like us, it feels connected to our values, it feels connected to our vision and mission," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a nonprofit organization's rebranding and its housing development activities, which aligns most closely with business and economic news rather than the other listed categories.

title: Regulations could choke economy
author: Staff Writer
content:
Regulations could choke economy

 May 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 306
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I've poured my heart, savings and energy into Tidewater Vacation Rentals, helping families and visitors create cherished memories in Talbot County. But proposed short-term rental (STR) regulations, introduced by Council members Lynn Mielke and Pete Lesher, threaten my livelihood and the community I love.These regulations add red tape, longer minimum stays, stricter licensing, inspections and hearings that make running a responsible STR feel impossible. They don't just impact me; they jeopardize the local cleaners, landscapers and businesses like restaurants and boutiques that thrive on tourism. My guests, often families or bridal parties, pour money into our economy, supporting the $260 million tourism industry that employs one in nine residents, per tourtalbot.org.
We already follow strict rules: We're licensed, pay taxes, meet safety codes and pass inspections. I support fair regulations, but these changes feel like a solution in search of a problem.
At the May 2025 Planning Commission meeting, over 40 property and business owners, including STR Review Board members Keith Watts and Cindy Reichart, raised concerns about their necessity. This should be a wake-up call.
Tourism is Talbot County's backbone, with 750,000 visitors in 2024. My business houses them, keeping dollars flowing to local shops and services year-round. These regulations could choke this economic engine, driving away guests and hurting small businesses.
I'm not asking for a free pass — just fairness. STR owners like me support local events and keep tourism vibrant. I've built my dream here, and it's heartbreaking to feel that effort penalized. The current rules work: they protect residents, ensure safety, and generate revenue. Why fix what isn't broken?
I'm speaking out for myself, my family and every worker and shopkeeper who relies on tourism. Talbot County Council, please don't shut out the people who serve this community.
Let's keep our doors open for visitors who love this place as much as we do.
MICHELLE HOYLE
St. Michaels 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses proposed short‑term rental regulations and their potential impact on tourism revenue and local businesses, focusing on economic consequences rather than purely governmental procedure.
