title: Economic reality needs to drive budget decisions
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Economic reality needs to drive budget decisions

 May 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 706
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In a recent column, I wrote about the following three thought-provoking news reports on Maryland's bond ratings and fiscal policies that merit immediate attention of Gov. Moore and the leadership of the General Assembly:Decisions by Moody's to downgrade Maryland's fiscal outlook from stable to negative for the first time since 2011.Unanswered questions on how to address structural state budget deficits driven in large part by state funding obligations for the Blueprint for Maryland's Future.The potential for Maryland to experience similar outcomes to those recurring in Delaware where businesses have relocated or are planning to relocate their Delaware incorporation after concluding that state has a hostile to business environment.
Now comes the unwelcome news that Standard & Poor's Global Ratings has issued a negative outlook for outstanding revenue bonds issued by the Maryland Transportation Authority.
Since 1971, the transportation authority has been responsible for building, operating, improving Maryland's toll facilities, and financing new transportation projects.
Currently MDTA operates, maintains and collects tolls on the Fort McHenry Tunnel, Harbor Tunnel, Chesapeake Bay Bridge, Hatem Memorial Bridge, Gov. Harry W. Nice/Sen. Thomas "Mac" Middleton Bridge, Millard Tydings Bridge and Maryland Route 200, aka the Intercounty Connector highway in Montgomery County and Prince George's County.
MDTA is also in charge of the massive job of rebuilding, reopening and operating the Francis Scott Key Bridge that will, at some point, once again connect Anne Arundel and Baltimore counties.
While Standard & Poor's recently reaffirmed MDTA's current AA bond rating, they also downgraded its outlook on MDTA's bond rating from stable to negative. They warned of the potential for future changes, in part due to S&P's uncertainty over the costs of building the Key Bridge replacement.
These costs have been estimated to be at least $1.8 billion.
Funding sources for those replacement costs are uncertain especially if the Trump administration continues to aggressively pursue further reductions in federal government spending.
What if only some or none of the $1.8 billion promised by former President Biden for bridge replacement is delivered by the federal government?
Such an outcome is possible given a Republican president and a Republican Congress.
In any event, S&P does not foresee raising the recently reaffirmed AA bond rating upward "given MDTA's relatively high debt burden and additional borrowing plans."
Conversely, S&P has warned there is "at least a one-in-three chance they could lower the rating within the two-year outlook based on final costs to replace the Key Bridge along with MDTA's s $5.1 billion capital improvement program."
Currently MDTA has $2.1 billion in outstanding debt. In fiscal 2026, which begins July 1, 2025, that debt amount is expected to "increase significantly" to $2.6 billion, according to an analysis of the General Assembly's nonpartisan Department Legislative Services.
That analysis projects outstanding MDTA debt will increase to $3.3 billion in fiscal 2027, before peaking at $3.8 billion in fiscal years 2029 and 2030.
Those amounts are slightly less than that provided for in MDTA's statutory authority on a borrowing cap.
To date, MDTA seems unconcerned by these negative news reports.
An MDTA spokesperson has said, "The agency will continue to meet its debt payment obligations despite the loss of the Key Bridge and temporary loss of associated revenues, the MDTA expects to remain in compliance with all board directed financial policies and trust agreement covenants."
One has to ask: Is that based on rigorous analysis or wishful thinking?
I predict all the above news will result in Gov. Moore calling a special session of the Maryland General Assembly well before the next regular session convenes in January 2026.
If and when a special session is held this year, Gov. Moore and the leadership in the General Assembly have a responsibility to every Maryland taxpayer.
That responsibility is simple and achievable.
Collectively and individually, they need to acknowledge, understand and respect the observations in all of these bond rating reports.
They need to give special attention to Moody's report which includes the following: "The negative outlook incorporates difficulties Maryland will face to achieve balanced financial operations in coming years without sacrificing service delivery goals or adding to the weight of the state government's burden on individual and corporate taxpayers."
It is imperative that in any special session and in future regular sessions, decisions on state spending levels, spending cuts, new taxes, tax increases, new fees and fee increases be based solely on economic realities. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses state bond ratings, fiscal deficits, and budget decisions, focusing on economic and financial implications for Maryland, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Maryland's wineries begin to thrive as reputation grows
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Maryland's wineries begin to thrive as reputation grows

 June 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 634
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Port of Leonardtown Winery Winemaker Lauren Zimmerman relayed a story back when a judge during a wine tasting contest didn't believe the drink had come from the winery. In fact, he even requested to see the bottle complete with the label.But wines from Maryland in general, and Southern Maryland in particular, have come a long way since then.
"I think our reputation has definitely improved," Zimmerman said during a lecture titled "Port of Leonardtown Winery, and the History of Wine in Maryland" held May 21 at Historic Sotterley. "I think people and their wineries experience has improved. There's also a lot of experienced winemakers coming into the area, which has improved the quality of Maryland wines immensely."
The Leonardtown winery is celebrating its 15th season this year and has won numerous wine industry awards.
"We're very well known for producing wines in general, dry and sweet," Zimmerman said.
The lecture also featured wine tastings of a limited edition sparkling red the winery will release in June.
"It is a dry red sparkling and it's loaded with red berry flavors," Zimmerman said of the wine, the label of which was designed by local artist Bernard Matus. "It has lots of notes of blueberry, raspberry. I think it's going to fly off the shelves."
The lecture also included Southern Maryland Grape Grower's Cooperative President David Wood, who is also owner of Forest Hall Farm Market in Mechanicsville.
"We needed a viable alternative. Nobody's going to create a market just for grape juice," Wood said of the winery's beginnings in 2007. "Just like anything else that is new, you learn as you grow. The money's not in the grapes, the money is in the profit of the wine."
But Wood added it wasn't easy for former tobacco farmers to start growing grapes.
"You weren't prepared to do the marketing, to go out and shop your crop to find a buyer who was willing to buy it," he said. "That's not a farmer's strength; they're used to staying at home and dealing with their crops. The selling of the crop was the big issue and the co-op stepped up and provided a solution to that challenge."
With the start of the wine co-op in 2007 — the first in the state — farmers still faced hurdles before seeing the literal fruits of their labors.
"The [profit] net was pretty good because tobacco was labor-intensive; it didn't require a lot of investment," Wood said. "Grapes on the other hand are costly and it takes about three years of growing the grapes before you get your first harvest."
Wood said wineries require an investment of about $10,000 an acre "before you get your first crop, and you probably won't break even until your fifth or sixth harvest."
But he added growers will "probably get 20, 25 years of harvests, so once you get over the hump, you can really get ahead."
The Port of Leonardtown Winery had its first crush of grapes in 2009 and opened a year later.
Wood added that a single winery can usually offer the basic red and white varieties, but having a co-op means a selection of 20 labels or more.
"It gives us not only more grapes, but a wider variety," he said. "It turns into a product mix of more unique wines."
Zimmerman said Port of Leonardtown produces about 5,000 cases annually, and that red and white grapes are treated differently; reds get a mix of seeds and skin where it gets its flavor and color, while whites are made with whole cluster pressing.
All reds are aged in an oak barrel, while all white grapes are aged in a stainless steel drum.
"Chardonnay made in stainless steel barrels have crisp, clean like green apple flavor," she said, "versus chardonnays in made in oak barrels have a baked apple, vanilla cinnamon-spiced, clove flavor. They're different styles, but just both beautiful wines." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the growth and profitability of Maryland wineries, investment costs, market development, and economic impact, making Business/Economy the strongest match, with Agriculture as a close secondary theme.

title: Average Maryland gas price was $3.01 last week
author: Staff Writer
content:
Average Maryland gas price was $3.01 last week

 June 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 440
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 3.4 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.01 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 12.1 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 58.4 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has decreased 2.4 cents in the last week and stands at $3.465 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.65 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.79 per gallon, a difference of $1.14 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 3.8 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.09 per gallon Monday. The national average is down 6.9 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 41.0 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
June 2, 2024: $3.60 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.50 per gallon)June 2, 2023: $3.44 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.54 per gallon)June 2, 2022: $4.67 per gallon (U.S. Average: $4.76 per gallon)June 2, 2021: $3.03 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.04 per gallon)June 2, 2020: $2.02 per gallon (U.S. Average: $1.99 per gallon)June 2, 2019: $2.72 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.81 per gallon)June 2, 2018: $2.94 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.95 per gallon)June 2, 2017: $2.37 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.38 per gallon)June 2, 2016: $2.33 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.33 per gallon)June 2, 2015: $2.72 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.76 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $2.97 per gallon, down 1.9 cents per gallon from last week's $2.99 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.12 per gallon, unchanged from last week's $3.12 per gallon.Hagerstown: $2.98 per gallon, down 10.8 cents per gallon from last week's $3.09 per gallon.
"The national average price of gasoline has continued its gentle descent over the last week, with the most notable declines seen in the Great Lakes region, where a minor refinery issue was resolved, sending wholesale gas prices lower," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "We're also beginning to see prices retreat in California, a trend that should soon extend across much of the West Coast as additional gasoline shipments from Asia help offset recent refinery disruptions. While gasoline inventories remain somewhat tight heading into the summer, I'm optimistic that increased refinery output could pave the way for further price declines. That said, any unexpected outages could still cause short-term price bumps."

title: Ocean State Job Lot opens at former Big Lots site in Easton
author: Konner Metz
content:
Ocean State Job Lot opens at former Big Lots site in Easton

 June 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 255
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A new discount retailer opened in Easton last week, replacing the former Big Lots.Ocean State Job Lot, a retail chain with more than 150 stores across the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic regions, opened doors to Easton shoppers on Memorial Day. The store then held a grand opening Saturday with company leaders and town officials.
The 35,000-square-foot store is located on Marlboro Avenue, nestled within the Tred Avon Square business center. The business offers household goods, clothing, food and more at discount prices.
Town Council President Don Abbatiello expressed excitement for Ocean State Job Lot during Monday's council meeting. He said replacing the former Big Lots was important.
"It's always good for us to be reusing facilities as opposed to trying to break ground on something new," Abbatiello said.
In March, Ocean State Job Lot announced it acquired 15 Big Lots locations across many states following Big Lots' bankruptcy claim last year. Three of those locations are in Maryland: Easton, Elkton and Chester.
Easton's opening makes it the second Ocean State Job Lot in to welcome Maryland shoppers. The company's Hagerstown location cut the ribbon in April.
"We're thrilled to introduce Maryland to our unique brand of shopping," said Easton store team leader Bob Thomas in a press release. "We've worked hard to create a bright, friendly, and convenient shopping experience for residents and visitors alike, and we're grateful to be part of the Easton community."
The Easton Ocean State Job Lot is open Mondays through Saturdays from 8 a.m. to 9 p.m. and Sundays from 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: American Cruise Lines will dock less often in Cambridge this summer
author: Lily Tierney
content:
American Cruise Lines will dock less often in Cambridge this summer

 June 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Business 
 
 358
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The large, white American Cruise Line ship is a frequent summer sighting at Cambridge Harbor, but this year that will change, according to Dorchester Chamber of Commerce President Bill Christopher.American Cruise Lines's Chesapeake Bay Cruises will dock at the wharf six times this year as opposed to the 26 to 30 dockings seen in previous years. The cruises have been a major driving force of Cambridge's tourism and economy, Christopher said.
The Dorchester Chamber of Commerce has not done data collection on the economic impact of the cruise line visits, but Christopher said they certainly helps local shops and restaurants.
According to Elusive Tours owner Jerry Hayes, the cruise line has shifted its focus from Cambridge to St. Michaels this year. Elusive Tours partners with the American Cruise Lines in both cities, and Hayes said the business is currently operating two tours with cruise guests in Cambridge: one at RAR Brewing and the other at Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge.
Hayes said even though Cambridge is no longer a primary port this summer, it won't be neglected.
Elusive Tours helps to bus cruise ship guests from St. Michaels to Cambridge to visit Harriet Tubman's historic sites and museums, the market at Church Creek, and RAR's brewery.
For one excursion, Elusive Tours takes guests with author and Dorchester County historian Jim Duffy on a boat ride through Cambridge Harbor as he narrates the tales of the Eastern Shore.
The Chesapeake Bay Cruise sets sail from Baltimore, stopping in Annapolis, Yorktown, Williamsburg, St. Michaels and sometimes Cambridge. The cruise is advertised on the website as an eight-day riverboat cruise that takes guests to the "crab capital of the world."
Hayes said the cruise is a great opportunity to explore the Chesapeake. "Even if you're a local, it's a unique way to see where you live, and if you've never been here before, you'll fall in love," he said.
Christopher and Hayes said the less frequent stops in Cambridge is likely a temporary change in the American Cruise Line's Chesapeake Bay Cruises itinerary, but that is not certain. American Cruise Line's did not respond to a request to comment.
This has been updated to correct a name spelling. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses changes in cruise ship dockings and their impact on local tourism and the economy, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Gut punch to seniors, families
author: Staff Writer
content:
Gut punch to seniors, families

 June 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 319
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I want to publicly thank Congressman Andy Harris for casting a "present" vote on the so-called "Big Beautiful Bill" (H.R. 1). While this vote may seem inconsequential at first glance, in today's hyper-partisan climate, even a moment of hesitation is a sign worth recognizing.But the job isn't finished. When this reckless piece of legislation returns from the Senate, I urge Congressman Harris to take a stronger stand — and vote no.
This bill is fiscal malpractice. It will send the national debt into the stratosphere, piling trillions in unfunded giveaways onto future generations. It slashes the foundation of health care for millions by stripping access to Medicaid and chipping away at Medicare — a gut punch to seniors and working families alike.
Even worse, it's a shell game. Clever accounting gimmicks are buried in the text to disguise the real cost and delay the fiscal fallout just long enough to clear a few election cycles. But voters and markets alike will not be fooled forever.
Let's call this bill what it is: the largest single transfer of wealth from the working poor to the ultra-wealthy in U.S. legislative history. While corporate tax cuts and loopholes proliferate, everyday Americans are left to carry the burden.
To put things in perspective, in the 1950s when the American economy was firing on all cylinders, the typical CEO made about 20 times the salary of the average worker, and the highest income tax bracket was 90%.
Today's CEOs make roughly 200 times their average worker's salary and pay a maximum tax rate of 37%. Do the drafters of this bill really think that another big tax break for rich people is a higher priority than reducing the deficit? Or food assistance for pregnant women and hungry children?
Congressman Harris, you had the wisdom to pause the first time. Now have the courage to oppose it. Eastern Shore families — and the nation — are counting on it.
ROBERT MURPHY
Stevensville 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on federal fiscal policy, tax cuts, Medicaid/Medicare funding, and national debt—key economic issues—making Business/Economy the best fit.

title: Data centers could cause significant electricity challenges
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Data centers could cause significant electricity challenges

 June 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 536
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Data from phones, computers and many other devices has to go somewhere, and that somewhere is data centers.The Patuxent Partnership addressed that issue June 16 with a discussion titled "Data Centers: The pros and cons and what it means for you, the residential customers," at the USMSM Building in California.
Data centers are giant warehouses filled with microprocessors that manage all data on the Cloud. There are currently 44 data centers in Maryland, and almost 300 in Northern Virginia.
With more data centers comes the need for more electricity to supply them.
"People should not so much be concerned about them, but aware of them," said Scott White, who is on the The Patuxent Partnership board of directors and is CEO/President of HTii. "I think it's important to understand the economic forces that are driving this integration of data centers, but also the potential impact for their power supply and whether the cost goes up if there's more demand."
Panelist Sonja Cox, president/CEO of SMECO, said the co-op can put out a maximum of 1,036 megawatts — or peak load — and data center developers are talking about the need to add another 4,000 megawatts.
"The data center developers want the data centers built yesterday," Cox said, "so they want the power, they need the power to run them."
She added SMECO is working on some feasibility studies, but was unable to go into details because of non-disclosure agreements.
"I will say that the main thing we want to make sure is that our customers are not subsidizing this bigger load," she said.
Larger data centers can use as much electricity as a medium-sized town.
"It's a brave new world right now with AI and data centers," panelist and Constellation Vice President of Government and Regulatory Affairs Lael Campbell Campbell said, adding that the matter is one of national security, which "we have to take seriously. We see ourselves as the key part in how America is going to win that race and how America is going to support this new growing economy."
Campbell added that a new data center "is not going to just plop down 1,000 megawatts of demand overnight. They're phasing in that demand over time, so it's not like all of a sudden the entire output of a nuclear power plant is going to be sucked off the grid. Frankly, that's a bit of fear mongering."
Data centers can also have an effect on power grids, telecommunications and power lines.
"We're talking about 100 acres of forest or farms in Southern Maryland. We're talking about a fundamental shift in our economy, our way of life, our natural resources," independent advocate and panelist Rosa Hance said, adding that data centers "could be shifting the way we use our land and other natural resources."
Calvert County is in favor of data centers.
"There are legislators who want to keep data centers out of Maryland," Commissioner President Earl F. "Buddy" Hance (R) said in an April Southern Maryland News story.
He added he was "tired of hearing Annapolis say, 'We can't allow these data centers because we don't have power.' We all draw power from the same grid. We are going to lose revenue and jobs. If the state of Maryland creates obstacles, they [data centers] aren't coming here." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the economic implications of data centers, including electricity demand, power grid impact, and local policy debates, making Business/Economy the most fitting category.

title: Molly’s Place opening second store in Easton
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Molly’s Place opening second store in Easton

 June 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 511
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Molly's Place is expanding to Easton late this summer.The sporting goods store has a location in Kennedyville, Maryland. Co-owners Nick and Chikki Shajwani credit the Waterfowl Festival as one of the main reasons they're coming to Easton.
"The biggest thing that drew us to Easton was the Waterfowl Festival. We've been coming there for over a decade, plus now, and being part of that festival. It's been an amazing run," Chikki said.
The journey for the brothers started long before they owned a store. It goes all the way back to visiting the United States as tourists in the summer of 1998.
In 2002, the brothers moved to the United States, setting up in Galena, Maryland. The began to work for a man named Scott Mason, the original owner of Molly's Place.
"Molly was a black lab, and that happened to be Scott Mason's dog," Chikki said. "We used to be in a hardware business. We had a hardware store in Galena, and it used to be slow in the winter time. Nick had this crazy idea because since it was so slow in the winter."
According to Nick, all summer long Mason would be there every day, and then during the winter he would disappear. Nick asked Mason where he went during the winter, and Mason told him he went to his hunting property.
After Nick found out about the Eastern Shore's wintertime hunting culture, he thought of the idea of opening a sporting goods store.
"That's how the sporting good store came to be. We opened a little sporting good store in a 900-square-foot space that used to be our lawn mower repair shop. That's how we got into this sporting goods business. We did great the first year," Nick said.
Mason bought out a building that housed a store named Vonnies in 2009, and in 2010 the brothers open Molly's Place's Kennedyville location.
The brothers now open their second location, which will feature partnerships no other store on the east coast offers, they said.
"This store is going to be more of our experiential store," Nick said. "We are going to really go into and specialize in the product that we feel the community would really support. We have a great partnership coming through, which is the first of its kind. A strategic partnership with a brand called KUIU which is high-end hunting gear, which they have never done that with any other independent retailer in the country."
According to Nick, the California-based company coming to the Easton is a "huge feat for every outdoorsman and outdoor women that's out there."
The brothers are excited to bring Molly's Place to Talbot County and surrounding areas, with the store expected to open in late July or August.
"Molly's, at the end of the day, is a core-values driven company," Nick said. "We are going to carry the same values that we have worked towards, perfected and delivered here and been part of us, and we are excited about carrying and bringing that to Talbot County and those surrounding areas."
This report was updated to clarify misspelling from "Bonnies" to "Vonnies." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the expansion of a sporting goods retail business, focusing on store openings, partnerships, and economic activity, which aligns best with the Business/Economy category.

title: The Blue Crab meets the Bagery: St. Michaels restaurant gets new owners
author: Lily Tierney
content:
The Blue Crab meets the Bagery: St. Michaels restaurant gets new owners

 June 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Business 
 
 447
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — The beloved Blue Crab Coffee Shop in St. Michaels has reopened under new ownership, but they're not new to many on the Eastern Shore. Bagery owner Matt Andrews has expanded his reach from Easton to St. Michaels with the Blue Crab.Andrews took ownership of the establishment in May, and he says he's excited to honor the history of the space.
The Blue Crab building was a formerly Odd Fellows Lodge, built in 1867. It was originally named the Shealtiel Lodge No. 1024. Four years after the Civil War ended, the building was renamed to the Freedom's Friend Lodge No. 1024, and is the oldest Odd Fellows Lodge remaining in Maryland.
"All the plates that we use are from former Odd Fellows Lodges around the country," Andrews said.
He wants to pay homage to the building's former use by learning and preserving its history through social media videos, interviews with members of the historical society, and by getting footage of some of the artifacts.
"We're anxious to learn more and tell people about it," he said.
Along with the interesting history that comes with the establishment, Andrews is excited to expand service beyond breakfast and lunch. He said they plan on testing out dinner service soon but want to get their footing at the new location first.
Andrews says the community response has been overwhelmingly positive with strong feedback on the organic bread products made from scratch in Easton.
"All the feedback has been good about the food and the coffee and service," Andrews said.
Former Blue Crab owners Helen and Brian Herman stepped away from the restaurant in mid-April so Helen could focus on her architecture practice, Brian on his recording studio and so the two could spend more time with their three children, according to a Facebook post made by the Blue Crab in early April.
Andrews said the Herman's still own the building and he has a good working relationship with them. "We've had a good relationship with them over the years," he said. "They have been buying bagels wholesale from the Bagery since we opened in 2018."
According to Andrews, a majority of the menu uses the products they make in house at the Bagery and has an array of vegan options.
Blue Crab baristas Anna Szwaja and Alyssa Skinner said the transition in ownership has been smooth. Szwaja worked for the Blue Crab's previous owners last summer, and Skinner started at the Bagery a year and a half ago.
"We all get along really well," Szwaja said. Skinner agreed, saying she really enjoys her co-workers.
"I like getting to know customers and people that come in regularly," Szwaja said as she gestured to the knitting club in the back of the restaurant. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Board of Realtors distributes 50th down payment grant
author: MID-SHORE BAORD OF REALTORS
content:
Board of Realtors distributes 50th down payment grant

 June 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Words

 EASTON — On June 20, the Mid-Shore Board of Realtors awarded its 50th down payment grant to first time home buyers Christopher and Sarah Bergling.The buyers' agent was Penny Introcaso with Benson & Mangold, who worked with the couple for over a year to help them find their dream home. title: Guidebook aims to 'get people out there'
author: BROOKE ENSMINGER
content:
Guidebook aims to 'get people out there'

 June 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BROOKE ENSMINGER | Section: Business 
 
 560
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A second edition of an Eastern Shore guidebook connects locals and visitors to places and activities they might not have known were just a short drive away.Writer Susan Moynihan, who grew up in Annapolis, decided to create an updated version of her guidebook titled "100 Things to Do in Annapolis and the Eastern Shore Before You Die" to accommodate changes after COVID-19. The book highlights beloved Eastern Shore destinations.
"The fact that we have this beautifully preserved and cared for expanse of land and culture that still stays so close to its roots, I find fascinating," Moynihan said. "I find it to be a really unique part of the world."
In compiling her list, Moynihan began with the things she loved to do in Annapolis and the surrounding areas. She then asked friends and other locals for recommendations, considering whether each item was worth recommending in the book. She said she wanted to put a focus on activities and locations that "wouldn't exist anywhere else."
"Going out on the Skipjack or going to a seafood festival and trying all the food. There's so much," Moynihan said.
Amy Kreiner, the president of the Talbot County Chamber of Commerce, said guidebooks can help visitors find more affordable activities when they have to be financially careful in what they're choosing to do.
"They give an idea of what can be experienced in the different areas," Kreiner said. "There's just so many more things to do that can be explained in a guidebook than a lot of other places."
The list kicks off with food and drink, and includes Rise Up Coffee Roasters and Bas Rouge in Easton and Booze in St. Michaels. Moynihan describes Rise Up as having a distinctive style with its black-and-white graphics and an "indie-inclusive sensibility."
"We have really amazing restaurants and places to stay with really, really outstanding chefs and dining experiences," Kreiner said.
Oysterfest is an annual seafood festival in St. Michaels hosted by the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum. The festival kicks off oyster season in October with a day full of oyster-themed events.
While the diverse dining options can be an attraction of their own, Kreiner said the biggest draws to the area are the history and the waterfront.
Moynihan's book highlights waterfront gems like the Skipjack Nathan in Cambridge, where guests can take private sails, and the Oxford-Bellevue Ferry in Oxford, the oldest private ferry in the United States.
Building on the history of the Eastern Shore, the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum in St. Michaels showcases the largest collection of Chesapeake boats. Other featured museums include the Water's Edge Museum in Oxford, the Museum of Rural Life in Denton and the Tilghman Watermen's Museum on Tilghman Island.
Entertainment is another unique experience on the Eastern Shore. Many locals have attended a show at the Avalon Theatre, a must-visit entertainment venue on Moynihan's list. Lesser-known, however, is Chesapeake Ghost Tours, where guests can take a haunted walking tour in towns around the Eastern Shore and beyond. Each location offers its own unique tale, but Moynihan recommends the Cambridge tour.
While guidebooks are often seen as tools for tourists to effectively navigate an unfamiliar area, Moynihan wants her book to be a guide for Eastern Shore residents and visitors alike.
She said her goal is "just to get people out there." Locals don't have to travel far to find unique places and activities that are rich in history, culture and entertainment. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a new guidebook that promotes local attractions, restaurants, festivals, and museums, highlighting economic benefits for tourism and referencing the Chamber of Commerce, making Business/Economy the strongest fit.

title: 'Sharp contrasts': Tourism sees international 'headwinds', domestic travel resilience
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS Adams MultiMedia
content:
'Sharp contrasts': Tourism sees international 'headwinds', domestic travel resilience

 July 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS Adams MultiMedia | Section: National 
 
 1452
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Is the glass half-full or half-empty for travel and tourism this year?International travel to the U.S. faces some "sentimental headwinds" with Canadians, Europeans and other travelers having negative views of President Donald Trump and his "America First" rhetoric and agenda.
The World Travel & Tourism Council said in May the U.S. could lose as much as $12.5 billion in international tourist spending this year (a 7% decline from $181 billion in 2024 to below $169 billion projected this year).
Oxford Economics also has a "negative outlook for inbound travel to the U.S." citing "sentiment headwinds" with international views toward Trump including his tariffs, geopolitical posturing, hardline immigration moves and cuts to U.S. foreign aid .
Trump has also talked about the U.S. making Canada the 51st U.S. state, taking over Greenland and stepping back from European alliances. His hardline immigration efforts include the arrests, detentions and deportation of undocumented migrants, including many from Latin America.
Trump issued an executive order July 3 raising entrance fees for foreign tourists and groups visiting national parks.
The economics group expects an 8.7% drop in international trips to the U.S. with significant pullbacks on visits to the states by Canadians and Europeans.
"We forecast international visitor spending to fall by $8.5 billion (-4.7%), relative to last year," the Oxford group said in its negative outlook report.
'WE'VE SEEN A SHIFT'But Americans continue to travel in force domestically and internationally this year, according to tourism executives and business owners on the frontlines of travel trends.
The industry paints a less dire, more watchful picture of the economy and travel trends.
"We've seen a shift," said Stacy Ritter, president and CEO of Visit Lauderdale (which promotes tourism to the Fort Lauderdale area of South Florida).
"International travel is relatively stable overall, but we have seen a noticeable dip in visitation from Canada. That said, the increase in domestic travel has more than made up for it," Ritter said.
That has made for "strong and steady" tourism flows so far this year, she said.
"What's especially notable is that off-peak travel is out-performing expectations. That's a strong indicator that people are prioritizing travel, even in uncertain economic times," Ritter said.
But she is also seeing "shorter booking windows" for travel plans.
Ritter said shorter stays can translate into less spending and succeeding tax revenue.]
She said local tourism tax revenue is trending slightly down. That suggests visitors are coming, but they may be choosing shorter stays or being more mindful with their spending.
Jorge Salas-Guevara Succar, founder and president of New Paths Expeditions (which leads tours and operates small cruises across the globe), is also seeing a shift among international bookings. 'Over-tourism' has become a soar point in Europe wit large.crowds stressing popular destinations such as Paris and Barcelona.
Some of our most seasoned travelers are now actively pivoting toward destinations that offer smoother logistics and fewer crowds, especially Latin America," Succar said. "We've had a noticeable number of travelers switch their European reservations to Latin America trips mid-year, citing overcrowding, uncertainty, and a desire for deeper, more authentic experiences."
Wars in the Middle East since the Oct. 7, 2023, attacks inside Israel have also discouraged travel to that region.
'A RAPID RISE'Domestic travel has been carrying the tourism load with AAA reporting a record 72.2 million Americans traveling for the July 4th holiday and more than 45 million for Memorial Day weekend.
Lower gas prices are encouraging for inflation-weary households. The average price of gasoline stood at $3.14 per gallon as of Monday, July 7. That is down from more than $3.50 per gallon a year ago and down from the record $5-plus gas prices during the summer of 2022 and 40-year highs with inflation.
Mountain West states such as Montana, Wyoming, Utah and Idaho are seeing increased interest from tourists.
"We have seen a rapid rise in clients traveling to the Western U.S. especially near or abutting National Parks. Yellowstone, in particular. Incredible vistas, cultural experiences, and easy access especially for those from the Northeast. Alaska has also seen a huge uptick," said Carolyn Addison, head of product of Black Tomato, a New York-based luxury tour operator.
Yellowstone National Park had its busiest May on record — 566,363 visitors this year. That is up 8% from a year ago and 20% from 2021, according to the National Park Service.
In May, passenger counts at Bozeman Yellowstone International Airport in Belgrade, Montana, were up 12% in May compared to two years ago.
Richie Khandelwal, president and co-founder of PriceLabs, a Chicago-based firm specializing in software for vacation rentals, sees "sharp contrasts in short-term rental booking favoring smaller and rural areas with cheaper rates than pricey bigger cities.
He points to markets such as Ocean City, Maryland, Bend, Oregon and Saratoga Springs, New York, as performing well.
"One key trend we're seeing is guests booking later, perhaps waiting to see how things play out before deciding where to travel — or if they can afford to travel at all," he said.
Addison said more travelers are seeking peace and tranquility on their vacations for personal resets "away from urban rhythms."
"This isn't about isolation, but intentional connection. Month-long stays are becoming increasingly common, as travelers trade rushed itineraries for unhurried exploration," Addison said.
Succar agrees seeing more travel motivations stemming from "a desire for less screen time."
Ritter said her Fort Lauderdale tourism group has stepped up its promotions of the local food scene.
Culinary tourism is a top travel trend this year, according to Eleanor Moody, a travel expert at HomeToGo, which operates an online vacation rentals marketplace and platform.
She said experiences such as sporting events, concerts and natural events (such as eclipses and animal migrations) are also on tourists' contemporary vacation wish lists.
There are also travelers eyeing off-the-beaten path experiences. That could help draw visitors to Mississippi's Gulf coast as well as the Pacific Northwest, according to HomeToGo.com,
Many travelers are still cost conscious — still feeling the financial impacts of post-pandemic inflation and higher prices.
Moody said there are instances where travel to Europe can be cheaper than some popular U.S. destinations.
"With extended, cost-conscious vacations on the rise, more U.S. travelers may consider international vacations to stretch their dollars," she said.
MESSAGES TO MOMOther tourism groups are promoting trips closer to home.
"We're seeing a lot more staycations and shorter vacations this year. Less people are flying internationally and are choosing to vacation here in the U.S. instead," said Steve Schwab, CEO of Casago.com, a Scottsdale, Arizona-based vacation rentals and property management company.
Schwab said he is seeing more road trips and vacations closer to home.
"All of these things seem to be pretty consistent among age groups but perhaps more dominant for Gen-Zers and Millennials, and that's likely just due to less funds at their disposal for traveling.
The Wisconsin Dells Visitor & Convention Bureau has its tourism marketing efforts focused on Midwestern drive markets such as Chicago, Minneapolis, St. Louis and Des Moines.
The area is known for its water parks, amusement parks. and summer fun.
"We are typically trying to reach the family household vacation planning decision-maker (usually 'mom')," said Andy Larsen, spokesperson for the Wisconsin group.
Dodie Stephens, vice of marketing for Explore Asheville, said the North Carolina tourism group also focused its marketing to regional drive markets with an emphasis that the area is open for visitors after all the damage caused by Hurricane Helene last year.
"We're shouting it from our beautiful Blue Ridge mountaintops—the Asheville area is open for business and eagerly welcoming visitors after Hurricane Helene impacted our region in fall of 2024," Stephens said.
She said the western Carolina region is still getting that word out to the travel marketplace.
"We're seeing a mixed picture of business as we continue to invite leisure travelers back. In May, hotel occupancy averaged 67%, down five points from 2024 and ten points from 2019," she said.
Carl Cronje, co-founder and CEO of TourAxis, an international tourism firm specializing in coach tours, said he's not seeing Americans "step back from international travel."
"Our South African tours are performing exceptionally well, and European tours continue to be favorites," he said.
"Our primary focus continues to be the U.S. market, and we particularly target female travelers in their mid-50s who represent our core demographic for coach travel," Cronje said.
Those can include group and solo vacations (a growing trend among women), he said.
He also sees travelers focus on experiences and the "memory economy."
Jakob Wahl, CEO of the International Association of Amusement Parks and Attractions (IAAPA), said domestic tourism is performing well in the U.S., China and Brazil and that vacationers are cost conscious.
"Affordability continues to be a key consideration, particularly for families and multi-generational travel," he said.
Wahl said if tourists are uncertain about the economy or world affairs, they may be more prone for shorter trips.
"We've also seen an increase in spontaneous, last-minute visits" he said, pointing to attractions offering localized and specialized promotions and digital services focused on those visitors. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on tourism trends, spending forecasts, and economic impacts of travel, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy category.

title: Washington Street Pub coming back ... with pub chips
author: Staff Writer
content:
Washington Street Pub coming back ... with pub chips

 July 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Headlines 
 
 180
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Jim Johnson here. Managing Editor Wendy Weitzel is taking a few well-deserved days off, and I am filling in for her.Many in Easton lamented the closing of the Washington Street Pub. Lament no longer. The restaurant is reopening in a few days under new ownership.
The question everybody is asking, "What about the pub chips."
Good news. They are back too.
Elsewhere in The Star Democrat today, read about Caroline County Sheriff Donald Baker taking over leadership of the Federalsburg Police Department after the resignation of its police chief.
Baker said his leadership role is just for 30 to 60 days until the town mayor and council determine how they want to proceed. He added, however, that all options are open, including folding the police department into the sheriff's office as was done more than a year ago in Ridgely.
A public forum will be held later in July, giving residents an opportunity to voice their opinions on public safety in Federalsburg.
As always, the Star today is packed with news. Check it out in your print edition or read the e-edition online.
— Jim Johnson

title: Washington Street Pub returns to Easton
author: Konner Metz
content:
Washington Street Pub returns to Easton

 July 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 575
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — An iconic restaurant in downtown Easton is back — and so are its renowned pub chips.The Washington Street Pub is opening Wednesday under new ownership, a rebirth for the staple dining spot after it closed a few years ago.
Bluepoint Hospitality Group, owned by Paul Prager, has added the Pub to its portfolio of downtown restaurants and businesses such as the fine dining Bas Rouge and pizza service Roma Alla Pala, among other establishments.
Located at 20 N. Washington St., the restaurant has undergone significant renovations from what was a building in rough shape with structural issues, says Holly DeKarske, executive director of the Easton Economic Development Corporation.
"It is really, really satisfying to now see the Pub back open and to be here and bring some vibrancy back to Washington Street," DeKarske said.
Prager and Washington Street Pub Executive Chef Daniel Pochron emphasize that the Pub will be affordable, something many residents have been asking for since plans to reopen it were announced. Almost the entire menu will be under $30, Pochron said.
The two-level dining area seats around 160 people, complete with a sizable bar on the first floor and large TVs visible from both levels.
Employees worked on finishing touches Tuesday. Sitting on the second level, Pochron, a 26-year resident of the Eastern Shore, beamed with excitement when thinking back to how he and his wife often dined at the former Pub.
"We'd come here on a Friday and a Saturday night, and this place was packed," he said. "That's the excitement that I want to bring back. I love it more than anything."
There'll be a raw bar with five types of oysters, Pochron said. Other seafood options include lobster, shrimp (peel-and-eat, cocktail and tacos), fish and chips, crab cakes and cream of crab soup.
Pochron noted additional entrees such as the meatloaf, chicken pot pie and burger are reasonably priced. There are salads under $20 and sandwiches around $15.
Desserts include apple pie, carrot cake, a root beer float, bread pudding and a chocolate chip cookie skillet.
"To make the food comfort food that's good and fair priced. That's what brought me back to the pub," said Pochron, a longtime chef in the area with stops at the Tidewater Inn and the Inn at Perry Cabin in St. Michaels.
Prager said in an interview last month that it was important for the establishment to remain as the Washington Street Pub, a place where he hopes "everybody would feel comfortable in."
And yes, the highly requested pub chips are back. In fact, Pochron said it was a lengthy process to try to source former Pub employees to find where to get the chips.
"Anywhere I go, the first question I have to answer is, 'I got the pub chips back,'" the chef said.
"You wouldn't believe how many people asked about pub chips," Prager said. "So it was like, 'OK, we got to figure that out.'"
The Washington Street Pub will be open Wednesday to Monday from 11 a.m. to midnight and closed on Tuesdays.
DeKarske shared excitement for the boost she believes the restaurant will bring to Easton's downtown, especially during the summer months and the Waterfowl Festival in November.
"To have another dining establishment is huge," DeKarske said. "That's what brings people downtown. That's what gets locals and visitors out and about, and then also helps boost all of our retail.
"It was definitely felt when it closed," she said. "But I think that we are going to feel it when it reopens as well." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the reopening of a local restaurant, its ownership, renovations, pricing, and its expected impact on downtown commerce, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Commerce secretary: ‘We want to know what we need to do better’
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Commerce secretary: ‘We want to know what we need to do better’

 July 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: Dorchester 
 
 417
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Maryland Secretary of Commerce Harry Coker visited Dorchester County Thursday, part of his tour of Maryland counties as he nears six months on the job.Coker visited the Harriet Tubman monument, then went to the Dorchester Center for the Arts for a tour. He talked to county officials at a roundtable discussion at the Dorchester Innovation Center before touring the facility.
"It's important to be here because we want to focus on all of Maryland and all Marylanders," Coker said. "There's always a lot of focus on the major metropolitan parts of Maryland, and we need every Marylander to know that we care about all of them, where they live and what economic development opportunities are there to include rural areas like Dorchester County."
Coker's walk through Cambridge served as a time to learn about historic sights and scenery. Coker said he enjoyed the Harriet Tubman monument.
"Just seeing that monument, that's the first time I've seen that particular one," Coker said. "It's a lot of history there, a lot of symbolism, and that symbolism actually serves to tie history to the present and the future. That's what I really appreciate."
Coker said his focus is providing growth opportunities throughout the state, including counties that don't get much attention. According to Coker, making sure attention is shown to those counties will require continued visits and help with economic diversity.
"This is the second time I've been in Cambridge in my almost six months in the job," Coker said, "so I've been here twice already. I'll be back because I want to come back in a non-work capacity to see the communities and frankly to contribute to the economic growth of the communities."
The commerce secretary said he wants his department to be "an advocate for the tourism industry that's here."
Coker talked about diversity in the state, saying he wants to consider diversity when his department allocates funding.
"We have to continue again to advocate for all of Maryland, and we'll do that," Coker said.
"That diversity certainly includes racial, and ethnic and gender, but it also includes social and economic diversity, and it includes geographic diversity and industry sector diversity as well," Coker added.
While the Star Democrat talked to Coker before his conversation with Dorchester County officials, Coker hoped the conversation would bring light to what the state can do better.
"I'm not out here to have anybody pat us on the back and tell us how wonderful a job we're doing. We want to know what we need to do better," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the Maryland Secretary of Commerce discussing economic development, tourism, and funding allocation across counties, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic. It also involves interaction with county officials, giving it relevance to Local Government, but the primary focus is economic.

title: Caroline Pharma opening their doors July 10
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline Pharma opening their doors July 10

 July 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: Caroline 
 
 242
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — According to its business Facebook, Caroline Pharma, will officially open its doors on Thursday.Caroline Pharma will be the first dispensary to open in Caroline County since recreational marijuana was legalized in 2023.
"We are very thankful for the Town of Federalsburg council and town administration for approving us to open this dispensary in this town," owner Amar Kalidindi told The Star Democrat in April.
Caroline Pharma, located next to Cantner's Pharmacy, hopes to provide a safe and fun experience for guests interested in recreational cannabis use, the owners said.
Owners of the medical and recreational cannabis dispensary hope the dispensary will bring access to cannabis closer to home for Caroline County residents.
"There's a lot of medical card holders around here," Kalidindi said. "They only have one location within an hour and a half of here, and that one location has wait times of hours, so here we are the second location in the Mid-Shore. So we'll provide great service to people, nice parking, nice friendly atmosphere, great staff. We will keep it local."
According to its Facebook page, Caroline Pharma will offer daily pop-ups at its store with many different brands, each day will be a different brand.
All Caroline Pharma products are state-certified and organic. The business plans to follow state laws and regulations, the owners said. To enter the premises, a person must be 21 or older, unless they have a medical card that is issued by an authorized physician and state-certified.

title: Caroline’s in Denton making strides in new owners tenure
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline’s in Denton making strides in new owners tenure

 July 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: Caroline 
 
 512
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Caroline's in Denton has been open for just about nine months under new owners and in that time has seen increased following on social media and increase revenues.Owner and Executive Chef Ken Zellers and his wife, Robin Zellers, have ideas to take Caroline's in Denton to the next level. They will be putting a permanent food truck at a new brewery in Denton called Eden Town Brewing Company.
"We purchased the food trailer out back, so we're going to be doing the food at the brewery, putting the trailer over there, next step of expansion," Zellers said.
This next step in expansion brings hopes for Caroline's in Denton to keep growing.
"That's a scary part of getting in the restaurant industry," Zellers said. "You never know how the community is going to take to you, how they're going to like your food, your drinks and what you're doing, but it seems to be working out pretty well."
Zeller took over ownership from previous owner Nancy Minahan, Zeller interviewed multiple times for the chef position at Caroline's in Denton but was never granted the opportunity, until Minahan called him about buying the restaurant.
Zeller started working at a restaurant at just 14 years old and began cooking at 16 years old and running a kitchen at 18 years old. He is an award-winning chef in Anna Arundel County including best chef of the year just last year.
One thing Zellers has done since taking ownership of Caroline's in Denton is tweaking the menu away from fine dinning to more affordable menu with high quality ingredients.
Zellers keeps the high quality ingredients by serving fresh farm to table items on the menu, fresh farm items that come from Caroline County and other counties across the Mid-Shore.
"Ingredients is always the No. 1 thing," Zellers said.
Starting with a good ingredient is important, he said, plus it supports the local economy and the community, not to mention local farms.
"I think that's the biggest thing like just the quality of the ingredient. You just put that on the plate and let it shine, and you don't have to do much to it," Zellers said. "I think it's a big part of why people have taken to our food so so much because we really can't mess it up because the flavor's there."
The Zellers have added an enclosure onto the porch for extra seating for the winter and summer days. Next to the restaurant is Caroline's side bar which features outside and inside seating with a different menu than Caroline's in Denton. Zellers called the outdoor seating "beautiful."
With plans of more expansion, Zellers says the love and growth Caroline's in Denton has seen still hasn't hit home for him yet.
"This is always going to be the baby, we're always going to make sure this is taken care of, but it's just like I said, I don't think it's hit me," Zellers said. "I could have never imagined especially a restaurant that's this beautiful that I would be the owner of it, but I fell in love with when I first interviewed with Nancy." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

It also mentions farm‑to‑table sourcing, giving secondary relevance to Agriculture and Environment.

title: Denton dress boutique expands operations with small business assistance
author: MARYLAND DEPARTMENT OF HOUSING AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT
content:
Denton dress boutique expands operations with small business assistance

 July 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARYLAND DEPARTMENT OF HOUSING AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT | Section: News 
 
 515
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Over two decades, Lizzie Hernandez and her mother, Elizabeth Escobar, have transformed a dream that began in their home into a flourishing cornerstone of their local community.Escobar created Betty's Boutique in 2012 and began sewing and tailoring wedding gowns, prom dresses, quinceañera dresses, suits and tuxedos — all out of her living room. By 2019, she was able to open the first brick and mortar iteration of Betty's Boutique, a small shop in Denton.
But, as was the case for many small businesses, the pandemic came as a big challenge.
"We were shut down, and a little bit lost as to where we were going to go from here, y'know, to not have to close down," Hernandez said. "And then my mom had an idea from my aunt, to start making masks for the family. Sooner or later, we made an entire operation out of it. We sold over 30,000 masks."
As word spread, the Denton community rallied behind Betty's Boutique, purchasing so many masks that by the time lockdowns were lifted, demand for the boutique had soared. Escobar and Hernandez were thrilled, but as a team of two, they struggled to keep up with community interest.
"This business is run by just me and my mom, which puts a lot of pressure on both of us — I'm at the front of the house and she is basically at the back of the house, so it's her brand, but I'm the one who is taking the appointments, organizing everything, doing the social media," Hernandez said.
The Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development's Neighborhood BusinessWorks Program was able to alleviate some of this pressure. With $26,355 in funding from the Business Boost Microgrant program, Betty's Boutique has been able to hire additional staff, delegate tasks and take in more clientele.
Business Boost awards are offered through the department's Neighborhood BusinessWorks program and provide applicants with microgrants ranging from $20,000 to $50,000 to support growth or expansion opportunities. In fiscal year 2025, Neighborhood BusinessWorks provided $21.2 million in investments to 108 small businesses across Maryland — including Betty's Boutique.
This extra support has given Betty's Boutique the ability to give back to the community of Denton.
"We may be a very small, quiet, out-of-the-way town, but I will say the town has been nothing short of incredible. With all sorts of diversity, we have been able to connect with many communities," Hernandez said. "And we have now actually been able to offer free sewing classes with our local church every Saturday."
Hernandez and Escobar look toward the future, with plans to one day expand into casual wear and create their own designs.
"My mom has been building this business since 2012, and although we've had many, many hiccups, as many times as she wanted to throw in the towel after having to start over again, she never did," Hernandez said. "She kept going, she kept showing up, to not only prove to herself but to be an example to others, that no matter what, as long as you put the work in, the results will come — with time, patience and discipline, for sure." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a small dress boutique receiving microgrant funding and expanding operations, which aligns primarily with business and economic development.

title: New Wendy's coming to Denton
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
New Wendy's coming to Denton

 July 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 229
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — A Wendy's is coming to Denton.In November of 2024, the public heard a request by Bohler Engineering for property owned by Strato Holdings LLC. for a major site plan application to construct a Wendy's fast-food restaurant to be located at 601 Legion Rd.
In May, the application was approved by Denton Planning and Codes. Now, construction has started on Legion Road to expand the road connected to the Taco Bell and Dunkin Donuts, creating a lane for the new Wendy's.
"At this point in time, what they're doing is they're actually taking and extending the road that goes behind Taco Bell. It actually comes in and goes into the property where Dunkin Donuts is," Bill Clemens, building code official and property maintenance inspector for Denton Planning and Codes, said to the Star Democrat on Wednesday.
"So that road will go back and wrap around Dunkin Donuts, and then they'll develop the site for Wendy's. So that's the starting point."
According to Denton Planning and Codes department, without any delays, the Wendy's should be up and running no later than the end of the year. Clemens expects the Wendy's to be a good economic addition to Caroline County.
"It's going to do the same thing all the others have done. They offers options, brings jobs/ It'll bring revenues to both the town and the county," Clemens said. "It's a good name brand."

title: Hand specialist surgeon joins Orthopedic Center
author: Staff Writer
content:
Hand specialist surgeon joins Orthopedic Center

 July 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Business 
 
 197
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Orthopedic Center has welcomed orthopedic surgeon Dr. Rowan Michael to its provider team. The Orthopedic Center is an affiliate medical practice of University of Maryland Shore Regional Health, a member organization of the University of Maryland Medical System.Michael is board certified in orthopedic surgery, with a subspecialty certification in hand surgery, by the American Board of Orthopaedic Surgery.
He earned his Doctor of Medicine from Rutgers' Robert Wood Johnson Medical School in New Brunswick, New Jersey, and his Bachelor of Science from the University of Delaware in Newark, Delaware.
He completed a hand and upper extremity fellowship at University of Florida — Shands Hospital in Gainesville, Florida, and his residency at Dartmouth Orthopaedic Surgery in Lebanon, New Hampshire.
Michael has earned numerous accolades, including "Top Doc" recognition from Main Line Today and the prestigious Bruce Fisher Award, presented to the top two graduating medical students in each class.
"We are thrilled to welcome Dr. Michael to our practice starting July 1," said Dr. Thomas Stauch, principal provider at the Orthopedic Center. "His specialized expertise in hand and upper extremity conditions will be a tremendous asset to our community."
To make an appointment with Michael, call The Orthopedic Center at 410-822-8226.
