title: Four join Shore Regional Health Board of Directors
author: Staff Writer
content:
Four join Shore Regional Health Board of Directors

 August 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Business 
 
 738
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The University of Maryland Shore Regional Health Board of Directors recently welcomed four new members: Aaron Gabrielian, Pamela Metz Kasemeyer, Michael Molino and Kevin M. Morgan.The Board's membership includes representatives from the five counties served by Shore Regional Health, the regional physician community and the University of Maryland Medical System, of which Shore Regional Health is a member organization. In addition to these new members, the following members have been elected as new officers on the board: Steve Satchell has been elected to serve as chair and Marlene Feldman as vice chair.
Gabrielian, of Easton, is senior vice president-branch director and senior portfolio director of the Coastal Private Wealth Group at RBC Wealth Management in Easton. He began his career as a financial adviser at Morgan Stanley and prior to joining RBC, worked at a leading independent advisory firm providing family-office style investment advisory services, business succession planning and estate preservation strategies to some of the nation's most successful business-owning families, institutions and endowments. He has extensive experience managing individual investment portfolios on a discretionary basis and providing multigenerational wealth planning to corporate executives and business-owning families.
Gabrielian graduated from Towson University with a Bachelor of Science degree in finance where he played baseball and was the recipient of the Towson University Tiger Leadership Award for his efforts on and off the baseball field. He went on to graduate study in financial planning through New York University. He holds active volunteer roles with several local organizations including the Mid-Shore Community Foundation Board of Directors, The Sultana Education Foundation Board of Directors and Shore Regional Health Board of Directors, where he serves as chair of the Finance Committee.
Kasemeyer, of Easton and Columbia, Maryland, currently serves as director of the Office of Government Affairs for Baltimore County. She was formerly a partner with Schwartz, Metz, Wise and Kauffman, P.A. in Baltimore, representing business, professional and trade associations before Maryland's legislative and executive branches. Before joining Schwartz, Metz, Wise and Kauffman, P.A., Kasemeyer held several positions, including associate attorney at the law offices of J. William Pitcher, executive director of the Maryland Delaware Solid Waste Association and director at the Maryland Association of Health Maintenance Organizations.
Kasemeyer earned a Juris Doctor from the University of Maryland School of Law, a Master of Health Services Administration from George Washington and a Bachelor of Arts in public policy studies from Duke University. Her bar admissions include the Maryland Court of Appeals, the United States District Court-District of Maryland and the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals. Kasemeyer is chairman of the Board for Sisters Circle, a mentoring organization in Baltimore City, and serves as a court-appointed special advocate for CASA on the Mid-Shore.
Molino, of St. Michaels, is executive vice president of corporate growth for SeaCorp, an engineering and technology company that builds electronic systems for submarines and related technology solutions, where he oversees corporate strategy, mergers and acquisitions, business growth and federal government affairs.
Before joining SeaCorp, Molino served in similar positions at ASRC Federal and Leidos, both government contracting firms. Prior to working in the private sector, Molino served in the U.S. Army, handling various logistics roles and leading deployment exercises, natural disaster relief and training programs. He continues his military service by volunteering on the Army Science Board, where he reviews Army projects involving robotics, personnel management, nuclear testing and technology. Molino earned a Bachelor of Science degree from the U.S. Military Academy at West Point and a Master of Business Administration from Cornell University.
Morgan, of Cambridge, currently serves as regional health and wellness senior director for Sam's Club Inc., based in Annapolis. In this role, he oversees a large network of pharmacies, as well as optical and hearing centers, across 12 states. During the COVID-19 pandemic, Morgan played a key role in the vaccine rollout within Walmart, collaborating with Walmart Supercenters, Sam's Club and Neighborhood Markets to deploy immunization services across the various retail platforms supporting all 50 states and Puerto Rico.
Morgan served as a commissioner on the Maryland Board of Pharmacy from 2016 to 2024, including three terms as board president. He has represented Maryland as a delegate to the National Association of Boards of Pharmacy and contributed as a member of multiple pharmacy committees. He holds a Doctor of Pharmacy from Shenandoah University and a Bachelor of Science in biology and environmental studies from St. Lawrence University. His professional certifications include APhA immunization delivery, American Board of Opticianry and basic life support. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Hot or not?: Trump touts U.S. economy but businesses are leery of what lies ahead
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS Adams MultiMedia
content:
Hot or not?: Trump touts U.S. economy but businesses are leery of what lies ahead

 August 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS Adams MultiMedia | Section: Business 
 
 1108
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Is the U.S. economy hot, cooling or somewhere in between?President Donald Trump and his acolytes say the U.S. economy is humming, citing rising stock markets, big promised corporate and foreign direct investments and lower gasoline prices.
"We have the hottest country on Earth. We have the hottest economy on Earth," Trump said earlier this month.
"We have hundreds of billions of dollars falling in from tariffs …One year ago we were dead as a door nail. Now, we have the hottest country," Trump continued.
The White House touts $8.7 trillion in announced or promised U.S. investments since Trump took office in January from corporate titans such as Apple, NVDIA and IBM as well as countries such as United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Japan and Qatar.
Trump's always-vociferous critics counter that the cost of housing, child care and groceries are still high compared to before the resets of the coronavirus pandemic, and they worry about the president's very-malleable tariffs regime driving up prices and straining supply chains.
Some economists and analysts see the potential for slower growth and hiring combined with higher prices from tariffs and post-pandemic inflation. Some employers are also looking to artificial intelligence and robotics to take over some workers' duties.
A new forecast from Capital Economics released Aug. 25 foresees 690,000 new jobs created in the U.S. over the next 12 months, 64% less than the jobs created in 2024, according to reports by the Telegraph and Business Matters. That comes after major revisions trimmed recent government jobs growth numbers.
'HOLDING PATTERN'In the middle and on the frontlines of the economy, some businesses loaded up on inventory and materials from China and other importers to help stave off some of the impacts of Trump's tariffs.
Other business owners are in a wait-and-see mode for the impacts of the tariffs and other Trump economic policies with job growth slowing and wholesale prices coming in higher than expected in July.
"A lot of people are really in a holding pattern with spending," said Nathan Green, CEO of Next Level Radio. The Maryland-based company provides radio and music content to hotels, casinos and other venues in 29 U.S. states.
Green sees some more careful spending among both businesses and consumers.
"People are just not sure if the other shoe is going to drop," Green said.
Melissa Katrincic, co-founder and CEO of Conniption Gin in Durham, North Carolina, has also been navigating the Trump landscape.
The downtown distillery sources its juniper berries for its gins from Albania and Bulgaria. Trump has imposed a 10% tariff on Albania while Bulgaria is part of the European Union, which is currently subject to a 15% U.S. tariff rate under the most recent deal with Trump.
Katrincic said her distillery gets its bottles and glassware from China.
"We source from China for a custom bottle design," she said. "We over-purchased at the end of 2024 knowing there could be a lot of uncertainty."
Trump kicked the can until November with trade negotiations with China. The current U.S. tariff rate on Chinese imports is 30%. Trump's use of emergency powers to invoke some of his tariffs faces legal challenges.
Katrincic is keeping tabs on tariffs as well as broader trends such as consumer spending, travel, inflation and social connections.
She is hoping to see a rebound in "ritualistic pauses" such as having a drink after work or before a special event, noting how those activities were lost during the COVID-19 pandemic.
TRAVEL TRENDSThe summer tourism season has seen a similarly mixed picture.
Diane Medler, executive director of Discover Kalispell in Montana, saw a drop in tourism activity in the spring and early summer but was more optimistic about the rest of summer and into the fall. The Kalispell area is home to Glacier National Park and has other outdoor attractions.
"We do anticipate more road trippers throughout the summer and into fall," she said.
Medler has seen a "steep decline" in Canadian tourists. Trump's tariffs and previous jabs of making Canada the 51st state have made him unpopular north of the border impacting tourism to the U.S.
Like other tourism groups, the Montana organization has been putting an emphasis on attracting visitors from nearby markets.
Consumers and businesses are still impacted by post-pandemic inflation.
U.S. prices are up 26% from the end of 2019 and before the COVID-19 pandemic, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.
U.S. households are carrying a record $18.39 trillion in debt, according to the New York Federal Reserve Bank.
"We are placing a heavy emphasis on drive market traffic, specifically Montanans who are looking to explore closer to home, as well as Spokane and Seattle," Medler said.
Annette Brown, chief marketing officer at Visit Temecula Valley in California, said her group has seen continued healthy visitations from Canadians.
"For the remainder of this year, we've paused all international PR and marketing efforts, except for Canada, where we're still seeing demand that justifies continued investment," she said.
Brown also sees more road trips.
"This year, driving vacations, or road trips, are a prominent trend. Many travelers are opting for road trips to have greater flexibility for exploration and to avoid the costs and potential hassles of air travel," she said.
'PROCEED CAREFULLY'As of close of Thursday trading, U.S. stocks markets are up for the year with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up more than 7%, the S&P 500 is up more than 10% and the Nasdaq is up more than 12%, according to Google Finance.
Stocks jumped Friday after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell indicated the central bank was getting ready to cut interest rates.
Trump has been pressuring Powell and the central bank to cut rates.
Powell has been reticent to cut rates citing uncertainty about tariffs. On Friday, Powell indicated that sentiment is changing during remarks in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, at the annual meeting of U.S. and global elites.
"The stability of the unemployment rate and other labor market measures allows us to proceed carefully as we consider changes to our policy stance," Powell said.
The U.S. jobless rate is currently 4.2%. Gas prices stand at $3.16 per gallon on average nationally (as of Monday, Aug. 25), according to AAA Fuel Gauge Report. That is down from $3.35 per gallon a year ago and the record-high $5.02 per gallon set in 2022.
Wall Street reactively negatively to Trump's higher tariffs pushes but then rallied when the president eased the U.S. stance, retreated or "taco-ed" (Trump always chickens out) as part of negotiations, according to University of Michigan economist Justin Wolfers, a Trump critic.
"The stock market is not the economy, but if you listen carefully, the stock market can be informative, " Wolfers said in a social media analysis. "Every time Trump leans into his economic instincts — threatening tariffs, undermining the Fed, or destroying institutions, stocks tank. Every time he tacos, they bounce back." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on U.S. economic performance, tariffs, business sentiment, job forecasts, and stock market reactions, which aligns directly with the Business/Economy topic.

title: St. Michaels prepares for tourism drop, but the businesses are ready
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com

St. Michaels prepares for tourism drop, but the businesses are ready

 When you think of St. Michaels, you often think of tourists coming to see the town's many sights.While walking around the streets of St. Michaels Wednesday, I talked to multiple business owners about the tourism season and how they prepare for the fall and winter months, when there are fewer tourists around.

title: St. Michaels businesses prepare for tourism drop in the fall
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
St. Michaels businesses prepare for tourism drop in the fall

 August 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 377
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — The summer tourism season comes to an end after Labor Day. For multiple businesses in St. Michaels, it could mean a slow down in business.Businesses in St. Michaels are preparing for the fall and winter months by cutting back on some costs.
"It's something that we know is coming every year," Craig Schury, owner of Pemberton Pharmacy & Gift St. Michaels, said. "This year has been a little more difficult than most, so we're prepared. We pair down our staff a little bit and we try to keep our merchandise pretty tight. If we control those cost, we know we can be alright."
According to some business owners in St. Michaels, this year's tourism season has not been as good as previous years. While data specific to this year's tourism in St. Michaels is not yet available, domestic tourism nationally has seen a slow down.
According to Bank of America, their aggregated card data showed softer lodging, tourism and airline spending in 2025.
Some St. Michales businesses plan shift merchandise to fit with upcoming seasons in hopes of keeping revenues up.
"We have less families in the fall, more couples, more anniversaries, more getaways, baby moons once the kids are back in school," said Courtney James, manager for The Preppy Redneck store.
"So, it's a different vibe in that a lot of people stop on their way to the beach in the summer and they have more families. Boating season also goes into October. So, a lot more people when it's cooler come out on their boats, um, which is a different vibe too. Each one brings kind of a different vibe."
While the shift in merchandise and savings is key for business, the one major factor business owners hope to continue to see during the fall and winter months is support from the local community.
"It's paramount," said Jay Hudson, owner for Blue Heron Coffee. "We're here for the community, so having the community support throughout the winter means the world. I look at the community as more of the sustainable business model, they're here every day, so their support means all the world. Tourism kind of comes and gos, but to have the community support, not just through the winter, just in general, means the world to a business." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: QAC Economic and Tourism Development welcomes Manufacturers Roundtable
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QAC Economic and Tourism Development welcomes Manufacturers Roundtable

 September 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 362
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — Local manufacturing representatives gathered to hear about available resources and opportunities to connect during a Manufacturers Roundtable with the Queen Anne's County Economic and Tourism Development at Chesapeake College Aug 28.Collaboration is the key to economic and workforce success, and QACETD welcomed manufacturers, county officials and regional partners for open dialogue on training initiatives, grant resources, technology adoption, supply chain resilience, and policy support as well as a tour of Chesapeake College's Advanced Manufacturing Program.
Serving as the voice of manufacturers across industries and regions of the state, Maryland Manufacturing Extension Partnership is a nonprofit focused on growing and strengthening Maryland manufacturers.
Maryland MEP Executive Director Mike Kelleher said finding, recruiting and keeping qualified talents is the number one challenge faced by manufacturers.
There is no one-size-fits-all for training and Maryland MEP has a number of programs to support honing qualified talent and helping companies apply and find services and programs, including specific to rural manufactures, he said.
"It is important to improve the skills of the people," Kelleher said.
Providing a glimpse into what manufacturing officials are seeing out in the field, open discussion shared challenges in recruiting and marketing the availability of quality local jobs especially for a younger generation, as well as a lack of affordable housing and transportation.
QACETD Workforce Development Administrator Connie Dean stressed the power of connecting local business with local youth.
The county's Workforce Development supports opportunities for youth on-the-job training and experiences, especially those in technology and trade industries and since the implementation of high school career coaches, workforce development has increased the number of students in "career focused internships," Dean said.
Understanding students can't get interested about an industry they don't know about, this year, the department is moving forward to bring local industries to the students, with more career fairs and field trips to visit manufacturing areas in person, Dean said.
Partnering with QACTV, the department also highlights business and local field opportunities with career awareness videos to present in schools and online at QACTV.com.
Encouraging local industries to get involved with workforce development, "It's important to let people know what the business is," she said.
More information about QAC Economic and Tourism Development can be found at choosequeenannes.com.

title: A developer's dream: deep-water port and opportunity zone in Cambridge
author: Lily Tierney
content:
A developer's dream: deep-water port and opportunity zone in Cambridge

 September 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 534
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The City of Cambridge is the only city in Maryland that has a deep-water port and a designated opportunity zone.Having an opportunity zone is unusual for a waterfront community, which is why the city's recently proposed new comprehensive plan emphasizes this unique dichotomy. Opportunity zones are economically distressed areas designated by the state and federally funded to create economic growth and job opportunities.
The deep-water port and established maritime industry are significant assets for economic development, and the tax incentives that come along with the opportunity zone designation are attractive, said growth strategy advisor Shean Bourgeois, who is working with the city on its comprehensive plan update.
When city staff created the previous comprehensive plan in 2011, Cambridge did not have an opportunity zone designation. Now, the combination of the designation and the city's deep-water port are seen as significant assets to its economic growth.
In August, the city hosted a weeklong charette where residents could voice their opinions on the future of Cambridge's development. On the final day, representatives from Able City, the development company assisting the city with its comprehensive plan, presented the visions that came out of the charette.
"Right now, what we hear is that there's room for improvement when it comes to the mooring fields and the harbor facilities," Able City partner Jason King said. "What we hear is that there's room for improvement in terms of waterfront dining, the ability to pull your boat up to a restaurant, and there's not any sort of coherent waterfront walk."
Bourgeois said during the planning process, they looked at the things that set Cambridge apart from other cities on the Eastern Shore.
"The one that jumps out is the opportunity zone designation because it's federal. The state has to recommend which areas that fit the criteria. And then when you combine that with the fact that there's port access, really the only one on the Eastern Shore, it stands out," Bourgeois said.
Cambridge's 470-foot wharf is home to the only port on the Eastern Shore that has the depth, space and infrastructure to accommodate the largest and heaviest ships used in global trade. The deep-water port took shape in 1963 and was once the port of call for the Presidential Yacht, U.S.S. Potomac.
For King, the project is about more than just the port or the opportunity zones. It is about reconnecting the city to the waterfront. "Generally, when we talk about economic development for Cambridge, we talk about maximizing waterfront potential," he said.
King said it is important that the development project is equitable, ensuring that the economic development benefits all residents and does not displace existing businesses.
The charette presentation was a first step in the comprehensive plan, and the process of understanding the implications of the opportunity zone and deep-water port are ongoing, King said.
Currently, the plan is being drafted, which King said will take about 1,000 hours of work.
"Having worked previously with King and Bourgeois in both Florida and Georgia I can assure you that this will be a transformative document... a type of Comprehensive Plan that I suspect has not been seen before in Cambridge (or on Maryland's Eastern Shore)," Cambridge City Planner Brian Herrmann wrote in an email to the Star Democrat. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the city's deep‑water port and opportunity zone as drivers of economic growth and job creation, focusing on development plans and incentives, which aligns most closely with Business/Economy.

title: Taking stories on the road: Brackish Books mobile bookstore opens in QA
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Taking stories on the road: Brackish Books mobile bookstore opens in QA

 September 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 463
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTER — Understanding books can transport us to new worlds, a local business owner is taking that one step further by bringing that experience to the community with the opening of a new mobile bookstore, Brackish Books.Sharing a love of books with the community, former teacher and now Indie business owner Liz Gilbert along with her partner Ken Nyczaj, of Kent Island have converted a horse trailer into a whimsical mobile bookstore filled with a curated collection of new and used books for the community.
Proclaiming "Books, not bots,' Gilbert said, "In a world of algorithms and AI, we want to do things the old fashioned way."
With a new and used book selection spanning from history and biographies to the latest fiction, as well as selections of children's books, readers off all types are encouraged to discover hidden gems to "Treat your shelf for your TBR (to be read) pile.
All of us can be guilty of at least a little too much screen time, Nyczaj said, and the duo seek to foster closer camaraderie and reconnect the community with the joy of a good book.
"Reading to me is like education, meditation and relaxation all at once. We are the best versions of ourselves when reading becomes part of a daily routine," Nyczaj said.
Many of the curated books come from Gilbert's own collection as an avid reader seeking to share her passion with others and inspire a love of reading.
"We believe that humans will always learn more from books, not bots. We are a community focused on knowledge and growth from all genres of literature," she said.
Inviting everyone to pick up their next read, Brackish Books is interested in providing suggestions as well as listening to what the community is reading and catering to local tastes, according to Gilbert.
"We love to talk about books, recommend books and shout out our amazing local authors," Gilbert said, "Let's talk about books, and see if my TBR list matches yours."
Gilbert is immensely proud of her local authors section, highlighting the local talent of the area.
The trailers pop up locations are based on strong connections Gilbert and Nyczaj have made through their time living on Kent Island and the Eastern Shore.
"We improve our lives in more ways than one through reading," she said.
The ultimate goal is to open a Brackish brick and mortar bookstore, but for now the bookworm duo are happy to meet the community where they are.
Because, as the official Brackish Books' t-shirt merchandise proclaims, "Life is short, buy the books."
Beginning this month, Brackish Books is now a regular vendor at the weekly outdoor Kent Island Farmers Market from 3:30 p.m. to 6 p.m. outside Cult Classic Brewery.
More information including upcoming times and pop up locations can be found on the Brackish Books social media pages. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the launch of a mobile bookstore, highlighting the owners' entrepreneurial effort, market presence at a farmers market, and future business plans, making it primarily a business/economic story, with secondary ties to education and cultural aspects of reading.

title: Treasures resurface at Foxwell Auction
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Treasures resurface at Foxwell Auction

 September 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Headlines 
 
 229
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It appears that the Foxwell Auction on Aug. 13 had more valuables than the eye could see. A few weeks ago, I was alerted that a decommissioned Old Trinity Church sign was sold at this auction and returned the rector the following Sunday.Another story came out of this auction. Bernie Dryden perused every item of the large auction until he found an old Bible he described as "tattered" and had fountain ink stains from water damage over the years.
The Bible sat on the final table of the auction hall and he decided to purchase it for $12.50 to give to his grandson, who is studying theology. Upon getting home, he began flipping through the pages of the old text and realized it was a family bible.
Dryden read through the names listed in the birth, marriage and death records held within the religious text and found a familiar name. His grandson decided returning the Bible to the original family was the Christian thing to do.
Once again, a religious relic has gone home. Read this story and more from the day in today's edition. As always, thanks for reading.
Do you love puzzles? The Star Democrat is considering adding a daily puzzles page to stardem.com. We are looking for readers to test it and give us their opinion on the puzzles. Interested? Contact Executive Editor Jim Johnson at jjohnson@chespub.com.
— Lily Tierney

title: Popular brewery closes flagship Delaware location
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Popular brewery closes flagship Delaware location

 September 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 769
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Iron Hill Brewery, a mainstay of downtown Newark since 1996, abruptly closed its doors Wednesday.In a statement, the company said it made the difficult decision to close three of its restaurants "as part of the company's ongoing efforts to adapt to a changing business landscape while focusing on strengthening its long-term growth and success."
In addition to the flagship Main Street location, Iron Hill also closed locations in Voorhees, N.J., and in the Chestnut Hill neighborhood of Philadelphia.
"At Iron Hill, our team is deeply committed to creating memorable culinary experiences, award-winning beers and delivering exceptional hospitality," CEO Mark Kirke said in a prepared statement. "We're proud of the strong relationships we've built with our guests over the years and incredibly grateful for their loyalty. None of this would be possible without our dedicated teammates, who have made Iron Hill a place where great beer, great food, and genuine hospitality come together."
Sixteen other Iron Hill locations in Delaware, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Georgia and South Carolina remain open. The closest to Newark are at the Wilmington Riverfront and in West Chester, Pa.
"While we are closing a few locations, this is truly part of a larger growth story — we are evolving, strengthening our brand, and positioning Iron Hill for long-term success," said Kirke, who took over as CEO in January.
Iron Hill was founded in Newark in 1996 by Kevin Finn, Mark Edelson and Kevin Davies. Finn and Edelson were making beer out of home brew kits, and they teamed up with Davies to open the Main Street restaurant.
"At the time, Main Street was catering to undergrads with mostly pub-type food, so we were unique because we were offering something that was more upscale," Finn recalled in 2016 as Iron Hill was celebrating its 20th anniversary. "Main Street needed that and people really loved it. Iron Hill became a place where families could come to instead of a bar."
Since then, Iron Hill expanded into a multi-state chain and earned the coveted "World Champion Brewpub" title at the World Beer Cup several times. In 2016, the company announced it was partnering with a Connecticut-based private equity firm to accelerate its expansion along the East Coast.
On Wednesday, a company spokesperson would not provide details about why the company chose to close its Newark location, nor would she make the company's leaders available for an interview.
"Newark holds a very special place in Iron Hill's history as the community that helped the Iron Hill family grow from its very beginning," Danielle Guzzetta said in an emailed response. "The decision to close was not made lightly; it reflects the company's ongoing efforts to adapt to a changing business landscape while positioning Iron Hill for long-term strength and success. We are deeply grateful to the Newark community for its support over the years."
Though the company provided only vague answers Wednesday, during remarks Edelson made to Newark City Council last November, he hinted at financial difficulties for the Newark restaurant and said the number of customers patronizing Main Street businesses had decreased in recent years.
"We have less customer traffic than we ever have," Edelson said at the time. "It really started with COVID. COVID was terrible for the hospitality industry, and the hospitality industry continues to suffer from that. Load on top of that, we have the worst consumer downturn in the last 30 years right now."
In Newark, he said, one of the biggest issues is parking. He said parking in Newark was the second-worse in any town the company operated in. Phoenixville, Pa., where Iron Hill had just closed its restaurant, was the worst, he added.
Though Iron Hill is one of the few downtown Newark businesses with a private parking lot behind it, the restaurant's owners have long complained to the city about parking issues, including that non-customers were parking in their private lot.
In 2016, Edelson floated the idea of moving the restaurant out of Newark if the city didn't build a parking garage or pursue other solutions.
"Iron Hill is at a crossroads here in Newark," Edelson said in 2016 "As we come up on our latest lease renewal, we're left with weighing the decision to continue to do business in Newark or look for other options outside of the Newark property in New Castle County. Continuing to kick the can down the road gives us a signal that we can't look forward to the city supporting improving parking in the business district."
In 2019, Iron Hill's landlord, Tsionas Management, converted the parking lot behind the restaurant from a free lot reserved for Iron Hill customers to a privately-run pay-by-the-hour lot open to anyone willing to pay the fee. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily reports on a brewery's closure and its business strategy, financial challenges, and market conditions, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic, while also referencing city council and parking issues that relate to Local Government.

title: Waterfront project promises to transform Cambridge
author: BARBARA KNEPP
content:
Waterfront project promises to transform Cambridge

 September 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BARBARA KNEPP | Section: Columns 
 
 736
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In the heart of Maryland's Eastern Shore, along the scenic banks of the Choptank River, lies an ambitious vision for renewal: the Cambridge Harbor project. Spanning 30 acres of prime waterfront property, this initiative — led by Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. (CWDI) — promises to transform a neglected industrial site into a vibrant hub of economic opportunity.Imagine a boutique hotel anchoring the development, surrounded by retail spaces, residential units, public parks and a promenade that invites residents and visitors alike to stroll, shop and savor the river's beauty. Modeled in spirit after Baltimore's Inner Harbor, it's a project designed to boost tourism, create jobs and revitalize our community after years of planning and progress, including recent concrete pours on the promenade and ongoing talks with developers.
Yet, scroll through the Facebook comment sections under any local news post about Cambridge Harbor, and you'll encounter a digital deluge of negativity. A chorus of self-proclaimed experts — let's call them the "citizen know-it-alls" — chimes in with dire predictions, unfounded accusations and outright misinformation. These are folks with zero credentials in urban planning, economic development or environmental science, yet they post as if they've got Ph.D.s in all three.
"This will destroy the ecosystem!" one declares, without a shred of data. "It's a waste of taxpayer money!" another rants, ignoring the project's reliance on private investment and grants.
"Gentrification alert — say goodbye to affordable housing!" pipes up a third, overlooking the inclusionary plans for mixed-income residences.
Don't get me wrong: Healthy debate is the lifeblood of democracy, especially in a small town like Cambridge where everyone has a stake in our future. Questions about timelines, environmental impacts or funding are fair game and have been addressed through public meetings, environmental assessments and transparent updates from CWDI.
But what we're seeing isn't informed discourse — it's a toxic brew of speculation, conspiracy theories and knee-jerk negativity that clogs up comment threads and drowns out constructive voices.
The real danger here isn't just the annoyance of scrolling past these rants; it's the tangible harm they inflict on the project itself. Misinformation spreads like wildfire on social media, shaping public perception and eroding support among residents who might otherwise champion this revitalization. When baseless claims about "environmental disasters" or "corrupt deals" gain traction, they can sway local policymakers, leading to unnecessary delays in approvals or funding.
We've already seen tensions, like the 2024 lawsuit between the City Council and CWDI over land use, which was exacerbated by public outcry fueled by online hysteria.
Worse, this social media blitz has real-world consequences for the project's viability. Investors and developers, who are essential to bringing the boutique hotel and retail spaces to life, are increasingly wary of committing to projects mired in perceived controversy.
We've seen it happen: negative online campaigns have scared away potential partners who see the vitriol and question the community's support. This isn't speculation — it's a pattern seen in other developments where social media storms have chilled investment. Beyond that, the project's reputation, tarnished by relentless online attacks, can even impact its ability to secure insurance. In the eyes of insurers, reputation equals risk. A project painted as contentious or unstable becomes a liability, driving up costs or making coverage harder to obtain, which further strains the budget and timeline.
This echo chamber of uninformed outrage wastes precious resources. CWDI and city officials end up spending time debunking myths instead of building. In a community still recovering from economic challenges, every stalled month means lost jobs, untapped revenue from tourism, and a fading chance to make Cambridge a destination rather than a drive-through. The promenade's progress this year is a win, but imagine if unchecked negativity derails the next phases—residential builds, retail influx, or the waterfront park that's already breaking ground to enhance public access to the Choptank.
To these Facebook warriors: If you're passionate about Cambridge, channel that energy productively. Attend a CWDI meeting, review the official plans on their website, or volunteer with local groups focused on sustainable development. Expertise isn't born from a smartphone screen; it comes from facts, research and engagement.
And to the rest of us: Let's not let the loudest voices dictate our future. Support Cambridge Harbor not blindly, but with eyes wide open to its potential. Our town deserves progress, not paralysis from the peanut gallery. If we tune out the noise and focus on the facts, we can build a waterfront that benefits us all — for generations to come. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a waterfront development project aimed at boosting tourism, creating jobs, and attracting investment, which aligns most closely with Business/Economy. It also discusses city council actions and environmental concerns, making those secondary candidates.

title: Tariffs upending international economic order
author: MEL GURTOV
content:
Tariffs upending international economic order

 September 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MEL GURTOV | Section: Columns 
 
 988
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Tariff hikes across the board, political interference through trade threats, pressure on U.S. multinational corporations, supply chain disruptions — these are among the ways the Trump administration is trying to change economic globalization, from one based on consensus among the major trading states to one based on America First.Few countries find America First a model worth supporting.
Trump administration officials consider the global trading order established at the end of World War II "untenable and unsustainable," to quote Jamieson Greer, the U.S. trade representative. He writes about "American frustration at the system's failure to adapt to meet the essential needs of sovereign nations," which really means the U.S. alone.
The alternative? Not a new global system based on multilateral cooperation, since that would limit U.S. actions. Instead, the Trump people prefer "a mix of tariffs and deals for foreign market access and investment" — in other words, the approach taken with the European Union and Japan.
And as between tariffs and "deals," tariffs have priority because they can punish countries that have protected their markets and used various measures, such as subsidies and "lax labor and environmental standards," to enhance their trade position. China comes first to mind. The administration is determined to stop the consequent flight of US capital and production abroad.
This America First argument is a recipe for trade protectionism, the weaponization of tariffs and shakedown of U.S. corporations. We can see the early results: not a win for American workers and consumers, nor even for many multinational corporations, but another opportunity for the concentration of political power in the Oval Office.
Tariffs can be wielded to benefit those who are willing to play Trump's game: invest in the U.S. or suffer the consequences. In an unprecedented display of state capitalism, the administration has taken a slice of investment deals abroad — such as Nvidia's AI chip sales in China—and a government share in U.S. corporations, as in the Nippon Steel-US Steel deal and the 10% government share Trump demanded of Intel.
NEW TRADING ORDER
Trump's new trading order doesn't distinguish between friend and adversary. Tariffs are being imposed based mainly on political rather than commercial considerations. With few exceptions — Russia, so far, is one — high tariffs have hit India, Canada, Japan, South Korea and the European Union just as hard as they have hit China.
The U.S. trade deficit is rarely cited as the main reason for the high tariffs. India's purchases of Russian oil, Canada's constant criticism of Trump, South Korea's low level of military spending, Brazil's trial of right-wing former president Jair Bolsonaro and China's challenge to the U.S. as global leader — these are among the actual reasons for Trump's tariffs. He's a spiteful and vengeful man.
Careful reflection on the possible reactions of countries hit with the tariffs doesn't seem to have occurred in the Trump camp. Trump and his inner circle have always been oblivious to the power of nationalism abroad even as they nurture American nationalism.
The Canadians have turned to other markets and to "buy Canadian." No Kentucky bourbon on their shelves!
India is boycotting U.S. goods, and its leader is cozying up to Beijing and Moscow.
The Chinese have embraced self-reliance in computer chips, to the point where car manufacturers are being told to stop using foreign chips. A boycott of U.S. soybeans, sales of which Trump had insisted China should double, is underway.
Brazil's leader has firmly rejected Trump's interference in its judicial processes.
South Korea, Japan and the EU have all pledged major new investments in the U.S., knowing full well that they can string along the actual investment process — and might never have to make them at all if there's a change in administration.
Writing in Foreign Affairs, Michael Froman warns:
"If Washington continues on its current course — defined by unilateralism, transactionalism and mercantilism — the consequences will be grim, especially as Beijing continues on its own damaging course of subsidized excess capacity, predatory export policies and economic coercion. The risk of the United States and China playing by their own rules, with power the only real constraint, is contagion: if the two largest economies in the world operate outside the rules-based system, other countries will increasingly do the same, leading to rising uncertainty, drags on productivity and lower overall growth."
THE REAL WORLD
Blame should, however, fall mainly on the U.S., for while Trump is rejecting globalization, the Chinese are embracing it. If the entry of their goods into U.S. markets is proving too expensive, they are moving exports and production elsewhere.
The Chinese have become Global South leaders through their Belt and Road Initiative, which provides development loans, and through the export of goods, services and production lines, particularly to Africa and Southeast Asia but increasingly to Latin America. The more trade pressure Trump exerts, the better the Chinese look to many developing countries.
The U.S. economy is supposed to be the chief beneficiary of these trade policy shifts. But it's not happening. At a macroeconomic level, there is modest growth in GDP. And corporate profits are up. But most key indicators of economic health speak to serious problems already in sight or soon to be. Job figures are far below expectations.
Fortune magazine reports that a third of American CEOs plan to reduce their work force and increase prices. Farmers who rely on migrant labor are suffering. Consumer confidence and spending are down, inflation is moving upwards, home purchases are down and foreign tourism is way down. Some economists are predicting a recession, others stagflation.
Trump's tariffs are widely understood to be a national sales tax which, as Forbes reports, "will yank back from consumers' wallets about half the projected tax savings from the One Big Beautiful Bill's extension of the 2017 Trump tax cuts."
Yet Trump and his yes-men will continue to claim to the bitter end that all the bad news is fake and that tariffs are working as intended. But have you noticed that they now say the good news won't come until next year? 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses tariff policy, trade wars, and macro‑economic impacts, which are core subjects of business and economic news rather than local, cultural, or other categories.

title: Gas prices drop with more decreases on horizon
author: GAS BUDDY
content:
Gas prices drop with more decreases on horizon

 September 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GAS BUDDY | Section: State News 
 
 418
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 11.9 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.04 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 5.2 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 2.3 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has decreased 2.6 cents compared to a week ago and stands at $3.658 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.73 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $4.79 per gallon, a difference of $2.06 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 3.6 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.12 per gallon Monday. The national average is down 1.8 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 2.8 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
September 15, 2024: $3.07 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.15 per gallon)
September 15, 2023: $3.67 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.85 per gallon)
September 15, 2022: $3.43 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.68 per gallon)
September 15, 2021: $3.04 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.19 per gallon)
September 15, 2020: $2.25 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.18 per gallon)
September 15, 2019: $2.45 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.55 per gallon)
September 15, 2018: $2.83 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.85 per gallon)
September 15, 2017: $2.66 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.62 per gallon)
September 15, 2016: $2.15 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.18 per gallon)
September 15, 2015: $2.31 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.32 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.01per gallon, down 14.6 cents per gallon from last week's $3.16per gallon.
Washington, D.C.: $3.23per gallon, up 3.7 cents per gallon from last week's $3.19per gallon.
Hagerstown: $3.16per gallon, down 4.3 cents per gallon from last week's $3.20per gallon.
"While gas prices fell in more states than they rose last week, the West Coast continues to face challenges, with Oregon and Washington seeing some of the largest increases due to regional infrastructure issues," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "The good news is that the transition to cheaper winter gasoline begins tomorrow across most of the nation, and with improvements underway in the West Coast market, I expect that average gas prices will continue to decline in the weeks ahead in most states — assuming hurricane season remains quiet." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on recent changes in gasoline prices, includes market data and analysis, and discusses factors affecting fuel costs—content that aligns primarily with business and economic news.

title: Donuts on wheels: New food truck pops-up with a grand opening at vineyard
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Donuts on wheels: New food truck pops-up with a grand opening at vineyard

 September 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 374
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The panoramic view of Chesapeake Manor Vineyard in Stevensville became even more irresistible with the smell, sights, and tastes of fresh baked donuts as gourmet truck Gonuts Donuts celebrated its grand opening Sept. 13.A mechanic his whole life, owner Kevin Roskosky sought to try something new and out of the ordinary with his family, "and what's more fun than donuts?" he said.
Roskosky's expertise in vehicles lent itself to tricking out the self-built trailer for delicious donut goodness.
The family operation Gonuts Donuts crafts made to order donuts in a variety of flavors and toppings, including classics of chocolate and vanilla to Fruity Pebble, s'mores, and chocolate peanut butter. And sprinkles. Lots and lots of sprinkles. Through trial and error the family has perfected their tried and true recipes, he said.
The current seasonal fall flavor is maple bacon, a perfect combination of salty and sweet with homemade maple glaze and generous chunks of bacon.
Gonuts Donuts also sells snacks of fruit, chips and drinks.
Community reception for the donuts on-wheels has been overwhelmingly positive, Roskosky said, with eager crowds sugar-surging for dozens of donuts all throughout the opening day.
Taking in the scenic view of Chesapeake Manor Vineyard while the rest of the family played nearby was mother and daughter Beverly Coursey and Jessica Beckmann of Kent Island.
Their first time visiting the winery, it was when the two heard about the donut truck's pop up grand opening on Saturday that they knew they had to check it out.
Happy to support local businesses and enjoy a glass of wine with their donut, "They are delicious and have so many flavors," Beckmann said.
"Mimosas and donuts pair well, you can't go wrong," Coursey said.
The vineyard itself lent a wonderful atmosphere for the whole family, with plenty of activities and space for children, and a relaxing environment for adults to sit back, Beckmann said.
Providing surprise deliveries of fresh donuts to community members who go above and beyond, Gonuts is initiating a Donut Drop Poll, inviting the community to decide each week which Hometown Heroes to deliver to, including first responders, teachers, and doctor's offices.
Still looking into potential permanent locations, more information about Gonuts Donuts, including pre-ordering, and upcoming next stops can be found on Gonuts Donuts social media of Facebook and Instagram. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the launch of a new food‑truck business, its owner, menu, and community reception, and is placed in the Business section, making Business/Economy the most fitting category.

title: Ironman brings economic boost to Cambridge
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Ironman brings economic boost to Cambridge

 September 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 394
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Cambridge residents may have noticed it has been trickier getting around this past week.Traffic has increased, reservations at their favorite restaurant are difficult to get and all hotels and Airbnb's from Salisbury to Annapolis are filled, according to Operations Manager at the Ironman Angie Hengst.
1,250 athletes who will be participating in the Maryland Ironman on Saturday began making their way to Cambridge on Monday to preview the courses, enjoy their welcoming events and attend athlete briefings.
"Driving around town, it's about three times as busy as you would normally see it," Hengst said.
A few years ago, the Ironman did an economic impact study on Cambridge and Dorchester Counting post-event that discovered the event has a $7.14 million impact on the community, Hengst said. This number may have increased since the study.
This is the 11th annual Maryland Ironman, an extreme triathlon race that requires approximately 1,200 volunteers to pull off. The Ironman Foundation has grant funding available for local nonprofits that volunteer for the race, per this year's Race Director Brian Snow.
"We have over $40,000 in nonprofit money, and it goes to volunteers and groups to help stimulate the economy with people participating as volunteers," Snow said.
Both Hengst and Snow said Friday that they were still looking for volunteers for Saturday's big race.
The race will include a 2.4-mile swim in the Choptank River in between Gerry Boyle Park at Great Marsh and the Yacht Club, finishing at the boat ramp at Gerry Boyle Park. Next, there will be a 112-mile bike ride through Dorchester County and the scenic Blackwater Wildlife Refuge. The race will finish with a 26.2-mile run through historic downtown Cambridge and beyond.
Snow said athletes from all 50 states and over 30 countries will be participating on Saturday. He said every athlete generally comes with one other person considering the intensity of the race.
Both Snow and Hengst expressed their gratitude to the volunteers and residents of Cambridge and Dorchester County for being gracious hosts.
"I do want to put a huge thank you out to the community, you know, Cambridge, Dorchester County, everyone, for being so welcoming and supportive of the athletes," Hengst said.
"We're one of the smaller towns that hosts an event of this size, and we couldn't do it without the community's support. The athletes always comment about how nice everyone is and how welcoming it is here," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the economic impact and financial benefits of the Ironman triathlon for Cambridge, highlighting a $7+ million boost and grant funding, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic, though it also discusses the sporting event itself.

title: Easton business leaders reflect on summer, look ahead to fall
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton business leaders reflect on summer, look ahead to fall

 September 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 806
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — After an up-and-down summer with mixed results for local shops and restaurants, Easton business owners and leaders are keen for the fall season to start.Holly DeKarske, executive director of the Easton Economic Development Corporation, said when she's checked in with business owners across the town, they've been pleased with foot traffic as summer has come to a close.
"They admit it started out kind of rough, and there have been some slow days," DeKarske said in a recent interview. "But it's all been a, knock-on-wood, things seem to be up."
"We're hoping for a solid fall, Christmas season," she added. "It's gonna be fascinating to see how Christmas season goes. I don't have any idea."
Nanny Trippe, owner of the Trippe Gallery on North Harrison Street, said she's excited to see how foot traffic fares in the fall, especially with more weekend events. The Waterfowl Festival, slated for Nov. 14-16, is the main headliner.
The artist acknowledged the beginning of 2025 started off "wonky" and unpredictable due, in part, to national economic trends.
According to U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis data, consumer spending took a dip in May, a 0.2% drop from April. But that monthly change rebounded in June and July. In the latter, consumers spending on goods rose 0.9% from the month prior, according to the data.
For the restaurant scene, DeKarske said while new additions like the Washington Street Pub have provided a bump, national spending concerns are reflected locally.
"You can go in any of these restaurants right now and you'll see it's a little bit down," she said. "It costs a lot more to go out."
'UNCERTAINTY'
Trippe said she thinks unpredictability in foot traffic is common for years following a presidential election. But this year stood out to her.
"I've been in business here for 13 years and I've not heard this much uncertainty about the economy before," Trippe said.
Linda Laramy, owner of the Crackerjacks toy store on South Washington Street, said her business picked up as the summer went along. She said the slow start could have been from customers' concerns about tariffs, among other things.
"We had a fairly slow spring and May," Laramy said of the 46-year-old store. "But then starting in June, and July and August, we had a good normal amount of business and customers."
Tim Boyle, owner of Vintage Books, had an opposite trend, with a "phenomenal" spring that led into a more normal July and August.
"July and August typically are slower months for me, not too far off of January and February, because the visitors are generally heading to the beach," Boyle said. He expects business to pick up this fall.
DeKarske said the business landscape isn't usually as volatile as it has been this year.
"Usually you can kind of cruise into the season knowing what's going on," she said. "But right now with tariffs, you don't know what's gonna impact. People were trying to place orders, and then some of them are holding off on orders."
DeKarske said the fall and Christmas seasons will be especially interesting to watch through the lens of the economy.
MARKETING EASTON
With summer officially ending next week, event season is in full swing for Easton's downtown. The Easton Economic Development Corporation, or EEDC, spearheads many events, such as Fall Kickoff on Oct. 3 and 4.
But for non-event weekends, DeKarske said the nonprofit corporation homes in on digital marketing toward people that can make a one-day drive to Easton. That effort has yielded good results, she said.
And the focus isn't just on the downtown — businesses on U.S. Route 50, Easton Parkway and other areas of town are just as important, DeKarske said. One example is the Mistletoe Hall business park. This week, animal nutrition manufacturer Vetagro broke ground on a facility in the commerce park.
"We're hoping by now, having broken ground out there, that that'll bring a little more visibility, too," Klein said of the Mistletoe Hall area.
DeKarske and EEDC Board Chair Tom Klein noted multiple challenges with driving that EEDC tackles. Signage to direct travelers to downtown Easton is often limited on state roads or highways. But once visitors do explore the downtown, DeKarske and Klein said they're often looking to return.
While EEDC staff have consistent communication with Easton officials, it isn't an official entity under the town government. DeKarske said while that's been an obstacle in the past, there have been "huge strides" to better communication so that EEDC can advise businesses on construction and other town activities.
EEDC does have a memorandum of understanding with the Town of Easton to manage its arts and entertainment designation, visitor's center and economic development responsibilities.
Trippe, the art gallery owner, said the EEDC's staff have been helpful.
"They do a fantastic job of promoting all of the businesses," Trippe said. "They walk the streets, checking in to see what you've got going on, and maybe even inspiring you to do something special." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on local business conditions, economic trends, and the role of the Easton Economic Development Corporation, making Business/Economy the most fitting category.

title: Maryland gas prices up 2.2 cents over past week
author: GAS BUDDY
content:
Maryland gas prices up 2.2 cents over past week

 September 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GAS BUDDY | Section: State News 
 
 452
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have risen 11.3 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.16 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 2.7 cents per gallon higher than a month ago and stand 10.7 cents per gallon higher than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has increased 0.7 cents compared to a week ago and stands at $3.665 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.67 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $4.79 per gallon, a difference of $2.12 per gallon. The lowest price in the state yesterday was $2.67 per gallon while the highest was $4.79 per gallon, a difference of $2.12 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has risen 2.2 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.14per gallon today. The national average is unchanged from a month ago and stands 1.8 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
"The national average saw a slight increase last week, primarily driven by states that experienced price cycling just ahead of the switch back to winter gasoline," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "Florida, Ohio, Michigan and Maryland— all states known for routine price cycling— saw double-digit jumps to average gas prices."
He predicted the transition to cheaper winter gasoline and with driving demand seasonally tapering off as temperatures dip, gas prices face additional downward pressure.
"We're still on track to potentially see the national average fall below $3 per gallon for the first time in years this autumn," De Haan said.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
Sept. 22, 2024: $3.05 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.16 per gallon)Sept. 22, 2023: $3.62 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.84 per gallon)Sept. 22, 2022: $3.41 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.65 per gallon)Sept. 22, 2021: $3.09 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.18 per gallon)Sept. 22, 2020: $2.23 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.20 per gallon)Sept. 22, 2019: $2.59 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.66 per gallon)Sept. 22, 2018: $2.81 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.85 per gallon)Sept. 22, 2017: $2.57 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.56 per gallon)Sept. 22, 2016: $2.26 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.21 per gallon)Sept. 22, 2015: $2.25 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.28 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.15 per gallon, up 14.5 cents per gallon from last week's $3.01 per gallon.
Washington, D.C.: $3.21 per gallon, down 1.8 cents per gallon from last week's $3.23 per gallon.
Hagerstown: $3.10 per gallon, down 5.3 cents per gallon from last week's $3.16 per gallon.

title: Easton Crossing cuts ribbon on office; major construction to begin soon
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton Crossing cuts ribbon on office; major construction to begin soon

 September 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 314
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Construction on the Easton Crossing housing project on Brookletts Avenue will begin soon.The 116-apartment project, led by nonprofit developer Fello, will see site work begin this fall, project leaders said last Thursday at a ribbon-cutting ceremony. They opened the doors on a new leasing office at 407 Brookletts Ave. adjacent to the Easton Crossing site.
Ross Benincasa, Fello's senior vice president of community development, said demolition at the Easton Crossing site was finished earlier this summer.
"Early next year, we'll start to see vertical construction underway," Benincasa said.
Approved by the town earlier this year, the project is one of the larger housing endeavors in town, replacing the former Perdue AgriBusiness operation that used to occupy the space.
Elsewhere in Easton, Fello opened nine units and offices on Port Street in 2024 and received town approval for 28 townhomes at Silo Court, the second Perdue site bought by the developer to turn into housing.
Easton Crossing will include market-rate and affordable units. The units will not majorly differ based on the rates, Fello President and CEO Jonathon Rondeau said.
"Our philosophy for Easton Crossing is all about creating a neighborhood where everyone of all backgrounds, abilities and incomes can live together successfully," Rondeau said.
BuilderGuru Contracting and Gardiner & Gardiner Contracting will serve as the general contractors for the project.
In an interview, Rondeau said he was excited to get the leasing building opened as a preliminary step for the project.
"For us it was important that, while we're not yet leasing, that we show the community what's possible and what will be happening at this site," Rondeau said.
"I think people are still sort of cautiously optimistic," he added when asked about the project as a whole. "We're also respectful that people already live here, so there's a balance of making sure that we're not being intrusive to people's livelihood as we are going through construction."
This story has been updated.

title: Watermen oppose striped bass cuts, urge status quo at Chesapeake College forum
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Watermen oppose striped bass cuts, urge status quo at Chesapeake College forum

 September 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 1084
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — Eastern Shore watermen packed Chesapeake College on Monday and overwhelmingly opposed draft striped bass rules that would trim total removals by 12 percent in 2026 and could add more closures.The public hearing — organized by the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission and the Maryland Department of Natural Resources — drew more than 100 people, including county commissioners, council members and state delegates. By a show of hands, virtually every attendee opposed any change to current rules.
At issue is Draft Addendum III, the Fisheries Commission's proposal to support rebuilding the East Coast striped bass stock by 2029. The action seeks to reduce fishery removals by 12 percent beginning in 2026. For the commercial sector, the draft proposes a quota cut; for the recreational sector, it considers season closures and/or size-limit changes.
It also contemplates requirements for commercial tagging programs, a coastwide definition of total length for size-limit compliance, and changes to Maryland's recreational baseline season to simplify rules, improve enforcement and better align fishing access with release mortality and stakeholder input.
The Commission intends to take final action no later than October, with most measures implemented in 2026.
"Tonight is a way for the members on the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission to hear your concerns," said Mike Luisi, an associate director with the Maryland Department of Natural Resources' Fishing and Boating Services and a member of the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission. He later added: "The plan is to get the striped bass healthier so we can [return] to additional quotas in light of having a healthier population. That's the truth. It is to provide for a better stock so we can provide more quota back to the commercial industry and [lighten] restrictions on the recreational industry. For those who say we do not take the watermen's advice, we do a spring spawning stock assessment where watermen take us out on their routine."
Emilie Franke, a fishery management plan coordinator for the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission, walked the audience through the options, including a potential allowance for catch-and-release during part of the spring — a period that has been closed in recent years to protect spawning fish. That drew a sharp reaction.
"Catch-and-release will be on spawning grounds," said Brian Hardman, president of the Maryland Charter Boat Association. "How could you push this through knowing this information?"
Franke said striped bass–specific research about catch-and-release effects on spawning — such as impacts on egg production or pre-spawn behavior — is limited. "The research is inconclusive," she said, noting the technical committee is working to incorporate environmental factors into models where appropriate.
Speakers repeatedly pressed the agencies on data and modeling. Hardman questioned the federal Marine Recreational Information Program estimates. "The MRIP data that they use is off by about 40 percent," he said. "Maybe the numbers you are trying to hit are so artificially high we will never get there."
Delmarva Fisheries Association President Rob Newberry cited a Maryland study from the late 1990s to argue release mortality is higher than assumed. "There's 200 years of data you people have flagrantly not paid attention to," he said, urging the state and the Fisheries Commission to complete socioeconomic and pollution analyses before tightening rules. "Start using good science — it's there."
Robert T. Brown, president of the Maryland Watermen's Association, said the draft's rebuilding target is unrealistic. "You all are wrong that they put the target so high," Brown said. "You can only go so far until it is out of reach. You can't maintain it. When it comes to it, we've got so many rockfish out there now. The big fish are there, the small fish [are] coming back."
Elected officials echoed the industry's frustration. "Send this back, rework it," said State Sen. Johnny Mautz. "The reality of how this plays out is it is overburdening our local economy. Last year's impact from two fish to one fish was catastrophic."
Dorchester County Council member Mike Detmer said the draft has eroded trust. "I am deeply concerned about the 12 percent cut," he said. "What I hear is a lack of confidence in the board. The watermen are the most concerned to have a robust fishery. We have to protect this magical resource."
Wicomico County Council member James Winn urged the agencies to look beyond fishermen for causes. "Are we the issue?" he asked. "Could it be a menhaden fleet up in Virginia catching more than just menhaden? Have you done studies on other industries affecting the fish? Maybe we should be restricting what they're doing — not what we're doing."
Talbot Watermen's Association President Jeff Harrison said stricter rules have hollowed out traditional working communities. "When I ran charter there were about 40 [charter boats] on Tilghman," he said. "Right now there are three. It's hard to call it a fishing village anymore."
Del. Jay Jacobs called spring catch-and-release "the wrong direction," arguing it contradicts prior steps to protect broodstock. "It's an unscientific position to take without knowing the damage it's caused," he said. "We're here to maintain a historic livelihood."
Several speakers described the proposal as a choice between the status quo and more closures, with some options allowing spring catch-and-release. Many said they prefer no change. "Why haven't you considered giving us 12 percent back instead of taking?" asked waterman Dan Dierker. "Start talking to people who pay the most to fish, who have the most to lose. Stop listening to the wrong people like the CCA (Coastal Conservation Association).
Veteran Kent County waterman Don Pierce said cumulative quota cuts are pushing families out of the business. "I've been doing this for 60-plus years," he said. "You come in for one day, trying to run this industry. … Had a 12,000-pound quota when this all started. When you're done with this one, I'll have seven. Take a 50 percent cut in your salary, see how long you sit there."
Luisi said the Maryland baseline season concept grew out of feedback from many quarters — including watermen — and that nothing has been finalized for 2026. "We heard that it would be in Maryland's best interest to try to drive the economy," he said. "These changes weren't meant to harm anyone. They were meant to try to offset different times of the year."
What's next: The Fisheries Commission is scheduled to consider Draft Addendum III later this fall in Annapolis, with final action expected no later than October 2025 and implementation in 2026. Commercial tagging requirements, if adopted, could take longer to roll out. Maryland's DNR said it would carry comments from Monday's forum to the board. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on proposed striped bass quota cuts and their economic impact on local watermen, highlighting concerns about livelihoods and regional commerce, which aligns most closely with Business/Economy. Environmental aspects and local government involvement are also present but are secondary.

title: Elliott Road apartments to begin move-in this weekend
author: Konner Metz
content:
Elliott Road apartments to begin move-in this weekend

 September 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 347
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Town officials and project leaders cut the ribbon on a 136-apartment complex on Elliott Road on Wednesday.The Promenade at Easton is made up of four buildings, each with at least 30 apartment units. It will begin to welcome new residents this weekend.
The project, which sits right off of Matthewstown Road, was led by Mallard Construction Group.
Easton Mayor Megan Cook, Ward 2 Councilmember Robert Rankin and other town officials toured the apartments on Wednesday, getting a look at the first of four buildings at the site.
Jim DiDonato, president of Mallard Construction Group, thanked town officials and his team for making the project possible.
"We're glad that we can deliver a product that I think the town can be really happy with," DiDonato said.
Units include one-, two- and three-bedroom apartments. Amenities offered are a bike storage room, pickleball court, dog wash station, patio and more. The one-bedroom units start at just under $1,800 a month, while larger apartments range from $2,000 to $2,300, according to the complex's website.
Stephen Margerum, principal with Cove Property Management, said five people will move in this weekend, which will kick off a "consistent flow of move-ins" through November.
"We have a lot of demand, a lot of people wanting to move in as quickly as possible," Margerum said. "The response from the prospective residents have been really great."
He said the two 38-unit buildings will be filled out by the end of the year. The other two buildings, both 30 units and still under construction, will be delivered next spring, Margerum said.
Property management has been busy with tours and applications, he said. Before the leasing office was set up, more than 400 people signed up or went into the The Promenade's applicant database, Margerum said.
The Elliott Road project is one of Easton's larger housing developments, by units, currently in the pipeline. More than 1,000 units have recently opened, are under construction or have received town approval.
Earlier this month, developers for a downtown apartment complex on Brookletts Avenue cut the ribbon on a new leasing office. Construction on that 116-unit project begins later this fall.
