title: Delaware brewery closes remaining locations, will file for bankruptcy
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Delaware brewery closes remaining locations, will file for bankruptcy

 September 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 513
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Iron Hill Brewery closed all of its remaining locations on Thursday, bringing an unceremonious end to the restaurant that went from humble beginnings on Newark's Main Street to a regional chain with more than a dozen locations across several states.The decision is a dramatic reversal from just two weeks ago, when the company shuttered the Newark restaurant and two other locations but said 16 others would stay open.
"After many wonderful years serving our communities, all Iron Hill locations have closed. It has been our pleasure to serve you, and we are deeply grateful for your support, friendship, and loyalty over the years," the company said in a message to customers Thursday. "We sincerely hope to return in the future, and when we do, we promise to welcome you with open arms."
In an email to employees, the company said it plans to file for bankruptcy "due to ongoing financial challenges." It said the company did not warn employees of the pending closure because it was "working diligently behind the scenes" to find new funding sources.
Iron Hill was founded in Newark in 1996 by Kevin Finn, Mark Edelson and Kevin Davies. Finn and Edelson were making beer out of home brew kits, and they teamed up with Davies to open the Main Street restaurant.
"At the time, Main Street was catering to undergrads with mostly pub-type food, so we were unique because we were offering something that was more upscale," Finn recalled in 2016 as Iron Hill was celebrating its 20th anniversary. "Main Street needed that and people really loved it. Iron Hill became a place where families could come to instead of a bar."
In the decades that followed, Iron Hill expanded into a multi-state chain and earned the coveted "World Champion Brewpub" title at the World Beer Cup several times. In 2016, the company announced it was partnering with a Connecticut-based private equity firm to accelerate its expansion along the East Coast. It had locations in Delaware, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Georgia and South Carolina.
During remarks Edelson made to Newark City Council last November, he hinted at financial difficulties for the Newark restaurant and said the number of customers patronizing Main Street businesses had decreased in recent years.
"We have less customer traffic than we ever have," Edelson said at the time. "It really started with COVID. COVID was terrible for the hospitality industry, and the hospitality industry continues to suffer from that. Load on top of that, we have the worst consumer downturn in the last 30 years right now."
Still, Iron Hill took many customers and employees by surprise Sept. 10 when it announced it was closing its flagship Newark restaurant, along with locations in Voorhees, N.J., and in the Chestnut Hill neighborhood of Philadelphia. At the time, CEO Mark Kirke said the closures would help stabilize the rest of the company.
"While we are closing a few locations, this is truly part of a larger growth story — we are evolving, strengthening our brand, and positioning Iron Hill for long-term success," Kirke said, just two weeks before changing course and closing all the remaining restaurants. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the closure of a regional brewery chain and its impending bankruptcy, which are primarily business and economic news.

 September 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 The Chesapeake Bay Beach Club on Kent Island is building a new 32-room waterfront hotel called Wilson's Cove."The new hotel is aims to elevate the Beach Club as a premier Chesapeake Bay destination," the venue said in an announcements.

title: Maryland’s housing order aims to boost affordable housing, cut barriers
author: SANDRA SMITH Capital News Service
content:
Maryland’s housing order aims to boost affordable housing, cut barriers

 September 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SANDRA SMITH Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 638
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Gov. Wes Moore signed an executive order on Sept. 3 aimed at tackling Maryland's escalating housing affordability crisis. The Housing Starts Here initiative seeks to expedite housing development, reduce production delays and make home ownership more accessible across the state.According to the Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD), the state faces a deficit of around 96,000 housing units — a gap that has been widening over recent years.
The 2025 Maryland Housing Needs Assessment, an analysis of Maryland's housing gap conducted by DHCD and The National Center for Smart Growth, reveals significant disparities in housing availability across the state. Counties like Montgomery and Howard have median home prices exceeding $600,000, making homeownership unattainable for low and middle income residents.
Conversely, areas such as Allegany and Wicomico counties report median home prices below $200,000, which indicates regional inconsistencies in the Maryland housing market.
The executive order will broadly target each county in Maryland in order to create more housing development throughout the state.
"[The executive order] says that everybody has a piece of the housing crisis, and everybody deserves for their local and state governments to be working in concert to solve that crisis," DHCD Secretary Jake Day said.
In more than half of Maryland counties, renters are spending more than one-third of their annual income on housing costs, which is considered unaffordable by federal standards.
While Maryland's median income is 28% higher than the national median, the state's median home price is 35% higher, highlighting the disproportionate cost of housing.
"How we got here is really the post-2008 financial crisis. It was real-estate driven… that had to do with risks that the financial industry took at the time," Secretary Day said. "It led to a collapse in the economy, in residential home values and more. The over-correction of the market meant we stopped building houses at a pace that matched population growth."
The Housing Starts Here Executive Order directs state agencies to identify underutilized state-owned properties suitable for transit-oriented development, aiming to increase housing density in areas with existing infrastructure.
Transit-oriented development is a strategy that promotes dense, mixed-use communities around transit to help increase ridership and the use of public transportation.
"There are a lot of benefits to it… we want to develop state-owned land for transit-oriented development, since state-owned land is not currently taxable. There's no revenue generation for the states or local jurisdictions. It also provides an opportunity for Marylanders to live closer to transit and use it more," Maryland Department of Transportation's Chief of Real Estate and Transit-Oriented Development, David Zaidain, said.
According to Zaidain, transportation is the second biggest household budget item behind housing. It costs roughly $600 a month for Marylanders to own a car, which is pushing the state towards more transit usage.
Zaidain also noted the climate change benefits that come with transit-oriented development.
The executive order directs the state to speed up timelines for housing permits and establish a state housing ombudsman, or overseer, to help projects move forward.
The legislation comes on the heels of a 2024 legislative package that made housing more affordable and accessible for Marylanders struggling with construction barriers, along with creating the Office of Tenant and Landlord Affairs.
The Housing Starts Here order also directs agencies to track housing production progress annually, coordinate with local governments to address regional shortages and ensure accountability across jurisdictions.
By centralizing oversight and removing barriers, the administration aims to close the housing deficit and expand affordable options for Marylanders in the years ahead.
"When regulatory processes add cost, that cost has to be recouped — either with higher rents or a higher sales price. So, the more regulatory burden we place, the more likely it is that we're just producing expensive [places] for people to live," Secretary Day said. "By cutting time and money out of the process, by streamlining it, we can make it easier to get to the finish line." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a state executive order aimed at addressing the housing affordability crisis, discussing market deficits, pricing, and economic impacts, which aligns most closely with Business/Economy. It also involves government policy implementation, making Local Government a secondary match.

title: Longtime Caroline County trucker retires
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Longtime Caroline County trucker retires

 October 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 673
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — Guy Murphy loves to help people. For decades, he helped families on the Eastern Shore with everything from heating oil to pool water needs.After over 50 years in the trucking industry, Murphy is set to retire.
"It's something I didn't want to do, but it was time. My health wasn't get any better," Murphy said. "I'm going to do what I want to do, like travel and so on and so forth… try to take care of the grandkids."
Murphy was born in Baltimore in 1953 and moved to Caroline County in his youth. In 1974, at 21, Murphy started his career as a truck driver.
He worked at Lady Bug Lines in Harrington, Delaware for five years from 1987 to 1992.
In 1992, Murphy started his own business, Murphy Transport. In 1994, Murphy added a pool water company to Murphy Transport, and in 1998 he created America's Best Oil, hauling petroleum products and heating oil to multiple states around the county.
America's Best Oil helped with the fueling process for multiple Chesapeake island restoration projects.
"When they did Poplar Island, we loaded seven trailers in one truck on to the barges," Murphy said.
At both businesses' peak, Murphy operated 24 trucks and employed more than 30 people.
Murphy was involved in multiple aspects of his businesses including mechanics and dispatch. His wife of 53 years, Mary Lou Murphy, also played a significant role, handling home affairs and supporting him in his work.
Murphy's daughter, Kristy Murphy-Taylor, recalled her mother getting up at 4 a.m. to make her husband breakfast before a long day of work.
Despite financial challenges, Murphy's daughter said he prioritized helping customers, often providing services like emergency heating oil deliveries without extra fees, even if it meant personal sacrifice.
"If somebody ran out in the middle of the night, he would get up and take them heating oil, he'd restart their furnace for no fee. Any other company charges and people really appreciated that," Murphy-Taylor said.
Murphy recalled one customer during the winter afraid of running out of heating oil at her house. While this customer paid, some customers didn't, but Murphy looked at the potential for doing good.
"If that woman had not paid me, the way I looked at is five to 10 other customers called that did pay, that would that would justify for that one lady not paying. That's the way I always looked at business," Murphy said.
Murphy believed in helping the community and that positive word-of-mouth would ultimately benefit the business.
Due to a diagnosis of lung cancer in 2022 and amyloidosis, a rare blood disease, Murphy sold his business on Feb. 28. Throughout his long years in business, Murphy touched many hearts.
Mansour Ali worked for Murphy Transport for over 25 years. Ali enjoyed every year working under Murphy.
"Back in the day, Murphy was just getting started, and he was a hard worker and he wanted hard working employees. I stayed with Murphy for as long as I did because it was the best job I ever had and the best employer that I ever worked for," Ali said.
Ali recalled Murphy coming out to help him with a flat tire in the middle of the night.
"You would call him and he would get out of his bed for flat tires, he would bring his trailer over and he would actually change the tires himself," Ali said.
"One time I had been running all day and I happen to see him pass me going in the opposite direction. I called him and asked 'what you doing over here?' He said 'I got all this work in here and I don't got nobody to do it.' So he would come out and do it himself. I said, 'Man send me half of whatever you got.' If he had six loads, send me half of them, and we stayed out there until that work was done," Ali said.
"That's how really he got his name, because he wouldn't turn any work down and companies knew when you call Murphy Transport, they're going to get the load to you," Ali said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a longtime trucker’s retirement, his entrepreneurial ventures, and impact on the local economy, making Business/Economy the most fitting category. Health is mentioned only in relation to his personal diagnosis, and there is no focus on government actions.

title: New life for historic general store
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
New life for historic general store

 October 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 854
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Nelson and Jeania Stewart have transformed a historic general store into Harper's Coffee Tavern and Shelter & Co., a combination coffee shop and antique emporium that the couple hopes will become a community gathering place in the small Kent County town of Still Pond.As Halloween approaches, Harper's Coffee Tavern and Shelter & Co. has opened in the historic W.M. Medders & Co. building, offering coffee, antiques and a Gothic atmosphere unlike any chain store.
At the intersection of Main Street and Still Pond Road the Stewarts prepare for their favorite holiday, emblematic of the looming pumpkin figure on the roof glowing in the night sky.
Open now from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Fridays and Saturdays and Sundays from noon to 4 p.m., they invite visitors to stop for a brew and to browse their collection.
William Medders purchased the store from George Harper operating it from 1894-1959. During that time, he expanded the business by selling housewares and grocery items.
Carrying on the Medders' shopping tradition, the Stewarts offer more than coffee to the community.
This is not a Starbucks.
And not Dunkin'.
Those designer coffees will eventually be offered, but it is the enriching experience that sets Harper's apart. Entering Harper's is like journeying into a world of classical novels and Edgar Allen Poe stanzas.
In the serving area, patrons are treated to a spacious Victorian/Gothic atmosphere. Busts of historical figures, candelabras, vintage furniture, beautiful designs, musical instruments, paintings and art sculptures are featured.
Beyond a donated piano and latticed windows are classic books inviting customers to stay for a while, read and enjoy the atmosphere.
In time for Halloween, there are skulls, werewolves and horror/suspense type imagery everywhere, like in the bird cage displayed there is a sculpture of novelist Stephen King's "It" clown facing off with the demon from "Legend."
There are werewolves, hanging bat skeletons, a giant skull with glowing eyes, a face in a jar and coffin-shaped cabinets.
Above the comfortable seating area hangs a message, "Needful Things" a King story about neighbors taking the Faustian bargain (deal with the devil).
"If you appreciate art, history and especially mystery, this is the place for you," Nelson said.
An area inspiring creativity is ideal as Nelson and Jeania are founding members of The Devil's Brigade, an international Celtic band known for its epic, multi-instrumental sound including jigs, reels, hornpipes, ballads, originals, covers, soundtracks, patriotic and military music and Irish foot-stompers.
Sitting down with them and their dogs, especially little Kaiser, (don't mistake his cuteness for weakness) they have intriguing stories behind their items.
They talk about touring cities, his love of teaching, the interesting people they meet day by day and their plans to make Still Pond a place to host community events.
For both, having an establishment like this has been a dream. They are looking on ways to improve upon it in increments with Jeania lending her talents of art, sculpting, and textile conservation as well as plumbing, roofing, flooring and carpentry.
"She does it all," Stewart said with a smile. "And I do as she says."
The Stewarts are now closer to their goal of keeping Harper's open more often. Finding someone like-minded, matching the duo's energy furthered that mission along. Jeania said she sensed that regular customers Marion Green from Rock Hall, with his girlfriend Nicole Sheffer were the right people to oversee the shop while out of town. "I knew right away I could trust them. Now we can go away and keep the store open. It really helped open things up," Jeania said.
Exiting Harper's, the antique portion of the location is called Shelter & Co. Inside, the Stewarts and Green offer their world of antiques and many other items. Everything is for sale, Jeania pointed out.
The downstairs portion holds Green's collections through the years, antiques and art deco items like animal sculptures, shot glasses, vintage bottles, models and more. Upstairs are Jeania's items. There are quilts, bedspreads, fine china, paintings, mirrors and even old documents left from George Harper in the late 1800's.Tourists, yard sale enthusiasts and lovers of antiques can spend hours browsing through all the items.
The amount of goods on both sides of the building might have made Medders proud.
Upstairs, encased in glass there is an old Baltimore Sun article about his life and vision for the store. Reporter, Walter V. Brooks wrote about it: "During these days of drastically curtailed retail stocks and critical goods, a trip to the store is like a visit to Aladdin's cave."
That certainly could sum up an experience at Harper's and at Shelter & Co.
Nelson envisions the place as a meeting and gathering hub and for hosting events such as birthdays and weddings. "I like to see it as a destination for learning and big dreams. There's something magical about Still Pond."
Stop in and visit Nelson and Jeania or see them perform at the Fairfax Fall Festival Oct. 11. Nov. 7-8, they will be at the the National Navy UDT-SEAL Museum in Florida supporting veterans, a cause they are passionate about, and then back performing at the annual Dickens of a Christmas, Dec. 5-6 in Downtown Chestertown.
Their albums can be found online and for information about renting the space contact them at info@thedevilsbrigade.net. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the opening and operation of a new coffee shop and antique store, highlighting the owners' business plans, community role, and economic impact, which aligns best with the Business/Economy topic, though it also touches on arts, culture, and entertainment aspects.

title: Governor says shutdown hits Marylanders extra hard
author: HALEY PARSLEY and ALINE BEHAR KADO Capital News Service
content:
Governor says shutdown hits Marylanders extra hard

 October 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HALEY PARSLEY and ALINE BEHAR KADO Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 478
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Gov. Wes Moore last week blamed President Donald Trump for a federal shutdown that he says is landing especially hard on the Maryland workforce."Since Donald Trump has come on board, he has fired over 15,000 Marylanders that are federal workers," Moore said in a press conference. "Donald Trump doesn't have an interest in governing. He doesn't have an interest in a fully functioning relationship between the federal government and the states."
But state Republicans say Democrats bear responsibility for the fact that many Marylanders will be missing their paychecks until Congress can approve a continuing resolution that would keep the government running.
State Sen. Justin Ready, the minority whip, blamed Democrats in Washington and elsewhere for the shutdown.
"Maryland Democrats must abandon the political theater and focus on governing. They need to prioritize Maryland families first by putting D.C. grandstanding aside by supporting a clean CR to reopen the federal government," he said in a statement.
Trump has threatened mass government layoffs if congressional Democrats refuse to get on board for a Republican spending bill. And that means something in Maryland, where a huge chunk of the workforce is employed directly by the federal government, or is a contractor for one of its agencies.
In 2024, prior to job cuts under the Trump administration, an estimated 269,000 Maryland residents were employed by the federal government, state officials told reporters on Wednesday. They said about 210,000 were federal contractors.
Moore said that 15,000 jobs have already been cut in the past year. Now, those who are still on the payroll will go without paychecks, and those who are nonessential will be furloughed.
State officials can't do much to help those employees absorb the impact, but Moore vowed to do all he could to provide some support.
His administration plans to keep paying out for safety net programs, assuming they'll get their federal reimbursement as usual. They haven't heard otherwise, state officials told reporters last week.
The governor is asking the courts and utility companies to protect furloughed federal workers from eviction, foreclosure or utility shutoffs while they are involuntarily suspended from work. He's also expanding emergency assistance programs for federal employees.
But the state will not be able to support these programs indefinitely, Moore said. If the shutdown continues, the state and its residents face worsening consequences.
"We can see big infrastructure projects delayed," he said. "We can see military families, people who already sacrificed for this country, go without pay for weeks. We can see small businesses dip into the red."
Moore said that his administration will monitor and respond to growing uncertainty caused by the shutdown.
"We are going to do everything in our power," Moore said, "to make sure that, despite the federal government deciding to leave all of us on our own, that people in the state of Maryland will know that the state, at least, and this administration will continue to fight for them." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the economic impact of a federal shutdown on Maryland workers, state support measures, and implications for businesses, making Business/Economy the most fitting category.

title: Average gas prices drops to under $3 per gallon
author: Staff Writer
content:
Average gas prices drops to under $3 per gallon

 October 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 478
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 7.0 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $2.99 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 17.3 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 22.6 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has increased 1.1 cents compared to a week ago and stands at $3.663 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.69 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $4.79 per gallon, a difference of $2.10 per gallon. The lowest price in the state yesterday was $2.69 per gallon while the highest was $4.79 per gallon, a difference of $2.10 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 0.3 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.08 per gallon today. The national average is down 10.8 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 4.7 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
October 6, 2024: $3.22 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.13 per gallon)October 6, 2023: $3.44 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.71 per gallon)October 6, 2022: $3.56 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.90 per gallon)October 6, 2021: $3.13 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.22 per gallon)October 6, 2020: $2.26 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.17 per gallon)October 6, 2019: $2.50 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.65 per gallon)October 6, 2018: $2.84 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.91 per gallon)October 6, 2017: $2.45 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.49 per gallon)October 6, 2016: $2.24 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.26 per gallon)October 6, 2015: $2.23 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.29 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $2.96 per gallon, down 9.3 cents per gallon from last week's $3.05 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.14 per gallon, down 5.0 cents per gallon from last week's $3.19 per gallon.Hagerstown: $3.13 per gallon, up 5.4 cents per gallon from last week's $3.07 per gallon.
"While the national average slipped slightly over the last week, it's once again been a mixed bag depending on where you fill up," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "Gas prices cycled upward in Ohio and Michigan, declined in Indiana and Delaware, and pain is about to return to California and neighboring states following last week's refinery fire outside Los Angeles. While OPEC again agreed over the weekend to boost oil production for November, the real story for motorists has been regional variation — especially in areas served by California's supply system. Though the damage from the fire appears limited, the West Coast is likely to see prices climb, while most other areas can expect relative stability or slight declines." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Easton hosts Main Street conference; visitors weigh in on downtown atmosphere
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton hosts Main Street conference; visitors weigh in on downtown atmosphere

 October 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 738
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Many new faces walked the downtown streets of Easton this week for the second ever Main Street Maryland Conference.Hosted jointly by the Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development and the Easton Economic Development Corporation, among other partners, the conference brought Main Street managers and economic development officials together in one space to exchange ideas and advice.
Easton Mayor Megan Cook encouraged those visiting the town to take it all in.
"Look around and notice the historic buildings that anchor our downtown," Cook said during her opening remarks on Tuesday morning. "The parks and open space tucked throughout, and the small shops and restaurants that give our Main Street its unique energy."
On Tuesday and Wednesday, conference attendees walked the downtown streets, dined in restaurants and joined tours with local officials and leaders to learn more about Easton.
Lisa Challenger, executive director of the Beach to Bay Heritage Area encompassing Somerset, Wicomico and Worcester counties, said Easton's gardening and plants caught her eye.
"Somebody has really been paying attention and giving all of that lots of love," Challenger said. "No trash. Your first impression is just, 'Wow, it is so pretty.'"
Kara Norman, executive director of the Downtown Frederick Partnership, felt similarly. She said Easton's streetscapes are "lovely" and the "subtle" things next to sidewalks and buildings really make a difference.
Carol Gilbert, an assistant secretary at the Department of Housing and Community Development, touched on the historic aspect of downtown Easton.
"The level of authenticity of the core downtown," Gilbert said. "There's really beautiful architecture."
On Tuesday, local officials and leaders led tours to shed light on what makes Easton unique, including The Hill district, the Talbot Historical Society and an overview of housing revitalization by Ross Benincasa, senior vice president of community development for the nonprofit developer Fello.
Town Planning and Zoning Director Miguel Salinas, meanwhile, led attendees on a tour of Easton's East End area, explaining land use opportunities and challenges the town faces.
Those who toured Easton largely had positive words. Challenger did note small area of dissatisfaction: "I wished I didn't have to park so far away." She said she parked near the library and walked to the Avalon Theatre. But it's not necessarily a negative, she added.
"I think when there's a lack of parking or not enough, it's probably a good sign," Challenger said. "It's so busy."
State officials stop by
During the two days, multiple high-level officials in Gov. Wes Moore's administration spoke to attendees, including Lt. Gov. Aruna Miller (D) and Department of Housing and Community Development Secretary Jake Day, the latter of whom has expressed interest in running as a Democrat for the 1st Congressional District seat currently held by Rep. Andy Harris (R).
Miller recalled her first trip to Easton in 2022, a visit she was nervous for given the governor had to cancel last minute. Many more people showed up than she expected.
"The thing that I learned about Easton that day is never underestimate how much this town shows up for others," Miller said in front of more than 100 people inside the Waterfowl Festival building on Tuesday evening.
Day arrived later Tuesday, joining town and state officials on an evening out at restaurants including Tiger Lily. He hosted a roundtable with his department's top officials on Wednesday to close out the conference.
Afterward, Day said in an interview that the state made the right choice in selecting Easton for the second annual conference. Last year's was held in Frederick and next year's will be in Hagerstown.
Day, the former mayor of Salisbury, said Main Street managers take on difficult jobs in rebuilding and maintaining Main Street designations and downtown areas.
"When I was mayor, we tore up our Main Street," Day said of Salisbury. "We went under the knife for three-and-a-half years. This can be disruptive work to do transformative placemaking. And even the small stuff, policy-changing, trying to bring events, it's hard."
Julia Glanz, deputy secretary of DHCD, said in an interview that the two-day conference was the longest she'd spent in Easton. The restaurants stood out to her, and she said she's made a mental note to come back after missing out on an "incredible" mushroom soup at Legal Assets.
"It's been so exciting to see all of the shop owners come together and buy into this event," Glanz said. "I know that's how they buy into all their events. … They all understand how to work in unison to create an environment that's really engaging for residents and visitors alike." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a Main Street conference focused on downtown revitalization, economic development, and business support, involving local officials and economic development agencies, making Business/Economy the strongest fit.

title: 'Out here in God's country': Molly's Maryland Outdoor Festival draws 3,000
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
'Out here in God's country': Molly's Maryland Outdoor Festival draws 3,000

 October 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Life 
 
 519
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Molly's Place 15th annual fall tent sale returned late last month, rebranded last year as the Maryland Outdoor Festival.The three-day event in Kennedyville, held Sept. 26-28, featured a tent filled with deals on hunting, fishing and outdoor gear. Major sponsors included Benelli USA, Hevi-Shot, Banded and Vortex Optics.
Sales representatives answered questions while food vendors, live music and children's activities kept crowds entertained.
"We're out here in God's country, the Eastern Shore, surrounded by like-minded people. It doesn't get better than that," said world champion duck caller Sean Mann, who offered a calling clinic Sunday, teaching mallard calls.
"Most ducks respond to mallard calls. That's always the first thing we teach on the Shore," he said.
Nearby, Jimmy Wren, owner of United Call Works, led Saturday clinics and gave away merchandise. A Maryland native, Wren said he was glad to be home and reported selling more than 40 calls during the festival.
Decoy artists Jeff Coates and Nick Castiglione demonstrated their painting techniques, with Coates applying a natural-looking feathered texture to cork wood.
Firearm retailers and representatives such as Retay from Easton, shotgun manufacturers and LWRCI discussed trends in gun ownership. A hot topic this year was silencers and short barrels, with attendees asking questions following the decision to reduce the National Firearms Act tax on suppressors from $200 to $0 beginning Jan. 1.
"Using silencers is all about hearing protection," said sales representative Liam Parker, who praised lawmakers' move to eliminate the fee.
"This will open up a section of new buyers," said Scott Tull, account manager for LWRCI.
Other vendors also had strong sales. Under Armour sold out of many items, while Banded Hunting Gear reported hip waders, panel blinds and Phantom Tech soft shell hoodies as top sellers.
Outside the tent, Chestertown Lions Club members directed parking while families enjoyed children's activities. Shore Party Rentals provided a bounce house, Kent 4-H Triple Shots offered a BB gun and archery range, and Beth Hill, principal agent associate for 4-H Youth Development in Kent County, demonstrated leaf-pattern tracing. Face painter Ashley Burl kept a steady line of children waiting for designs.
Food vendors drew crowds as well. The Robinson family's Madhouse Oysters sold 300 oysters by Saturday afternoon. The Farmers Daughter BBQ served pulled pork, Jimmy's Fat Rolls offered lobster rolls, and Get the Scoop dished out hand-dipped ice cream, milkshakes and sundaes.
Music filled the festival grounds with Friday performances by Gunner's Rest, Nicholas Ray — playing one of his last local shows before moving to Nashville — and Ashley Vagnoni Chapa. Saturday featured singer-songwriter Joe Bryan, playing alt-country, classic rock and indie covers, followed by the Old School Duo from Galena. Easton country artist Justin Ryan closed out the weekend Sunday.
Chestertown Lions Club member Michael Moore estimated 300 vehicles were parked on-site around noon Saturday.
Marketing coordinator Justin Ly said more than 3,300 people attended the three-day event.
"Another one in the books! Thank you to everyone who came out, to our vendors, brand partners, sponsors, nonprofits and every member of the Molly's family. It was a great weekend," Ly said.
Molly's Place operates in Kennedyville and recently opened a second location, Molly's Easton. More information is available at mollys.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a local outdoor festival highlighting vendors, sales, sponsors, and economic activity, making Business/Economy the strongest match, with Entertainment and Arts & Culture as secondary themes.

title: Crafted Roots exhibits handcrafted art and food from Eastern Shore residents
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Crafted Roots exhibits handcrafted art and food from Eastern Shore residents

 October 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 494
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGLEY — When owner Sophia Marron thought of opening a vendor store, she envisioned a place to showcase all the amazing work the residents of the Eastern Shore can do.That idea came to life when she opened Crafted Roots in Ridgely earlier this year.
"I'm very personal and talkative. Like, I like to talk to people, and just like a lot of aspects nowadays, like, people are all on the internet and not really face-to-face," Marron said.
Marron and her husband, Dan, own a farm just outside of Greensboro. They would do vending shows at the farm to showcase art, food and clothes made by Eastern Shore residents.
The shop in Ridgley allows a permanent location for vendors to showcase.
"I would do vending shows, and it's really hard for the vendors," Sophia Marron said. "You have to set up, you have to load, you have to unload, you're in the hot hot weather, you're paying a fee... I wanted them to be able to have a space to provide that to the community at a low cost."
Now, the Marrons are seeking to evolve the vendor shop concept further.
They plan to move the shop to their farm, Constellation Farmstead, and reopen on their own land, where they can offer the space to vendors for free.
"I won't have to charge them a rent fee, and we can just do it on a lower overhead budget, and that will be better for the vendors," Sophia Marron said. "So if their stuff sells, it sells. If it doesn't, it doesn't, and it doesn't hurt the vendor."
The decision came after Sophia realized she spends a lot of time at the shop that could be spent at the farm.
"We farm as well, so farming, and being here and running the shop," Sophia Marron said. "I can be at the farm and do the vegetables, the produce and the meat and also offer vendors."
Crafted Roots has featured 27 vendors at one time. The vendors sold different items from homemade goods and candles to 3D-printed items farm to table healthy food items and much more.
According to Sophia Marron, when people come into the store and they see all of the hand-crafted items, they are fascinated.
The art and handcrafted items are the highlight, but for Marron, the importance of eating healthy farm to kitchen food is also key. A variety of healthy food options are available at the shop.
Marron suffers from stomach issues, and per doctors orders she has to eat fresh and non processed foods. The importance of selling fresh farmed food is a key to help others.
"So, I think it with my stomach issues and stuff I found eating fresh and local, not sprayed, no pesticides, it's really beneficial to your health. So that's another reason why I wanted to open this as well to offer that to the community," Marron said.
The new location for Crafted Roots is expected to open next fall. The Ridgley location will close its doors on Oct. 25. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Economic strategists offer cloudy view ahead during event at Tidewater Inn
author: JIM JOHNSON jjohnson@chespub.com
content:
Economic strategists offer cloudy view ahead during event at Tidewater Inn

 October 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JIM JOHNSON jjohnson@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 541
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The weather outside the Tidewater Inn on Tuesday morning was gloomy. A drizzly mist filled the air, obscuring vision in downtown.Inside the inn, two nationally renowned economic strategists gave an equally cloudy view of the economy for the last quarter of 2025 and 2026.
There are many mixed messages on the economy, said Meghan Shue, the chief investment strategist for Wilmington Trust, a division of M&T Bank, a sponsor of the event.
The 2 percent target for inflation in the United States has become "increasingly elusive," said Anirban Basu, a leading economist based in Maryland.
The two offered their insights at the economic symposium breakfast sponsored by the Talbot County Chamber of Commerce, described by one financial executive as a "must attend event" for business owners and managers.
Shue and Basu ran through dozens of economic indicators and market trends, using them as evidence for their predictions. Their hazy outlook is based on mixed markets and uncertain and shifting regulations by the federal government.
Since President Trump announced tariffs on April 8, markets have posted strong returns, especially in international stocks and gold, but the volatility could be seen when there was a significant drop in the markets Friday after Trump announced a 100% tariff on goods from China.
At the same time, the country's gross domestic product is strong and inflation does not seem to be a concern, Shue said, adding that if there is a recession the economy will "bounce back quickly."
"Being diversified is really important," Shue said.
She said that domestic spending is weak. Half of the growth in domestic spending has come from artificial intelligence capital spending such as data center growth. Job growth has ground to a halt and there are 900,000 fewer jobs than there were last year. While there are not many layoffs in the economy, there is not much hiring either.
"The tariff headwinds have really done a number on business confidence," she said.
Still corporate earnings so far this year have been good, and Shue predicts continued growth in the coming year.
"Companies have a remarkable ability to adapt to any situation," she said.
Shue sees the Fed continuing to cut interest rates — by as much as 75 basis points in 2026.
Basu echoed Shue's concerns for mixed messages and shifting federal regulations, noting that markets are down this week as the trade war between the U.S. and China heats up.
"You are poorer now than when you woke up," he said.
His talk was salted with references to Denzel Washington movies that had the audience laughing.
Federal regulations are adding to the clouded outlook. The Big Beautiful Bill passed in July will add an estimated $3.4 trillion to the national debt over the next decade and deportations will result in higher prices.
Unemployment rates are not astronomical, he said, but they are higher than they were last year.
He noted that grocery bills, which are rising, really capture Americans' attention. As a result of continued rising prices for consumer goods, Americans are drawing down on their personal savings, which is a big concern for economists.
Shue summed up her outlook, describing the current economic look as a Rorschach test. Different economists see different pictures in the economic inkblots. There are a lot of mixed messages, she said, which makes the economy subject to "headline drift." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on economic forecasts, market trends, and a business symposium, which aligns directly with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Maryland average gas prices edges back up over $3
author: GAS BUDDY
content:
Maryland average gas prices edges back up over $3

 October 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GAS BUDDY | Section: State News 
 
 463
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland rose 5.7 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.05 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are unchanged versus a month ago and stand 17.5 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has decreased 3.5 cents compared to a week ago and stands at $3.628 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.59 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.79 per gallon, a difference of $1.20 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 6.4 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.02 per gallon today. The national average is down 13.7 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 14.4 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back ten years:
Oct. 13, 2024: $3.23 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.16 per gallon)
Oct. 13, 2023: $3.35 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.58 per gallon)
Oct. 13, 2022: $3.73 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.92 per gallon)
Oct. 13, 2021: $3.25 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.29 per gallon)
Oct. 13, 2020: $2.31 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.17 per gallon)
Oct. 13, 2019: $2.47 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.63 per gallon)
Oct. 13, 2018: $2.81 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.89 per gallon)
Oct. 13, 2017: $2.39 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.47 per gallon)
Oct. 13, 2016: $2.25 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.25 per gallon)
Oct. 13, 2015: $2.23 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.30 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.05 per gallon, up 8.7 cents per gallon from last week's $2.96 per gallon.
Washington, D.C.: $3.23 per gallon, up 9.4 cents per gallon from last week's $3.14 per gallon.
Hagerstown: $3.11 per gallon, down 1.9 cents per gallon from last week's $3.13 per gallon.
"Americans appear to be on the cusp of seeing the national average drop below $3 per gallon for the first time in years, as prices have fallen across the vast majority of the country," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "With well over 40 states seeing gas prices decline and oil plunging below $60 per barrel to end the week, the good news may not end if — and when — the national average hits that magical $2.99 mark. We could even see a handful of stations in places like Oklahoma, Texas, or even Wisconsin drop below $2 per gallon in the weeks ahead — something not seen since the pandemic. In addition, with wages up and gas prices down, Americans are spending the smallest share of their paycheck on gasoline in many years." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on recent gasoline price trends, market comparisons, and economic implications, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Senior artisans open new creative shop
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Senior artisans open new creative shop

 October 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Seniors 
 
 612
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The enthusiasm and creativity shared among staff and seniors at the Amy Lynn Ferris Activity Center can now be experienced in Rock Hall Village.The new shop, The Yellow Dragonfly, takes its name from its bright yellow exterior and the dragonfly — a symbol of "new beginnings, prosperity and fortune." A ribbon-cutting ceremony was held Friday with Jamie Williams, director of Kent County Economic and Tourism Development, and her team.
Town Manager Bob Resele and Laurie Walters of Main Street Rock Hall joined in welcoming the new business to town.
Owners Colleen Upp, Susan Higgs, Brenda Foehrkolb, Pam Holland, Nancy Meeks and John Elburn have combined their talents to create what they describe as a "shopping experience for the senses."
"This all started at the senior center," said Activity Coordinator Colleen Upp. "Everyone comes in and we have our own special talents we bring to the table. When we heard about this property, we said, 'How awesome would it be to have it all in one shop?' Before we knew it, we were signing the papers — and now here we are."
Inside, uplifting music plays and the air is filled with holiday scents. Shelves are lined with homemade purses, jewelry, wildlife art, paintings and seasonal items.
"It's all of our creativity that we put into the center week in and week out," Upp said.
Among the featured works are Foehrkolb's Baltimore screens, a traditional art form that began in 1913 and became a popular Maryland trend. The painted screens are part of her childhood, and she said she cherishes sharing them with the Eastern Shore community.
Elburn's carvings, hand-painted sculptures and woodwork reflect life on the Shore. His craftsmanship is also visible across the street, where his restoration work on "Old Salt" preserves the cherished Rock Hall landmark originally carved by local sculptor Jac Smolens.
"Elburn's exposure to the everyday activities of Rock Hall watermen influences his art," Upp noted.
Meeks keeps the shop festive with wreaths, door swags and floral arrangements. "She does just about everything," Upp said with a smile.
Higgs offers homesteading items, herbs, oils, honey, soaps, sea salts, teas and other all-natural products.
For four-legged customers, Holland bakes all-natural dog treats called Smoochie Poochies.
Upp, like Meeks, creates a bit of everything — from jewelry and handbags to charm bracelets, just in time for the holidays.
Her jewelry draws inspiration from a Hawaiian luau party the center hosted Aug. 21, where guests picked a pearl from a shell to take home. Now, that same pearl jewelry, along with other pieces featuring quality gems and stones, is available at the shop.
Upp also sells her own beeswax chapstick made with essential oils and offers something for kids — a chance to "adopt" their own dragon.
Created by a local 3D-print artist, the unhatched baby dragons come with an egg, wristband, miniature house and adoption certificate — "because dragons need homes too," Upp said.
The Yellow Dragonfly showcases what Upp calls a "fun, eclectic bunch" of handmade goods.
"We offer unique, handmade items at affordable prices you won't find anywhere else," she said.
During the ribbon cutting, Upp's granddaughter Addy had the honor of cutting the ribbon, followed by applause from the crowd.
"We're so excited to see the village popping back into life with a lot of activity," Walters said. "It's a great addition to the community."
"Welcome, Yellow Dragonfly. We're so happy to have a good business here in this space," Resele added.
"On behalf of everyone, we are tickled to be here," Upp said, pleased with the turnout and strong sales throughout the evening.
The Yellow Dragonfly is located in the little yellow building at Rock Hall Village on Main Street. Fall hours are Friday, noon to 6 p.m., and Saturday and Sunday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the opening of a new shop by senior artisans, highlighting local entrepreneurship, economic development, and community commerce, which aligns best with Business/Economy.

title: AI course offered for business owners, managers
author: Staff Writer
content:
AI course offered for business owners, managers

 October 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Business 
 
 296
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Eastern Shore business owners are encouraged to participate in a free, first-of-its-kind artificial intelligence online training series for local businesses this fall.The two-part online program takes place Oct. 27–28 from 6 to 8 p.m. via Zoom and marks the first time the economic development departments of Dorchester, Caroline, Talbot and Worcester counties, along with the Mid-Shore Regional Council, have partnered on a training initiative of this kind.
The training will give entrepreneurs and business owners practical tools to integrate AI into marketing, sales, lead generation, fundraising, operations and proposal writing.
Cassandra Vanhooser, director of Talbot County Economic Development and Tourism, recently completed an AI certification course through Johns Hopkins University and says the timing could not be better for local businesses to embrace these new tools.
"This partnership allows us to bring high-level, practical training to entrepreneurs across the Eastern Shore, free of charge," Vanhooser says. "It's an unprecedented opportunity to make sure our local businesses aren't left behind, especially as this technology becomes essential for growth and competitiveness."
Consultant Will Holmes, who facilitates the program, emphasizes that the program's purpose is to demystify AI and empower business owners with practical strategies they can implement immediately.
"AI is no longer a futuristic concept. It's a present-day tool that can dramatically accelerate growth," Holmes says. "By breaking down what can often feel like a complex or intimidating subject, we're helping entrepreneurs gain a clear understanding of how AI can drive results for their businesses."
The AI training series reflects a broader regional commitment to fostering innovation and economic vitality. By combining expertise and resources, the partners are delivering an accessible program that would otherwise be cost-prohibitive for many small and midsized businesses.
Eastern Shore business owners and entrepreneurs are encouraged to register for the free online training sessions. Registration is available at talbotworks.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article announces a free AI training program aimed at local business owners and entrepreneurs, emphasizing economic development and practical business applications, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic. It also involves educational content, but the primary focus is on supporting the business community.

title: Pepco names vice president of government affairs
author: Staff Writer
content:
Pepco names vice president of government affairs

 October 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Business 
 
 381
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Pepco Holdings has named Marcus Beal as its new vice president of governmental and external affairs and region president for Delmarva Power.In this role, Beal will lead the company's external affairs and stakeholder engagement strategy for the company, working closely with elected officials, business leaders and community partners. His focus will include advancing customer-centric initiatives and fostering collaboration to support reliable, affordable and sustainable energy for all customers. Beal replaces Phil Vavala, who retired after more than 30 years with the Exelon family of companies and its predecessors.
"Marcus brings a unique combination of operational knowledge, strategic insight, and deep community connection," said Jaclyn Cantler, senior vice president of governmental, regulatory and external affairs for Pepco Holdings, which includes Delmarva Power. "From his start as an intern nearly two decades ago to now leading our external affairs efforts, he has demonstrated an unwavering dedication to the people and communities we serve. His leadership and local insight will be instrumental in strengthening partnerships across our region."
Beal's experience spans multiple disciplines — from systems engineering and information technology to communications and regulatory strategy — making him exceptionally well-positioned to guide the company's external affairs efforts. Over the years, he has played an integral role in advancing key initiatives that enhance reliability, strengthen operations and support transparent communication with customers and stakeholders.
Most recently, Beal served as director for governmental and external affairs at Delmarva Power, where he oversaw engagement efforts with key stakeholders in the region.
"This region has always been part of my story," said Beal. "From my days as a student at the University of Delaware to starting my career as an intern at Delmarva Power, I've had the privilege of working along the Eastern Shore and in Delaware for many years. I'm excited to continue serving the people and communities that have shaped my journey."
Beal is deeply engaged in the communities Delmarva Power serves, holding leadership roles across several organizations. He serves on the boards of the New Castle County Chamber of Commerce, the Greater Salisbury Committee Executive Committee, the PHI Community Foundation (as president), the Riverfront Wilmington Business Improvement District, the Maryland–District of Columbia Utilities Association, Wor-Wic College and the University of Maryland Eastern Shore Business Advisory Board. Beal holds a bachelor's degree in computer science from the University of Delaware. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a corporate appointment at Pepco Holdings, focusing on executive leadership and stakeholder engagement, which aligns with business and economic news rather than government policy or other categories.

title: State average gas price drops back under $3
author: Staff Writer
content:
State average gas price drops back under $3

 October 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 450
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 8.3 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $2.97 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 19.1 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 16.9 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has decreased 3.7 cents compared to a week ago and stands at $3.591 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.59 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $4.89 per gallon, a difference of $2.30 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 4.1 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $2.98 per gallon Monday. The national average is down 19.3 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 15.2 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
Oct. 20, 2024: $3.14 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.13 per gallon)
Oct. 20, 2023: $3.35 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.53 per gallon)
Oct. 20, 2022: $3.69 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.82 per gallon)
Oct. 20, 2021: $3.29 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.35 per gallon)
Oct. 20, 2020: $2.28 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.15 per gallon)
Oct. 20, 2019: $2.49 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.63 per gallon)
Oct. 20, 2018: $2.74 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.84 per gallon)
Oct. 20, 2017: $2.39 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.45 per gallon)
Oct. 20, 2016: $2.24 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.22 per gallon)
Oct. 20, 2015: $2.20 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.24 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $2.96 per gallon, down 9.2 cents per gallon from last week's $3.05 per gallon.
Washington, D.C.: $3.13 per gallon, down 10.1 cents per gallon from last week's $3.23 per gallon.
Hagerstown: $2.95 per gallon, down 15.5 cents per gallon from last week's $3.11 per gallon.
"Gas prices have finally fallen below $3 per gallon nationally — the earliest date we've seen a $2.99 national average since 2020, when COVID was the primary driver of low prices," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "OPEC+ deserves much of the credit for this trend, having steadily raised oil production for much of 2025. Currently, 35 states have average gas prices below $2.99 per gallon, and GasBuddy even recorded the first $1.99 cash price at a station in Evans, Colorado, with stations in Oklahoma and Texas not far behind. Barring any major disruptions, gas prices are likely to remain slightly below year-ago levels and could stay under $3 for much of the next few months." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on changes in gasoline prices, a market and economic indicator, making Business/Economy the most relevant category.
